name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the council and Commission statements on the Luxembourg Presidency's programme of activities (2015/2718(RSP)." Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for your excellent work. I would like to point out at the beginning of this sitting that there is no catch-the-eye procedure on this point and that no blue cards are allowed either. Let me be clear: this is a decision of the Conference of Presidents. I call for the Luxembourg Presidency, together with a warm welcome, Prime Minister Xavier Bettel.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, on 1 July Luxembourg took the reins of the Council of the European Union for the twelfth time. We hope that the coming months will allow us to demonstrate our commitment to the European integration project. This presidency will not be a routine presidency for Luxembourg. With the years now separating the presidencies of each Member State, the benefit of experience is fading. The Treaty of Lisbon and the redistribution of the institutional situation make it a first for us as well. Finally, or rather alas, the circumstances are not the most favourable. We are in fact the presidency at a critical time for the Union. The challenges we face are serious. Growth is not on the agenda in all Member States. Unemployment, and above all youth unemployment, remains a real scourge. The desperation of hundreds of thousands of migrants seeking to reach Europe forces us, politically and morally, to put in place a new migration policy. I am also thinking about security challenges or sustainable development.  We will do everything we can to establish sincere and effective cooperation with the European Parliament, based on pragmatism and common sense. Mr President, the Luxembourg Presidency will also ensure that the real and direct interest of citizens is better taken into account in all EU policies. We are counting on the commitment and determination of the European Parliament because, without Parliament, the Union cannot move forward. In these times of great challenges that test the people, it is up to us, politicians and representatives of European citizens, to demonstrate that Europe can bring solutions. Together, we must act in a united and determined way.  The new inter-institutional agreement on improved regulation is in this context. The Luxembourg Presidency will endeavour to achieve success before the end of the year. It looks forward to starting talks with Parliament and the Commission in a constructive and pragmatic spirit and bearing in mind the European interest and its effectiveness. Let me share with you my thoughts on the situation in Greece. Indeed, the Greek people spoke on Sunday. We have taken note of his decision and we must respect it. However, I must express to you the disappointment of most European leaders meeting yesterday in Brussels that they did not have any concrete proposals from the Greek Prime Minister. That is why he has committed to making concrete proposals by tomorrow. I must tell you that these proposals, which are not unilateral proposals, will also have to be accepted by the other 18 members of the Eurogroup. I hope that we will find a solution for the benefit of all. In any case, the Luxembourg Presidency does not advocate Grexit as a priority and hopes that we will find a solution in the interest of all, especially when we see the economic situation of many Greeks as well as that of businesses. In line with the 2014 European Council's strategic agenda and taking into account the Commission's political guidelines and programme, the Luxembourg Presidency has set out seven objectives that cover the major projects of the European Union. The most pressing challenge and the first of our priorities must be to free up investment for growth and jobs. We want the investment plan for Europe to be implemented robustly and quickly. Measures to facilitate access to investment, especially for SMEs, will need to complement the effort in order to multiply the effects of the investment plan. The Luxembourg Presidency will encourage the initiatives taken by the European Commission to this end.  The establishment of a true capital markets union serves the same purpose. The European Union must make it easier for our companies to access European capital markets without barriers. The new regulatory framework should also be used to encourage investment beyond capital markets. We want to complement the regulation of financial services by moving the negotiations forward on a number of issues, in particular that of structural reform banking and money funds. Mr President, the Luxembourg Presidency will also continue the Union's efforts to implement a genuine European industrial policy, including, for example, in the steel and space sectors, by systematically integrating the competitiveness imperative in all areas of the Union's action. The development of the European Research Area will make it clear that the potential of the single market for researchers and knowledge on our continent, which is often caught between the United States and Asia, will be fully exploited.  Secondly, Mr President, social cohesion is the mainstay of European integration most affected by the economic and financial crisis. Deepening the European social dimension will be a priority of our Presidency.  Our Presidency will strongly support the idea launched by the President of the European Commission to keep this triple A social. To advance this ambitious project, our Presidency will work closely with social partners and institutions. The focus will be on social investment, particularly in areas of expertise, with a particular focus on digital skills. I will be looking after that as Prime Minister and also as Minister of Communications and Media in my own country. Governments must continue to improve the efficiency of their labour markets. In concrete terms, the aim is to improve the transition between the world of education and the world of work and to promote access to employment for groups further from the labour market, such as the long-term unemployed. It is also a question of facilitating the integration of young people through the "Youth Guarantee". I have received messages from a large number of people, especially youth organisations, who welcome this European initiative. However, this programme cannot be the only measure to combat youth unemployment. It must be accompanied by other measures, such as investment in education and training. The social dimension of the governance of the Economic and Monetary Union and the euro area needs to be taken more into account.  The Luxembourg Presidency will place particular emphasis on equal opportunities and emphasise the increase in the female employment rate and a balanced representation between women and men in political and economic decision-making as factors of competitiveness. Another pressing priority is to manage immigration, to combine freedom, justice and security for our citizens. The tragic loss of life in the Mediterranean calls for resolute and continuous action in the field of migration. The Presidency will give urgent importance to a range of internal EU measures and actions in partnership with third countries to put in place the beginnings of a fair, effective and credible immigration policy.  The Commission has presented an agenda on migration. It is now up to the Council to adopt a balanced package of measures to save lives, combat criminal networks and welcome migrants with dignity. It is also about guaranteeing them the necessary protections and promoting the return and readmission of irregular migrants to their countries of origin.  At the European Council at the end of June, we saw how sensitive these issues are. I am convinced that we will work together to bring together Member States, institutions and our citizens to promote healthy and inclusive management of migration. But I also know that it will take everyone's efforts. The European Year for Development will also be an opportunity to examine the link between development and migration. Indeed, deepening cooperation with third countries of origin, transit and reception will play a central role in the work of the Presidency. Mr President, the terrorist attacks have shown that six months after the deadly attacks in Paris and those that followed, the risk of such attacks remains real. The Presidency will vigorously and decisively implement the measures and actions decided by the Heads of State and Government on 12 February 2015.  The large flows of residents and citizens who have left to join terrorist groups in Syria and Iraq, and their potential return to Europe, are a major challenge. The Union will have to make full use of existing tools, develop new instruments if necessary and ensure that the coordination of the actions taken is perfected. These measures, of course, will have to be taken and implemented with full respect for human rights and the rule of law. With regard to the new tools to combat terrorism and organised crime, the establishment of the European Passenger Data Collection System (PNR) is essential for the safety of our citizens.  At the same time, the finalization of the reform of the protection of personal data is also essential. The success of the digital internal market will depend greatly on the confidence citizens and businesses to online data flows. The Luxembourg Presidency aims to conclude negotiations on this reform package by the end of the year. With regard to the European judicial area, Mr President, the creation of a European Public Prosecutor's Office to investigate and prosecute fraud in the European Union budget is the flagship project. The Presidency will work to move the negotiations forward so that the Union has an independent and effective European Public Prosecutor's Office as soon as possible.  The Luxembourg Presidency also considers that the Union must be determined to consolidate and promote the fundamental values on which it is based. Respect for the rule of law is one of them.  Fourthly, we want to restore its momentum to the internal market, in particular by focusing on digital technology. The latter remains under-exploited. The Presidency is committed to giving digital a cross-cutting priority and putting it at the heart of its internal market policy. We will work to dismantle the barriers that continue to fragment the digital internal market into twenty-eight national mini-markets.  The Luxembourg Presidency will encourage the use of the most effective regulatory and non-regulatory instruments, namely harmonization and mutual recognition. The examination of the future "Internal Market Package for Goods and Services" will be a priority for our Presidency.  The energy union, Mr President, must enable us to strengthen security of supply and to promote energy transition through the renewable energy and energy efficiency sectors, which are essential drivers of green and sustainable growth, creating wealth and jobs.  In the field of transport, the Luxembourg Presidency will contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the European transport policy, which aim to promote efficient, safe, reliable, accessible and socially responsible mobility.  The fifth task of the Presidency will be to support European competitiveness, within a global and transparent framework. Following the presentation of the report of the five presidents on the completion of the Economic and Monetary Union, we intend to lead the work to move forward on the four pillars of EMU construction. It is important to promote a return to growth and employment in a framework of solidarity and budgetary discipline, but also of a more social Europe. We remain committed to the triptych based on fiscal consolidation, the revival of growth through investment and structural reforms that have a positive impact on sustainable and balanced growth. This exercise takes on, of course, another dimension in the current context of the situation in Greece and the necessary acceleration of the deepening of EMU. Sustainable and balanced growth means the fight against tax evasion and evasion! This is a priority that Luxembourg intends to place within a global framework to ensure that all competition is fair. The European Union will have to take action in the wake of the decisions taken and to come from the G20 and the OECD. The establishment of a level playing field at the global level is a prerequisite for the effectiveness of this fight.  The Presidency is committed to moving tax issues forward in a spirit of openness and full transparency. While ensuring that the achievements of the internal market are respected, in particular in the area of the free movement of capital and the right to establish, the Presidency aims to carry out the proposal on transparency and the exchange of information on tax rulings. The expected progress in the context of the OECD's work on BEPS will inspire the European Union's approach in the second half of 2015. The Action Plan for Fair and Effective Corporate Taxation, which the Commission published in June, will serve as a starting point for the Presidency's tax work. The Luxembourg Presidency hopes to move forward on the international elements of the proposed directive on the consolidated common corporate tax base and on the proposed directive on interest and royalties.  Die gemeinsame europeische Handelspolitik ist ein weiterer bedeutender Aspekt auf dem Weg zu mehr Wachstum in Europa. Wir brauchen eine Handelspolitik, die Gelegenheiten liefert und uns dient, aktuellen Herausforderung gerecht zu werden, eine Handelspolitik, die Arbeitsplàtze schafft, die inklusiv und koh-rent ist.  Wir werden alles daransetzen, gemeinsam mit Ihnen hier im Parlament und der Europ-ischen Kommission genau eine solche Politik zu betreiben, sei es im Rahmen der Welthandelsorganisation oder bei bilateralen Verhandlungen. Der luxemburgische Ratsvorsitz wird deswegen auch die Verhandlungen 'ber die transatlantische Handels- und Investitionspartnerschaft voranbringen. Diese sollten go Voraussicht nach im Laufe des zweiten Semesters an Intensity gewinnen. Ferner werden wir Handelsabkommen mit weiteren Schlàsselpartnern der EU in Asien fàrdern. Ich denke hierbei vor allem an Japan sowie unsere Partner in der ASEAN-Region. Wir werden uns jedoch stets fer ein Maximum an Transparenz einsetzen und ermutigen alle implizierten Akteure, einen konstruktiven Dialog einzuhalten. Aus diesem Grund habe ich mich auch dazu entschlossen, gemeinsam mit dem European Parlament und der Europeischen Kommission eine Konferenz zur TTIP abzuhalten.  Zu dieser sollten vor allem Vertreter der Sozialpartner aus den 28 Mitgliedstaaten eingeladen werden. Die Konferenz soll am 17. November dieses Jahres in Bressel stattfinden und einen konstruktiven Austausch 'ber Chancen und Herausforderungen der TTIP erlauben. Schlie-lich mechte ich mich beim Europeischen Parlament ausdr-cklich fer das Engagement rund um die Debatten zur TTIP bedanken. The sixth priority of the Presidency will be part of a sustainable development approach. We often talk about tax and social dumping, but there is also a real international environmental dumping today. Sustainable economic growth at the service of the citizen goes hand in hand with the highest environmental ambition. The Presidency will seek to accelerate the transition to a green economy with low greenhouse gas emissions by creating the dynamics necessary for the emergence of a safe and sustainable society. It will also promote an innovative, circular and competitive, energy-efficient economy that preserves biodiversity and natural resources, avoids waste and promotes recycling at the best cost. This much-needed ambition will guide the Presidency on current legislative issues, such as those relating to air quality or the reduction of CO2 emissions.  Sustainability will also be at the heart of the Presidency's work towards the various international deadlines that will dominate the global agenda, whether it be the summit in New York or the COP 21 in Paris. The Luxembourg Presidency is working intensively with the French presidency of COP 21. At the Paris conference, international negotiations will have to lead to the adoption of an ambitious and binding new treaty with global participation. We will put a particular emphasis on the issue of climate finance. Finally, the seventh objective will be to strengthen the European Union's presence in the world. The Presidency will strongly support the Vice-President, Ms Mogherini. The Presidency believes that the prospect of accession remains a powerful engine for reforms at Europe's borders, benefiting the stability and prosperity of the entire continent.  The Presidency will continue negotiations with Turkey, Montenegro and Serbia as soon as the conditions are met, and will contribute to the continuation of the road to Europe of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Albania. The signing and conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo and the implementation of the recently entered into force stabilisation and association agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina are other issues that will be encouraged by the Presidency as long as the preconditions are met.  Furthermore, Mr President, on the basis of a Commission communication on European Neighbourhood Policy, the Presidency will contribute to the work to update this policy with a view to adopting conclusions in the European Council before the end of 2015.  The credibility of the European Union in the world is strengthened by decisive action on development cooperation and humanitarian action. The year 2015, called the European Year for Development, will be, from this point of view and because of the major international events, a pivotal year for development. In particular, we attach the utmost importance to the adoption of the Sustainable Development Goals. Improving policy coherence for development is an integral part of this new agenda, including migration. On 9 December, the Luxembourg Presidency will have the honour and pleasure of organising the closing of the European Year for Development in Luxembourg, but it will ensure that this strengthened solidarity continues beyond this year. Finally, allow me to say a word about the referendum that Prime Minister David Cameron is planning to hold. We will listen carefully to the British Government's proposals, and I am convinced that we will find common ground for solutions - but the acquis community cannot be jeopardised. I have no doubt that the United Kingdom will stay in the European Union. The Luxembourg Presidency is ready, for its part, to contribute to that objective. I am confidant. I cannot imagine the United Kingdom without a European Union, or the European Union without a United Kingdom. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these are the few major projects that the Luxembourg Presidency will have to launch, continue or complete. We will do so with enthusiasm and convinced that the European project remains the instrument par excellence to face the challenges of our time.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Prime Minister, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to see today the Prime Minister of the country I know best in a place I know well. I have chaired the European Council twice, the Council of Ministers four times, so I know the constraints that will be, dear Xavier and dear Nicolas, yours. You can count on the Commission, which I have the honour of chairing, to be useful to you in every place, at every moment and throughout the presidency and beyond.  I would like to thank the Latvian Presidency for ensuring that the investment plan proposed by the Commission can start its activities and I would like to encourage the Luxembourg Presidency to speed up all work, particularly with regard to the third part of the investment plan, which is to improve the overall context in which our businesses and businesses must operate and , in particular, small and medium-sized enterprises, which account for more than 90% of the EU's economic activity. I would like to encourage the Luxembourg Presidency to start the energy union, the capital markets union and the digital European union. Digital is of particular importance to Europe because, when we talk about the digital union, we are actually talking about an additional added value of 415 billion for European growth and 2 to 3 million jobs. I would therefore like to encourage the Luxembourg Presidency to do everything possible to speed up the work of implementing the ideas presented by the Commission. It is clear that all the issues that revolve around immigration are of particular importance. The Luxembourg Presidency has the task of ensuring that the objectives we have set for relocation and resettlement are achieved. The Council of Ministers will have to do so on a voluntary basis. I would have preferred that we use the Community method, but the European Council, in its near-wisdom, has decided otherwise, since it has opted for the intergovernmental method. But I am convinced that the Luxembourg Presidency will succeed in achieving the objectives we have set ourselves. In the same spirit, I would like to encourage the Luxembourg Presidency to redouble its efforts to make the Paris climate conference a success at the end of the year. The role of the Presidency is essential and fundamental and I am sure it will make the Paris conference a real success that will last. I do not see very big differences between the Luxembourg Presidency programme and the Commission's programme. It is actually the same thing and we will work together in the best way possible. Yes, the Luxembourgish Presidency will have to take action towards finding a fair deal with Britain. We will find a fair deal with Britain, and Mr Farage will of course be helpful. He did everything possible to stay in this House and now, as he is here, he will be the best ally of the Luxembourgish Presidency. (Applause) Also, Kollegen, funkt one! Ech sinn iwwerzeegt, Dir maacht dat gutt.

name: Frank Engel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, it was a joyous Reunion in Luxembourg in the European Parliament this morning. We might have been pleased if this had happened in more pleasant circumstances for the continent. But times are difficult and challenges are many.  I could try to paint a picture of the legislation that the Luxembourg Presidency should carry out, but it is extremely difficult for me to do so during the minutes that are allotted to me. I could talk about the need for reform of data protection legislation, we could talk about PNR - as they say in good French - climate negotiations, which the President of the Commission has just mentioned, as the Prime Minister, or the agreement that we will have, when the time comes, with the United States on free trade , and that worries our citizens. In this context, we will have to find a European way to complete a business that, at present, may well be moving away from many voters. This is not only about the German-speaking world, but it is particularly sensitive in this part of the European electorate. I could, Prime Minister, wish that it was precisely Luxembourg which, over the next six months, would achieve significant European progress in tax justice. It is strange that Luxembourgers are throwing such admonitions at each other. I remember several years ago that Prime Minister Juncker succeeded in putting a common tax base for commercial companies on the European agenda in 1997. It never came about, because it was challenged, not by Luxembourg, but by others. I would like us to re-enter the momentum in this area. Finally, there are even bigger issues. We must ensure that the European Fund for Strategic Investments achieves the success it deserves, because this continent is sorely lacking in productive investment, not only around the Mediterranean, but also throughout our continent. This fund is intended to remedy this situation. Secondly, in the context of Greece, in particular, Luxembourg has a great tradition of moderation and rapprochement of attitudes and the continent has reached a point where centrifugal movements are numerous, frequent and intense. My group and I would like the Luxembourg Presidency to try to give our continent a more centripetal dynamic. Many people want to leave, others don't want to leave. Above all, it is necessary to ensure that those who remain and who have always been there find a unifying and non-dissonant dynamic.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Luxembourg Presidency has a huge task ahead of it. As has been mentioned, the Greek crisis is before us, everything must be done to reach an agreement. I repeat: we do not even want to think about the idea that no agreement is reached, because this would have catastrophic consequences for the European Union and would also change its programme in certain respects. Too many European Councils have disappointed our citizens in recent months, while citizens are waiting for strong responses to Europe.  I have spoken about Greece, but it is not just that, I am also thinking of immigration. The Commission has presented a bold plan, which provides for the first time a mechanism for sharing refugees at European level. The Council has held back. It is now up to you, Mr Bettel, to return to this subject. We want a compulsory mechanism of solidarity between the Member States.  Solidarity for us also means taking back the social agenda. You mentioned the triple A of Mr Juncker's programme, in particular the issue of labour mobility. Everything must be done to stop social dumping. Solidarity means implementing the investment plan for growth and work. Solidarity means working with High Representative Federica Mogherini for Europe's decisive role in the world. Solidarity also means making a great effort to support the social economy; There is the big question of our development model in front of us: every effort must be made to accelerate the transition to a green and circular economy. The Paris Conference will perhaps be the last opportunity to reach agreement on climate change. We call on this Presidency to engage with the Commission in reaching an ambitious agreement, obviously with Parliament. Dear President Bettel, you have also been a close friend for many years and we are well aware of the quality, competence and commitment that your government has already amply demonstrated. We are therefore convinced that it will be able to face such demanding challenges and will certainly have the support of socialists and democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. On behalf of the ECR Group, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Bettel to this hemisphere today. He has outlined an ambitious programme with seven major points for the Luxembourg Presidency. I fear that you will not really be heading for a big summer holiday with the ongoing crises we are facing. I am thinking of the Greek crisis, which will be discussed in detail in the near future, but also of the migration crisis, perhaps the biggest challenge we face and will be in the coming years. To do so, you will need to have the necessary negotiating skills and skills to actually reach agreements and tackle the challenge. For my government and my group, the conclusion of an effective PNR agreement is also crucial, such that we have a common framework to effectively protect people's data and to fight and win the fight against terrorism. Prime Minister, another crisis lurks on our eastern borders. We are very clear on this. There is no place in Europe for the kind of aggression we see today in eastern Ukraine. Prime Minister, we will be happy to work with you on a number of important policy initiatives, such as the Better Regulation Agenda, the negotiations on an EU-US trade agreement, the energy union, the digital single market and the pursuit of a global agreement at the major climate conference in Paris. You will find in us an ally where you want to pursue reforms, but a constructive opponent where you do not. I will switch to English because I would like to say something about language. I take the opportunity to address you, Mr President: I know you meet a lot of people and have a lot of meetings every day, and you don't always remember everything. Let me just remind you of a promise you made back in 2012, as newly elected President of this Chamber. You said you would allow Catalan MEPs to speak the Catalan language here in the plenary. It is the thirteenth most widely-spoken language in the EU, with more than 10 million speakers. Well, their MEPs are still not allowed to speak Catalan in this House, which is supposed to be open and democratic. That, Mr. Schulz, is a shame and a democratic deficit. I urge you to think it over again and fulfill your promise.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council of the Union, we have just read the priorities of the Luxembourg Presidency.  I do not hide our satisfaction to also find our own, those of my group, including the promotion of growth, the opening of the markets of the future, the implementation of the Digital Single Market, not to mention the obligation to succeed in the fight against climate change and the Addis Ababa conference on financing for development. Recurrent topics, of course, but this time it's different.  The current presidency of the Council of the Union will not be judged exclusively on the number of laws it will pass, nor on how it will fulfil its protocol obligations. No, this time it's different. The time is no longer for hollow sentences, nor for the optimism of circumstance, much less for "there is only... Fewer of us have come to defend Europe's project. Here, in this very chamber, an impressive number of colleagues do not hide, or more, their pleasure at seeing the European construction shaken in its foundations. At the beginning of summer 2015, we need an unwavering will to preserve the essential: the link between our nations, between the citizens who live in our nations. Let us have the courage and determination to defend our freedoms. Let's be ready to take in the refugees. If they managed to escape the hell of Syria - often at the risk of their lives - it is certainly not to go drown off the Italian coast. It is on the irreducibility of human dignity that the European project is based and not on the Malthusian approaches that make citizens believe that the limits have already been reached, when we have not even begun to explore new possibilities for cooperation.  It is in this spirit, I hope, that we will still remain quite ahead, mobilizing the resources necessary to maintain the single currency, which is much more than a matter of money.  In view of the historical task before us, giving up 0.1 or 0.2% of GDP in the short term to rescue our assets could cost us a multiple of these amounts in the future with a Europe in tatters.  We are counting on your presidency as well as those that will follow. Let us not leave our Europe offered to the least federal, nor to the nationalists. In short, what is before us is the organisation of solidarity, the distribution of burdens and responsibility. Vill Chance Iech an 'r'team an der nechster Presidence!

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, the Luxembourg Presidency will be called upon to deal with many problems that are currently a cause for the peoples of Europe. But what Europe needs most today is solidarity and the promotion of a strategy of progressive political and social development towards a Europe of democracy and social justice. The Luxembourg Presidency must act as guardian of the parity of the Member States and the sovereignty of the States. Interventions such as those made in the wake of the referendum in Greece by the President of the Commission and the President of the European Parliament must not be made again. Because it is one thing to have a different view and another to intervene in the internal affairs of a Member State in order to impose your position on a sovereign people. Of course the Greek people gave the appropriate response with courage and determination with the overwhelming no on Sunday. We therefore expect the new Presidency to promote social development policies that will boost the real economy. The promotion of neoliberal policies of harsh austerity, which sustain the recession, which inflate public debt, which lead to unemployment and the poverty of the people, cannot continue. Finally, Prime Minister, with regard to immigration policy, we expect measures based on international law, solidarity and human rights to be promoted. Strengthen people-saving mechanisms first and foremost support states with measures to ensure an equal distribution of burdens between members, in line with their GDP and population.

name: Claude Turmes
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Prime Minister, Mr President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for the time being. Luxembourg is taking over the EU Presidency at a very important moment for Europe. Building and communicating bridges is necessary, and it has always been part of the self-image of Luxembourgers in Europe. I see four priorities: climate, refugees, fair tax policy, Greece. Climate: There is nothing to negotiate with nature. Either we respect the limits of nature – in the climate it is two degrees or less – or nature gets out of hand, as the heat waves in India, Pakistan and now in Europe show. Paris must be a success! Refugees: Reception of refugees from Syria. One million in Lebanon, one million in Jordan, two million in Turkey. What an international testament to Europe's poverty if, as the EU-28, we cannot even agree in the next few weeks on the regular admission of 60 000 people in need. (Applause) Fair tax policy: Social compensation and investment capacity are only possible if there is a fair tax policy. It is precisely we, as Luxembourgers, who are called upon to do so.  Greece: Above all this is the Grexit question. A Grexit would not only be a disaster for the people of Greece. Do the US need to remind us that an unstable Greece in the quadrangle between the Balkans, Turkey, Russia and the Middle East would be a bad, a very bad move? But Grexit could also be the beginning of the end of the euro and even of the European unification and peace process.  Of course, Mr Tsipras must do his homework. But we also need movement on the other side: from Mrs Merkel, Mr Schäuble, Mr Gabriel, Mr Schulz, the gentlemen from the Bavarian province and also the Greens in Berlin who have been swept away. Konrad Adenauer, Helmut Kohl, Willy Brandt, Helmut Schmidt, Joschka Fischer and perhaps even Franz-Josef Strauss would know what to do this week.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the past and present of Luxembourg sit before us today. Reading the programme of this Presidency, I felt a predictable sense of disgust. A few miserable lines about tax evasion. On tax rulings, shameful agreements that have allowed hundreds of large companies for decades to pay derisory taxes in the Grand Duchy, in the face of low profits in other EU countries: nothing! Hundreds of billions of euros in damage to us; from you only yet another deafening silence, even today. Mr Juncker, you were in charge of the Eurogroup at the midst of the economic crisis.  You are one of the greatest architects of austerity and rigour. Today pontifica ing, like others, on the future of Greece. But he didn't find a shred of courage to eliminate the shameful tax engineering that is a social hell for us. If that is your sense of community, it confirms to us that you are the anti-Europeans! When he's alone in his office in the evening and thinking about the social butchery of these years what image does his conscience see reflected in the bottom of the glass? What do you whisper in your grandchildren's ears when you talk to them about Europe? Do you dare to tell him that the wealth of Luxembourg, of your country, you have built it on the protection of tax avoiders, on our sick people thrown like rubbish in the corridors of dilapidated hospitals, on the suicides of pensioners and honest entrepreneurs, on families without water and without light, on the future denied to the generations of the Mediterranean? This Presidency, rigour should apply in returning these resources to us so that we can create a social compact to support the weakest and small businesses. If you do not have this dignity, then take another thirty denarii, the thirty money for betraying the European dream.  Shame on you!!

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Prime Minister, you look happy! You're joking with Mr Juncker, and you feel that lightness a bit like casualness. The Luxembourg Presidency opens in a very special atmosphere. A heady scent of chess floats in the atmosphere. The European Union seems to be in a state of clinical death, the problems insoluble, the tensions, the contradictions are piling up. The Europe of peace has become the Europe of debt war, of economic war, where the President of the European Parliament calls for the overthrow of democratic governments and replaced them with governments of technocrats, Europe of threats, permanent blackmail, unemployment, of course, and poverty. The euro crisis is starting again and taking a political turn, with peoples starting to say no to your hopeless hyper-austerity policies. Faced with the wrath of the peoples, no will hold, you must know, your worst nightmare is coming true. The people, whom you zapped, are rebelling. The crisis of illegal immigrants is taking on an unprecedented scale. You can't think of any other way than to explain to us that this is a good thing. This makes perfect sense, since this crisis is the result of your ideology. The aspiring pumps of immigration, which are the almost systematic reception of illegal immigrants and the social assistance they are granted are turning flat regime. This mirage is trying and will tempt more and more people dreaming of a better economic future, more and more illegals supported by already drained economies, ever more deaths off our coasts, attracted by this mirage. Let us not talk about your policy of almost permanent interference in the countries of the Middle East, which causes the destruction of states and allows the development and strengthening of the Islamic State. You have therefore become the facilitators, through your action, of the worst violations of human rights, those same human rights that you are fighting - oh, only with words, of course - in European forums. The European Union's software no longer works. It is high time to abandon this ideology, for the good of our peoples, to finally solve these major problems. Challenge yourself, challenge yourself radically, this is what people expect of you!

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, the European Union is based on three pillars: multinational companies and banks order, those in political power deliver and the media sells it to the people. It is a complete concentration of power, and of course the most important European value is completely absent from it: separation of powers, checks and balances. Because of this, a new Presidency is always a new hope. It is only individuals with their hearts and their brains in the right place who can challenge this system. Maybe in an office of the Luxembourg Government, or maybe in this room, there is a young lawyer – a young person with heart and brain in the right place – who is going to end up being the European Edward Snowden. I wish her well. God bless her.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, the debate was perfect, I have nothing to add.

name: Xavier Bettel
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, I would like to thank the broad support of most of the ranks here in this House, who are aware that the task is not the easiest, that current events will also dominate our agenda.  I am accused of being smiling. I must tell you that I am proud to be able to speak in an assembly where a peace project, which was built in 1957, is still at the heart of the priorities and ambitions of MEPs. Yes, I am one of those young people who have been fortunate enough to be able, thanks to Europe, to study in Greece, to work and study in France, to be from another country, to get to know each other and, above all, to know that it is through diversity that we are strong. Mr President, we have talked a lot about migration. No, the task is not easy and it is up to us at present to try to build bridges and, above all, to recall the solidarity that must exist in this regard. I would like to point out that people who leave their country with a plastic bag that sums up their whole lives do not do so with a cheerful heart and that, if they do, it is often to save their lives and that of their children. So to say that these are people who risk their lives and that of their families, their children, just for fun, I find it simply outrageous. These are people who leave in desperation, precisely to save their lives and that of their children. (Applause) We talked about the Paris conference and expressed the hope that it would be a success. But it must be a success! We have to make commitments. On this occasion, we must come to an agreement, to have ambitions, and they must also be shared by other States. Nor can we in Europe give ourselves rules that are not those of other continents, whether it is Asia or the United States. As I said earlier, this ecological dumping that exists in some countries that do not apply any rules, simply to be able to attract industry, must stop as well.   Therefore, Mr President, our task will not be easy, but we have, throughout history, always tried to build the bridges that are needed today.  The situation is not easy, whether it is Brexit, Grexit, immigration, I think solidarity today is more important than ever and it is our responsibility to explain it to our citizens. It is in the interest of all of us and, believe me, I will do everything in my power to create these bridges, which are now more than necessary.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The sitting was suspended at 9.35 a.m. and resumed at 9.55 a.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. A new rotating presidency opens with Luxembourg and opens with a whiff of failure. Europe is on the brink of bankruptcy, moral, political and economic bankruptcy and this is now being publicised, no one can deny it! The euro crisis is starting again and taking a political turn with the peoples who are beginning to say NO to the ultra-liberal policies advocated by Brussels and Angela Merkel. The migrant crisis is also present and is the result of your ideologies that always want fewer borders and more and more "living together". It must be noted that as successive presidencies progress, nothing changes and the Luxembourg Presidency in progress after the Latvian presidency will do no better. Moreover, Mr Bettel and his counterpart at the Commission Mr Juncker share the same ideas and the same political vision, only membership of a national or European party changes the situation...  The EU software no longer works, people wake up and it becomes urgent to break with these federalist policies that are killing our competitiveness, our jobs and sacrificing thousands of Europeans on the altar of globalisation and finance.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Union is no longer 'business-as-usual'. We must act now! Luxembourg is one of the most experienced countries with a clear long-term vision and strong voice in the Union, an example also of Slovenia. How to restore trust, bring people, countries, European and national policies together – this will be our biggest challenge. Citizens need to feel once again that they are part of the processes and not part of the problems. The refugee debate today focuses on numbers, not the need for a comprehensive migration policy. If the Luxembourg Presidency is serious, then it should provide support for a fair distribution of refugees between EU governments and reach an ambitious agreement on the Students and Researchers Directive later this year. The debate on tightening asylum and visa policy, introducing European PNR, automated borders focuses too much on security risks. Such measures must not undermine the fundamental right – to protect privacy. Will the 175-mile-long wall between Hungary and Serbia really fix the migrant problem? No! He's going to pour oil on the fire. It is a disgrace that we are building walls again on European soil. We have to address the problems at their source. Why are nationalist, populist and extreme rhetoric intensifying? Why are more and more young Europeans going to the battlefields in Syria and Iraq? That's what we need to worry about. We must give Europe a soul - cooperation and dialogue, and hope for a safe and decent life for Europeans.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I agree with most of the priorities set out by the Luxembourg Presidency on agriculture in its programme. It is good that they include the impact of the Russian embargo on the agri-food sector, as this crisis has particularly affected Polish fruit and vegetable and milk producers. The health of dairy farms continues to deteriorate due to the Russian embargo, falling global demand, price volatility and imbalances in the supply chain. I am therefore pleased that the Presidency will also address the problems in this sector. Every effort should be made to de-bureaucraticise and simplify the milk package. The mechanisms currently being implemented, in particular with regard to producer organisations, have not worked.  However, I believe that a bigger problem than the abolition of milk quotas is the high penalties imposed on m.in. Polish farmers in the last two years of quotas. These penalties are not justified on economic grounds, as eu-wide limits have not been exceeded. I expect the Presidency to take action to put pressure on the Commission on this issue.  The Luxembourg Presidency has announced its wish to participate in the debate on the revision of the authorisation process for GENETICALLY MODIFIED food and feed. As shadow rapporteur for european conservatives and reformists on this issue, I expect the Presidency to listen to the voice of our societies who do not want such food on their tables.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – I was pleased to read in the Luxembourg Presidency's programme that they intend to pay attention to energy issues in the coming semester. Among the different dimensions of the Energy Union, the Presidency highlighted R&D and innovation. These are really important issues that we need to address. We've probably talked very little about them. At the same time, I am confident that other important areas of energy policy, such as infrastructure development, two-way pipelines or diversification, for example, will not be overshadowed. Now we've escaped a winter without a gas crisis, but I'm sure none of us would want to have to worry about the next winter.  Guaranteeing security of energy supply is still the number one energy policy command for all responsible European leaders today. Tomorrow we will not be living in a world of smart meters and decentralised energy production. We must do everything we can to spread these technologies, but in the meantime we must ensure a continuous supply of energy. I therefore ask the Luxembourg Presidency to focus on the pressing problems of the present, in addition to the challenges of the future in the field of energy policy. In this work, you can count on the European Parliament, which has recently started to negotiate the Commission's proposal on the Energy Union.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am pleased that the Presidency will focus on promoting Horizon 2020. In this context, I draw the Presidency's attention to the success rate of the projects funded under this programme. Currently, the success rate of projects eligible for the programme is very low, sometimes even below 3%. At the same time, the number of stakeholders interested in participating in this programme and the quality of their applications (e.g. poland) are increasing. In the long term, this situation can have a dissuasive impact on potential programme participants and lead to a decrease in interest in the programme. I hope that the Presidency will address this issue and take steps to improve success rates in order to allow effective competition between applicants while maintaining the attractiveness of Horizon 2020 to academic and non-academic institutions.  The Presidency's approach to education as a condition for combating social exclusion and for the active participation of young citizens in public and social life is very important, m.in. in the context of the review of the Education and Training 2020 strategy. There is no doubt that we need new initiatives, m.in. in terms of access to quality early childhood education and care, prevention of early school leaving, lifelong learning and special assistance for the socially disadvantaged and people with disabilities.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – European industry is a key priority, which must improve European competitiveness by placing it in a global and sustainable framework based on digitisation, research and innovation. European energy policy must be another objective of the new Presidency, in the context of the energy union recently proposed by the Commission. The Energy Union could be a decisive step forward for the future of the internal electricity and gas supply market. A viable energy union requires new governance, in which final consumers must play a decisive role in designing the functioning of the new energy market. The Luxembourg Presidency must also continue the fourth rail package and launch a wide-ranging debate on European transport policy in general. The economic success of these three axes will be matched by the proper implementation of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, which could mobilise more than EUR 300 billion to finance projects of great added value for the EU. The strengthening of the European economy must move forward in parallel with the structural reform of banking and the formation of the Capital Markets Union. This will allow for viable financing of the European economy and boost the internal market.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – A few days ago, the Russian Federation decided to extend the embargo on imports of agricultural products from the EU. Much of European agriculture still suffers from this without adequate assistance from the Commission, but only with calls on it to find new production markets. There are no concrete measures yet proposed to assist European farmers as a result of the extended embargo and this is unacceptable. I call on the Luxembourg Presidency to pay urgent attention to this problem and, in close cooperation with Parliament, to propose intervention measures especially for the stone fruit sector, such as cherries, as well as for the dairy sector.  Last year, a number of dairy products, which are known on the Russian market as Bulgarian white brine cheese and yellow cheese, failed to take advantage of the measures proposed by the EC because they did not cover this type of products. European farmers should not be allowed to fall victim to geopolitical solutions without adequate assistance and compensation.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. – The Luxembourg Presidency, which will chair the Council for the 12th time, from 1 July to 31 December 2015, presented its programme of activities in which it set out the main topics and issues to be addressed by the Council during this period.  The Luxembourg Presidency's work programme is based on a total of seven titles: boosting investment to boost growth and create new jobs; strengthening the EU's social dimension; managing migratory flows, covering freedom, justice and security; reviving the single market by focusing on the digital dimension; placing the EU's competitiveness in a global and transparent framework; promoting sustainable development and strengthening the EU's presence on the world stage.  I am of the opinion that the programme of activities prepared for the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council fully revolves around current issues of concern to the EU. In doing so, I would particularly emphasise the social dimension of the EU, which is today severely affected by the economic crisis we are experiencing, and on promoting market revitalisation in order to make the EU as competitive as possible, thereby breaking this downward trend in the social segment. Consequently, I welcome the programme of activities presented.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council (25-26 June 2015) and the Eurogroup Summit (7 July 2015) and on the current situation in Greece (2015/2719(RSP)).

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, I would first like to wish the Luxembourg Presidency all the best. There is a very challenging six months ahead and I look forward to the closest cooperation possible. Knowing Prime Minister Bettel, I am sure that he will do an excellent job. We meet at a unique and difficult time for Europe, and for our economic and monetary union. Before I discuss the special Euro Summits of last night and in June, I will report briefly on the key outcomes of the June European Council. Leaders discussed how to support front-line European Union countries under the greatest migratory pressure. We agreed on the relocation and resettlement of 60 000 refugees over the next two years. For clarity, the scheme will complement existing national efforts, with EU countries now receiving 600 000 asylum applications per year. Yes, the discussion was difficult and at times divisive. To my mind, it was the first time European leaders have had such an honest exchange on the refugee question. The European Council chose to keep to the voluntary approach agreed at the Special European Council in April. There is a balance to be struck between national sovereignty and action at European level in this matter. Now we have an agreement with which we can work, and on which we can build. The Luxembourg Presidency is receiving voluntary pledges from Member States on both relocation and resettlement. Based on progress so far, we hope that the numbers agreed at the European Council will be reached. In the light of the ongoing emergency, leaders also agreed that the European Union will assist in setting up ‘first reception’ facilities in front-line states to ensure swift registration of irregular arrivals. Meanwhile, the Commission will accelerate talks with countries of origin and transit on readmission to strengthen our returns policy. These will be on the basis of the ‘more for more’ principle in related areas such as development aid. The British Prime Minister confirmed his government’s intention to hold a referendum on membership by 2017. Talks on UK renegotiation will now get underway. It was the first step in a longer process that will also end at the European Council. We will come back to this in December. The NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg discussed with us the new security threats facing Europe, just as we learned of the latest terror attacks in Tunisia, Kuwait and France. In the context of international terrorism and other security challenges, leaders tasked the High Representative with preparing a new European Union strategy on foreign and security policy for June next year. We also agreed to use EU funding to support collective efforts to invest in the future of European defence. Finally, we discussed economic matters, most notably the report on completing economic and monetary union (EMU), published on 22 June. The report makes clear that the priority in building a deeper monetary union is reform at national level. We can best address the structural weaknesses of the eurozone by confronting the weaknesses of its national economies. Leaders asked the Council of Ministers to examine the EMU report further to determine quickly the next steps. Leaders also highlighted the importance of building a digital single market and noted the Commission’s new work plan in this respect. Given the central role of the digital economy in job creation and growth, the European Council was absolutely clear that this area is now a top priority. To achieve this goal, the future co-operation of the European Parliament is vital. Two weeks ago, I called a Euro Summit on 22 June to help break the impasse in negotiations on financial assistance to Greece and to ensure that all leaders were on the same political page. Over the next days, leaders asked the Eurogroup to accelerate discussions on a last-minute proposal by Greece. We believed a deal was achievable then. Two weeks later, there is now a race against time to re-build trust. I will not discuss the rights and the wrongs of the Greek referendum. Everyone has their own perceptions. It is necessary at this stage to move on. Let bygones be bygones. At the Euro Summit last night, leaders had a frank and honest exchange about the difficult situation now before us. We asked Prime Minister Tsipras to present his government’s ideas for sustainable growth and prosperity in Greece. The Eurogroup will now consider the detail of Greece’s request for a programme under the European Stability Mechanism (ESM) Treaty. Clarifications will be needed in the coming days and should be provided as quickly as possible. All sides in the negotiations share the responsibility for the current status quo. I call on all leaders to try to find consensus – that can be our common success, with no losers or winners. If that does not happen, it will mean the end of the negotiations, with all the possible consequences, including the worst-case scenario, where everyone will lose. Our inability to find agreement may lead to the bankruptcy of Greece and the insolvency of its banking system and, for sure, it will be most painful for the Greek people. I have no doubt that this will affect Europe, also in the geopolitical sense. If anyone has any illusions that it will not be so, they are naïve. The stark reality is that we have only four days left to find ultimate agreement. Until now, I have avoided talking about deadlines, but I have to say loud and clear that the final deadline ends this week. All of us are responsible for the crisis and all of us have a responsibility to resolve it. As Plutarch once said, ‘To find fault is easy; to do better may be difficult’. I hope doing better is not as difficult as Plutarch once thought. Let us prove him wrong. (Applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, Mr President, Prime Ministers, ladies and gentlemen, the Task of the European Council in June was to formulate an answer to the problem of migration. The Commission had proposed a mandatory relocation and resettlement system. The European Council, after a very painful debate at times, has agreed on a system based on volunteerism. I did not like that decision, because I would have preferred a mandatory system. I would have preferred the application of the community method; we have a provision in the treaty. (Applause) But, to be honest, the gist is not there. We agreed on the principle of relocating and resettling 60,000 people.  This is a decision that is going in the right direction, since the Luxembourg Presidency, which I trust in this matter, will be able to organise volunteerism in order to reach this target of 60,000 people, which must be absolutely maintained.  But I would like to say that we should not be proud. I am not criticising anyone, but the pride of Europe to welcome 60,000 people to its territory is not a huge achievement, given the scale of the problem. (Applause)  Since it was the Commission itself that proposed this number of 60,000, I was not going to criticize that decision. But, if I let my heart speak, I must say that we are not up to each other! (Applause)  I was able to present the report on the deepening of the Economic and Monetary Union on behalf of the five Presidents at this June Council (because we thought it would be wise to involve the President of the European Parliament). I will not go into detail before you, because you have probably read it carefully, but I mean that, in the face of the Greek crisis, in the face of the many breakdowns of solidarity that are taking over in Europe, we will have to agree - or not - with all the steps proposed in this programme on deepening economic and monetary union. We have to apply it. The answer to the Greek crisis is not to do nothing. The right answer is to deepen economic and monetary union, to make it more sustainable.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Deviating from the previous agenda and following the wish that the Prime Minister of Greece, Mr Tsipras, should speak here in Parliament, I have invited Mr Tsipras and he has accepted this invitation. It is the first time that the Prime Minister of Greece has had the opportunity to discuss in public the situation in his country and perhaps the deepest crisis we have been facing as a Union in a long time. I welcome this and therefore give the floor to the Prime Minister of Greece, Mr Tsipras. (Applause)

name: Αλέξης Τσίπρας
text: Prime Minister of Greece. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour for me to speak at the temple of the Republic of Europe. Thank you very much for the invitation. It is an honour to address the elected representatives of the peoples of Europe at a critical time both for my country, for Greece, but also for the euro area and for the European Union as a whole. I am among you only a few days after the strong verdict of the Greek people, after the decision we took to give the Greek people the reason to decide immediately and to take a position, to take an active part in the negotiation concerning their future. Only a few days after his strong verdict, which instructed us to strengthen our efforts to achieve a socially just and economically sustainable solution to the Greek problem, without the mistakes of the past that condemned the Greek economy, without the perpetual and dead-end austerity that entraps the economy in a recessional vicious circle but also society in a constant and deep depression. The brave choice of the Greek people in conditions of unprecedented pressure with the banks closed, with the majority of the media terrified that the choice of no is a choice of rupture with Europe... It is a pleasure to be in the temple of the Republic, because I believe that here we hear arguments and judge arguments. So listen, I'm not going to let you get out of here.   I was therefore saying that the brave choice of the Greek people is not an option to break with Europe but an option to return to the founding principles of European unification, to the principles of democracy, solidarity, mutual respect and equality.  It is a clear signal that Europe, our common European structure, the European Union will either be democratic or have enormous difficulties in surviving the difficult conditions we are in.   The negotiation to be concluded between the Greek Government and its partners seeks to reaffirm the double respect of Europe, both in its common rules of operation and in full respect for the democratic choice of our peoples. My government took over, I personally and my government took over about five months ago, but the rescue programmes have been in place for about five years. I take full responsibility for what has happened in these five months or so. But we must all honestly realise that the main responsibility for the deadlocks in which the Greek economy is today, for the dead ends where Europe as a whole is today with the choices made, is not for the last five months but for the five years of implementation of programmes that have not led to the exit from the crisis, and I would like to assure you that , regardless of everyone's judgment on the right or wrong of reform efforts: One is a fact; Greece, over the past five years, and the Greek people have made an unprecedented attempt to adapt difficult, cruel. This effort has exhausted the resistance of the Greek people. Of course, a similar effort was not made only in Greece. It has been done in other countries, and I fully respect the efforts of other peoples to cope and governments to decide on tough and difficult measures. Austerity programmes have been implemented in many European countries, but nowhere have these programmes been as hard and as long as they have been in Greece. It would not be an exaggeration to say that my country has been transformed over the last five years into an experimental austerity workshop. But the experiment must all admit that it didn't work. In these five years unemployment has skyrocketed. Poverty skyrocketed. Social marginalisation has widened. The same has been extended to public debt, which before the programmes started was at 120% of GDP and is now at 180% of GDP.  Today the majority of the Greek people – regardless of our estimates this is a reality and we must accept it – feel that they have no choice but to claim to be freed from this dead end, and this desire, expressed in the most direct and democratic way, we are called upon as a government to implement. We are demanding an agreement with our partners, but an agreement that will signal a definitive way out of the crisis, giving the impression that at the end of the tunnel there is light; , workers, pensioners, those who can no longer bear burdens, and of course with redistribution policies for the benefit of the low and middle classes for a balanced and sustainable development perspective.  The proposal we are tabling to our partners is a proposal that includes credible reforms based, as I said before, on fair burden-sharing and with as little impact as possible. It includes the call for adequate coverage of the country's medium-term financing needs with a strong and forward-looking development programme, because if we do not put the growth agenda on the table, we will never get out of the crisis. Our first objective must be to combat unemployment and encourage entrepreneurship. And of course our proposal also includes the call for an immediate commitment to start a meaningful dialogue, a meaningful debate on tackling the problem of sustainability of public debt. There can be no taboo between us, we must see reality and seek to find solutions to this reality no matter how difficult these solutions are.  The proposal was tabled with these characteristics in the Eurogroup, at the summit we had yesterday. Today we are sending a request to the European support mechanism. We have undertaken over the next two days to make our proposals absolutely concrete and I hope that in the coming days we will be able to meet the demands of the critical juncture both for the good of Greece and the euro area, I would say mainly not only for the economic but also for the geopolitical interest of Europe.  I want to be clear here: the Greek Government's proposals to finance its obligations and to restructure its debt are not intended to burden the European taxpayer in addition. The money given to Greece – let us be honest – never ended up with the Greek people.  It was money given to save Greek and European banks but never went to the Greek people.  In addition, since August 2014 Greece has not received a disbursement of a instalment in accordance with the rescue programme in force until the end of June. Payments of 7.2 billion euros have not been given since August 2014 and it was not our government that was in power from August 2014 to January 2015. And then the instalments were not given, because the programme was not being implemented, and the programme was not being implemented and then not because there was then the specific ideological reference that exists today but precisely because this programme and then and now does not find social consensus. A programme is not enough just to be correct, in our view, it must be able and implemented, to find the social consensus to be implemented.  Ladies and gentlemen, at the same time Greece negotiated by claiming this 7.2 billion of disbursement but having to repay to the same institutions from which it claimed disbursements, during that period, of EUR 17.5 billion. This money was paid by the Greek people.  Ladies and gentlemen, despite what I have said to you, I am not one of the politicians who claims that all the evils of my country are the fault of bad foreigners. Greece has reached the brink of bankruptcy because for too many years the governments, the governments of Greece, have created a client state, strengthened corruption, tolerated or even strengthened the interconnection of politics with economic power, left the tax evasion of great wealth unchecked. According to a survey by Credit Suisse, 10% of Greeks manage 56% of national wealth, and this 10% of Greeks in the period of harsh austerity and crisis found themselves in the undisturbed; it did not contribute to the burdens as much as the remaining 90%.  These great injustices, the rescue programmes and the memoranda not only did not try to restore them, but unfortunately they have extended them. None of the supposed reforms of the Memorandum's programmes has unfortunately improved the tax collection mechanism, which collapsed despite the overzealousness of some enlightened but also rightly frightened state officials. No supposed reform has taken on the notorious triangle of interconnection that has been building in our country for years now and before the crisis, between the political establishment, the oligarchs and the banks. No reform has improved the functioning and effectiveness of the state machine, which has learned to operate in order to serve self-interests and not the common good, and unfortunately these proposals are now at the heart. Our proposals focus on real reforms aimed at changing Greece. These are reforms that previous governments, the old political system and the bailout programs, did not want to happen in Greece; this is real Truth. The effective treatment of the oligopolistic structure and cartel practices in individual markets, including the unregulated and unacvolved television market, the strengthening of control mechanisms in public revenues and the labour market, with a view to combating tax evasion and tax evasion, the modernisation of public administration are the reform priorities of our own government and we certainly await the agreement of our partners.  Today we come with the strong mandate of the Greek people and with our determined will not to clash with Europe but to clash with the incumbents in our country and with the established logic and mentalities that have sunk Greece and sunk the eurozone together.  Ladies and gentlemen, Europe is at a crucial crossroads. What we call the Greek crisis is nothing more than the eurozone's overall inability to find a definitive solution to a self-fuelled debt crisis. In fact, this is a European problem and not exclusively a Greek problem. A European solution is also needed to a European problem. European history is a history of conflict but, at the end of the day, compromises. But it's also a story of convergences and enlargements. A history of unity, not division, which is why we are talking about a united Europe. Let us not let it become a divided Europe. At this time we are called upon to find a fruitful and honest compromise in order to avoid a historic rupture that will overturn the tradition of a united Europe. I am sure that we all understand the criticality of the moment and we will respond, we will take our historical responsibility. (applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Welcome to the European Parliament! Before I talk about Greece, i would like to make a request to the President-in-Office of the Council: if this is the heart of European democracy, then I would also ask that the European Parliament be involved in the Council's deliberations, as it used to be, including in the person of our President. I believe that this is important. (Loud applause) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which I am not talking about economic policy today, I am not talking about budgetary figures, but I would like to talk today about the principles of European culture. Let's talk, for example, about decency, about partnership, about how to deal with friends. Mr Tsipras, you represent a government that has said the following in recent weeks: your defence minister has threatened the European Union that he will send waves of refugees across Europe if Europe does not pay. And your now-de Ladies and gentlemen, I would have expected the Prime Minister of Greece to come here today and apologise for these unacceptable remarks. But unfortunately, he has re-energised god today. (Applause, heckling) Let us talk about reliability and trust, including a cultural asset in Europe. In February 2015, at your first European Council, Mr Tsipras, you promised that Greece would present a reform programme. To date, there are no concrete proposals from Greece that form a basis on which to discuss. Yesterday, too, everyone sat together again, without even having any basis for consultation. They are destroying trust in Europe. The rest of Europe no longer has confidence in you. (Applause, boos) Prime Minister, you are talking about dignity, that is a key concept in your policy in Greece. Do you know what is part of dignity? Dignity involves truth, honesty. Her government has told Greek citizens that the banks will be closed because the bad ECB wants to exert pressure, and Varoufakis, your now-retired minister, has said: "The banks will reopen on Tuesday." Today is Wednesday, the banks are still not open. Mr Tsipras, you are not telling your people the truth, and that is a undignified policy! (Applause, whistles) I want to keep talking about dignity. Dignity also includes the question: with which friends do you surround yourself? All I have to do is look at the plenary: the extremists of Europe are applauding together on the left and on the right. Here are Le Pen, Strache, UKIP. (Applause, boos) Mr Tsipras, the extremists of Europe applaud, and one thing must not be missing, of course: Fidel Castro has congratulated you on the great success you have achieved. They surround themselves with fake friends! (Applause, boos) I would like to say another thought about dignity, namely the dignity of others in Europe. When we talk about a debt cut, please do not lie to the people! The debt reduction will not be paid for by foreign financial institutions, banks, any financial markets. No, Portugal will pay 3.5 billion euros for the debt cut and 24 billion euros for Spain. It will be the farmer in Portugal, it will be the nurse in Slovakia, and it will be the official in Helsinki who will have to pay your debt burden. In this respect, I would also ask you to see the dignity of these people. (Applause, boos) I would like to introduce the concept of solidarity. Greece is in an extremely painful time. That is why Jean-Claude Juncker has offered EUR 35 billion in reconstruction aid, which you have rejected. To the north, Greece borders Bulgaria. Bulgaria is a member of the European Union. As an experienced politician, you know what people's living conditions are. How can you actually explain to the Bulgarians – in solidarity – that Greece cannot withstand further cuts now, even though the minimum wage is lower in five eurozone Member States than in Greece? Are you thinking of these people? (Applause) I would like to add two other concepts to European culture, namely the question of hope. The people of this continent need hope for the future. Yesterday, Prime Minister Straujuma sat in your seat. In Latvia, gross domestic product fell by 14% in one year – in 2009 – an economic disaster. There, the politicians of all parties did not hold a referendum, but they put the budget in order, they reformed their country and led it into the future. Today we have a future for the people there. You, Mr Tsipras, have a disastrous record, and that is why you do not stand for hope. (Applause) The last thought is democracy. You represent here .... (Tumult in the Hall)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: If you continue to shout down Mr Weber, he will not be able to take advantage of his speaking time. In this respect, you are causing the overdraft of his speaking time. (Interjections) Democracy involves the ability to listen. We know that you don't own them. Please, Mr Weber, continue!

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats I am, frankly, relatively grateful for the applause, because it clearly shows who the extremist forces are here, who wants to destroy Europe here. (Interjections) I would like to say something about democracy. Tsipras is here representing Greek democracy. He has held a referendum and is the winner with 61%. Mr Tsipras, Slovakia's Socialist Prime Minister Fico, a Socialist, has said he now wants to consider holding a referendum because it is enough for Slovaks to open their pockets for the Greeks. Can other states now also vote, Mr Tsipras? We have enough national perspective in Europe. Europe is not the sum of national referendums, Europe is the compromise, the search for compromise. Unfortunately, you have left this path of God. (Interjections) I would like to say that we absolutely respect Prime Minister Tsipras as his country's elected representative. He has come into office democratically. But I say as a politician, as a representative of the Ppe-DE Group, that we will deal with you politically. You, Mr Tsipras, love the provocation, we love the compromise. They love failure, and we love success. They divide Europe and we love Europe. I hope that you will return to your senses and finally present a programme!

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which It was clear to all of us that this debate would be lively. That's why it's not bad if the emotions boil up a bit here. We know that you have a special joy today.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I want to say this from the beginning: for us Socialists and Democrats, Europe does not exist without Greece.
