(Applause from his group) Greece is an essential part of Europe and the eurozone. Without Greece in the eurozone, Europe would no longer be itself. That is why we have opposed and are opposed to extremists and political speculators playing on the skin of Greece and Europe. I could quote Varoufakis' sudden statements or Schäuble's extremist positions. I could respond to some of what Mr Weber said. However, I would prefer to stress the sobriety, seriousness and constructiveness of Mr Juncker, who has worked all these months to find a positive solution. Today is not the time for excuses, friends of friends... The hairpin bend we are experiencing is too serious for this and is too serious to turn this House into a cheering Chamber. This is not the time to divide this House! this is not the time to divide the European institutions! It's time to join them! Because you do not play the luck of a political party, but you play the luck of Europe, within which Greece is also in. I agree with Weber on one point. Dear President Tusk, you made a good speech today. But it is not possible for the most important European institution, Parliament, not to see its President attending the Euro Summits. I would therefore formally ask you to invite President Schulz to his meetings. Mr Tsipras, you do not belong to the party, but I feel European at the moment and as a European I tell you that, for the sake of Europe, we Socialists will never accept a Grexit. Never! In the last few hours, hope has been rekinded. I note a constructive attitude on the part of all. The attitude of yesterday's Heads of State or Government is a good one. Well the sharing of all the Greek political forces around a possible solution. I think the conditions are in place to reach an agreement this week. The agreement was already there.  We need a clear commitment from your government to reform. Support for development and work, reform of the Public Administration, the fight against corruption and evasion, liberalisation: these are not measures that Europe as a stepmother wants but are measures that serve the Greek citizens! And I think it is also right to discuss debt restructuring, which is not a forcing but a commitment made by creditors in 2012, which we must honour today, and I also believe that we need to think about a European debt conference, which will discuss the Redemption Fund and debt mutualisation. I believe that on this basis we must authorise a bridge loan to make greek citizens breathe and put the negotiators in a position to reach a medium-term agreement. Mr President, anyone who will read the history of these days must be able to read that in this Parliament, in the European institutions and in the Greek authorities and among the Greek authorities there have been women and men who have been able to put aside their shack, their political affiliation, in order to do an act of responsibility and constructiveness, to save Greece and to save Europe. (Applause from his group)

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I should start by saying that something is rotten in the state of Greece, but I can also add that something is the rotten in the EU too. In the beginning there was the original sin of the currency union, and today we are reaping its sour fruits. I do not know about everyone else here, but this gives me the impression of a pièce de théâtre that has been unfolding before our eyes; nothing really is what it seems. The Greeks want help and, at the same time, they want to have a free hand, apparently not aware of the old saying that ‘he who pays the piper gets to call the tune’. They organised a referendum which was, and at the same time was not, about what it was purported to be about. In Greece-EU relations we have witnessed a number of final rounds of talks, and we know that the word ‘final’ does not mean final – it means something else. The hard-core currency unionists speak about Greece, but what they have in mind is the monetary union, and they want to defend the monetary union and see it as the crucial point. They argue – and you heard it here in this Chamber – that once Greece is out, the entire construction, said to be so magnificently stable and firm, will fall to pieces. Either one or the other, ladies and gentlemen. So if this pièce de théâtre continues, I think we will be more and more confused about who and what we are trying to save: is it the currency union, the Greek society, the credibility of the government, the creditors, the reputation of Angela Merkel or the infallibility of the ever closer union? We certainly cannot save all of these; there will be some casualties, I am sure. (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I want first of all to support what Mr Weber and Mr Pittella said to Mr Tusk. I say to him that, at the moment, when there is such a crisis in Europe, our Europeans institutions have to be united – the European Council and the European Parliament – and, as you are invited here, you should also invite us to Council meetings, and please do that for the extraordinary meetings as well. Mr Tsipras, welcome. You can see that you do not have to be afraid of the European Parliament. You refused at first – I did not think that it could be true that such a big democrat as Mr Tsipras was afraid of a debate! – but you are here. I am pleased that you are here, because this is the first time that we have in fact discussed this with you in the European Parliament. I do not think that there are any possible solutions in the case of Greece, and in the case of the eurozone, if they do not have the backing of democracy and are not debated in a democracy and debated here in the European Parliament. That is what we are doing today. But I have to tell you – and you started, and what you said is true – you said the Greeks made enormous efforts, and that is true. But the problem is not there. It is that the Greek political class did not do enough in the case of Greece. That is the problem today.  (Applause) I have to tell you that I am angry because you are talking about reforms, but we never see concrete proposals for reforms.  (Applause) I am angry because we are in fact sleepwalking towards a Grexit. We have already been sleepwalking for five years with the help and the support – do you hear them? – of the people of the extreme right at the end. Not only have we been sleepwalking, but in recent months I have more the impression that we have been running towards a Grexit. But it is not you and it not us who will pay the bill.  It is going to be the ordinary Greek citizens who are going to pay the bill of a Grexit of 30-40%.  (Applause) So I have to tell you that if we want to avoid that, there is only one possible way, and you know very well what it is. The only possible way is that you come forward in the coming days – in the coming 48 hours – with a credible reform package. That does not mean you saying ‘Yes, I want to end clientelism’ and so on. It means that you make a roadmap and a clear calendar (no intentions) with end dates of the different reforms we need desperately in Greece.  (Applause) And let me tell you the five things you have to do – I am even ready to come to Athens to discuss it with you, because I like a challenge! But what do you have to do? First, end the clientelistic system. You need to put on the table legislation for that that does not exist and not to apply clientelism yourself, because a few weeks ago 13 directors in the Ministry of Education had to be nominated, and by accident there were 12 from the Syriza party. There was only one of them whose affiliation they do not know.  (Applause) That is the reality. You are using the system. You are falling into the trap which PASOK also fell into. That was also the big party of change in Greece after the colonels and which did nothing at all except use the clientelist system for years and years to its own advantage. You have to downsize the public sector. I know that is perhaps difficult for a leftist, but it has to be done, because there are 800 000 civil servants! That cannot work.  (Applause) You have to transform the public banks into a private banking sector. You have to open the markets and the professions for young people. We do not have legislation. Put legislation on the table to open at least 10 professions which are still closed in your country. Finally, let us propose ending the privileges in your country – the privileges of the ship-owners, the privilege of the military, the privilege of the Orthodox Church in your country... (Applause and interjections from the floor) you like privilege – that is fine, they like privileges, but I do not! There is also the privilege of the Greek islands. And let us not forget the privilege of the political parties in your country who receive loans and money every day from public banks which are in fact bankrupt. Syriza, your party, also receives such money. What I ask you to do is put all this together in a credible package and put it on the table in the coming days. I am pretty sure that from the other side – from the European side – we are going to be ready to find a solution to that. We are going to find a solution to all these problems. But it has to be done in that way. You can do it because there has never been a Prime Minister in Greece who had such a strong mandate as you. You even have a double mandate. You won the elections and you won the referendum. So you are in the position of being the only political leader in Greece who can put an end to that system in Greece. I have said to you that we also have a responsibility. In my opinion we have to make a debt redemption fund as fast as possible, and we have to do it as fast as possible in the Council as well. But first things first: you need to come forward with your reform package. It is not a chicken or egg discussion. You have a choice, and that is my conclusion. The choice that you have is very simple. How do you want to be remembered? As an electoral accident who made his people poorer in his country? Or will you not be remembered, Mr Tsipras, as a real revolutionary reformer in the tradition of Trikoupis and Venizelos? I am not talking about the Venizelos of PASOK, the new one; I am talking about the real Venizelos, the big leader between the two world wars who modernised his country, a liberal who in fact modernised his administration. That is the choice to be made, and I know what your people want. Eighty percent of your people want to stay in Europe and in the eurozone. So, show what you can do now and show that you are a real leader and not a false prophet. Do it! (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the European Parliament for his excellent work and Since I have given part of my speaking time to colleagues in my group, I would like to put it very briefly and concisely here. Firstly, ladies and gentlemen, I do not believe that this is the time for us to use this podium here, on the one hand, in the face of the crisis and the disaster that has become very concrete for many people and which could possibly occur next weekend, in order to develop acting talents on the one hand – Mr Weber, I say it to you in concrete terms: to preach arrogance, schoolmastership and anti-communism here in the old German manner. (Loud applause) You can leave that stuck, because it won't help anyone. This is not the Bavarian regular table, here we are in the European Parliament. (Loud applause) Mr Tusk, I have taken very good note: you have been very reserved, very matter-of-fact in your assessments. I hope that this style will prevail. What we cannot use is the constant building up of threatening scenes, as if there had been no decision on Sunday, as if people had not said: for us the measure has been reached, we cannot go any further. However, you also said that we want to remain in the European Union, we want to remain in the euro area.  Please withdraw the sharpeners and the hardliners, especially on the creditor side! It does not help to stand up and impose its own ideological reservations on a country as regulatory measures. On the pretext that everyone must abide by the rules, something is being done that has not played a role in the history of Europe, especially in the history of Germany. With regard to the debts of the First World War, Germany has proved that you do not have to pay any debts for 37 years, that you can have 93 years to pay the debts of the First World War, and that, with a view to the Second World War, one had an international debt conference of 1953, which in the first place created the precondition for Germany to go down this path! (Loud applause) It is time for us to finally take this historic responsibility towards the people of Europe and finally put aside some of our better knowledge. I also call on my fellow Members from Germany in particular, regardless of which group – mine is, of course, behind us, that is quite clear.  But I believe that this is the way forward: let us finally sit down together and talk about what needs to be decided now. It is about solutions that are sustainable, not just an explanation of what should be done and what is required of others.  Respect the people of Europe. Also respect Sunday's decision. (Loud applause)

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is Yesterday, as I tried to prepare for the debate, I went through the newspapers that I have been piling up in my office for a week. I always do this when I don't know what's going on – and I'm doing that at the moment – then I collect and collect. And on top of the stack of these newspapers last week was a German newspaper with the photo, a portrait of a Greek pensioner who had collapsed in front of an ATM crying. And for me, at least, it's the photo that's in my memory this week. I believe that in this photo both the reasons that led to 60% voting 'no' in Greece have actually been captured. However, I believe, and this is the madness of this situation, that many of the reasons in this photo have also been captured by the people who voted 'yes'. For the vote in Greece was a vote on the fact that the impoverishment of a large part of society – and it is by no means the whole of society – can no longer go on. However, the vote was also clearly a vote on the fact that hope for change is still being linked to the European Union. (Applause) And that is your job now. I also think that, in a historic situation, you are the strongest Prime Minister of Greece, at least in my own memory, and that you must now be the one who leads your people into a proper prospect of reform. What has not happened so far and where, incidentally, Europeans also have a responsibility. This reform programme of the troika makes the word reform itself something that can only be recoiled from. (Applause) I have to tell you now: maybe I am naive, but I actually expected you to come here and not just say: stop nepotism and corruption, but I had this naive desire, tsipras is coming now and saying: this is how I will do this with my people. (Applause) This is what a fair tax system will look like. This is what a fair pension system will look like. We all know that small pensions cannot be cut any further. But the question is: how do pensions in Greece do justice? This is what the health system in Greece will look like in the future, so that we no longer need poor clinics. I believe that this is actually what you can not only lead the Greeks into a better future, but with which you can ensure that the Europeans join you. And we have to! This cohesion, which has been lost over the last five years, can be regained if you talk to your people and to the citizens of Europe in this way. I am not just referring to the Heads of State or Government or some of those who have not necessarily helped to invite you here today. You need to get into this direct debate, and europeans– as Guy Verhofstadt said– must get out of a wrong policy on the debt burden. And I agree with Guy Verhofstadt that a solution must be found that is not only needed for the Greeks, but which is needed for other crisis countries. That is fair. And then it is also European. (Applause) Mr Tsipras, I know that, unfortunately, time cannot be stopped. I wish we could. It is obvious that everything has to be decided this week. Listen to those who want a European solution! And remember because you are so appealing to democracy: Europe is great. The East is one of them, and it also needs solidarity. And democracy and Putin, that is not possible! I wish you luck, and I wish Europe happiness! (Applause)

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, what we are seeing in this Chamber this morning, and indeed across the whole of Europe, is an irreconcilable cultural difference between Greece and Germany: a split between the north and the south of Europe. Europe, the European project, is actually beginning to die. Nobody in this room will recognise that, but actually the peoples of Europe are saying, ‘We were never asked whether we wanted this: this has been foisted upon us.’ And we need to understand why economic and monetary union does not work. Those monsters Kohl and Mitterrand, backed by a clever but dangerous Delors, believed that if they put in place an economic and monetary union, then, as night follows day, there would be political union. They believed there would be acceptance of this project; that the North and South of Europe would converge; that we would all start to love each other; that we would all begin to feel a European identity; that we would all begin to show allegiance to the flag and the anthem. Those of us, of course, who criticised this were told that we were extremists and we lacked vision. Well, in one respect we did not lack vision: we understood that the countries of Europe are different, and that if you try to force together different people or different economies, without first seeking the consent of those people, it is unlikely to work, and the plan has failed. This is not just Greece we are talking about today: the whole of the Mediterranean now finds itself in the wrong currency, and yet virtually nobody in the political arena has got the courage to stand up and say that. I feel that the continent is now divided from north to south: there is a new Berlin Wall and it is called ‘the euro’. The old enmities have been resumed. Just listen to the way that the German leader of the Christian Democrat group this morning attacked Mr Tsipras. I think it was absolutely disgusting, but it shows the way north and south now feel about each other. Mr Tsipras, your country should never have joined the euro – I think you acknowledge that – but the big banks, the big businesses and big politics forced you in. Goldman Sachs, the German arms manufacturers, they were all very happy. And when the bailouts began, they were not for the Greek people. Those bailouts were to bail out French, German and Italian banks: they have not helped you at all. These years of austerity, these years of high unemployment, of increasing poverty: none of it has worked. In fact, your debt-to-GDP ratio has gone from 100% at the start of the crisis to 180% right now. It would be madness to continue on this course. You have been very brave. You called that referendum, although when one of your predecessors tried to do the same, the bully boys of Brussels had him removed. They tried their best again – Mr Juncker said you would have to leave the euro and the European Union. Even Mr Schulz, the President of Parliament, who one would have thought might be neutral, said that if the Greeks voted no, their power supplies might even go down. There were threats and bullying, but the Greeks stood firm. However, sir, you cannot have your cake and eat it. They will give you no more, these people: they cannot afford to. If they give you more, they will have to give other eurozone members more. So your moment has come. And frankly, if you have got the courage, you should lead the Greek people out of the eurozone with your head held high: get back your democracy, get back control of your country, give your people the leadership and the hope that they crave. Yes, it will be tough for the first few months, but with a devalued currency, and with friends of Greece all over the world, you will recover. (Applause from Group)

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Mr Tsipras, we have radically divergent positions on a whole range of issues. It is a fact, but we share the desire to give people a voice against the Europeanist and technocratic dictatorship, and we therefore very legitimately welcomed the organisation of the referendum.  This referendum in Greece on austerity marks the return of politics in its noblest sense, in a European Union often reduced to technocratic attitudes. The European institutions - and this is perhaps a positive point - have shown their true face: horror! They tried everything to win this referendum. There have been multiple moral pressures. Proponents of austerity predicted disaster in the event of a "no" "no" We, the French people, know this because we experienced the same thing during the campaign on the European Constitution.  The Speaker of parliament here has even dared to call for the overthrow of your government legitimately elected by the people, Mr Tsipras, in order to replace it with a government of technocrats. Eurozone countries tried in vain to prevent the release of the IMF's report on Greece's debt on Thursday. This report indeed echoed your arguments, it must be admitted, and believes that Greece cannot repay the debt, because this debt is unsustainable and must therefore be renegotiated. Finally, the European Central Bank has tried to sow fear by suffocating Greek banks and causing their temporary closure. I believe this is the first time in history that a central bank has created a crisis from scratch, in an absolutely artificial way. But the anger of the Greek people towards the European policy of hyper-austerity was such that all the manoeuvres were swept away by popular fervor. Beyond the threats, the Greek people have pushed back the path without hope or prospects for the European Union.  Which people would have accepted for five years what the Greek people went through, for God's sake? Which would have accepted that? Gentlemen of the EPP group and liberals who have been frantically applauding Mr Weber's indictment, would you be willing to campaign? Do you agree with that? So campaign by promising your respective peoples a 25% pay cut and a 25% reduction in pensions! Campaign by offering your peoples the explosion of infant mortality, the threefold increase in unemployment! Be brave! Take responsibility for your positions! That is not what you do when you are on the campaign trail.  (Applause) Mr Tsipras, the euro and austerity are Siamese brothers. That's the reality. You will not be able to get your people out of austerity if you do not allow them to escape the euro.  What I think is that Greece must, in agreement with the European institutions and in a concerted way, quietly, get out of the iron jaw that the euro represents for all the countries of the South. All European peoples would then have their eyes fixed on Greece and could verify that the exit from the euro allows for the renewal and return of sustainable growth. That is what Mr Krugman, the Nobel laureate in economics, said. What you are afraid of, gentlemen of the European institutions, is not that Greece will go bankrupt, what you are afraid of is that Greece, by leaving the euro, shows that we can do better without the euro than with it. The veil is tearing. The euro is not irreversible. This is what you have sold us for years: "the euro is forever". No, the euro is not forever. The euro is not irreversible. The first euro crisis was financial and was stopped by the ECB in 2012. The second crisis is political, do not displease you, with peoples who dare to say "no", and you will not be able to stop this one. After so many mistakes, it is time to dissolve the euro area in a concerted way, no longer to keep the euro as a common currency. The economies of the countries of Europe will be better off and tensions between peoples will finally ease. (Applause from his group)

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, first of all I would like to address you, Mr Schulz, for your unacceptable intervention with regard to the Greek referendum. Who and with what authority says that, if no is voted, Greeks should be looking for another currency? In what mindset, with what competence and what fascist mentality do you get into the political issues of my country?  I would like you to address the German chancellery about what Germany did to the Greeks during the Second World War: one million one hundred and six thousand dead from losses, executions, diseases and hunger; 11 and a half billion forced occupation loans of the Third Reich, without counting interest; many thousands of billions of war reparations that you refuse to include in the debt.  So do you have the audacity to address this proud people with suggestions? How small are you, Mr Schulz, in relation to the greatness of a nation! You and Mr Weber should also address the Chancellor of Germany about what is owed. Do you think the Greek will be afraid and bow his head for not bowing four hundred years of slavery in the Ottoman Empire, in the Turk? You got the answer the other day: "no." No, of course, categorically to the Tsipras government, which is preparing and intends to pass a new onerous memorandum for the Greek people. Blessed Greece can survive with or without the eurozone. The euro area should either be stabilised or dissolved.

name: Herbert Reul (PPE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the European Parliament for his I have prepared for this debate like everyone else and I have thought: what can come next? I hoped that the Prime Minister of Greece – and Mrs Harms is absolutely right – would have put forward proposals today. The frightening thing about the debate on this issue over the last few months is that many years ago, in my own country, I helped to show solidarity with countries in difficulty. And then I saw that this was used in Portugal, in Spain, in Ireland, that they have made their contribution and that has preceded it.  In Greece, too, Prime Minister – who is not listening, I have imagined it in a similar way – greece too – excuse me, I thought you were interested in hearing our opinion – it went a long way. And then, Prime Minister, came the election, and everything changed. And from that day on, Greek politics has been seen as a new promise every day, a promise, but nothing concrete was ever put on the table. Since that day, you can no longer believe that you are really sticking to what you are saying. And solidarity does not just mean taking, claiming, hoping that this will somehow go well. But solidarity also means making your own contribution. Otherwise, this is sheer selfishness and only think of itself.  And, Prime Minister, I think that is precisely the mistake. You have to deliver. I would just like to mention the President of the Commission here: what has Jean-Claude Juncker shown as an effort to accommodate you? In the end, it was 60 million, and he offered you 35 billion. Then you go back to Greece and say: we are now going to hold a referendum and we are destroying everything. Is that solidarity? Do you think anyone can still believe that you mean it honestly? That's the problem.  Credibility is an important prerequisite for history to work. And if you can't believe it, if you think that the man is just telling commonplaces again, nothing concrete comes out again, then Greece will get into the greatest trouble. But it is not those who are struggling for help who have the responsibility, but those who refuse and tell the untruth. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I should like to inform Mr Tsipras that I am speaking on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, and as he knows, we really want Greece to remain in the eurozone and we want a fair deal for Greece. Mr Tsipras knows very well that this is our position. But what is a fair deal for Greece? This deserves a political discussion. That is why we need to create a political governance of the eurozone. Important steps have been taken in recent weeks in this regard, and we are now having regular meetings at the eurozone summits. This is a very important development. The Commission is coming with proposals to these eurozone summits. This is also a very important development. And now the European Parliament has a role to play, because the European Parliament is the parliament of the euro. That is why the President of the European Parliament should also be represented in these discussions and bring our message to these discussions. But let us use this opportunity today to discuss exactly what a fair deal is, because what is at stake is whether we can reconcile the euro with democracy. Is it possible? Mr Tsipras, you come with a strong mandate from your country; you have just won a referendum. But other prime ministers can also argue that they have a strong democratic mandate, and we here also have a strong democratic mandate. Therefore, we need to find a way to draw up a new compromise in democratic terms: a real European compromise. That is why this discussion today is so important. My question to Mr Tsipras, but also to my colleagues in the European Parliament, is: can we accept a fair deal with a real opportunity for recovery in Greece, a real opportunity to invest, with more fiscal space, but also a clear solution for the debt burden in Greece in exchange for clear commitments for reform, ensuring good public administration, tax collection and a sustainable pension system? Do you think these are terms for a fair deal? I think they are. (Applause)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, Prime Minister, Mr Tsipras, we welcome you to the European Parliament. Mr. Weber, you've continued your Greek delirio today. So first tell Mrs Merkel to pay off the German war reparations and then talk about dignity. So stop waving your finger at the Greek people, who have been impoverished by mercely austerity, your own policy. You know the memorandum failed in Greece. It reduced GDP by 25%, ejected debt from 127% of GDP to 180% of GDP.  Greece in the last five memorial years has received 214 billion euros in loans, yet my country has 1.5 million unemployed and 40% live below the poverty line. So where did the money go, Mr. Weber? Why don't you say they went to rescue the German banks? Why are you hiding it? So make a decision: The Greek people no longer tolerate Mercely austerity and memoranda, and this message sent you with the thunderous no that they said last Sunday in the referendum.

name: Sylvie Goulard (ALDE).
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister, thank you for being with us this morning in this Parliament which is the precinct of European democracy. The ALDE Group really wanted this debate to take place and we thank you for being there. I would like to make three proposals: the first, Prime Minister, would be for us to change our method. So far, we have worked behind closed doors. The European Council decided without us always knowing exactly what was going on. For the first time, you are here in front of us and I wanted to tell you that there is only one euro, there is not the Euro of the Germans or the French and the euro of the Greeks. There is only one euro and there can only be a democracy!  We must avoid at all costs to continue to pitt people against each other. This method is extremely dangerous. My proposal is to use Parliament and that if there is an agreement, it should be followed up at the political level. You know that we have written a report on the troika and we have tried to hear it. Accept a compromise by following up in this Parliament. Second, the change in procedure cannot prevent us from making substantive efforts. Guy Verhofstadt went into detail. I want to tell you as they say in America: "Just do it!". You have said a lot of things that are quite right about tax reform, about the need to move forward. Do it, implement it. The Greeks said no, but they want to stay in the eurozone. What would you say yes to? What are you prepared to say yes to? Are you prepared to say yes to a minimum of rules, to a minimum of respect for its word, to an attitude towards the ECB, which reminds everyone that the ECB is the central bank of all Europeans and not just of the Greeks. How to return to fair cooperation, not insults. There would be much to say about the reparations of the Second World War. The reason we gave up reparations is that we did not want to redo the Treaty of Versailles and the Treaty 2-4. You can talk to Barack Obama about it the next time he calls you: it was the Americans who wanted reparations to be abandoned, and Mr Tusk here knows full well that it is also the treaty that has set the borders of Germany and Poland. We don't touch history, Mr Tsipras! Let's move on! Let's try to find solutions for the future, don't wake up the corpses of the past! Finally, I am chair of the anti-poverty intergroup. Take the lead in an initiative to fight poverty across Europe. It's not just the poor in Greece and the rich elsewhere. There are poor people in Germany, there are poor people in Finland and there are poor people in France. Stand up for them and help fight inequality! Misery has no borders. Also respect the modest people whose taxes are used to pay for your emergency plans! You said that you have to respect the people's choice. Let us respect the choice of all peoples!

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker, Mr Timmermans, Prime Minister of Greece, a united Europe without Greece is like a child without a birth certificate. The Greek government and the Greek people do not want Grexit at 80%. The Commission and the Council also categorically reject this, because it will cause enormous economic, social and geopolitical costs. These costs have been measured and are enormous. So you all need to do in practice, as a matter of urgency, by Sunday, whatever it takes– as Mr. Draghi– so that the word Grexit can finally be removed from the European vocabulary, away from the mistakes of the past, which have caused enormous recession and unemployment and incredible social pain in my own country of Greece, and the Commission and the Council and the Greek Government must really try to do so.  Mr Weber, stop insulting Greece and the Greeks! Stop playing with matches in a fuel depot! Mrs Le Pen and Mr Farage, stop playing the populist game on the backs of Greek women and Greeks to advance your far-right aspirations! We want Greece not a debt colony but a respectable member state of the euro zone and the European Union. My country needs not to escape From Europe but a programme of strong changes for balanced public finances, a stronger economy, a reduction in unemployment, better administration rather than a client state, a fairer and more efficient tax system, a reduction in tax evasion, to finally pay the rich and powerful, to break the privilege of oligarchs that hinders both healthy competition and entrepreneurship; cutting red tape and corruption.  And in order to achieve what is the objectives of the Greek Government, Mr Juncker, both the Commission, Mr Tusk, and the Council must provide another solution with European characteristics to the debt problem, not to do that they do not listen to the reports and proposals of the International Monetary Fund.  And they must also help to boost the Greek economy by making the most of existing and new social resources. This is no time for mutual blame, this is no time for blame game. The cost of a Grexit is prohibitive for everyone and not just for Greece. Now is not the time for one ball to fly, Mr Juncker, at the other's teren. Enough tennis on the backs of Greek women and Greeks! The common interest is the solution with a developing, respectable and equal member of the eurozone, not a debt colony. The eurozone must avoid mutilation, and I am sure that by Sunday the forces of realism, optimism, growth, democracy will win and the extreme forces of division and the far right and populism will be defeated overwhelmingly.

name: President. –
text: Colleagues, I shall just repeat my concerns about the timing of our debate. I would ask that we try and respect the time. I will be reasonably flexible but I will have to tell colleagues to stick within the timeframe.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, spirits are heating up, but we must not lose our minds. Telling the truth to our peoples is a condition of appeasement. If we are on the brink, it is because those who say today that they will not pay for Greece have preferred to turn a blind eye to the actions of the former Greek governments. Yes, we will have to pay for imposing the purchase of our warships rather than the fight against tax evasion. The only question is whether we want to lose everything, namely the loans to Greece and the European spirit, or whether we want to save the furniture and give ourselves a chance to continue together in the eurozone.  Mr Tsipras, even if we do not agree on everything, I thank you for holding on. You are right to ask that Europe's debt file be resolved. To get out of the crisis from the top, Mrs Merkel must stop playing with fire and Mr Hollande must get out of his torpor.  The threat is not Mr Tsipras. The threat is the extreme right, which revels in seeing us weaken Europe in advance. Our national leaders have until Sunday to become European leaders. (Applause)

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe is facing two major challenges: on the one hand, the management of migratory flows and, on the other, the current situation in Greece. In this scenario, the role played by the European institutions has produced highly disappointing results, results that are undermining the principles and values on which the Union is founded and threatening its own credibility and existence. What happens with migrants on the borders of Italy and other states, just as the 'No' vote in the referendum in Greece clearly teaches us that the European project that has been achieved so far must be renewed deeply and quickly, otherwise it will be doomed to failure. We cannot think of building and supporting a Europe in which national self-interest prevails over adequate solidarity, imposing disproportionate burdens on states under greater migratory pressure. And that is the meaning of a letter that the five-star movement delegation sent to you, Mr Tusk, which I do not know if you are listening to. We cannot regard as europe's enemy a people that speaks out to reaffirm its dignity, that does not want to be slaves to austerity policies, banks, international finance and lobbyist interests.  A People's Europe, with a renewed sense of community, is possible and it must be everyone's duty to try to rebuild it.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am ashamed that someone in here is said to represent Europe. I am ashamed that someone in here is managing 500 million people, leaving a future of war and unemployment for our citizens. I thank Tsipras and thank the Greek people. We are on different political positions. I reproach him for not going all the way and therefore not calling into question this European Union, which is an anti-democratic cage, this single currency that makes no sense whatsoeving. But I thank him because he has shown that the king is naked.  I am sorry for someone who, on behalf of the largest party represented in this Parliament, speaks with crap and spite of the referendum, of the citizens who vote, of the citizens who choose, because, coincidentally, if the citizens vote and choose, then perhaps reject the idiotic choices of this Europe, as they voted against, in France, ten years ago. How they voted against in holland. How they will vote in Denmark. How they will vote in the UK. I am afraid of this Europe that supports sanctions against Russia, putting 2 million jobs at risk and deploying 40 000 armed men in our house while there is someone who cuts the throats of others in the name of his God. But there's some phenomenon in here that says the problem is not Islamic terrorism but it's the right, it's the populists, it's Orbán, it's Le Pen, it's Cameron, it's the Northern League. You're hospitalized. You're dangerous.  I would like a Europe based on work, respect for human rights, agriculture and fisheries, which does not approve of disgusting international treaties, which serve multinationals and not our citizens and our workers. The roof is falling on your head. I thank Tsipras, I thank the Greek people and I thank the citizens who have courageously chosen to get out of this cage, because I do not leave the future of my children in the hands of someone who sucks democracy.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Madam President, the European Union promotes democracy everywhere. It has seen it done in Greece, but the Greek people were quite rational. They were told that moderate euro-socialism is good, so perhaps the more radical socialism of Syriza is better. It is as simple as that and very logical. Moreover, they were advised by half-wits in the IMF, ECB and the World Bank that they should cut social expenditure – which is right – but also raise taxes. How are the Greeks supposed to pay their debts if anybody trying to work is being punished by income tax? Only very rich countries can survive income tax and other socialist inventions. I think that for Greeks, torn between euro-socialism and national socialism, there is only one way to be rescued. In 1973, Chile – occupied by the gang of Salvador Allende – was in a much worse state than Greece is today. Then General Augusto Pinochet introduced a normal economy, and in two years Chile became the richest country in Latin America. (Sustained heckling) Black colonels are not the solution, but I hope that some golden general will fulfil his duty and save Greece from the present turmoil. Moreover, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. The moment is very difficult for the European Union, but also for all our institutions. I would like to ask the President whether the situation in which, as part of the European Council's agenda item dedicated to the conclusions, we invite the Prime Minister to one of the countries that is most important in terms of crisis, means that next time we will be able to invite one of the Prime Ministers to meetings on the report of the European Council. This is a precedent, and this is a situation where it would be better to have a debate on Greece than to include an element of Greece in the report of the European Council. We are interested in talking to the European Council on a number of issues, and I therefore believe that this is a political error and should not be repeated in the future. I am a representative of Polish, so we do not need to explain what solidarity is. We express our great solidarity with the Greek people, who today suffer the consequences of the wrong political decisions. We are in a situation where we have agreed to join the euro area in the accession treaty. Today we are attentive observers of what is happening in the euro area. It is extremely important for us, politicians and people in our country, what is the situation in the euro area, how the euro area countries treat each other, what the principles, responsibilities, mutual commitments, keeping their word mean today. We are looking at this very carefully, because sooner or later we will have to make a decision.  In fact, the entire European Union will depend on what the euro area is going to be.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D). Madam President, in my country, despite the mistakes of our governments and the experiments of harsh austerity of the lenders, the Greeks still pay the bill with dignity with sacrifices and respect for the struggles of our ancestors for the alliance of twenty-eight peoples of mutual compromises. Prime Minister of all Greeks, the double mandate you have is one: to change Greece and Europe but only from within, from the core of the eurozone. You have the support of all parties and the alibi to go beyond your party duty in the national interest, without delay and dangerous game theories. Close the accounts with the past, because Europe is changing in practice. With Juncker's 35 billion aid package and our allies for growth in Greece within the euro, in the fight against austerity, so that we do not isolate ourselves and fall from the clutches of the IMF into the teeth of the drachma speculators. No one has the right to risk that. Colleagues, the European family shows solidarity, forgives and does not avenge. She's protecting her children. He protects them in the rough. Alexis, we have friends and competitors in here. Only together can we stand against our enemies, our common enemies for our common future, because Greece is a democracy but it is also a Europe.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am deeply sorry for the Greek people. They have been ill-served by a corrupt political class who spent too much and borrowed too much for far too long. Not only did Greece fiddle its economic statistics in order to join the euro, but the other states knew they were a fiction. Greece was allowed to join the euro because it was always a political, rather than an economic, project. Sad to say, the euro is not working. Nor are millions of young people in Greece and across Europe. I am not surprised that the Greek people voted ‘no’ to reject further austerity. Further tax rises now are insane. I would have voted ‘no’ as well. But if I were a taxpayer in a eurozone country, I would also vote ‘no’ to giving Greece any more money. Greece is bankrupt, and it would be best if the eurozone states admitted this to their taxpayers. Mr Tsipras, your behaviour suggests you know Greece has to leave the euro, but you do not want to admit it. You are waiting to be kicked out so you can play the martyr. I recommend you negotiate an orderly exit from the euro, which is the best chance Greece has of recovering.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Weber said that democracy is knowing how to listen. He's right. May you, Mr Weber, listen, I hope you will be able to listen, Mr Juncker, to what the Greeks said in last Sunday's referendum. I would like to thank the Greek people, their Government and their Prime Minister from this House for raising the flag of Europe better than anyone in recent months. Europe is not being destroyed because there are citizens who say in a referendum that they do not agree with the adjustment policies promoted by the Troika and the International Monetary Fund. Europe is not being destroyed because there are governments that have the audacity to ask their people what they think. What is destroying Europe is financial totalitarianism. What destroys Europe is the arrogance of the German government. What destroys Europe is the inability of certain rulers to defend their peoples. I appeal again, in this House, to the socialist family. Take the step. Stand up to the social rights-defending side and abandon, at once, that damn grand coalition that's bringing us to disaster. To defend the Greek people and their Government today is to defend the dignity of Europe. And rest a day, Alexis, that times are changing. 2015 is the year of change and very soon we will be stronger.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Prime Minister, thank you for opening a door to the hope of the peoples of Europe; thank you for resisting the blackmail of the Troika's "austeritarian" programmes, which have sunk so many lives in our beloved Europe; thank you for resisting the permanent blackmail of the European Central Bank to the Greek people and their Prime Minister; Thank you so much. Heads of State and Government, these are crucial times for Europe. Cease your efforts to continue in Greece with the same thing that has failed for years, and offer a fair agreement for Greece, a rational fiscal path, an investment program that allows the Greek economy, sunk over all these years, to recover. Support the reforms proposed by the Greek Government, which is proposing them. Tackle the issue of debt with height of sight and realism, and stop threatening grexit, gentlemen of the right, because, if Greece is expelled, it is the European project that you are putting at risk, and your attitude in this House today has been totally irresponsible and it is a real shame.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Prime Minister Tsipras, I am bowing to you, you have allowed the people of Greece to make democratic decisions and people have said that they do not want a dictation of the European Union that is clearly harmful to them. If I were Greek, I'd vote the same way you do. But now it is the turn of other politicians in other countries to let their voters decide democratically. Mr Schulz, Mr Weber, Mr Verhofstadt, ask people in Germany, Finland, Slovakia if they want to send more taxpayers' money to Greece. I think then you'll have to swallow the bitter pill that the euro itself is ending.  Mr Tsipras, I wish that the transition to the drachma would be smooth, and then you will see that you will regain competitiveness, that the economy will grow again and that people will start to find work again.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to say a word in the direction of the Bureau in advance: I find it unacceptable that people such as Weber or Verhofstadt – including in the direction of my political grouping – are talking about extremism here. The opposite is true. If anyone stands up for patriotism, freedom, sovereignty and democracy, that is not extremism. I also expect the Bureau to intervene in such outrageous allegations. Speaking to Mr Tsipras, I am also representing a country that has helped you with up to EUR 9 billion. I miss the commitment from your side that you also want to repay this money. It is a matter of honor and decency to repay your debts.  I know that this year's aid has not brought the money into your population. They are also unhappy in this situation, and there can only be one conclusion. If you want to implement your Marxist model in Greece, do it. But do it with the money of the Greek billionaires and the shipowners, but not with the money of European taxpayers. Their only way to make yourself fit for the future is: get out of the euro, into the drachma. Attract yourself, do your homework, and if you are economically fit to return and meet all the requirements, then you are welcome

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Madam President, both the European Union and all its institutions and the SYRIZA-ANEL government with provocative blackmail are seeking to accept the Greek people, who have already gone bankrupt, the new very harsh measures that you are striking against, either by agreement-third memorandum or by Grexit, and again they will pay the unaffordable bill. The agreement of all parties serving the capital in Greece aims to keep the people imprisoned in the impoverishment of the lasting memoranda.  No such authorization has been given to you by the people. The Communist Party condemns the new unpopular attack and opposes it. In practice it turns out that there is no pro-grassroots negotiation or solution within the European Union, within the capitalist path of development, which has only the criterion of the profitability of capital.  The only way out is that of organizing, of fighting for a break with the European Union, with capital, because the people can truly find themselves in power, owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE).
text: Madam President, the truth has too often been hidden from the Greek people. Greece is in trouble, it is very bad. Its underground economy has become completely commonplace and the level of its debt is unsustainable.  But no more playing, Mr Tsipras, we have to tell the truth! You did not want to trust President Juncker who, with great humanity, has continued to reach out to the Greeks. It is not austerity that is being asked of you, but simply to put your country in order. Ideology has no place at the negotiating table. The dialogue must not be broken, but it must be realistic. You want to play the big democrats, but there are democrats in every other member state of the eurozone, and the citizens no longer want to fund Greece at a loss.  What can we say to the Spaniards, the Portuguese, the Irish and the Latvians, who have never accused Europe of all their ills, but who have made their reforms and who today can finally reap the fruits of their efforts? What can we say to European citizens who are even poorer than the Greeks? They don't want to pay for Greek laxity anymore.  It is not Europe, it is not the creditors who will decide whether or not Greece leaves the eurozone. It is Greece itself that will de facto be outside the eurozone if it does not agree to the necessary reforms. Your referendum, Mr Tsipras, was a sham, and once again you did not tell the truth. Your government today is deadlocked, know that European solidarity is not unilateral, it has counterparties, we are waiting for your concrete proposals, reasonable to reduce your public deficit, to fight corruption, against privileges, against tax evasion. You now have an obligation to achieve results, yes Greece has its place in the European Union but stop playing with fire. Europe will not be your scapegoat indefinitely.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Madam President, Prime Minister, it is very important that you are here today, near the end of the road. The road that began in January, when the Greek people punished those who catastrophically managed the crisis and humiliated their four-year terms; the road to ending a viable agreement that would allow the country to rebuild within the Union.  We knew that on the way to the agreement you would have forces that would probably use Greece to give the message that austerity, even without growth, is the only way forward. We knew it, so you know it. Now we get to five.  Unfortunately, as President Hollande said,"Greece's stay not only in the eurozone but probably also in the European Union depends on the proposals you will submit on Thursday". And the voices that want to punish our country have become very powerful at your own risk. The referendum in the time that took place, with the question asked and with the rhetoric that came with it was wrong and, instead of strengthening the negotiating effort, weakened it. At this last moment I have nothing more to do but appeal: Ask for help from all the European leaders who support the country's stay in the Union. Ask for technical assistance. Present the best you can, because there is no tomorrow and remember: The mandate of the Greek people is to keep the country in the euro and the Union. You promised you'd do it before the referendum. You're committed. There's no excuse for the rough road. And beware: If we end up in Grexit and the misery of the people, history and citizens will not judge that you have made mistakes and omissions, but that you have implemented your plan to drag the country into the adventure of isolation. Disprove them. For the first time you will be judged not by words but by the result of your thies.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President of the Council, I am sure that Jens Stoltenberg was referring to the security of the Lord and my region and the situation in Ukraine. I don't believe he's silent. And now about Greece. The euro area has been and is a political project and solved the dramatic situation of one of the members of the euro area also requires a political solution. There are no innocent parties in this case, neither in Greece nor else, so the language of aggression, provocation, paternalism is not and does not fit the allies. Greek society has repeatedly demonstrated its ability to make sacrifices in history, but it does not want to sacrifice its own dignity, and we should also respect that.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, what we see in the overwhelming majority of the faces here is the image of defeat. Contempt for democracy, blackmail, pressure and threats were defeated by the Greek people. The alliance of arrogance and fear, which they try to impose on the peoples of Europe, has suffered a heavy defeat.  Yes, the Greek people have vigorously rejected the dictates and impositions of the European Union and those who command it. And, yes, this was a heavy defeat for the European Union and for those who command it.  From here we tell you, you have tried everything and you will try everything, but from here we tell you, the political terrorism to which you are dedicated only demonstrates your weakness. What the reality shows us is that the instruments of domination of the European Union, from the euro to the Budgetary Treaty, are contrary to the development, progress and sovereignty of peoples. What reality and history show us is that it is the path of resistance and struggle, not that of submission and subordination, that which defends the rights and interests of peoples.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister Tsipras, an abraada des de Catalunya per a Gracia i per a cada dels grecs i de les gregues. For a few months we have lived with a repeated image to the full: Greece is a problem for Europe. Since last Sunday we know that Greece has been a hope for Europe, despite the petty and anti-European attitude of Mr Weber and his People's Group, working towards the division and confrontation between countries; despite Mr Tsipras' demands that he do in forty-eight hours all that was not required of the Greek governments of the last twenty years; despite the negative consequences of blind monetarism, which prevailed at the time of the creation of the euro area. If Europe drops Greece, it will cease to be Europe to become a society of limited unspeakable interest. Financing, real growth, debt restructuring, reforms: four areas of immediate and demanding decision-making, four issues for the active and committed involvement of the European Union. Next Sunday is the historical starting point for a new stage of construction in common; reconstruction, if preferred, for Greece; affirming a new horizon for Europe and for all Europeans. Mr Tsipras, Mr Juncker, Mr Tusk, from today until Sunday we will work to deny Mr Weber, Mr Farage or Mrs Le Pen, to win together, to build a Europe of peoples and citizens in which so many of us continue to believe.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for This must probably be described as the greatest failure in the history of the European Union, and the series of failures is infinitely long.  In the case of Greece, the state of the economy was fratted, and the EU did not even properly review it. If the EU had been a private company, it would have been put under compulsory administration a long time ago because of the completely irresponsible way in which taxpayers' money is handled. It is tragic, what has happened, and the big losers will be the Greek people and taxpayers in all the Member States who will foot the bill. And now you are sitting here, the European elite, booing at the outcome of a democratic referendum by the Greek people, and you call yourself the representative of democracy. You would be ashamed of your behavior! Greece now manages large sums of money from several of our Member States and banks. The loans must, of course, be repaid from Greece just as any private individual has to. I expect that a solution will be found by the parties involved.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tsipras, you said that aid has not reached the people. So where is the money given to you by the Spanish retirees, workers and families? When you came to government, Greece's growth forecast of 2.5% of GDP. Now Greece is in recession. What then have the more than EUR 200 billion that the European people, which European citizens, have lent to the Greek people, served for? Spain has lent you 6 billion euros that you did not have, that you had to borrow, and 20 billion euros more in guarantees, which, if you do not pay what you owe, will have to pay for you spanish workers and the Spanish middle class with their taxes. Do you think that is fair, after what you have said here about European solidarity and where the aid given by the European Union has gone? It will seem normal to you, and it seems to me, that European public opinion is beginning to wonder what all this effort has served for, and I certainly assure you that it will seem normal to you, and I think it is normal for European public opinion to find it unfair for workers across Europe to pay for their mistakes and the mistakes of Greek politicians. Mr. Tsipras, now you're going to ask for a new ransom. How would you like any country that is going to lend money back to Greece to hold a referendum on its territory on whether to give more money or not to give more money to Greece? Do you think that would be democracy or do you think that would be just sovereignty? What opinion of Europe do you have, which comes here with little but words and the enthusiasm of the far left and the enthusiasm of the far right? Mr Tsipras, Europe, the European nation, is a dream of unity, peace and solidarity. It is a dream from which no one should ever be expelled, but also in which no one has to do to expel or to divide others. When we need help, Europe gives it to us. When we want to help, we Europeans are here to do it. Europe is a project based, Mr Tsipras, on good faith. How long are you going to abuse our good faith, Mr. Tsipras?

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a Grexit would be a very severe blow to the European Union, not only financially and geopolitically, but also ethically, politically and morally. This is the time for the union's ruling classes to show a stature equal to their predecessors who have been statesmen and to look beyond the contingency and belly of their electorates.  The starting point is the facts. Firstly, the ESA was built to safeguard the stability of the euro area and is full of resources – it gets resources, among other things, at very low interest rates – so no European citizen will have to pay a euro and you, Mr Weber, would do well to tell the truth and not excite fears. Secondly, the EMS operates on the basis of conditionality, so we need serious agreement on reforms. Everyone here wants to suggest their recipes: but it would be good to remember – and you should remember this first, instead of just talking about the referendum – that on 30 June you personally signed a letter accepting the detailed list of measures proposed by creditors and meritoiously published by the Commission on its website. The five amendments proposed by Greece clearly cannot now be the end of the negotiations and, therefore, it is urgent that you present new additional proposals immediately.  At the same time, it is good to know that there is already agreement on the basic conditions of the new programme and the differences would not clearly justify a Grexit and a European ruling class worthy of its name would certainly be able, with the political will, to bridge the gap that currently exists between the Commission's proposal and the five amendments. Otherwise, we will all take on a very serious historical responsibility, including you, of course.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Much has been said here about European values, about truth, about dignity, about democracy. But there was also a lot of hypocrisy. The leader of the Christian Democrat Group has said that Mr Tsipras has not told his people the truth. But what did the Christian Democrats do when they promised the German people that they would never have to stand up for foreign debts? Was that the truth, Mr Weber? The leader of the Socialist Group has said – to great applause from the House – that there will never be a Grexit. Yes, has it not always been said that our aid is only granted under conditions? If it is said that there will never be a Grexit, it means that there will always be help: that is, nothing is with conditions. Grexit will definitely be prevented, and the money will definitely flow. That is the truth, ladies and gentlemen. The leader of the Liberal Group has also spoken out in favour of democracy. At the same time, he dictates to the Greek prime minister five points in his notepad on how to govern. This is not democracy! Democracy is the rule of the people, and if the Greek people have decided, then, ladies and gentlemen, then we must also accept that decision.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, the brave and dignified Greek people asserted the primacy of democracy over the technocratic and neoliberal order in Europe. During, before and since Sunday’s decisive vote, your government upheld its democratic anti-austerity mandate whilst trying to seek agreement with European partners. However, creditors are inflicting poverty and deprivation on Greece, refusing debt relief and investment. Even the IMF, which is not a friend of the Left, confirms that Greece needs debt relief. Despite hostility and interference from President Martin Schulz, who has behaved like a self-appointed dictator, or the cowardly behaviour from a sturdy poster boy of the EU, Irish Taoiseach Enda Kenny, the Greek Government has stood up for Greece, stood up for Ireland,  stood up for Spain, for Portugal for Europe, more than any government has ever done. Irish people from Kerry to Derry stand with you. Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras, you used the most powerful weapon in the world – democracy – and it won before the first vote was cast. We are proud of who you are and the policies that you represent. (Applause from GUE/NGL party)

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Even more than the excitement in this debate, in which, unfortunately, Mr Weber has been particularly negative, I believe that President Tusk's calm speech at the outset made the serious situation clear. We are facing a fundamental course. Too much has been said to me in this debate about what who said 'no' to, for what good reasons. If we cannot agree on what we want to say 'yes' to together, there is no way forward. Europe must say yes to debt relief for Greece, and Greece must say yes to large-scale reforms by common and concrete name. Much of the european idea in general does not help. The truth is concrete: Hic Rhodus, nunc salta!

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start from what Mr Juncker said yesterday in this House: the Greeks and Greece can count on the European Union. I would like to thank the President for these words, which express the feeling of this House. However, you see, Mr Tsipras, once again you have come here and said nothing concrete: only so many words that, in theory, are also acceptable but we need concreteness.  You say: I have only been in government for five months. Well, let's look at some concrete data: Greece's largest industry, tourism, which last year recorded record figures of 22 million visitors, 13.4 billion receipts, with an increase of 23% and 10.6% respectively for a total of 17% of GDP. Today cancellations travel at a rate of fifty thousand per day. In Italy, we too have calculated that every citizen has put EUR 600 out of his own pocket. Well, we have always been convinced that, in order to defeat unemployment and to bring Europe back to growth, we must put the revival of industry, small and medium-sized enterprises back at the centre of economic policy; that we must encourage new investment and the development of the capital market, facilitate access to credit and that, in order to reform these policies and to pursue the objective of 20% of European GDP by 2020 from manufacturing, we also need to achieve concrete tax harmonisation. But, you see, it is because we believe in all this that we do not support its economic policy today, because it is harming the Greek people and is, as a result, damaging the whole of the European Union. Let's go back around a table. Let us come back with concrete proposals. Let's find the solution together. Our citizens are asking for this. Your citizens, the Greeks, are asking for it first. Someone said we're in the theater. If we were really in the theatre, you would be a tragic example of Hybris only that you would not pay for it: the Greek people, the citizens of Europe, are paying for it and will continue to pay for it more and more if you do not change your pace and come here with concrete proposals. Together the way, we find it!

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D). Mr President, the greatest challenge for Europe is to convince its citizens that they care for their well-being. Today a key predictor of how a young person will evolve in his life is the financial performance of his parents. The crisis made the right to progress seem hereditary. So the popular mandate of the last European elections is for this Europe to change, for the policies of harsh austerity to be taken to the sidelines. But what is at the same time the popular mandate that the Greek government has? It is simply a fair deal within the euro area, a deal that will vindicate the Greeks who are struggling to pay their taxes, the Greeks who left their money to the Greek banks, those who are struggling to keep our country upright and not of course those who made the money abroad waiting for the collapse to buy us for free; not those who have learned to profit with public money and are afraid of European rules.  Colleagues, let us end the blame game that the Greek people pay dearly. Respect the sacrifices of the weakest Greek citizens over the past five years. Finally, I would like to condemn the booing of certain Members of the European Parliament towards the Greek Prime Minister. But you too, Prime Minister, in the face of the great decisions you have to make, should reflect on the fact that today you were applauded by the worst enemies of the European vision and finally never forget that the euro for Greece is not an economic choice but is a national choice.

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: Mr Tsipras, nationalism and patriotism are concepts that offer people security, a warm nest, a home. But at the same time, this requires openness and an international view, otherwise you will fall into protectionism and navel-gaing. I note that the Socialists in Europe have become very narrow nationalists, because everything that comes from Greece and Syriza is apparently defended. But that international view is lacking, because everything that comes from the European institutions is apparently bad. The Greeks want to choose their own recipes. Frankly, I understand and respect that. But, Mr Tsipras, where is your openness? Where is your international view? You claim that you want to stay in the eurozone. Prove that to us, too. Are you prepared to take your share of the tough reforms to get the Greek economy back on track, or do you just want to get out? The opportunity is yours to put the evidence on the table today and in the coming days.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first I would like to confront Mr Pittella and Mr Gualtieri. The pair of them criticised our leader, Mr Weber. But I would like to know if their statements are in line with those of Mr Schulz, Mr Dijsselbloem or even Prime Minister Renzi last weekend. They completely contradict everything that we have said here. Now, Prime Minister Tsipras, I would like to ask you five or six precise questions, because I know that you like rhetoric and philosophy but not precise proposals and not concrete questions. Why have you extended the negotiations to the edge, to the limit? Why have you held a referendum only now? If you wanted to have a referendum, you were completely free to do so. Why did you not do it before? We would have had time to negotiate after that. Why have you not reduced and changed the fiscal system? Why have you not taxed ship owners, the Orthodox Church, or the rich? You have had six months to do so, and you have not done it until now. Why have you let all the capital leave Athens and Greece? Now your banks are in this situation, but it was your policies and your rhetoric that made the Greeks take their money out of Greek banks. You did not create trust in your own country. I would also ask you why you did not reduce expenditure on the military, the army and defence: that would also be an alternative to resolve your problems. Finally, I would ask you this: you are totally sovereign in the definition of your external policy, but when you are allied with right-wing radicals, and when you visit Putin every month, you are sending a signal to the markets and you are sending a signal to the pro-European camp and the European Union. You are responsible for the signals you are sending to us.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we Socialists and Democrats are among those who do not resign themselves to throwing in the towel, with an expression that we use in Italy to say who wants to give up; we are among those who – as Mr Pittella said very well – feel the historical responsibility of the moment. However, the responsibility lies not only with the Council, the Commission and the creditors: greece is also responsible and it is also greece's responsibility, President Tsipras, towards its people and towards all the other peoples of the countries of the Union. So you must take a clear position: if you do not want to give a very precise, very precise alibi to those who are pursuing Grexit. If the proposed package was not socially sustainable, and we are sensitive to this observation, then finally say a reasonable proposal. It is not a challenge that we do to her, it is a heartfelt request. Give irrefutable, unequivocal proof that you want to find a concrete solution. Escape the doubts that still remain, even among his friends, as to what his real intentions are ultimately. It's not just Greece that's at stake. Europe is at stake, as the Italian Prime Minister said, and if Europe has lost its order of priorities, if it has changed its ends with procedures, if it has lost its right to be, if it has weakened the democratic foundations, it is not by chance. If we have come this far – and I say this to my fellow Members of this House – it is because unity has not been completed, integration has sobbed and political strength has been called into question by national or even nationalistic regurgits, as we see in this Parliament. And they do not help bilateral summits in this regard. So what can we expect of a Europe to which we have not given the necessary sovereignty? I say this with the strength of a group which, in recent years, has repeatedly called for a change in economic policy, social policy, political and institutional strengthening of the institutions, and we have often been left alone.  I say this to my fellow Members who call themselves and are pro-European. I challenge you to resume this programme and to strengthen and re-reflect together Europe's challenge.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I have the impression that there is a game going on here about who will be responsible for the wrong decision, not the search for a compromise. I, like Mr Olbrycht, believe that it was a mistake to invite Prime Minister Cipras. The European Parliament controls the European institutions, not the Greek Government.  The European Union needs two things: stability and flexibility. Either a quick compromise or a Greek exit. The Drachma will stabilise the Union, allow us to live without the burdens of this Greek drama. There are non-euro area European countries that are stabilising Europe, like Poland, like Sweden, so there will be no drama if the Greeks leave the eurozone. We also need flexibility, less paternalism. Europe must also see interests other than those of the North. Many bad decisions have been made: decarbonisation, centralist immigration policy, these are the bad fruits of centralism. Stability and flexibility are the answer to Europe's needs.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, to the Council: I share Jean-Claude Juncker's disappointment at the lack of European solidarity and common political will to come to a binding sharing key for the people fleeing to the EU. It is a disgrace how we, as a community of rights and values, are behaving in the face of the largest wave of refugees in decades.  Now to the subject that has been going on for us all the time: up to now, I have believed that European fundamental rights unite us despite our diversity. Anyone who violates European values weakens the unification process. The European Union is more than the sum of national egoisms. The EU is a community of values and the rule of law. Mr Weber has only recalled this. The reactions show how necessary this was. Without action as a community of solidarity, Greece would have long been insolvent. Mr Tsipras, you have disappointed us today. You have squandered another opportunity today, as you have done since you took office. Even today, we do not know what you want. Even today, we have not heard a single concrete proposal on how to combat corruption, how to increase tax revenues, how to make administration more efficient, how to prevent the humanitarian disaster, how to create growth and employment.  You now have only forty-eight hours left. Finally, start working and taking responsibility. Stop pitting the peoples against each other. Quit your game. I have the impression that you do not want to.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
