text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Tsipras, you said that you do not want a confrontation with Europe, that you want a confrontation with the establishment at home, in Greece. There is now only one way left. You have to say very specifically – within a few hours – what that means.  Firstly, how does tax justice come into the country? Secondly, how is poverty combated? Thirdly, how do we have a decent administration again, and how will we ensure that the tanker kings pay taxes again? We know very well that the weak shoulders in your country have worn everything and the strong shoulders have actually carried nothing. If you do this in concrete terms, there will be a wave of sympathy in Europe that will accompany you. But you have to do it in concrete terms, and you must stop talking about wanting it, but you have to do it. That is the order of the day, and you do not owe it to us, but to the young people in your country, who continue to need a safe place in Europe. The second point, Mr Tusk, goes to you, to the Heads of State or Government and to the finance ministers of the euro area: we expect something from you. It must stop the game of wanting to set an example. Solutions must be found! (Applause) And you don't need much. They need 50 percent of courage, 50 percent of prudence and 50 percent of the European commitment that the President of the European Commission has shown in recent weeks. You don't need more, you two! But you must bring this in the interests of Europe, in the interests of the people of our countries. (Applause)

name: Николай Бареков (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Mr Tsipras, I speak to you as a friend and only neighbour from an even poorer country – Bulgaria, which has not spent 300 billion. The parties are fighting federalism today, and the rest on you, Mr. Tsipras. It's not your fault. The genesis of the problem is the irresponsibility of Eurobureaucrats and the Greek political class. Bringing an unprepared Greece into the eurozone is a crime for the Greek people and European taxpayers. Mr Tsipras joked with Merkel on "cat and mouse," but soon the cat will eat the mouse. Today you came humble because the Greek house burned down and someone will have to put out the fire with a lot of money. Now you will simply leave the extinguishing in the hands of Europe.  But who will pay for the Greek experiment? Not the euro zone, but the European Union is doomed, without profound reform. Colleagues, Mr Juncker, do not forget about the poorest European citizens - in Bulgaria, with even heavier savings than the Greek poor and pensioners. They will be the most innocent victims of greek bankruptcy.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Mr President, we must all prevent Grexit together, because a Grexit means a 25% fall in gross domestic product, it means that the poor will become poorer in Greece and the rich richer and it means that Greece will return to Balkan chaos. So we must do what all Greek politicians and first of all the Prime Minister of Greece, Mr. Tsipras, can do. I understand that Mr. Tsipras has a problem with reducing public spending, he has a problem with reducing the costs of the insurance pension system, but we cannot destroy the country by giving pensions to people who have worked only fifteen years, accepting that already many categories of civil servants can retire at fifty-two or by continuing the appointments of relatives and friends in the bankrupt public sector. , a tradition that was not created by Mr. Tsipras's party was created by my own party, but we must finally leave it behind. If Mr Tsipras makes a shift towards economic realism and in favour of the European Union, we will support him vigorously and I also think that Mr Juncker should support him with a brave investment programme, because for at least two to three years Greece cannot operate on market criteria, it cannot attract investment, because it has a huge problem. So let the Greek Prime Minister dare and see that things are less difficult than he thinks. We will protect him even from the left wing of his party, which may object to this policy. If Mr Tsipras dares, I think we will disappoint the fake friends of Greece who have emerged today from the far-right wing and give the right answer to the opponents of the European Union. All of us Greek politicians must assume our responsibilities. We must stop hiding behind the Greek people.

name: Elisa Ferreira (S&D).
text: – Mr President, by Sunday, Europe has to make historic decisions, it has to decide whether it has a future or dies in Greece. We have persisted for five years on an agenda that does not work. And it doesn't work, Mr. Weber, because you can't pay off debts with economies in forced recession, and in austerity there are no success stories.  In the eyes of the world and in the eyes of citizens, the European Union is disaggregated because Europe apparently cannot solve a problem worth little more or little less than 2 % of its wealth. Is this the image that Europe gives in a world that looks at it at all times?  But solving greece's problem is not a technical issue – technical solutions are there. It is a matter of political will, in a common agenda which also includes filling gaps identified in the architecture of monetary union, such as joint management of at least sovereign debt. It is a political issue and it is a matter of method and trust. And on the method, President Tusk, I would like to ask you if you think it is possible to find solutions between the different legitimacies of different parliaments – did we not find a solution to this problem in 1957? The solution was the Community method. That is the element that is missing in this agenda, and that is why you have to turn to the Commission and to this Parliament to help you solve the problem. The second issue is the issue of trust, and on that, Mr Tsipras, I do not blame you for what was done five years ago or over the last five years, because you have only been there for five weeks. Mr Tsipras, I am talking to you! You have been accused in this Parliament of having developed a hidden agenda to get Greece out of the euro without being blamed for it. Can you assure this Parliament that you will do whatever it takes to make the Greek economy viable in order to remain in the euro? This is a crucial question for trust. (Applause)

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – Greece cheated with figures at the entrance into the euro area, and in the budget deficits in 2010. Now this Trojan horse is thundering through the eurozone, to the horror and despair of many. Reckless European banks began to finance the irresponsible lending behaviour of the Greeks. Because those banks knew: if things go wrong, the ECB is our safety net. Greece must now put the household book in order and reform its economy. But how? The country is already bankrupt, with a national debt of 180 percent of gross national product. Since the dictates of the Treaty of Versailles we know: you can't pick a bald chicken. It took us a second world war to understand that and, in fact, after that war, Germany, of all people, got the widest debt forgiveness ever. Are we stupid enough to make that mistake again and start picking a bald Greek chicken? No, no, no, no Greece only has a future with a partial debt and its own currency. By the way, I believe, Mr President, that you should not have interfered in the yes campaign in Greece.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: Despite all the enthusiasm in this House, this debate is particularly sad. I think it should be an eye opener – or I hope it is – for the Greek Prime Minister when he sees that his biggest fans, except in his own constituencies, are particularly on the far-right side of this House. That side that has said from the beginning: we want to destroy european cooperation. Three quarters of this House, despite the political differences, does not want the EU or the euro area to fall apart. Three-quarters of this House does not want a Greek departure. We did not walk away from the negotiating table and your greatest friend at the moment, no matter how you portray him at home, is sitting there. (speaker points to Commission President Juncker) Time and again, the chairman of the committee tried to reach an agreement. Unlike the S&D, which apparently issued a blank cheque today, the EPP does attach conditions to a potential agreement with your country. There are also 18 other democracies in the euro area. They must also be respected. We want concrete proposals. I therefore regret that in your story I have not heard the word competitiveness – because that is what it is all about – once. I do not think these two conditions are too much to ask. The time for games is now over. The time for game theory is now over. It's time to put the cards on the table and show you what you want. The reason Why I am so sad is that I think from your behaviour today that you do not want an agreement at all. Poor Greece, poor Europe, which will have to bear the consequences of that.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D).
text: – Mr President, for the past five years the Greek people have suffered. They have been subject to austerity measures that have led to mass unemployment, with over 50% of young people out of work. Families have struggled to feed their children, unable to pay their rent: to think that we are talking about a country which is proudly known as the cradle of democracy. It is unbelievable, yet still it goes on and on and on. Is this predicament the fault of the Greek people? Of course not – but still they struggle. They have been asked to choose between a future of further suffering, or a journey into the abyss. They look one way and see people who only care about austerity. In the other direction there are only those who preach irresponsibility. They have been failed by successive governments, including this one, and an EU too entrenched in the dogma of austerity. So what happens now? Please put your egos aside, all of you, and provide a solution now – a solution that does not let down the Greek people. No more brinkmanship, no more games. This is about the future of the Greek people. For God’s sake, please give them some hope. (Applause from Group)

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – The story "Greece 2015" has a series of faces and more interpretations. In my humble opinion, this is about the extreme left government resurrecting the old paradigm, the premodern economic and political culture and practice expressed in life at a foreign expense and subsequent generations. The Greek Government wants to introduce socialism co-financed by European taxpayers. In a world of normal culture, things are set differently, because responsibility and ethics are embedded in the way of business and political life. Personal and social well-being depends on work achievements. The Greek Government imagines solidarity one-way. I ask whether it is fair that my Slovenia had to devote eur 1.7 billion to Greece in loans and guarantees, which is the highest per capita in the European Union. How can we persuade the Slovenian taxpayer to continue to fund someone who has a higher standard and who demands debt relief? Dear! Siriza took over the running of the country five months ago with good shape and 2.6% projected economic growth. In just five months, the party has destroyed the efforts of previous governments and re-launched the country into recession. It is up to the Greek Government to put forward a new and economically sensible proposal, which must include reforms that will improve the economic environment, so that Greece can finally become able to make a living on its own.  But frankly, I doubt this will happen, because Mr Cipras's government shows no desire to agree. Besides, she's lost confidence. At least two credible negotiators are required to be successful.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, I thank you for saying here that we are all responsible for the crisis and that it is together that we must find the solution. Mr Tsipras, thank you for being here, where the heart of European democracy is beating. You carry a strong message, born of a double legitimacy against austerity. Your adversaries today are obliged to recognize how gnawed your country is by the turpitude of the behaviours of the governments that preceded you and which must now be confronted together.  Here you are demonstrating that the Community method is perhaps the way to overcome certain national selfishness and to rediscover what is the heart of Europe, namely solidarity. It is she who must enable us to take the last steps, those who must lead us to this honourable compromise, to which you have said you aspire. It is it that must enable us to find this comprehensive, sustainable and reliable agreement. It is the one that should allow us to deal honestly with the issue of debt, which everyone here knows is untenable and which is one of those subjects that we are too inclined to put under the carpet. It is the one that should enable us to mobilise all Europeans so that you can lead the battle of tax evasion with countries outside the European Union.  So, Mr Tsipras, we are waiting for you. We are at your disposal and I hope that today's debate will have given you some inspiration to feed the concrete proposals that you need to put on the table and that we are waiting for. Good luck! (Applause)

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom fáilte a chur roimh Phríomh-Aire na Gréige go Parlaimint na hEorpa. I come from Ireland, and the Irish people – like most people in Europe – want to see Greece remaining within the euro and within the European Union. The question is: does Mr Tsipras and his government want that? I think we should know the answer as soon as possible if that is ideologically against their wishes. Secondly, I want to say that I listened carefully to Mr Tsipras. He spoke about corruption, tax evasion and inequalities in Greek society. What has he done to address that in the past six months, and what will he do to address those failings in the next six or 12 months? As I said, I am from Ireland. Six years ago we were in a similar position to Greece. We were regarded as the basket case of Europe, but with good leadership, taking the decisions that were necessary and engaging with our partners in Europe, we negotiated our way out of the difficulties. Was it hard? Boy, was it hard. People lost their houses; people lost their savings; people lost their jobs; people lost their children to immigration. But now, thankfully, because we took the hard medicine, we have the fastest-growing economy in Europe, at 4.8%. That is because of good leadership. I say to Mr Tsipras: leadership is about giving leadership and taking the hard decisions, not going around Europe giving interviews to every newspaper, television station and radio station, as we have seen. I would suggest to him that he go back to Greece, bring his colleagues together for two days and come up with a sensible reform package. He will not be found wanting in meeting them more than half way.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my first words I would like you to be to send a message of solidarity to the Greek people. Let us not forget that this debate and the shared effort of those of us here should focus on them, those who have been suffering from the wrong policy, and those of us who cannot turn our backs today. But it is also time to appeal to the coherence of all parties in order to find a fair agreement. We are in one of the most delicate moments of the Union and, therefore, you must set aside the particular and partisan interests, the excessive egos, and also set aside the desire to make this a story of victors and vanquished. Here we are not creditors and debtors, here we are European partners. And if we do not act as such, we will be jeopardizing the Union project. Greece is the example of misguided and failed policies, because neither ultra-strong austerity was the solution nor the passivity of the Greek authorities the solution and the contribution to changing this scenario. But there's no time to waste on reproaches. It's time to look to the future and put on the table proposals that will serve to get out. We need, on the part of European partners, a willingness to dialogue, greater flexibility, growth stimulus and debt solutions. And, on the part of the Greek Government, a plan of credible reforms that give solvency to the country. There is still room for agreement with fair solutions, and it is your responsibility to find it. Don't make us feel ashamed of the historic moment we're experiencing.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr There is one person in Europe who has more responsibility for what is now happening in Greece than anyone else, and he sits here in place 23, Alexis Tsipras, Prime Minister of Greece. He has not taken responsibility in one word for what is happening today in Greece. Your government took over an economy in crisis, but also in economic upswing. That could have been the euro area's highest growth. In five months you have reversed that trend and we are seeing the result: closed bank branches, shrinking tax revenues, the flight of entrepreneurship, a closed economy. Mr Tsipras, do you have no responsibility for what has happened under your political leadership? You have not said in a word in this House what you want to do to reverse Greece's development, yet you see here representatives of a wide range of countries that have been in deep crisis. But what has characterized their leadership is that they have not fled responsibility. They have taken responsibility, implemented the reforms, ensured that growth is up and running and have ensured that confidence in the future is realised. You're running away from responsibility and saying it's other people's fault. Those who want to lead a country must take responsibility for it and ensure that Greece can be proud. You have not made Greece proud here today. You have not given Greece more opportunities. Think again and take responsibility for Greece!

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The ideological trench warfare and populism must now stop immediately. No matter who governs, it must be all about the well-being of all European citizens. Undoubtedly, serious mistakes have been made on all sides, and there is no doubt that Greece must undertake structural reforms. But creativity must also go far beyond austerity and austerity policies. It is hard to believe that in Greece the churches, or even the rich shipowners, are still not involved in the financing. The system is unfair. It is also a fairy tale that nothing has been done yet, as incomes have fallen by a third since 2008. Meanwhile, one in three households in Greece has to make do with less than EUR 7 000 per year. That's less than 600 euros a month – for families, not for individuals! In terms of labour standards, Greece is on the same level as Qatar. From an economic point of time, none of this made sense – none of these victims. They prevent consumption, public revenues do not increase, and no prospects are created for the Greek economy and for new, good jobs.  It is all the more important now that everyone sits down at the same table, that there is a balanced solution and that we all have solidarity with the Greek citizens here in this House. Greece belongs in the heart of Europe. (Applause)

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to extend my solidarity to the Greek people and equally to Commission President Juncker. The words ‘referendum’ and ‘reform’ sound very similar initially, but they do not mean the same thing. You cannot simply substitute a vote for the urgency of fundamentally reforming your country. Mr Tsipras has not explained why his government, having a strong mandate, was not willing or able to come forward with any concrete reform programme, including cutting the civil service and clamping down on tax evaders. While I have every sympathy for Greek pensioners, Greece spends 17% of GDP on pensions – while Estonia, Ireland and Lithuania each spend less than 8%. We survived and reformed. Equality and solidarity apply equally to all, except in Communist times, when there was the saying ‘some are more equal than the others’. If there is no concrete reform offer in the coming days, the conclusion can only be that Mr Tsipras is not operating simply in the interests of the Greek people, but that he could well be part of a bigger enterprise of rocking the European boat in a typical leftist communist fashion of ‘the worse, the better’.

name: Iliana Iotova (S&D).
text: Mr President, negotiations must continue. That is Parliament's message. The Greek referendum is a catharsis and, from now on, the decision is on the negotiating table and awaiting a compromise. The troika's policy has failed. We Socialists have repeated over the last five years that the policy of austerity leads to bankruptcy. We must move towards a new agreement and we must have a new philosophy: to develop the economy and to give social guarantees to the citizens.  We must show a new Europe to the Greek people and to the citizens of Europe, a Europe that defends their interests. That is our responsibility. The question is not to choose between the euro and the drachma, the question is the future of the European project. We want a Europe that rejects two-speed development. We want a Europe that rejects the double standard and does not divide by the Member States between those in the centre and those on the periphery. We believe in the European project, in solidarity, in the outstretched hand, when it is up to the citizens and not the financial institutions to make decisions.  Reaching an agreement together today will be a powerful signal that we so desperately need in the current situation, where we face enormous challenges: the crisis, the influx of refugees, conflict and terrorism.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, our debate has been, quite normally, on the Greek situation and the euro area. More to the end of the day, we exchanged, we fought on the only two issues that matter. What direction do we want to give the European Union? What do we do together and how do we do it?  I may be the only one to do so, but I would like to go back to the June Council's conclusions on the migration issue. You will see that they generate the same kind of questioning - and this also concerns Greece. In the face of such an acute crisis situation, which affects hundreds of thousands of people, are we able to do a common analysis? Are we able to overcome our national selfishness and are we able to propose solutions? And above all, what common and solidarity political will do we put into it? All Member States agree by the end of July on a distribution of asylum seekers and refugees. Even if the principles seem to have been taken for granted, it is a game of dupes that is played out, since the modalities are in the dark. No mandatory allocation mechanism, no distribution criteria defined by the Commission. The Council wants to experiment with a new concept, that of generosity with variable geometry. At the end of the bill, I'm not sure that this account, and it's a bit sordid, will be good. By this commitment, the Council may be taking a big step, but our Europe is making a very small one, because it is returning to national selfishness, and we know that this attitude is not responsible.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Yes, thank you, Mr President, to tell you that in a debate like this, I think it is entirely appropriate that there should be a catch-the-eye for at least every political group in this House.  At least every group must have one minute: it seems to me fair and fair to everyone and, above all, to the pluralism of this Parliament. Three minutes doesn't change anyone's life.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure. I have countless wishes here for catch-the-eye. However, I can only call five Colleagues. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Tsipras for coming. Thank you for bringing this debate into this House, which I think is the appropriate place to debate something as important as the future of Europe. I think it is up to us to discuss that – not just for the President of Parliament, Mr Schulz, to present his own opinion as if it were the view of this House. The Greek crisis is not just a problem of Greece. It is a European problem, and we can only solve it if we see it as our common endeavour to show to the people of Europe that Europe still offers positive prospects for a better future. Let us handle that future with care. Greece can only overcome the crisis if we offer a fair and viable solution that gives security to the people and space for manoeuvre for the reforms that you have mentioned – reforms, not austerity. The returns from those reforms also needs to stay within the country to give new prosperity to people. They should not be spent on years of debt repayment only; we need to have debt reduction on the table. It is our common future that is at stake. So let us be prepared to go to the table to negotiate for a fair and good deal for Greece and for a common future of all of us.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Mr President, Mr President of the European Commission, Prime Minister of Greece, Greece urgently needs an agreement. An agreement that can even now guarantee financing, emphasise structural changes, facilitate servicing public debt. Greece also needs to immediately restore confidence in the relationship with the partners. You, Prime Minister of Greece, have no mandate to lead the country out of the eurozone. You don't have an order to rupture. Any delay in reaching an agreement leads the real economy deep into chaos. It further increases the pain of the Greeks. It is only here that Farage, Le Pen and your left-wing comrades in Greece recommend a return to the drachma.  I hope you don't follow them. And you, Mr President of the Commission, as the first elected by the citizens, have a duty to exhaust all the room for Greece to stay at home. Mr. Tsipras, I'm pretty sure you won't be the fatal face of history. Mr Juncker, I am almost certain that you are the man who does not think of Europe without the Greeks. Run out of time until Sunday.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, Prime Minister of Greece, welcome. I want you to know that here I have heard many things that have caused me grief, because some are not sincere. Many times they play games communicatively that only the far left or the extreme right supports you. But I want you to know that you will have the support of the great political group of Socialists and Democrats if you take a step and help us strengthen you. Stay in the eurozone by proposing something very specific. And I am now also addressing the President of the European Commission, Mr. Juncker, whose vision for a united Europe is not Europe. That is why, in the name of the values and principles of European culture, I believe that any personal frustrations must be put aside, and we will be with you to support the new Europe.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, my country came out of a military dictatorship in horrible condition. We were an industrial ruin, violence stalked us and we were able to blame others and live exploiting grievance, or understand that much of the solution was in our hands. So we got to work and checked that we actually had the will and ability to get ahead. I believe that the current representatives of Greece and, of course, the previous ones are stuck in the first option. Trust the Greeks, because they know and can. And today the priority is people and there are solutions and willingness to alleviate the humanitarian emergencies that this situation has created. The President of our group has also taken five essential steps to make the transformation they need sustainable. The Greek system was unsustainable without Europe and has the opportunity to reinvent itself with and within our Europe. Our community owes a lot to classical Greek culture, which taught us that nothing can be built against each other. Listen to this message, President Tsipras.

name: Εμμανουήλ Γλέζος (GUE/NGL). –
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I set out the insults against Alexis Tsipras, against the Greek government, against the Greek people. Anyone who swears proves they have no arguments. But I warn all those who dream of kicking Greece out of Europe that they are in a state of futility. Europe, verbally, morphologically, conceptually, is essentially the birth of Greece. We're not giving you Europe. We're not giving you Europe.   (applause) We're not going to solve this in the heat.  It takes a while for us to deal with the solution in cold blood. Let us, we ask, give us a period of time when we will not accept loans, we will not accept to repay loans. We accept, of course, Mr President-in-Office of the Commission. Juncker to help us – this is another matter – and I expect him to do so and we are asking for the law. To triumph over the law. We've been fighting for justice, and we're fighting for justice in here. (applause)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Diogenes the Cynic would come back to life today with a lantern in this House and ask us: where is Europe? Of course, not in the speeches of the austerity hawks, to whom I would remind you that almost all the billions of euros of the bailout have ended up in the pockets of French, German and, to some extent, Italian banks. It is they who have saved, not the poor, the marginalized of Greece, who have deprived you of all dignity. So throw in the mask of hypocrisy. Anyone who is honest with himself knows that there are two ways: either there is the sure, sincere and frank will for a social, fiscal union, without havens, with shared debt but, above all, based on truly transparent and democratic institutions, or this fictitious monetary union must end, but not an economic one, with a euro that has become the end of its denial as an instrument of citizens' well-being. President Tsipras, I and other colleagues of the 5-star Movement, were in Athens on Sunday in Syntagma Square. Your people have given you a message of democracy and hope. Don't be intimidated by bank lobbyists. 'OXI to austerity': we owe it to the Europe of social justice, we owe it to the future of the Mediterranean.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: "Mr. President, I agree that we in this house have no right to tailor Greece by our standards. I also agree that each country can spend its taxpayers' money as it suits it, but it has no right to irresponsibly spend the money of taxpayers of other Member States, especially those who do not have half as good salaries and pensions as they do in Greece. They knew that some loans were almost loanee, but they still accepted them because they didn't want to change their lifestyles.  Imagine now that the citizens of other member states are demanding a referendum in which they say they no longer want to finance Greece. It's also a democracy to which they are entitled. But I believe they won't. I also believe that all relevant parties will sit at the table and finally solve this tapeworm. Stubbornness and spite, no matter which side they come from, are not the answer. Especially when such a solution is almost always broken over the head of ordinary citizens who are least to blame.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I have asked in writing for the floor long before the procedure begins. I understand that the choice is made in some way. Please very much, I would like to know this way. Why didn't you give me the floor?

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I have tried to give the floor to one speaker from one group, in the order in which the wishes have been received and taking into account all the political groups. I thought to you that Mr Glezos should be given preference for reasons which were then visible after his speech.

name: Αλέξης Τσίπρας
text: Prime Minister of Greece. Mr President, I think that this meeting should have taken place some time ago, because the debate we are having here today is not just about the future of Greece, it is about the future of the euro area and indeed this debate cannot take place in closed-door rooms, and it is not our responsibility to do so. For five months the negotiation took place in closed-door rooms, but it is an extremely political question of how it will proceed and where it will end up and how it will end up. We have realised this today from the very fruitful debate here and from the confrontations which did not have a confrontational character of states against states within the euro area but had a profound political and ideological content. I really respect all the views that have been heard, even those that have had a particularly polemic rhetoric. I would also like to say that I fully agree with the view that the European Parliament should play a more active role. I wonder how it is possible that we have authorised three institutions, the troika, and of course the Commission, reasonably the European Central Bank, because it pays, but how can we have authorised within the troika those responsible for taking decisions to be the International Monetary Fund and not to be the preeminent European institution of the Republic, that is, the European Parliament. I'd like to say...  (applause) ... with absolute sincerity: In this European case, if the debate and negotiation had taken place exclusively between the Greek side and the Commission, a solution and agreement would have been found a very long time ago. Unfortunately or fortunately, we had to conduct a negotiation process – please listen to arguments and you have reason to refute them – we had an obligation to discuss, on the one hand, the Greek Government and on the other hand three different institutions with different and conflicting, many times, positions and proposals; I would like to come to the substance and answer some of the questions raised in our debate.  First, whether or not the Greek side has put forward proposals, credible or not, you will judge them. The Greek side has put forward proposals. He tabled a forty-seven-page text, which was not our positions, but the result, in our view, of a difficult and arduous negotiation process. Unfortunately, the picture that has been created is that it has not put forward any proposals. Last Monday, the Greek side came back with a new text of credible proposals, which was accepted as the basis for discussion by all three institutions. Last Monday. In these proposals we are obviously committed to meeting the budgetary targets required by the rules, because we recognise and respect that the euro area has rules. However, we reserve the right of choice to choose where we, as the sovereign government, will add the tax burdens in order to meet the required budgetary targets.  And I truly believe that it is the sovereign right of a government to choose to increase the taxation of profitable enterprises and not to cut the allowance for the lowest pensions, the EKAS, in order to meet the budgetary targets. If it is not the right of a sovereign government to choose how to find equivalent measures to meet the required objectives, then we should adopt an extreme and undemocratic concept: that in countries on a programme, there should be no elections; governments should be appointed, technocrats appointed and they should take responsibility for decisions. I would like to inform the House that, indeed, you are right; in Greece, there are distortions from the past that need to be removed, such as the distortion of early retirement, and we were the first to take the initiative to say that we want, without anyone telling us, to abolish early pensions in a country that is in such a dire economic position. The reforms are therefore necessary and our commitments to the necessary budgetary adjustment in order to have surpluses, not deficits. These commitments are given. But we reserve the right to choose the redistribution of burdens, which, I believe, could and should and I am sure most of you agree with. Ladies and gentlemen, the question has been asked: 'Do you have a secret plan to take Greece out of the eurozone?'. I want to answer you honestly. All last week, the vast majority of statements by European politicians and officials were that a no vote in the referendum automatically means Greece leaving the euro. People knew this when they were asked to vote, when they went to the ballot box and brought all this a result that some surprised. If I were to take Greece out of the euro, I would not go immediately after the close of the ballot box to make the statements I made and interpret the referendum result not as a mandate to break with Europe, but as a mandate to strengthen real efforts to get to a better deal, a more credible deal, an economically viable and socially just agreement. That's my goal. I don't have any other secret plan, and I'm talking with open papers. Finally, I would like to say to you: I have heard from many, and especially those who have used the strongest polemic rhetoric, talk about our inability to respond to the solidarity of the European partners. I would like to say that, of course, borrowing is a form of solidarity, there is no doubt about that. But we want a sustainable programme, precisely in order to be able to repay the loans we have received, and when we ask for debt write-downs, we are asking for this write-down, precisely to be able to repay these loans and not to be constantly obliged to repay the old ones. I would like to remind you, Mr Weber, that the strongest moment of solidarity in modern European history was in 1953, when your country was coming out in debt and plundered by two world wars and Europe and the European peoples showed the greatest solidarity at the London summit in 1953, when they decided to write off 60% of Germany's debt, as well as a development clause. This was the most important moment of solidarity in modern European history. I heard from my friend Guy Verhofstadt – we were co-candidates last year for the Presidency of the Commission and we know each other well and we have good relations – ask him: 'How are you going to deal with the problems? with what reforms? You are not proposing reforms; what have you done?" and I would like to reply: Indeed, in these five months, we are more negotiating than governing, in conditions of financial suffocation. Our concern, our concern, our thought is more how we will manage to keep the Greek economy alive. Nevertheless, we did things, my dear friend Guy. We were the ones who tried and brought to the stool of Justice many of whom had fled tax. Previous governments have not. It was we who made an agreement with Switzerland in order for the Greeks who made their money abroad to pay taxes. It was we who passed a law to limit triangular transactions. No previous government had done it. It was we who asked the owners of the media in Greece to pay their taxes. No previous government had done it. It was we who strengthened customs controls in order to hit smuggling.  Of course, we must and we have before us an obligation to do much more. We didn't have much time to do and we ask for your support to change Greece. It is our shared responsibility to change Greece and from this we will be judged. In conclusion, I would like to tell you this: everyone understands that the debate is not just about one country. It concerns the future of our common construction, the euro area and Europe, and here two diametrically opposed strategies for the future of European integration collide. Let's all take responsibility! Despite our ideological differences, despite what divides us at home, at a crucial national moment we have the opportunity to join forces and the day before yesterday all the political forces under the President of the Republic found themselves at the same table and we agreed on a framework of positions and on the basis of that framework tomorrow we will re-table concrete proposals for a sustainable and fair agreement , proposals for credible reforms I want to tell you, but in closing, this: Many people have referred to the ancient Greek tragedy. I want to tell you that I fully respect the laws governing the European Union and the euro area. Without laws, no one can move forward. But since you mentioned the ancient Greek tragedy, let me tell you that one of the most important ancient tragics, Sophocles, with his masterpiece, Antigone, taught us that there are times when the supreme law of the laws of men is the law of men. And I think now is such a moment. (applause)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, Prime Minister, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I agree with all those who have said that we must return to the negotiating table. That is where we belong, and it was a mistake to leave this negotiating table! (Applause) But I have asked to speak in order to be able to supplement the speech by the Greek Prime Minister. It is true that the negotiations took place behind closed doors. I can't change that either. It is also true, however, that these negotiations were completely different from what they used to be. Mr Barroso has never met with the Greek Prime Minister, the head of the International Monetary Fund, and the head of the European Central Bank for hours – thirty in total – to find a solution. Technocrats used to rule, in my Commission it is the Commissioners who sit at the table, including the President of the Commission. The negotiations that we have conducted – always in a friendly tone, incidentally – were high-level negotiations, and if the negotiations had not been interrupted, we would have reached an agreement between the three institutions and between the Commission and the Greek Government. But because these negotiations took place behind closed doors, Mr. Tsipras could not tell everything. He will not contradict me when I say that I have proposed and enforced that shipowners should finally be taxed in Greece. (Applause) The Commission has proposed a reduction in the Greek defence budget. Thank God this proposal was accepted. No one in the Greek delegation will be able to accuse me of not putting myself before the small pensioners and the minimum wage earners in Greece. I have always resisted the fact that pension cuts will happen again. Nor has any pension cuts been proposed that would have affected small pensioners. Nor has any wage reduction proposed that would have affected wage earners who are at the lowest level of the wage scale. In this respect, I believe that we must describe things in the way that they really have gone on behind closed doors. (Applause) The Commission has proposed to its Greek colleagues a multiannual investment programme of EUR 35 billion to get the real economy in Greece back on track. It is not enough to consolidate public finances. We also need to make dynamic economic policies that are growth-oriented and job-oriented. We would have provided the money, we are prepared to provide that money. In this respect, I would have been grateful if everything had been said. Much has not yet been said. (Applause)

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, almost everybody is talking about the need for unity, but just like in the European Council, our debate today shows how divided we are on the subject of Greece. This is the reason why we should return to our common simple principles that have accompanied people for many centuries. Firstly, in this crisis we must unconditionally respect one another. Secondly, morality means paying off the debt you owe to others. It is not so that the creditors are bad and immoral, while the debtor is the innocent victim. (Applause) Thirdly, it is simply impossible to keep spending, over a long period of time, much more than one earns. This is the source of the crisis in Greece, not the common currency. (Applause) Fourthly, seek help from your friends and not from your enemies, especially when they are unable to help you. (Applause) And finally, if you want to help your friend in need, do not humiliate him. (Applause) Today we need unity, not because unity is a beautiful idea, but because it is indispensable in order to take concrete decisions. Without unity on Greece, we will wake up in four days in a different Europe. This is really and truly the final wake-up call not only for Greece, but also for us: it is our last chance. I want to inform you that the last chance procedure has just started. President Dijsselbloem received, while we were debating here, the formal Greek request for the ESM programme, as we agreed yesterday. I hope that this is a good sign, a good omen for tomorrow. (Loud applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you, Mr Tusk. I would like to thank you all very much. I would like to thank Mr Tsipras, you, Mr President of the Council, the President of the Commission. Ladies and gentlemen! I believe that it can be said that this debate today has certainly been a landmark debate for the future of Europe and that, with this debate, the European Parliament has played its role as the heart chamber of European democracy. Thank you. (Applause)

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The Greek people, who have been battered in recent years by the draconian austerity measures imposed by the former Troika, have been called upon to express their opinion and the answer has been irrefutable: the 'no' vote has won overwhelmingly. The mandate signal was strong and democratic. For the first time we can talk about a European debate among all citizens. We often complain about the absence of a European public sphere, of a European debate. From home or syntagma square, citizens have followed the debates, the vote and the results of this democratic consultation.  Now a very difficult game is opening up for Tsipras and his government. For this reason, Athens must not be left alone: its isolation would have the effect of neutralising the voice of the Greek people. For this reason, I would like to express my full solidarity with the Greek people for this courageous choice and I am ready to make my contribution as a Member of the European Parliament to support them. I believe that a revision of the Treaties is necessary so that the governance and rules of the eurozone are rethought and the human person is put at the centre with his dignity, rather than a failed budgetary rules.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – The problem of Greek public debt has caused one of the most serious crises in EU history. It has been emphasized that the single currency is an unfinished project. It is urgent to complement monetary union with the fiscal, financial and budgetary union, as well as with a debt repayment fund. The Eurogroup has been unable to find a just and definitive solution to an economic and financial situation, the causes of which include the years of 'austericide' policies, which put debt before people and whose main consequence is the suffering of thousands of Greeks and Greeks. The EU must resolve crises through its common institutions, including the European Parliament. It is now the responsibility of the Euro Summit and the European Council to quickly find a balanced agreement, which provides for debt relief, on the basis of the Commission's last proposal of 28 June, and thus to prevent the bankruptcy of the monetary union. The integrity of the Eurozone must be preserved, otherwise the European construction project will no longer be credible. In the meantime, the ECB must ensure the functioning of the Greek banking system, increasing the volume of the urgent provision of liquidity.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D)
text: in writing. – This is more than ever a critical time for the people of Greece. The sacrifices made and hardships endured by so many Greeks have been unjustifiable and must not have been made for nothing. Yet another strong democratic message has been sent by Greek citizens in support of their key demand to end unfair austerity measures. The British Labour movement stands in solidarity with Greece, and I congratulate my colleagues in Westminster, including eight London Labour Members of Parliament, who have this week signed an Early Day Motion in support of Greece. The European Union and its institutions must stop the blame game and find a solution that includes reasonable assistance terms and restructuring of Greek debt.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – It is high time to move forward and make decisions. A new European summit on Greece will be capped on Sunday evening. We expect the Greek Government to put constructive proposals on the table, which form the basis for a compromise. We definitely want to prevent a Grexit. The priority now is to achieve a breakthrough. We are living in Europe in far too turbulent times to allow this matter to drag on any longer. Important issues, such as the Energy Union, the European Investment Plan, Jobs for Young People, Measures to Combat Global Warming and the convergence of social standards in Europe, are not getting out of the way. All euro area countries must now be prepared to take difficult measures so that we can give the economic revival every chance and offer a perspective to all fellow Europeans looking for a job. I'm counting on this to happen.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. I have the greatest respect for the decision taken by the Greek people, less so for the political form in which the Government in Athens has put the entire EU's holding at risk by hoisting a wall in the face of dialogue and mediation. Now, I expect a sense of responsibility and a greater predisposition to negotiations from President Tsipras, because, whether we like it or not, the fate of the Greek people is in his hands today.  I say, however, quite frankly, that the priority today is not to save a single country, but europe. At any price. I hope, of course, that the parties will come to an agreement and that Greece can remain within the eurozone, but I believe that we must give priority, at this stage, to the collective interest and the collective interest of the EU partners, not that of a single government. Especially in view of the Greek government's unwillingness to make specific commitments to reform the country and bring it closer to the parameters required by the EU.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – What is happening in Greece is certainly something that we should be concerned about, not only as Portuguese, but also as European citizens. The limit situation we have reached can only be attributed to the way in which the Greek government has decided to conduct the negotiations. Europeans and their governments cannot ignore what has happened so far, but they cannot forget the spirit of compromise that always has to guide the European negotiation process. It is therefore therefore imperative that the Greek government present concrete measures which, not ignoring the limit situation in which its people are located, will enable the reforms much necessary to the Greek economy and finances to be carried out. This is also the only way to win back the trust of European partners. We must be prepared for all the scenarios, but I have no doubt that it would be very negative for the European project, for the Greeks and each of the European peoples if the euro zone lost one of its members.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. Prime Minister Tsipras has used the quintessential democratic instrument, the referendum, to ask the people for confidence in a decision that is quite delicate for his future. Tsipras could have used the parliamentary majority that supports him to impose his NO line on the creditors' proposal. Instead, he decided to challenge creditors and risk the chair in the event of a negative result.  Tsipras, with more than 61% of "OXI", has achieved greater support both among Greek citizens, albeit in circumstances different from the 36% with which he had risen to the leadership of the Greek Government, and towards the Troika, with which he will now sit strengthened by popular support. This figure is all the more important when you consider that Tsipras had to show that he had the "pulse of the leader" towards the more "harshpurist" fringes of Syriza and against the allies.  We must also bear in place that Merkel had made the referendum more of a personal challenge than anything else, convinced of a 'Yes' victory that would permanently sink any ambition and problem, increasingly handing the country back into the hands of any government. In the light of all this, this is an extraordinary achievement.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – Just as it was a mistake to accept Greece as a member of the eurozone, it is still a mistake to be too soft and too tolerant of the negotiations. It is increasingly clear that the Greek Prime Minister only understands the word of strength and considers excessive tolerance on the part of his partners to be a sign of weakness. If the current Greek Government is playing the role of leaving the eurozone, it must be obvious to everyone that no European politician and no European institution can prevent this. The Greek government is primarily responsible for Greece's future, and if the Greek government decides to leave the euro area and reintroduce its own currency, they must be helped in this process.  In this context, the key phrase was said by German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who stated that it was up to the European Union to protect the stability of the euro and the eurozone. The eurozone is in a situation where there is no longer a good solution. Whatever solution is adopted will also affect Slovakia as a member of the euro area. The public statements made by Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico only show that he deeply underestimates the citizens of Slovakia and that he does not understand the European processes.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – I think it is important that EU leaders have taken note of the need not only to jointly solve the problems of housing people rescued from the sea, but also to deal with the problem of those arriving on land quickly. Hungary been subjected to a wave of immigration that is the highest in Europe in terms of population. Last weekend only, more than 2,000 asylum seekers were registered, reaching 70,000 this year. This year's wave of immigration is not the result of a special war event, persecution, which would be limited in time, space, numbers, finite. Europe has faced the latter, but it has been able to deal with them. The current migratory migration movements will soon lead to an unmanageable situation due to their size and size.  The unresolved problems of immigration, rolled before us, offer even the greatest challenges for our children and even our grandchildren. Therefore, we need less generous beauty today, more responsible future thinking. The statistics show that there is a much larger crowd of people who give up everything in the hope of better prosperity to get into the promised Europe. The number of genuine refugees is much lower in proportion. With the right sensitivity and empathy, we need to find a way for the truly needy to get the right help, but it cannot be interpreted as an invitation to tens of thousands of people. Only in this way can the Member States protect their borders, ensure a normal life, and maintain this Europe in the long term.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. – We are at a critical time for Greece and for the rest of the European Union. Let us be rational, sit down and negotiate and resolve this situation once and for all. There are two reasons why we must find an agreement that allows Greece to remain in the euro area. The first is solidarity. The Greek governments have made many mistakes, but it was the Greek people who have suffered the consequences. Our Greek compatriots have been adjusting for five years and the unemployment rate has soared. Let us stop resorting to negative stereotypes that could be extended to other peoples of the Mediterranean and focus on the sacrifices they have already made. In addition to the structural reforms that the EU is demanding, they need an investment plan that boosts their economy, in the style of the famous Juncker plan that has been so well received. The second reason is selfishness. If Greece leaves the euro area, the euro will lose much of its credibility and weight as an international currency. In addition, recovering countries, such as Spain, will again see the risk premium fired, making it difficult to get out of the crisis. Let us therefore have sight height.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – At the time of his inauguration, the Prime Minister of Greece stated peremptorily that he did not agree with the terms of the international aid granted to him. Over the past six months of governance, Alexis Tsipras wanted to renegotiate these terms of the agreement without presenting solutions that were accepted by creditors. Both the European Commission and the finance ministers or heads of state and government of the remaining 18 eurozone economies have tried to support and help Greece find new solutions to meet its international commitments, and has even made available a European investment package of around €35 billion. I believe that it is time for Alexis Tsipras to make a commitment to stay in the Eurozone, to implement the structural reforms so necessary to increase the competitiveness of the Hellenic economy and create jobs and to be with his European partners to the detriment of Russia, Venezuela or China.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – The situation in Greece is not only about the economy, but also about how we understand solidarity at European level. It is very important that the European Union's strategy with regard to Greece is a constructive one, focused on development and investment that ensures that Greek citizens have a better life and prospects for the future. We need a partnership between the EU and Greece that comes out of the logic of austerity and focuses on investing in people. Projects and programmes are needed to train human resources, create jobs, develop SMEs and innovation capacity.  To do this, both partners must stop attacking each other and restart negotiations on new solid and credible foundations. In this respect, I believe that all EU Member States must be involved in the negotiation process, even if they are not members of the euro area. Greece's situation also affects countries such as Romania and Bulgaria, and the experience of those in this area can be beneficial for the future partnership.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. – Responsible behaviour means being held accountable for your actions and ready to bear the consequences of your bad moves. Regardless of who is guilty of irresponsible conduct, anyone who has acted irresponsibly must suffer the consequences.  In the case of Greece, the above should be applied. At a time when Greek civil servants receive their 13th and 14th salaries, and social benefits benefits outsmack the average salary of citizens of several EU countries, and while average salaries in Greece are close to or above the European average, while in Greece they are still employed in state services solely at party key without the necessary qualifications, residents of other eurozone countries who do not have these benefits from their salaries and peacekeeping are allocating funds to help bail out Greek debts. In addition, citizens of these countries are insulted that they are to blame for Greece's problems. Greece today must show a different face, accept responsibility and pay for life beyond its means.  I hope that other Member States with a similar level of irresponsible behaviour will be taught these experiences and change their behaviour for the benefit of their citizens.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – The Greeks voted 'no' on Sunday by a clear majority, although the question itself was unclear to many. If the question is unclear, it is difficult to interpret the answer. The vote says nothing about the Greeks' desire to exit the currency union. However, the future is entirely in the hands of the Greeks as to what conditions will be negotiated in the future. The euro area has achieved sustainability and stability to out better than in previous years than in previous years, but reforms are still under way. A sustainable solution can be achieved by folding public sector indebtedness, which requires structural reforms from both Greece and other Member States.  Uncertainty and postponement of decisions are the most disastrous for confidence and investment on which future growth depends. Greece has been through this bitterly in recent years, and the withdrawal from the euro will not give the country any better prospects. Greece will not escape its economic ties with the rest of Europe and the euro countries with which it is tied, either on the path of joint growth or further uncertainty.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Greece should not be in the euro area at all, as it was not prepared from the outset and the first reports indicated serious breaches of the conditions for Greece to join the euroland. Despite the lack of respect for the so-called Stability and Growth Pact and despite the debt of the rest of the EU, the view was that Greece should be allowed into the euro area for political reasons. Athens's current troubles are also the aftermath of this decision.  There is no doubt that the Greeks are largely to blame for themselves, but few remember that the two largest EU and euro area countries, Germany and France, have systematically violated the provisions of the Stability and Growth Pact on debt and budget deficits for several years in a row and have not been penalised by the European Commission for this. This has set a precedent and an euthason for similar practices in southern European countries.  In order for Greece to have a chance of exiting the debt spiral, realistic conditions are needed to give it a chance to repay its debts and must be combined with the requirement to restructure the economy. It therefore seems that the decommission of parts will be necessary for a long time. Partial extension must be conditional on the necessary structural reforms, which in the first period will bring about a reduction in living standards. In order to prevent poverty and exclusion, there must be a special cover programme and, above all, the promotion of entrepreneurship.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Prime Minister Greece's speech to the EP was met with great anticipation, as the Problem of Greece currently employs all the European institutions. Personally, I am very disappointed with the greek Prime Minister's speech. His speech was full of phrases about democracy, solidarity, the eurozone's inability to find a solution to the crisis in Greece. He asked for help, he wants a deal, but he did not name concrete measures to restart the economy and reduce Greece's debt. After the weekend's referendum, Greece is in euphoria, celebrating, but its leaders should take immediate action. Take action in the banking and financial sectors. The Greeks have exported billions of euros to foreign banks in recent years, which are currently lacking in greek banks as currency. Other concrete decisions have to come very quickly, because in commercial relations no one wants to do business with Greek firms anymore, only in the case of advance payment. Various privileges need to be addressed acutely – for islands, churches, soldiers... In ten million Greece, it is now a great luxury to have more than 800,000 civil servants. The government must pass legislation for reforms, open up markets to investors and do everything possible before the summer season so that tourism revenues are not lost.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. – The "Economist" spoke of Greece in the decisive verdict: "The Greek economy is hopelessly uncompetitive." The reforms proposed so far are counterproductive and the institutional reforms required take too long to have an impact. As a result, Greece will not be competitive in five years' time. If Guy Verhofstadt is rhetorically attacking Alexis Tsipras and listing Greece's failings, why didn't he and the European Parliament speak sooner? The required reforms are institutional in nature. A decade goes by before they are implemented halfway. If Greece were not a member of the euro area, every economist and politician would propose a sharp devaluation of the Greek currency. This way out is not being done because Greece is to remain a member of the euro area. As a result, Greece's economy will remain uncompetitive for the foreseeable future. A Grexit would not be the downfall of Greece, but a liberating blow.

name: n/a
text: in writing. – In order to find a solution that will avoid Greece's exit from the euro area, it is necessary to determine the Tsipras government to get out of the vicious circle of a sterile, demagogic confrontation to the logic of economic recovery, which is much needed by his country. This is not possible without reforms that will sanitize public finances and unburden the budget. It is the obligation of any member of a group to follow the rules by which it is guided – in this case the Eurogroup, which brings together the 19 euro area states. On the other hand, I think there needs to be a more effective approach from Athena's external partners. Endless financing leads to unsustainable debt. I therefore share the view that Greece needs a long-term debt rescheduling and a grace period to stabilise economically, but I am totally against the cancellation of any part of the debt. With one condition: the Tsipras government to demonstrate that it can move from demagoguery to responsible action to save Greece from imminent disaster, presenting a viable recovery programme.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The message sent out by Greek citizens in the referendum on 5 July was unequivocal: the Greek people are no longer prepared to accept further austerity in exchange for staying in the eurozone at any price.  But over and above the outcome, by giving a referendum on an agreement imposed from above, Greece has also rebelled against the principle that decisions that affect the lives of millions of citizens must be taken, out of any democratic control, in the secret chambers of the top of the Eurogroup, where credits and not rights count. Faced with this explosion of democracy, Europe reacted by showing its true face, that of a political project that has reneged on its fundamental values, choosing to bypass democracy, the rule of law and national sovereignty in order to defend the interests of strong countries and finance. It remains a way to rebuild the Europe of the peoples from the ground up: to abandon the crazy project of the euro which, far from accelerating convergence between countries, has accelerated its disintegration, amplifying imbalances and contrasts between strong economies and weak economies. The European project has been dismantled with blackmail from the markets and authoritarian diktats and can now only be rebuilt by betting on democracy, the commons, the real economy, work and social welfare.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – The irresponsible actions of the left-wing Greek Government have been sad, downright gruesome to follow. As recently as last autumn, the Greek economy and employment showed signs of improvement. As a result of Syriza coming to power, tax collection has stopped and capital flight from the country has accelerated. To top it all off, the state has defaulted on its debts and left the negotiating table. The banks have had to close. Unfortunately, it is the ordinary citizens who suffer most from the foolishness of the Greek Government.  Europe has tried everything to help, but now the measure is beginning to be full. The Greek Government must now take responsibility for the country's economy itself. Without an additional loan, the country will not survive, but more loans cannot be granted unless Greece now implements really significant reforms. Greece can only survive through major, tough reforms. Without them, additional funding and membership of the euro area will no longer be able to continue.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (
text: PPE), in writing. – The 60% who voted NO in the 5 July referendum in Greece is by no means linked to the desire of the vast majority of the Greek people to keep the country in the euro and in the EU. In all polls with a question of Greece remaining in the eurozone, Greeks voted YES at a dizzying rate of 75-80%. Greek Prime Minister A. Tsipras deceived the Greek people by announcing a referendum with a false and misleading question, by suggesting NO instead of YES, while in the unprecedented five-day period of democratic data citizens were not properly informed and voted without a grasp of the stakes. Mr Tsipras was forced to roll back and bring back to the negotiating table the improved Juncker proposal, the one that was supposed to be voted down, which proves that the Eurozone for Greece is a one-way street. The fact that he was forced to remove the Minister of Finance and convene a Council of Political Leaders shows the difficult position he has taken. The Greek Government must rise to the occasion and finally put forward substantial proposals to find an agreement that will give Greece a future for future generations. But this future must go hand in hand with the country's European course.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. We have seen today that the term 'Union' is very inappropriate to complement the concept of Europe, and I say this with some regret, but taking note of the reality of the situation. The main political groups, an expression of the European leaders angry with Tsípras, have only been very criticised, even very heavily, at the choices of Greece and the Greek people. Firstly, they have shown deep contempt and disinterest for the leader of a democratically elected country, which on Sunday obtained a new popular legitimacy to support a certain type of programme.  We could discuss whether or not this programme is the solution that will allow Greece to recover, something about which I am very sceptical, but in any case it represents the clear choice of a country that does not accept top-down taxation. The fake European Union is showing its true face: the face of arrogance and arrogance, ready only to impose diktats and deaf to the demands of the people.  In my opinion, Greece has only one chance of growing again and being competitive: to abandon the single currency which imposes measures and conditions that cannot be sustainable for the Greek country.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes).

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – On this day a year ago, an attack on Gaza was launched, resulting in 1500 civilians dead, including 500 children. More than 70 Israeli soldiers also died. I would ask you to honour the memory of all these unnecessary victims with a minute's silence and with the hope that the Middle East peace process will lead to lasting peace.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Vajgl, thank you very much for pointing it out. We come back to that. At the moment I have to put that on hold.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yesterday, at the explanations of vote, Mr Korwin-Mikke showed the Hitler salute with the words: 'One Reich, one people, one ticket'. It is legitimate to oppose the unification of tickets. But the Hitler salute, ladies and gentlemen, has lost absolutely nothing in this House. (Loud applause) It is absolutely inexcusable to play down this greeting, which is synonymous with the horrors of the Nazi era, in a debate on the unification of tickets.  Mr President, I would ask you, and I trust that you will take appropriate measures, as you have done in the past, to ensure that Mr Korwin-Mikke fails to trivialise this greeting in the future.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I have already been made aware of the matter. The appropriate steps have already been taken.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to make a point of order: this voting list that we are about to go and vote on TTIP has something strange about. Amendment No 117 applies to paragraph 1 of 15 but also deletes our Amendment No 40, which refers to Article 1 of 14. Now, Amendment No 117, tabled by Mr Lange, is not a compromise amendment between different groups, because it is proposed only by one group, the Socialist Group. Rule 170 of the Rules of Procedure clearly states that an amendment may not affect a paragraph other than the one to which it refers. On the contrary, it says that in this case this amendment is inadmissible. If you then believe that this is a compromise amendment, if you really want to force the rules and consider that an amendment proposed by a group is only a compromise, I would ask you to read Rule 174(4) of the Rules of Procedure, which states that this compromise must be put to the vote. It is ironic that these amendments talk about ISDS, that is to say private arbitrators who decide without the possibility of appeal and seizing democracy. It seems to me that this Parliament has already had a gigantic ISDS.  Mr President, this Parliament is not your kingdom, you cannot move votes and bring down amendments because you do not like them.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much. I am sure we will come back to that with Amendment No 117.

name: Yannick Jadot (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, we definitely have some problems with expression between us on this subject...  Mr President, the rules are very clear. When groups table compromise amendments after the deadline, they must be approved by Parliament to be voted on. This is the first point of order.  The second point of the regulation is based on Article 174, paragraph 2, which states very clearly: "If two or more mutually exclusive amendments apply to the same part of the text, the one that deviates the most from the original text has priority and must be put to a vote first."  Unfortunately, for several votes, we see that this fundamental text is not respected and, in essence, compliance with the logical order provided for in the regulations is at the discretion of the President.  Therefore, Mr President, your role is to make Parliament's work more fluid, not to prevent the political expression of Members of Parliament or political groups. I therefore ask you to respect Parliament's rules, which must not become the Schulz regulation.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mr Jadot, I would like to thank Mr Jadot for his I have to live with the fact that any kind of interpretation of the Rules of Procedure that I am interpreting is interpreted politically by you. I cannot change that. However, I am still trying to follow the Rules of Procedure correctly. I received two compromise amendments at the end of the debate. First of all, as you have quite rightly stated here, I must ask the House whether it agrees that we should vote at all on these amendments, which were tabled as compromise amendments after the debate has ended. There must be a vote in plenary to do this. Only then can I put this to the vote. Now you have tabled one on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, amendment 118 as a compromise amendment. And you have one, which the rapporteur, Mr Lange, has tabled. It is clear from the content – and this is the nature of amendments mentioning compromise amendments – that they are intended to produce the broadest possible cross-party majority. From this point of view, after consultation with the rapporteur, I have clearly inferred that the Lange amendment has a greater chance of reaching a compromise. That is why I recommend the rapporteur's request to the vote. Mr Bütikofer, do not bother, I have decided to do so. I shall now also ask the House whether it agrees with this interpretation. (Interjections) Mr President, listen! You can't get upset until you have heard my argument. But you have already made your argument in advance. I know that. But at least listen to my explanation. I will now first ask the House whether the Lange motion should be put to the vote, which is the only democratic instrument I have. That is the best way to resolve the issue. I would therefore like to begin by asking: do you agree that I should put the Lange amendment to the vote? (Parliament voted in favour of the admissibility of Amendment 117.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, just to remind you that the rules are not decided by a majority. Rules are rules, and so it seems to me very strange that he is being behaved today, and indeed not just today.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Rule 22 of our Rules of Procedure clearly regulates the procedures to be followed when there are differences of opinion on the Rules of Procedure. There are now differences of opinion between Mr Jadot and myself. That is why Article 22 – and there is a clear explanation from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs on this – stipulates that the President must bring about a decision. The sentence that the Committee on Constitutional Affairs has written to us in the Rules of Procedure is: 'In accordance with the provisions of Rule 174(7), the President may first obtain Parliament's consent'. That's exactly what I just did.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With your permission, I would like to comment on a point of order. I do not think that the case you are raising here is relevant. You have not even argued that there is a difference of opinion on the paragraph of the Rules of Procedure quoted by Yannick Jadot.  This paragraph of the Rules of Procedure, quoted by Yannick Jadot, clearly states which motion should be voted on first. In your reply, you did not refer to this at all, but mentioned a completely different reason, namely a procedural political consideration of which motion might have a higher chance of winning a majority. However, this is not relevant to the question of which request is further away from the original text. I would therefore ask you to stick to the unquestionable text of the Rules of Procedure. (Loud applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: I am sorry, Mr Bütikofer, that you may not have listened carefully enough. I have referred to Article 174(3), which gives me the right to proceed as I am doing. Before the vote on the whole motion for a resolution:

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD).
text: Mr President – perhaps I should call you His Majesty in view of the course of this day – with regard to my point of order on Rule 170, I have not had an answer. You replied under Rule 174(4).
