I would like to have a definition of a 'compromise amendment', because, according to Rule 170, I believe that our Amendment No 40 should still be put to the vote, as it is not part of the same paragraph for which we voted on Amendment 117 Lange. Article 170 is quite clear in this respect. I have not had an answer; You replied, perhaps to Mr Jadot in a questionable way, but I did not have your answer on the 170.  I would like to know why it is not voted on. Under the Rules of Procedure, then, if Rule 22 allows the whole Regulation to be overturned, that is fine, what are we going to do.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: You don't need to say majesty to me. 'In accordance with Article 170(3), the President shall decide on the admissibility of amendments. In the case of compromise amendments tabled after the end of the debate in accordance with paragraph 4 of this Article, the President shall decide on admissibility on a case-by-case basis, while being satisfied of the compromise nature of the amendment in question.' That's what I did. "The general criteria for admissibility can be established:" The following is a long list of criteria, which we have already explained, to which Mr Jadot has already referred. It goes on to say: 'Only the President can propose the consideration of a compromise amendment'. I did that, in both cases, Jadot and Lange. "For the vote on such an amendment, the President must obtain parliament's assent," I have done, "i.e. he must ask whether there are any objections to the vote on a compromise amendment. If this is the case, Parliament shall decide by a majority of the votes cast.' I have followed this procedure in accordance with Article 170 exactly. I have now taken the vote on the basis of Rule 174. There were different interpretations. I referred to Article 174(3). I had already informed Mr Bütikofer of this, but you can also have it in writing from me in the form. (Members of the GUE/NGL Group, the Verts/ALE Group and the EFDD Group rose and held up banners reading 'No TTIP')) Ladies and gentlemen! Thank you very much. It is, of course, always interesting to see from this place how those who refer most to compliance with the Rules of Procedure always interpret them in their favour.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati
text: Rapporteur. Thank you, Mr President, as I have already informed the group leaders, to postpone the vote on the legislative resolution in order to start negotiations with the Council and the Commission and to examine the possibility of an agreement at first reading.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you to the rapporteur. This is a request to open negotiations and to postpone the vote on the draft legislative resolution in accordance with Rule 61(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I shall now put this amendment to the vote. (Parliament accepted the request for the vote to be postponed) The matter has therefore been referred back to begin negotiations on the basis of the mandate.

name: Ivo Belet
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I know it is late, but I think this file is important enough to introduce its importance in one minute. I think this proposed decision proves that it is possible on the one hand to reconcile the reduction of emissions and on the other to secure the future of a flourishing energy-intensive industry in Europe. It is a vital decision with regard to the Paris Conference in December. May I ask for your support and may I also thank the shadow rapporteurs and Commissioners Arias Cañete and Šefčovič for their very good cooperation on this long journey.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, he is going so fast, it’s ‘for, against, abstain’. It’s gone before you’ve got your hand up. (Sustained heckling) I am sorry if you want your lunch, but maybe we would like to vote. Get over yourselves and do your jobs!

name: President. –
text: In the interest of speed, I will do it in English so that our English colleagues can follow.

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: President. –
text: The explanations of vote will be taken on Thursday, 9 July 2015.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statement on the recent terrorist attacks (2015/2759(RSP)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on Friday 26 June, a kind of black day, was marked by several terrorist attacks. This time, three countries were hit almost at the same time: France, Kuwait and Tunisia. These attacks have once again reminded us of the despicable nature of terrorism and especially of those who sponsor and execute them. Our response must be firm and supportive. On 26 June, the European Council made it clear that we must step up our action against these terrorist threats. This fight against terrorism is one of the most important challenges facing our open and democratic societies and one of the very first priorities. Our presidency will make it a top priority. We will build on the work undertaken by our predecessors, taking into account both the internal and external aspects of security. The Luxembourg Presidency will work to ensure that the European Union adopts a coherent approach in the fight against terrorism, which encompasses both these internal and external aspects of security, namely strong and fruitful cooperation between the Member States, the Commission, the European External Action Service and the European Union coordinator. We have instruments such as Europol, Eurojust, Frontex and Cepol. These instruments must be given the means and resources they need.  In response to the attacks in Paris in January, the Heads of State or Government adopted a declaration on 12 February based on three pillars: ensuring the safety of citizens, preventing radicalization, protecting values and, ultimately, cooperating with partners at the international level. The Union Counter-Terrorism Coordinator presented a full report to the Council and the European Council on the implementation of these measures. On 28 April, the Commission adopted the European security programme. We discussed it yesterday. The fight against terrorism is one of the main priorities, the strong international dimension of terrorism has been highlighted and our action must be placed at the same international level. On 9 February, the Foreign Affairs Council adopted conclusions on the fight against terrorism aimed at precisely strengthening cooperation with the countries of North Africa, the Near East and the Gulf, as well as with Turkey and the Balkan countries. A number of counter-terrorism capacity building projects have been approved. Workshops on this topic have already taken place in Lebanon and Turkey. The Union Counter-Terrorism Coordinator visited Tunisia at the head of an inter-service mission, following which the High Representative proposed a series of support measures to the Tunisian Prime Minister. Finally, a task force for strategic communication was created to develop an awareness and communication strategy for the Arab world. We must also actively pursue our cooperation with the United Nations, NATO, the Council of Europe and other international organizations, as well as our bilateral collaboration with our key partners, such as the United States. On 16 June, the Interior Ministers concluded that tangible progress had been made in recent months. Preventing radicalization in our own countries and partner countries is essential. How is it possible that young people in our countries, who have gone through our schools, are attracted to these terrorist networks that preach unprecedented violence? There is an in-depth work to be done on several levels: education, integration, our values. To this end, the Centre of Excellence, called the European Radicalisation Awareness Network, is about to be launched. Other measures should be taken, such as strengthening the application of the Schengen framework: documents and individuals should be subject to more systematic monitoring in relevant databases through a risk assessment approach. This approach was finalized on June 15 and will now be implemented. The Schengen Handbook for Border Guards has been updated. A unit responsible for reporting content on the internet was set up on 1 July within the framework of Europol in order to speed up the pooling of resources and intensify cooperation with the relevant sector. The aim is to reduce the scale and effect of terrorist propaganda and extremist and violent propaganda on the internet, with full respect, of course, for fundamental rights. The Council intends to be quickly able to adopt a decision on the signing, on behalf of the European Union, of the additional protocol to the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention of Terrorism, which would criminalize the movement of foreign terrorist fighters. Externally and in close partnership with countries where the terrorist threat is particularly present, we must help these countries to combat the social causes of terrorism, such as youth unemployment, which is a source of frustration, and thus becomes a breeding ground for the recruitment of new terrorists. Tunisia is, alas, an example.  The Luxembourg Presidency will be actively involved. Next week we will propose a new initiative of cooperation with Maghreb countries on youth employment, on vocational training for young people, because I believe that it is at the root that we must take this problem of young people tempted by the terrorist adventure, whether in Syria or in their own country. Ladies and gentlemen, I would now like to return to the issue of radicalisation.  The rate at which this phenomenon is spreading is worrying. In some cases, young people become radicalized over a very short period of time, as little as two months. On 19 and 20 October, we will hold a conference on the topic of reintegration and radicalisation in prisons, which often reveal these young terrorists who are ready to take action. Another issue that we will have to address is the treatment of foreign fighters returning to our societies. Commissioner Jourova has also refocused funding to include the fight against terrorism in the funding programmes launched this year under justice.  We must strengthen the means to combat the use by terrorists of the internet and social networks to spread their hate propaganda and to radicalise and recruit young people. We must spread messages to counter this terrorist propaganda and launch concerted and well-organized campaigns, especially in the media. More needs to be done, in particular, with regard to the decommissioning of firearms and the strengthening of the fight against arms trafficking. Similarly, we must redouble our efforts in terms of information exchange. Tomorrow, at the informal meeting of justice and interior ministers in Luxembourg, there will be talk of improving the exchange of information between the intelligence services and the police services. Ladies and gentlemen, as I told you yesterday, the implementation of the renewed 2015-2020 internal security strategy for the Union is a priority for the Luxembourg Presidency and can become an extremely active and useful instrument in the fight against terrorism. We must act decisively by addressing above all the root causes of this scourge, but let us not fall into the trap of those who wage this terrorist war against our peoples and against our States, namely to weaken our democratic systems and our values. Democracies are all the stronger because their action also ensures respect for human rights, which must remain our common thread.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the appalling attacks perpetrated on Friday, 26 June 2015, in France, Tunisia, Kuwait and Somalia demonstrate once again the brutality and inhumanity of terrorists. Let me first extend, on behalf of the Commission, our condolences to the families of the victims and express our moral support and our sympathy to the countries affected in Europe and beyond. I wish to condemn these acts of terror in the strongest terms and reaffirm our determination to address collectively this threat. We need to provide security to our citizens while upholding our values. Of course, we face constantly-evolving threats, and the numerous victims of this year’s attacks remind us of this reality. Investigations are still being carried out by the competent national authorities. The available information tends to demonstrate that the atrocities committed in Saint-Quentin-Fallavier, in Sousse and in Kuwait bear the hallmarks of Daesh’s despicable ideology of intolerance. Their objective is to instil terror. It is also relevant to note that terrorists are focusing on soft targets, such as religious buildings or tourist resorts. This Commission, as you know, has been working closely with the Member States to identify areas in which the European Union can make a real difference in fighting terrorism and radicalisation. We have been working closely with Member States to enhance our capacity to address this threat. In April the Commission presented the European Agenda on Security. The agenda places terrorism very high among the future priorities. It embodies a concept of security that encompasses the rule of law and fundamental rights. The agenda sets out a number of actions to counter the threat posed by terrorism. We have started working vigorously on their implementation. Let me now focus on some of the ongoing work of high political and practical significance. First, preventing radicalisation remains essential. The Radicalisation Awareness Network Centre of Excellence, to be launched in September, will take the work of the existing RAN further. I consider the work of RAN and the whole prevention element of the counter-terrorism policy at EU level to be crucial. Secondly, on 1 July 2015, the Internet Referral Unit was established at Europol. It will be fully operational within 12 months. The mission of the Internet Referral Unit is to identify terrorist material in different languages and to help secure swift removal. Third, by the end of the year, the Commission will formally launch an EU-level forum together with the internet industry. This will allow us to discuss how we can reduce the accessibility of online terrorist material and counter terrorist propaganda on the internet and in social media. A first workshop under the forum will be held on 24 July 2015, with experts from the industry and the law enforcement communities. Fourthly, the protection of external borders is crucial. With a view to supporting Member States in performing enhanced and targeted border checks, the Commission finalised – in close cooperation with Member States – a first set of common risk indicators. Europol and Frontex are assisting Member States in their implementation, and we have just revised their handbook for border guards. In the framework of the European Union’s Customs Risk Management Strategy, work is going on to enhance cooperation and information exchange between customs and law enforcement and to detect suspicious movements of goods. Fifthly, in order to trace and disrupt terrorist financing, we are working on the strengthening of cooperation between financial intelligence units. Let me also stress that the recently-adopted Anti-Money Laundering Directive improves the tools to address terrorist financing. Sixthly, as stated in the European Agenda on Security, we also need to better protect our citizens and critical infrastructures from terrorist threats. This work includes practical tools such as the guidance material that my services have recently developed on soft target protection. We are also upgrading the European Programme for Critical Infrastructure Protection, which will help to prevent attacks and failures and to improve preparedness and the response to incidents. Seventhly, as civil aviation remains the preferred target of terrorists, the Commission continues to work to increase aviation security and safety. A joint process is being developed with Member States to assess the risks from conflict zones and support the issuing of recommendations to airlines and the public. Eighthly, let me mention now EU-PNR, which is an important component of our security agenda. I wish to express my thanks to Parliament for your efforts in bringing to completion the EU legislation on PNR. I am confident that we can all continue to work together in such a constructive way so that the co-legislators can agree on a text that adheres to the highest standards of data protection and that is, at the same time, effective. Ninthly, the recent attacks illustrate the need for better international coordination and cooperation. The attack in Tunisia was extremely brutal and symbolic, as it targeted tourism – a vital economic sector for the country. It was an attack on Tunisia’s hospitality and its long-standing and friendly relations with Europe. We must stand by our Tunisian partners and show solidarity. Increasing their security will also contribute to enhancing our security. In the wake of the Bardo Museum attack, I travelled to Tunis and discussed, with my counterparts, how the European Union can provide support. We need to work together in tackling the root causes of radicalisation, detecting terrorists’ travel and building security capabilities and capacities. Honourable Members, we have worked a lot in the past six months and we have made good progress in a number of areas, but the recent attacks remind us that a lot still needs to be done. We owe this to the victims, and we owe it to our citizens and our partners. Let us therefore continue, with resolve and determination, in our joint efforts against terrorism and radicalisation.

name: Monika Hohlmeier
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I warmly welcome you: the Presidency of the Council and the Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The recent terrorist attacks have shown us that our liberal societies are vulnerable. They have also shown us that in our immediate neighbourhood – in the Middle East, towards the African continent – there has never been so much unrest, as much cruelty as there is today. For this reason, it is imperative that, on the one hand, we help the partners who are willing to work with us to fight terrorists directly on the ground, that we try – I very much welcome what the Commissioner has said here, including what the Presidency has said – that we need to tackle the issue of security very seriously and very consistently. Consistent also means that we must take measures that we might wish we did not have to do, but which are simply necessary in this day and age in order to provide protection for citizens. An important component and a new instrument is the PNR system, which is to be used effectively and sensibly, so that it can work across countries, europe-wide and perhaps even in combination with third countries. To this end, we also need better protection of our external borders.  But we also need to be clear that it is difficult to spot sleepers who might have been believed – three or four years ago – that they were dangerous, then stopped watching them because they were believed to be no longer dangerous. They are people who feel that they are not very much different from you and I, and suddenly they become murderers. To counteract this phenomenon or to try to get it out of these circles is, in my view, essential; above all, to dismantle and destroy the networks of radicalisation. I believe that it is essential to put an end to this radicalisation and the possibility of extremists taking people for their own purposes and abusing them for their own ends, with all the possibilities that the rule of law requires.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. We Europeans must stand up to violence and hatred together, on the basis of the values that unite us: equality, freedom, democracy, respect and tolerance. Socialists and democrats are not only stressing the need to strengthen security and the social causes of radicalism, but we also draw attention to the need to tackle the roots of the origins of terrorism in third countries. We have to deal with poverty, we have to deal with conflicts. It is wrong to say that all acts of terrorism are religiously motivated. Terrorists and extremists thrive when people don't trust each other, building social pens and stereotypes. This is not a clash between Islam and the West.  Young Europeans going to the battlefields in Iraq and Syria and returning are a big challenge. We need to improve education programmes, social integration, understanding between different countries and religions. The European Air Passenger Data Record (PNR) may be becoming indispensable for many, but let us not, please, take such measures that will simply make every passenger a potential terrorist. If he overcomes fear in Europe, the terrorists have won.  I believe, dear colleagues, that our weapons in the fight against terrorism, radicalisation, extremism must be freedom of expression. Human dignity and security must overcome fear and hatred in Europe.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, a mosque in Kuwait, a factory in France and a beach in Tunisia – there should be little to connect these three disparate places, but following the devastating attacks on 26 June 2015, they will forever be linked in infamy. All of the perpetrators of the terrorist attacks were somehow linked to ISIS in terms of its poisonous ideology. One year on from the lightning advance of ISIS, the group is becoming a more permanent fixture, tragically and unfortunately, of the map of the Middle East. On the same day, and months after the liberation of Kobane had been celebrated, ISIS carried out one of its most deadly massacres to date, storming the city and executing up to 250 civilians, many of whom were children. These attacks illustrate that, by allowing ISIS to establish a foothold in Iraq and Syria, a new magnet for jihadi terrorism has been created. We became used to understanding, in the past, international terrorist activities of the al-Qaida model, based on perceived grievances, no matter how unjustified. But now ISIS offers a new, more brutal, territorial death cult model, in which terrorist attacks are more firmly based on attacking religious beliefs and minority individuals, and they are more involved in attacking these people than in attacking the state. Whilst clearly we need to do more in the European Union to ensure that our societies remain vigilant and develop means to detect and prevent radicalisation and recruitment, we also need to have enhanced domestic security measures, such as the passenger name records (PNR) system for aviation, and better internet monitoring of terrorist activities. Ultimately, however, we must also take the fight against evil ISIS everywhere, particularly militarily in Syria, Iraq and Libya. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question he asked by picking up the blue card. – Namely, I would like to address you with the question: do you agree with me that one of the countries that is in a very dangerous and difficult situation in Europe is Bosnia and Herzegovina, where a large number of Muslims live, often under attack from those who call for terrorism or who want to enlist them in terrorism? Do you agree with me that the European Union should have a special sensibility for the situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina and help security agencies in Bosnia and Herzegovina?

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – As someone who takes a great deal of interest in the Western Balkans – as the rapporteur for Montenegro – I have followed events closely as the shadow for Bosnia and Herzegovina. Clearly, in all the Western Balkan countries, amongst the Muslim minorities – particularly in Kosovo, Albania, Macedonia, and Bosnia and Herzegovina – there is a serious problem of radicalisation and of jihadi terrorists departing from these countries. Up to several hundred of them may be, as we speak, fighting for ISIS in Iraq and Syria. This is a serious problem. Member States are aware of it and NATO is taking it very seriously. Everything must be done to prevent this flow. I agree with you entirely: it is a major security risk to that region.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the chain attacks of 26 June left more than sixty dead, including numerous European citizens who were literally massacred on the beaches of Tunisia. The three attacks add to this wave of unprecedented hatred and radicality with which we are beginning to live together, an extreme situation that we seem to be willing to accept as usual. Worse, we know that they will strike hard again, especially those countries like Tunisia which, when they try to move forward on the democratic path, radicals plunge back into doubt and instability. It seems that it is clear that the High Representative stated in this House that the situation in North Africa is a priority of the European Union and its foreign policy. After the attack at the Bardo National Museum, we began to realize the importance and need for the European Union, with all the tools at its disposal, to become involved in the fight against terrorism in North Africa and to help countries such as Tunisia, Algeria or Morocco without mitigation. I heard numerous appeals in this regard in the last debate. But what progress have we made? What goals have we achieved? What's changed? Financial and financial aid is not enough. From this seat I reclaim and insist on the urgency of actively engaging us, not just dedicating good words to them. We must become aware, once and for all, that the border of our security is in North Africa. We cannot afford a single more focus of tension and instability on the southern European border. We cannot afford to lose Tunisia, because the Islamic State we are far from defeating is knocking on your door, at our door. We must reformulate the Union's neighbourhood policy. We must decide and act together on security our borders. We cannot wait any longer to help those countries that desperately seek our support in a comprehensive way. However, as I have been repeating, I fear that, as always, we will be late for this goal.

name: Cornelia Ernst
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The horrific acts of the last few days and weeks, which really depress you, and I feel the same way. But how many times have we said that? How many discussions have we had? Nothing has really changed. Most of the time, the answers were: more surveillance, more weapons, more repression. This has not produced the results we would have liked. Nor have we really asked ourselves the question: how can support for terrorists be prevented in countries where terrorism is practised? How can this support be prevented from being granted? How can democratic processes be developed? I say to you: I keep thinking about it when we were in Iraq and of course the question had to be asked for us: Why is ISIS so successful? Because, of course, he also has support in parts of the population. I never forget – as I have already said here – as the Bishop of Erbil has told us: we do not need weapons, but we need support, and that is for reconciliation with the Sunnis, and indeed in the population, not, of course, with the terrorists.  We don't do anything about that. We need an honest discussion about the reasons why young people or others – not just young people – see their ideal in terrorist actions. We must also speak seriously about the shortcomings of our coexistence – something is wrong when young people go there and take part in such actions – and really ask ourselves the question: where are our deficits, what can we do? A pNR system for Europe does not help us any further, not a millimetre, and that is why we should not waste our strength on this.

name: Paul Nuttall
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, a fortnight ago in the European Parliament, I warned that the next terrorist attack was a case of not if, but when and where. We had the answer 48 hours later. We had a beheading in the French town of Grenoble, a massacre of 38 innocents in the Tunisian resort of Port El Kantaoui and a bombing of a mosque in Kuwait. What did all of these attacks have in common? Now some may find what I am about to say to be unpalatable, some might find it politically incorrect, but the simple fact is the one thing they all had in common was they were done in the name of Islam. Now I hear people in my own country claim the opposite and say that these outrages have nothing to do with Islam. But this is not only ludicrous, it is also extremely dangerous. These terrorists commit these atrocities and quote the text from the holy book of Islam, so to suggest that these attacks have nothing to do with Islam is akin to suggesting that the Inquisition had nothing to do with the Catholic Church. Indeed, if we are to deal with radical Islamism then we must at least have the courage to name its source. It is not just poverty and poor education, it is a literal and backward interpretation of the Koran. But not only do we in the West turn another cheek to extremism, we actively encourage it. We turn a blind eye to misogyny, homophobia, limb amputation, and the funding of extremism in return for arms deals and oil, and this primarily takes place with the States of Saudi Arabia and Qatar. We must make a stand on moral grounds and say enough is enough. Because if we do not, I fear that there will be a clash of civilisations at some point this century, and this clash will not be fought in the deserts of the Middle East, it could well be fought on the streets, in the cities and the towns of Europe. We are the politicians of today, ladies and gentlemen, and we have a duty to hand on a stable and better society to our descendants, and that is not a society where the words of a woman is worth half of that of a man; it is not a society where homosexuals are persecuted, and it is not a society where unbelievers are second-class citizens. Christians and Muslims alike, if we do not take a stand, history will look upon us as the generation that surrendered our hard-fought liberal Western democracy in favour of something darker, something more intolerant and something wholly illiberal. Burying our heads in the sand, ladies and gentlemen, is no longer an option. We must act: we owe it to our children.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, but you are seriously thinking of defeating Islamic terrorism with this confused and inconsistent congeria of half-measures, which is, by the way, largely late. Starting with the Council, which does not tell us about the link between terrorism and illegal immigration. Yet the President of Eurojust now acknowledges that this trafficking in illegal immigrants serves to fund and infiltrate Isis in Europe. The religious element is fundamental: at the basis of these crimes is the legitimacy of extremist Islam conveyed by the preaching of imams in flies and through social media.  So, no half measures! Close all the fundamentalist mosques here too, as Tunisia wants to do. No more masochism and blah-blah about Islamophobia. I was standing in front of the Charlie Hebdo headquarters and talking to people a few hours after that very serious attack: no one told me about Islamophobia. It's only talked about here. This false masochistic anti-racism is actually the Trojan horse that serves the most fundamentalist Islam to block our immune defenses from a virus that also expands through the intimidating force of attacks. They want to create fear in the middle of our continent. With Islam we are faced not only with a powerful jihadist organisation but also with a political actor who, with the attacks, dictates his agenda to our countries. By blackmailing horror and fear, they want to impose Sharia law throughout Europe. Wake up, Europe!

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, there are at least three causes of terrorism that depend on us. The first is the destruction or attempt to destroy secular regimes, albeit authoritarian, but which contained the rise of Islamic radicalism. I am talking about Iraq, Libya and even Syria. This was done by abject means, by diplomatic manipulation, a war of destruction, a ruthless blockade that aroused against the West an unfulfilled hatred, of which we have no idea. Secondly, it is the lack of knowledge, in fact, of the aggressive aspects of a religion which many of its sectarians consider to be a legitimate means of extending their community and that, against what they call the disbelievers, including the civilian population, all means are good, even the most cruel. Thirdly, it is a massive, wanted, uncontrolled immigration from Muslim countries and generating an uprooted youth, confronted with our ageing European societies which have disowned their faith, their roots, their ideal. Their agenda is no longer triumphant materialism and the promotion of sexual deviance, further practicing the continual repentance of what they have been, instead of exalting the true values of their past civilization.  Terrorism feeds on this soil, not all European leaders are terrorists, but they have been complicit, at a minimum, unconscious.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Sur President, l-Ewropa u d-dinja ilhom fid-dell tat-terroriżmu għal ħal ħal żmien. Illum qed nitkellmu għaxar snin wara l-attakki terroristi大i mill-agħar f'Londra, ftit xhur mit-traġedja ta' Charlie Hebdo, ftit ġimgħat mill-attakki fuq il-knisja he' Charleston fl-Istati Uniti, ftit jiem mill-attakki fi Franza, it-Tuneżija u l-Kuwajt u ftit sigħat mill-attakki minn Boko Haram fin-Niġerja u Al-Shabaab fil-Kenja. Ejjew inkunu ikeari, il-kondoljanzi mhumiex biżżejjed. Irridu nagħmlu ħafna, ħafna iktar biex jitwaqqaf it-terroriżmu kull fejn jiġri. Fl-istess ġurnata rajna qtil ta' 66 persuna fit-Tuneżija, il-Kuwajt u fi Franza. Dawn inqatlu irrispettivament mit-twemmin tagħhom. Dak li erġajna rajna yuri l-ħtieġa li fuckmbattu iżjed it-terroriżmu u l-estremiżmu. Min iwettaq atti terroristiikei i għandu l-ebda rispett. It-terroriżmu i għandux fruntieri, ma għandux reliġjon u fejn tintuża r-reliġjon dan ikun bi skuża biex jiġi ustifikat reat faħxi. L-attakkanti fit-Tuneżija ntrabtu mal-Istat Iżlamiku. Ejjew inkunu ikeari, din hija organizzazzjoni, mhijiex Stat u i tirrappreżentax flower-Musulmani. Hija organizzazzjoni responsabbli mill-imwiet ikkaġunati minn vjolenza bla limitu u bla sens. Aħna għandna nuru l-appoġġ tagħna lil dawk li sofrew dawn l-atti kodardi. It-Tuneżija, mnejn bdiet iż-żerriegħa tar-Rebbiegħa Għarbija, issa qiegħda fi stat ta' emerġenza. Il-Libja tibqa' fi stat he' chaos. Al-Shabaab u Boko Haram is a jwettqu attakki kważi kuljum. L-Unjoni Ewropea teħtieġ tiżgura li jkunu implimentati miżuri ta' sigurtà għaħa-ittadinikollha. Huwa ż-żmien li nimxu 'l quddiem fuq sin tal-Unjoni Ewropea kontra t-terroriżmu. Sin biex neqirdu l-estremiżmu li jsir u jiġi ġustifikat għal raġunijiet differenti. Irridu ntejbu l-leġiżlazzjoni tal-Unjoni Ewropea inkluża l-PNR. Sur President, lit-terroriżmu rridu niqfulu! L-attakki li jsiru i għandhomx jintimidawna jew inaqqsu r-rieda politika tagħna biex niġieldu t-terroriżmu. Għall-kuntrarju għandhom isaħħu u għandna nsaħħu d-determinazzjoni tagħna. (Il-kelliem qabel li jwieġeb għal mistoqsija "karta blu" skont l-Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura).

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. "Thank you, dear colleague, for accepting this blue card.  You pointed out, citing the examples of the attacks in Tunisia and France, in particular, that it was necessary - I quote you - to "speak out against terrorism or to conclude an agreement against terrorism". But, apart from the particular case of the NRP that you mentioned, you are not proposing anything concrete. It bothers me because I do not believe at all in the effectiveness of the NRL, this system of screening aircraft passengers, in the fight against terrorism. I think he's unsuitable.  Do you have other concrete solutions to fight terrorism?

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: tweġiba map blu. – Grazzi ta' din il-mistoqsija. Le, jiena ma naqbilx miegħek do l-miżuri do jiġu proposti fil-PNR ma jistgħux ikunu forza tajba contra min qed jhedded is-sigurtà tagħna; in hemmhekk qed niddiskutu ħafna miżuri li nixtiequ li f'dan il-Parliament ikollna qbil fuqu fil-jiem li ġejjin. Irridu wkoll insaħħu l-poteri tal-Counter-Terrorism Coordinator tal-Unjoni Ewropea. Irridu nagħtu iżjed poteri lil Europol biex naraw kif nistgħu nsaħħu l-kooperazzjoni bejn l-operazzjonijiet polizjeski bejn il-pajjiżi tagħna. Hemm ħafna xi jsir imma għandna bżonn qbil bejn l-istituzzjonijiet Ewropej, inkluż f'din.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, Isère, Tunisia, Kuwait, Somalia: within a few hours, terrorist violence struck. While there is no evidence that these actions are coordinated, the horror of these massacres is multiplied by their simultaneousity. In this time of great threats, we must remember the lessons of previous attacks. It is by refusing psychosis and proclaiming unity, whether national, European or even international, that we will fight this unprecedented phenomenon. Resilience depends on the responsibility and unity of all.  The phenomenon of terrorism is very complex, as it is true that the causes are geopolitical, social, economic or even psychological. These multiple causes therefore call for a comprehensive solution. Yes, the unprecedented and evolving nature of the current crisis requires an upgrade of European security and judicial arrangements. Yes, it also requires new thinking and tools adapted to media and digital jihad, which allows terrorists to reach every point of the national, European and international territory. Yes, it requires an offensive against the financial flows that fuel the terrorist fight. Yes, it makes it essential to make full use of existing instruments to better prevent the movement of jihadists inside and outside the Schengen area. But we can't be content with repressive at all. Any solution also requires measures to prevent radicalization before it leads to violence. Inequality, marginalization, social exclusion, and difficulty in accessing quality education are all factors that can contribute to radicalisation. The Commission has rightly stated this in its European security programme. Education, youth participation, interfaith dialogue, and employment and social inclusion have a key role to play in preventing radicalization.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – On 26 June, evil struck in Tunisia, Kuwait, Nigeria. The target and the victims of the terrorist attacks were once again innocents: praying believers, tourists on the beach, civilians. Apparently, they didn't fit the worldview in which the perpetrators believe. But under no circumstances should we get used to this kind of bloodshed and become numb to it. For a country like Tunisia, this terror is a tragedy. In the country years ago the seed for the Arab spring was laid. The harvest seems negligible, society more fragile than ever. In addition, by staying away from tourists, she loses her main source of income. Tunisia urgently needs perspective, a recruiting project. Work and progress are the only cure for hate preachers. The Union can offer perspective. Europe must look at a Marshall Plan that can re-energate regional cooperation and help the affected countries to move forward instability. For the alternative is a new Libya, hopelessly ungovernable and therefore a coveted bride in a perverse IS marriage.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Mr President, in the face of the terrorist threat, we must unite, not only with words, but with tools and actions. We must do this to protect our values and citizens and to prevent these abominable acts that we see, that we live and that are teetering our societies.   We must also be the strongest of the terrorists, because it is the strength of our democracies. The prevention of radicalisation, the surveillance of networks that are used masterfully by terrorists for their morbid propaganda, especially against young people and the fight against arms trafficking must be our priorities.  I welcome the minister's comments representing the current Presidency. But we must join forces by improving the coordination of information exchange. We must multiply these exchanges of information and above all make them compulsory by optimising Europol and creating a genuine European NRP that becomes an effective tool. We must also reform the Schengen information system to make alerts about terrorism suspects mandatory and to share such reports. This is the common security policy that our fellow Europeans are calling for.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is truly frightening, and we do not need to look very far into the past to perceive particularly profound changes in our society. Tunisia, France, again France, Kuwait. I come from the city of Graz in Austria, where three weeks ago there was also an assassination attempt in which there were three dead and forty injured, and where it was not yet clear whether this was also motivated by a radical Islamic man. If these attacks come so close to you, you can believe me, you are of course particularly shaken. Of course, one is particularly shocked when – like us liberals – we have been warned for years that radical Islam will not shy away from attacks in Europe either, and when we have been warning for years that radical Islam is already in the middle of our society. We always hear and read in the media and from responsible politicians: these are all individual perpetrators. Slowly, it seems to me that we are dealing here with an army of individual perpetrators, ladies and gentlemen. We also know that ISIS is already deliberately bringing new assassins to Europe with the help of the wave of refugees. There are three different routes. The most dangerous leads over Bulgaria with fake passports. There, these assassins with EU passports are on their way. "The next battlefield will be Europe," "The World" is already headlined. In addition to the wave of refugees, this terrorist problem, which we imported ourselves because of the failure of the EU governments, will be one of the biggest we will deal with in the coming years.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, my colleague Paul Nuttall’s speech of a few minutes ago said many of the things that I might hope to say and with which I totally agree. The threat that we all face in the West – and not just in the West – is from fundamentalist Islam. The terrorists and the extremists all have one thing in common: they are all reading the same book, and it is called the Koran. It contains exhortations, such as ‘kill unbelievers wherever you find them’, ‘make war on unbelievers’ and ‘strike terror into the hearts of unbelievers’. Some people take that literally. We are told by our leaders that Islam is a religion of peace and love. The problem is that it is actually a contradictory mishmash of nonsense. The problem is that the extremists and the fundamentalists actually choose the bits that they like in order to satisfy their bloodlust and earn themselves 72 virgins in paradise, although nobody has actually come back to confirm that they get them. Western liberal democracies must make it plain that extremist, fundamentalist Islam has no place in western society. We all come into contact with moderate, peace-loving Muslims every day. They are not the problem. Their ideology is. We must support the moderates against the extremists. Sun Tzu said that the first place you win a war is in the mind of your opponent. All propagandists know the importance of words. If you control words, you control how your opponent thinks and reacts. Most religions are named after their founders – Christianity, the religion of Christ; Buddhism, the religion of Buddhists; Judaism the religion of the Jews – and yet we accept the word Islam – submission to the will of Allah. It is not. It is the construction of a person. Let us go back to what we used to call this religion 30 or 40 years ago: Mohammedanism. It is the cult of Mohammed, and these people accept the death cult of Mohammed. Let us make it plain that we do not accept this ideology and take practical measures to defeat the extremists and support those moderates who want to stay in western liberal democracies. If they want to live under Sharia law, then they should go and live in one of the countries where they can do that.

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my first words I want them to be for the victims, to which I dedicate all my work here. I have always maintained that many in this Parliament only remember terrorism when there is an attack, an attack. And, past the emotional wave, everything is forgotten. Unfortunately, this threat, which has been underestimated for so long, has become so serious that our society is terrified. And that is the victory of the terrorists: they kill one to put fear in the body of all and thus end our freedom. We must not stop traveling to Tunisia, Paris, or London, because they wanted to sow pain in the heart of Europe. Because if we do, if we're immobilized by fear, they'll have won. I therefore welcome the view that the Luxembourg Presidency has considered the fight against terrorism a priority. I call for better protection mechanisms to be included in the Security Agenda, because it is the best way to deal with those who want to destroy the holiest of our rights, the right to life. From here, I want to send a clear message to terrorists: that our society, with years of shared values, will never kneel before its knives, its bombs and its pistols. I defend the memory of the victims, because by doing so, we are defending the dignity of all Europeans, who will never, ever, ever give them our freedom. And I remind many of this House that freedom is not at odds with security. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to thank the Member for her words and particularly for her work with the victims of terrorism. Does she agree with me that we must stand up for the victims of terrorism and particularly ensure that this House and our own national governments distinguish clearly, and in a legislative framework, between those who carry out vile acts of terrorism and their innocent victims?

name: Teresa Jiménez-Becerril Barrio (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – Of course, Your Honor. Thank you very much for your question. Yes, I think it's time we did legislation, a resolution on the rights of victims of terrorism. It will never be the same as a person who shoots from behind as the one who has suffered it. And in this Parliament we are talking not only about Islamic terrorism, but also about ETA terrorism, because murderers and terrorists come and want to equate themselves to their victims. Never! And that's because there's a lack of clarity of ideas. Not for his part or mine, we have it very clear, but there are many who don't. Therefore, we need to clarify this: there has to be legislation because the victims of terrorism are representatives of the whole society.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Unfortunately, these opportunities are increasing to commemorate the innocent victims of terrorist attacks. I find that very threatening! I fear that it will not be the last time, but that these things will want to come back again and again. We can only hope that we can increase these intervals. This enemy that threatens us is a terrible enemy. He is concerned with our civilisation, with freedom, with the freedom of individuals, with freedom of religion, with freedom of expression, how we want to live our lives.  We must fight this enemy by all necessary means: with wisdom, with determination and proactive. We have to do de-radicalisation work, we have to go into the milieus, we have to dry up these biotopes, and we have to find the reasons why it drives people into the clutches of these terrorists. We must win this fight!

name: Timothy Kirkhope (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I agree with what has been said about the horrific attacks which took place in Tunisia. That brings into sharp focus the vulnerability people face all over the world against an enemy fixed on the idea of senseless terror and destruction. Attacks in Australia, historically the UK, France and Tunisia show that we are vulnerable everywhere. It is not scaremongering. It is a reality. What is clear is that the EU cannot operate in a vacuum. This threat extends beyond our borders. Whilst it is essential we cooperate with each other in Europe, it is vital also that we cooperate with third countries to provide global security, and of course we need an effective strategy to counter radicalisation and exchange information. Tunisia, like every other country in Europe, cannot be expected to respond to this threat on its own, and it needs our help. We need a global and a unified strategy for the fight against terrorism and against ISIS.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the fight against Islamist terrorism will mark the 21st century. I say this with sorrow — also, fondly for the victims — but with determination, because I would like to point out that we are obliged to attack their legitimacy effectively. Speech and concepts are as important as judicial or police combat. That society is not cowering is also key. There are no totally secure borders in the globalized world and, as we are going to have to engage around the world defending every citizen who wants to be free, it is best to be clear about it now. Commissioner, leading society requires safe leaders, courageous leaders and, as Europeans, as well as a Security Agenda , which we also need it , we have no choice but to consolidate democracies outside Europe. The current geostrategic situation—alliances with leaders who are not always democratic—will surely cease to be effective in the very short term. Therefore, a lot of encouragement, and it has all our support, because it is absolutely vital for all of us.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our enemy cannot be identified. It plays in troops all over the world; it is unpredictable, it has no face, it has no precise location; circumvents space-time coordinates. It has crept into our routine; hits beaches, factories, on the street as we go to work and fuels anguish. Our enemy does not defend a land, treasure or family. Our enemy defends a concept: the misconception that religion dominates every aspect of human life and infidels must be punished. It does not matter to determine to what extent the recent attacks in France, Tunisia, Somalia and Kuwait have been coordinated. Now that the threats are continuing to proliferate, we must channel our energies into the implementation of concrete and urgent initiatives. It's not easy, I'm perfectly aware of that. But I have the impression that when it comes to putting into practice actions to counter the jihadist terror strategy, we get bogged down in political and often swampy discussions. So, fight against radicalisation and propaganda and the de-underminement of terror financing strategies. We need to talk about this much more often and find concrete answers together. I will end, in the words of the Nobel Prize winner, Adolfo Perez Esquivel, who said that the only hope for defeating terrorism lies in observing democratic rules: more democracy and freedom for these countries.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is born and is formed as a force for peace and an obstacle force for terror, hatred and destruction within and outside its borders. The challenges we are facing seriously jeopardise our cohesion, and this is also the fault of the Member States and those that make choices with regard to countries outside the European Union and their foreign policy. On the other hand, we have a duty to relaunch the joint action of the whole Of the European Union. We must optimise our expenditure on security, in order to promote cooperation and the exchange of information. We must implement policies for social inclusion and, finally, we must fight above all hatred, the hatred that has caused the tragedies that have taken place in recent weeks in France, Tunisia, Kuwait and Niger.  The European Union must get out of the logic of monitoring and punishing. We have this task, we have a duty to respect first of all the fundamental freedoms of women and men from states that are not part of the European Union, and then we must be clear about the notion that security cannot be a reason for the suspension of democracy.  That is why I believe it is important to ask this Parliament to support as actively as possible the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, and above all her secular breakthrough, because this may be the best way to combat terrorism.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Recently, we have seen with horror terrorist attacks, carried out in a bestial way, but also organized. The Leader of the Islamic State, admitting to these attacks, said al-Qaida was too soft and pacifist. Without pardon, it murders mainly Christians, but also random tourists, such as in Tunisia, where nearly 40 people were killed, and in France and other places where victims are even cut off. Islamic State militants are demonstrating their strength and, in the face of their determination, the European Union is helpless. Unfortunately, this is the result of an earlier EU policy which, instead of supporting the United States in the fight against terrorism, has weakened this fight by setting up bizarre committees of inquiry, including here in the European Parliament, which reveal the mechanisms for combating terrorism. An idiotic spiral of tracking down special services officers fighting terrorists has been sparked, and the latter have been overly protected by "plush" human rights standards. A decisive change to this erroneous policy will be the first step towards counter-terrorism for the benefit and security of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, thank you so much for your effort to soak Romanian. I am very impressed. Mr President, Commissioner, the evolution of the terrorist phenomenon has, over the last fifteen years, seen considerable changes, both in terms of organisational structure and objectives, methods of action, recruitment and propaganda.  The main and common goal of all terrorists remains to undermine democratic values, human rights and societal structure. Terrorist activity is, in this context, a common, horizontal and cross-border threat with a growing dynamic.  Since the beginning of 2015 alone, there have been 138 terrorist attacks, six of which in July. Those who led the attacks include not only known terrorist organizations such as Isis, Boko Haram, Al-Shabaab or Taliban terrorist cells, but also the so-called "solo terrorists" or Lone Wolf terrorist, acting on their own initiative.  Recent attacks in Egypt, Tunisia, Libya, Yemen, Nigeria, Mali, Kenya, Syria, Somalia, Kuwait targeted not only crowded, touristic places with minimal security devices, which would have diminished the attractiveness of terrorist purposes but also targeted law enforcement with a view to destabilizing regions, states, a region of great proportions, MENA, as well as weakening the confidence of the local population and the international community in the state's competence to control the phenomenon.  However, the terrorist threat does not stop at the EU's borders, and the June attacks in Austria and France, as well as the forecast of imminent attacks in Member States, recall this fact.  In this context, I would like to stress the importance of increasing synergy among the Member States of the European Union in order to deal with this threat, as well as the full and effective implementation of the strategic anti-terrorist objective as set out in the EU Security Strategy, the elements agreed by the February Council and the priorities reiterated by the June Council.  I also support the High Representative's initiative to prepare a global EU security strategy for 2016.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, security in Europe and its wider neighbourhood is being challenged every day. The recent terrorist attacks by ISIL demand our full attention. Once more, we see the terrorists have no mercy. They do not discriminate; they are modern bandits who kill Muslims and non-Muslims alike. In the last few weeks they have killed tourists in Tunisia, Egyptian soldiers in the Sinai, Pakistani bus travellers in Karachi, worshippers during prayer in Kuwait, and beheaded one person in France. The death numbers are more than statistics, they are reminders that the fight against extremism, globally and here in Europe, is far from over. There is also good news: the Muslim world is increasingly taking a firm stance against extremism falsely conducted in the name of Islam. The EU should support such efforts by partner governments as well as ordinary citizens. However, a long-term solution depends on us solving the underlying root causes. Primarily, we must achieve a comprehensive, just and enduring Middle East peace. The EU must win the war against extremism right here in Europe. A recent public opinion poll suggests that 46% of Britons believe Muslims do not share British values. This is devastating. Not only is it not true, it has also fuelled the extremist narrative. EU Member States must increase cooperation in pre-empting further radicalisation of our citizens. We must work within communities, addressing questions of integration and identity, as well as ensuring that there is justice and that the social and economic well-being of all Europeans are adequately met. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have a question about the increasing immigration of people from the southern Mediterranean to Europe. Do you not think that this immigration should be restricted so that the terrorist threat that exists among these people is not transferred to Europe as well?

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think this is the best answer to this problem. What we need to do is look at the root causes of why so many people, who have their own home, their own families and their own society, are forced to leave. We need to bring about more stability and more equality in the world. It is only by tackling these issues that we will ultimately deal with the problem, not by attacking the refugees. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: question ("blue card"). "We hear in here that everyone has to do something – most people say that in here. But what do you do? Yes, concrete proposals are not made on how to stop this. At least I don't think so. In my country, Sweden, for example, foreign fighters are given priority in the labour market, rehabilitation and so on.  Why not impose tougher penalties? We can go after Resolution 2178 and, for example, take away their citizenship so that they will never enter Europe again. Answer that!

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – The answer is straightforward. Those who commit crime must do their time. Those who are innocent should not be being punished. What we need to do is make sure we have foreign policies where we can make sure that those who are actually committing these offences do not have that opportunity. But, at the same time, we need to make sure that hard-working people are given equal rights and the opportunity to work hard.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, Europe, unfortunately, has been experiencing a wave of terrorist attacks lately. Dozens of people have lost their lives. The comrades and companions of the terrorists of the Islamic Caliphate also introduce terror into our homelands. Unfortunately, with the fanaticism that distinguishes them and the inability of Europeans to give a decisive answer, these attacks will increase dramatically in the future. Golden Dawn has a clear position against terrorism. We need to find a way to shield ourselves from the invaders. We must give a strong response to these cowardly acts.  I can and am entitled to speak with rage and pain. A year and a half ago, when cowardly and dishonest, left-wing terrorists murdered my son, Giorgos Foudoulis, and his friend Manolis Kapelonis, two young children, in front of our offices, there was no reaction from all those who present themselves so sensitive today. I ask again today for your support so that 1 November can be declared a pan-European day against terrorism. I would like Parliament to be as sensitive to all terrorist attacks, wherever they come from. No one in the political system at the time condemned the attacks. No one was interested in finding the killers. Some people didn't bother, because that's how it was politically-motivated. That's something that makes me wonder: Are we better than terrorists or are we just hiding behind a fake mask?

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: "It is the responsibility and responsibility of all of us to protect the lives, dignity and fundamental rights of people anywhere in the world. The attacks we have seen in recent times are frightening in their reality and symbolism, because they send a message that any one of us, anywhere in the world, can become a victim. There is no plausible explanation for such actions, so we must prevent them by all means. One of our tasks is to do this: to come together, to find partners in the world, as has been said by the Commissioner. We need to gather the tools we have, we need trained, effective law enforcement for safety and our values.  We must prevent the radicalisation of young people who have grown up in our normal society before our eyes. At the same time, allow me to speak of innocent victims who are persecuted for their faith, I am thinking here of christians, often women, children who are now victims of ISIS atrocities. They're the martyrs of our century. In addition to human casualties, we must speak of the destruction of priceless monuments thousands of years old in regions known as the cradle of our civilisation . This will make our entire humanity less.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, due to the terrorist attacks, the world and Europe face a very serious danger. I strongly believe this global threat should be tackled globally. At European level we should take all possible measures to maintain the security and safety of our citizens and play a supportive role in building a cross-border response to this threat. Terrorism aims at undermining our societies and our way of life. It is a direct attack on the core values of the European Union – democracy, the rule of law, respect for fundamental rights of the citizen and unity in diversity – and a threat to the security, peace, stability and prosperity that European integration has given or is trying to give its citizens. I strongly believe that preventing and combating terrorism requires ensuring that security, human rights and law enforcement are complementary and that European foreign and security policies tackle terrorist threats around the world and their causes.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, the terrorist attacks carried out in France, Tunisia and Kuwait on 26 June are a clear sign that the once external threat to Europe has definitely become internal today. Terrorists are very effective in using our weaknesses and lukewarm approach towards Islamic extremists imported into Europe, but also those raised on our soil in hatred of Western values. Today, Europe only shyly emphasizes its Christian roots as if it were ashamed of its identity, and peoples and states without identity are an easy target for those who want to force another identity on us. With our disorientation and indecision, we actually attract and encourage such. I think it is high time to say clearly that extremists, that is, people who join together to harm others, have no rights in the European Union and that each of them has also chosen by their life choices and that there is no place for him in Europe.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Colleagues, south of our borders, the Arab world is facing unprecedented conflicts leading to the rise of terrorism. From Libya to Syria, countries are literally disappearing. From Paris to Sousse, we are all victims of the brutality of terrorists. We are all targets - Europeans, Arabs, Christians and Muslims.  Terrorism is the greatest threat to our security and it must be neutralised. We must mobilise all available resources in the name of restoring stability and security at all conflict points.  The challenges facing today's Europe oblige it to make an important choice, I would even define it as strategic: to respond to the threats of terrorism. We need not self-closure and isolation, but more democracy and tolerance as guarantees of a truly multicultural society.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the recent tragic terrorist attacks in various countries of the world must lead us to reflect further. We talk about terrorism at almost every plenary session.  In fact, there are always two paths that we can pursue at the moment. On the one hand, we could follow the avoidance of closing in on ourselves, precisely deluding ourselves that we can guarantee our security simply by spending more on weapons, intelligence, security. It may be useful, but I fear that we would end up like that child who wanted to empty the sea water with a shell. We may also be tempted to support authoritarian regimes in the hope that they will solve the problem in the Arab world. But that would be a mistake that we would pay for over time, because territorial conflicts would follow even further. Instead, we can tackle the problem directly, pushing for moderate Islam in Europe and the Islamic world to become our greatest ally, the only one that can truly isolate terrorism, and this can only be done if it participates in political life.  We must therefore review our approach in order to help these governments fight against pockets of poverty, because these are the real basin in which they unequivocally fish for terrorism.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks to the Members for having given me the opportunity today to react to the recent attacks and to present our response to the threats posed by terrorism. This is – and unfortunately will be for a long time – a crucial issue for our citizens. I am really grateful to you for having put this point on the agenda of this week’s plenary. In the past six months, this Commission has managed to put forward and implement a set of concrete actions to counter this threat. We need to join our efforts to ensure that there will be a swift and continued implementation of these proposals in full respect of the rule of law and fundamental rights. I took note of your remarks. Some of you have mentioned the Western Balkans. Let me assure you that, in matters of security too, the Western Balkans are key partners. Stability in this region is crucial. We are implementing targeted actions with the Western Balkans on radicalisation and firearms cooperation with Europol. Many of you focused – as is normal – on Tunisia. During my introductory remarks I made special reference to Tunisia. They are partners and they have our full support. In the framework of the EU European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) review, we will develop – and will keep developing – targeted policies with Tunisia. We are working on it together with Mrs Mogherini and Commissioner Hahn and we have already started producing results. I am sure that more will be said on this in the next debate. Let me reaffirm my strong commitment to working hand in hand with Parliament – and the Council, of course – on this matter. I really count on your support.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I think we all agree, there is an urgent need. We must intensify our cooperation in the various areas and effectively take the necessary repressive and preventive measures. There is also a need for a systematic and coordinated approach. But I would also like to say that we must not fall into stigma, exclusion, xenophobia or Islamophobia, because we would play the game of the sponsors of terrorism. We must continue to support the third countries with which we are engaged in the fight against terrorism, including the development of coordinated action plans. Here too, as the Commissioner has just said, you will be edising a debate on neighbourhood policy and on countries such as Tunisia, which are particularly vulnerable and must be actively supported. The work of the recently created Internet Content Reporting Unit and the European Counter-Terrorism Centre are also very useful and need to be developed.  Let me quote this last point in the last place: we will do everything we can to get agreement on the European Union's PNR directive during our Presidency. Please know that the Presidency wants to work closely with this Parliament on this very sensitive and important subject and we strongly count on your active support.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. Three terrorist attacks took place on 26 June in Tunisia, Kuwait and France in which at least sixty-five people were killed. All three attacks relate to the Islamic State, which continues to expand. On a proposal from the Socialist Group, tunisia's case has been brought to plenary. A trained student in Libya shot clients at two hotels in the city of Susa. Previously, in March, there was another attack on the Bard Museum in the Tunisian capital, in which nineteen people were killed. The economic consequences of these attacks are lethal to tourism, which is the main industry in Tunisia and other Mediterranean countries, where their hopes for economic recovery are based. I would like to underline the EU's special link with Tunisia and European support for democracy in Tunisia. The chain of attacks in Tunisia, France, Kuwait and Egypt shows that no country can ignore the terrorist challenge that seeks to destabilize our societies through fear, mistrust and prejudice. Europe and the Arab world are affected. You have to be together to fight violence and sectarianism. The response to terrorists must be more unity, a truly global alliance.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. We have said to each other several times: no state, no region is protected from the danger of terrorism. We have said this several times because all too often we have found ourselves in this Chamber listing the dead, commemorating the victims of attacks by the atrocious violence against innocents. We are all under attack, but unfortunately everyone is alone in trying to contain the danger. The Tunisian Prime Minister today announced the start of work on the construction of a new wall, after the one decided by Hungary against immigrants. Here, walls are raised and this is a defeat for everyone. As well as a desperate and futile attempt to denounce the weakness of all of us. No one is exempt. The fight against terrorism does not yet seem to be well coordinated, we do not see the joint efforts so announced. Declarations, what are not better known as 'political and military decision-making procedures', are no longer enough. We promote new awareness-raising debates here, they will foster dialogue between peoples and awareness. Here are the weapons we have.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. Three terrorist attacks took place in Tunisia, Kuwait and France on 26 June, killing at least sixty-five people. All three attacks relate to the Islamic State (IS), which continues to expand. On the proposal of our Group of Socialists and Democrats, the case of Tunisia has been singled out in plenary. There, a trained student in Libya shot clients from two hotels, one owned by the Spanish chain Riu, in the city of Susa. In March there was already an attack on the Bard Museum in the Tunisian capital. It underlines the EU's special link with Tunisia and European support for democracy in Tunisia. The economic consequences of the attacks are lethal. Tourism is the main industry in Tunisia and other Mediterranean countries, and the main hope for its economic recovery. The chain of attacks in Tunisia, France, Kuwait and Egypt shows that no country or region can ignore the terrorist challenge that wants to destabilize our societies through fear, mistrust and prejudice. Europe and the Arab world are affected. You have to be together to fight violence and sectarianism. The response to terrorists must be more unity, a truly global alliance.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Terrorism has no borders. The recent attacks on Tunisia and France demonstrate this once again. The best way to combat this complex and global phenomenon is through international cooperation, which implies that the European Union can speak with one voice. This struggle must be placed in the field of ideas. To weaken terrorist networks, our best weapons are what they fear most: education and the development of critical thinking. These groups have demonstrated that they have mastered the new communication strategies offered by the internet and social networks. States must therefore first use new technologies to adapt their responses and thus effectively disseminate counter-arguments in the face of terrorist ideas. In order to fight terrorism effectively, it is also essential to devote more resources to preventing radicalisation, while leading to an agreement on the European NNP, to prevent European fighters from joining the Islamic State group. This struggle must be fought in the preservation of our democracies, our values and our freedoms, otherwise it will enshrine the victory of those we fight.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – The recent escalation in the number of terrorist attacks, both on European soil and outside Europe, is certainly a cause for concern. We should not forget the victims and their families, and we should stand up for them.  However, we should not forget another issue which has remained unresolved for over half a year now. The victim in this case is still alive and could be saved by a relatively simple action. I am talking about the Estonian police officer Eston Kohver who was illegally kidnapped from Estonian soil by Russian state agents. In clear breach of international law he remains illegally detained in a Russian prison. This attack was clearly politically motivated as it came shortly after President Obama visited Estonia and pledged his continuing support for ʽfree and independent and democratic Baltic nationsʼ. Ceterum censeo the European Union cannot bend to such reprisals and illegitimate demonstrations of force, and therefore should unanimously demand the immediate release of Mr Kohver.

text: in writing. Three terrorist attacks took place in Tunisia, Kuwait and France on 26 June, killing at least sixty-five people. All three attacks relate to the Islamic State (IS), which continues to expand. On the proposal of our Group of Socialists and Democrats, the case of Tunisia has been singled out in plenary. name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU support for Tunisia (2015/2765(RSP))

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, we were all horrified by the images of tourists slaughtered in such a cowardly manner on the beach in Sousse. This was an attack that aimed to sow fear and division. We stand together with Tunisia so that the terrorists do not succeed. This was an attack on people, first and foremost, and our sympathy lies with the families and friends of the victims and the Tunisian people. It was also, however, an attack on Tunisia’s brave choice for democracy, targeting the tourism industry, which is the backbone of Tunisia’s economy and which was already facing enormous challenges. The democratic transition accomplished by Tunisia since 2011 is unique and, as recognised by the Tunisians themselves, fragile as a result of the remaining political and socio-economic challenges still facing the country. Courageous reforms are still necessary to consolidate the country’s democratic constitution and to meet the social and economic difficulties of the country, which primarily affect Tunisia’s youth. The European Union has supported Tunisia’s efforts since 2011 and will continue to do so as the government’s major source of external support. I sincerely hope that Europeans will continue to visit Tunisia and invest in the country. It is our shared responsibility to ensure that they can continue to do so safely and securely. The attacks in Sousse and at the Bardo Museum were not the first signs of the enormous security challenges facing Tunisia. Since the revolution the European Union has been engaged with the country’s authorities in a dialogue about a comprehensive reform of the Tunisian security sector in order to ensure that its security institutions can more efficiently provide security to its citizens, in full respect for human rights and international norms, as guaranteed by the new constitution. Despite the difficulties inherent in developing cooperation programmes on such a sensitive topic, the current political context of an elected government committed to reform allows us to launch an ambitious programme of support for the sector. We will speed up as fast as possible the implementation of this programme. As part of this wide-ranging reform, the fight against terrorism will be a major element, in particular to reinforce the confidence of the country’s citizens in its security institutions. However, we wish to go even further. Along with the EU’s counter-terrorism coordinator, Gilles de Kerchove, the Commission and the European External Action Service are currently identifying opportunities to act rapidly with all available instruments in order to assist Tunisia in strengthening its counter-terrorism strategy, particularly as regards counter-radicalisation, and reinforcing judicial and security mechanisms.
