High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini sent a letter to the Prime Minister of Tunisia in May with a number of concrete proposals. I also wrote to the Minister for Development, Investment and International Cooperation immediately after the Sousse attack to assure him of the EU’s steadfast support and to inform him that we intend to accelerate the delivery of certain tranches of support that originally would have been implemented later this year. As I have already said, the Tunisian example is a target for terrorists because it is a success. If there is a cause in the world which requires the European Union to be united in its support, it is with this country, with its democratic pluralistic government and a society that is committed to the protection of democratic freedoms, pluralism and the rights of women. We need coherent mobilisation of all the resources available to us to defend and strengthen Tunisia’s transition to democracy. This means that all of the European institutions and our Member States must undertake actions that demonstrate our common resolve. Our financial assistance is already substantial: EUR 187 million in bilateral assistance for 2015 alone. However, I intend to explore all avenues in order to reinforce this effort. Our macro-financial assistance is currently EUR 300 million and could be increased over the next few years. That said, Tunisia is a country in a particularly unstable region where our potential value added is commensurate with the size of the country and the crucial period of change the country is going through. We need to ensure that our contributions can be appropriately absorbed and remember that providing money for a problem will not, by itself, solve it. Our support to Tunisia is therefore of prime strategic importance to the European Union as a whole and, as such, requires speed and flexibility in some cases, but also careful planning. Tunisia has consistently been the main beneficiary of the so-called umbrella funds, which are intended to supplement the financial allocations of selected partners on the basis of their progress towards deep and sustainable democracy. This year, in recognition of Tunisia’s great strides in the implementation of agreed reform objectives, we are proposing an additional amount of around EUR 70 million in order to address all these positive outcomes so far, but also in the light of recent events we are now examining how best to employ these funds to boost the number of priority initiatives. Much remains to be done in order to consolidate Tunisia’s young democracy, including integration of the institutions provided for by the country’s constitution, reforms in the judicial and security sectors and launching the process of administrative decentralisation. Tunisia’s socio- economic transition demands considerable reforms and integration of a favourable climate for investment, growth and employment. Facing all these challenges will require efforts spread over many years, and in all these sectors the European Union has the capacity and expertise to provide support for Tunisia's efforts. We can also play a central role in enriching the privileged partnership that we have established with Tunisia. Tunisia wishes to take advantage of the potential offered by our Community policies, which can provide additional opportunities for our partner countries. In areas such as education, youth and university exchanges, innovation and research or agriculture, which is a vital sector for the country, together with my fellow Commissioners we are exploring opportunities for additional actions, including by placing an emphasis on measures that lead to the creation of jobs. Faced with threats such as the threat of terrorism which play on fear and prejudice, our response should be to reinforce the links which bind our peoples and our economies. We should be ambitious and creative in order to ensure that we make a real difference in our support for the people of Tunisia.

name: Michael Gahler
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has I would like to express my sincere thanks for your presentation and also for the work that we, as the European Union, as the Commission are doing there in Tunisia. I would also like to begin by expressing my horror at the attacks in Sousse, but also in the Bardo Museum, and expressing my deepest sympathy to all the families. I believe that we really have every reason to support this young democracy with all the forces at our disposal, and we are doing so, as you have explained. I myself was allowed to do my work there as Chief Observer of the EU back in 2011 and was there with the European Parliament. I see some colleagues who were also present at the second democratic elections. We have seen that the Tunisians want this democracy. There were no extremists competing in these elections, even though there was a very low threshold to stand in elections. They did not vote. The Tunisians do not want extremism and we should support them in this endeavour. You mentioned a number of aspects there. It would be important to me that we perhaps examine an additional aspect, and here I would ask you perhaps to include this with Mrs Mogherini: as you know, we have a suspended EU Border Assistance Mission between Tunisia and Libya. Somehow she has now moved to the Tunisian side and is waiting for better days.  I think it would be really essential if we could see whether we could set up an EU-CSDP mission on the border with the Tunisians there on the Tunisian side in order to stop the influx of terrorists and other elements. The perpetrator of Sousse has been trained in Libya, as have those who attacked the Bardo Museum. That would perhaps be something we can actually provide in this important area. I would ask you to check whether this would be possible.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, on behalf of my own group and on behalf of my group, I would like to express my sincere condolences to the families of the victims, to the government and to all the Tunisian people for the terrorist attacks. These attacks attempt to destroy the heroic struggle of the Tunisian people for freedom and dignity; they are trying to convert tunisia, the greatest example, perhaps the only successful example, of the so-called Arab Spring, into a non-state, won by the armed terrorist and extremist organisation.  We cannot allow it. The Tunisian people do not deserve it and we must protect stability, Tunisian democracy and the fragile process of political transition. That is why I am asking you, Commissioner, and the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, to make a strong, political, institutional and moral commitment. The European Union is on the front line! But do so not only with the solemnity and authority that is its competence, but also with concreteness.  Our proposal is a 'Marshall Plan' for Tunisia. Tunisia has been hit at the heart of the nerve in the nerve-wracking sector of its economy: the tourism sector, which is a key component. We must help them in practice because the relationship between the European Union and the Mediterranean is a fundamental point, a successful point of democratic transformation of those societies. We cannot give it to the terrorists. We cannot give it to the fundamentalists. We cannot give up our Euro-Mediterranean strategic perspective. That is the thrust of our proposal for a Marshall Plan.  The Socialist and Democratic Group is asking you and Federica Mogherini to commit themselves to this great proposal and implementation.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the terrorist attack against Tunisia saw the tragic loss of 39 lives, 30 of whom were my fellow British citizens, and many possibly even constituents; my condolences go to all their families and friends. This atrocity comes just a few months after a similar attack on the Bardo National Museum in Tunis, both committed by Jihadi extremists and both targeting areas with high concentrations of Western tourists. This attack also reminds us of the support that traditionally secular Tunisia now vitally needs. As the country that was the home of the Arab Spring and indeed its most successful manifestation – probably why it is now a target – the overthrow of long-time dictator Ben Ali in 2011 ushered in the hope for multiparty democracy in a western style. The EU and its Member States now need to support the inclusive government of Habib Essid, allowing Tunisia to flourish as a secular modern and model state for North Africa and the wider Middle East. With tourism accounting for 10% of Tunisian GDP, such attacks are extremely damaging to the country’s prosperity and, with a very young population, a stable economy is vital to ensuring political stability and preventing radicalisation and potential Islamist terrorism in the future.

name: Marielle de Sarnez
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Commissioner, we are all saying the same thing and that is natural. Basically, if the terrorists have hit Tunisia twice in three months - at the Bardo Museum and in Sousse - it is because the young Tunisian democracy is doing well and the democratic transition is going well. That is what the terrorists are trying to undermine.  Of course, this implies that our European Union is present alongside Tunisians and alongside Tunisia in an even more important way than in the past. We have to be there in terms of security, as you said, in terms of management, for example, and border control with Libya. This is a no-brainer. We need to be there on the issue of migration flows. We need to manage with them the flows of Tunisian and European migration. We must, of course, also be present on an economic level.  You talked about unlocking funds and giving what we had to give. We also need to contribute to the creation of long-term projects. We are going to enter into a partnership agreement because we are going to develop trade relations. It is very important that this is done for the benefit of Tunisia, by preserving sectors that are vital to it, such as certain sectors of services or agriculture.  In any case, it is absolutely clear that our Parliament is telling you that Europe must respond here. It must be on the side of Tunisia and the Tunisians. This is not negotiable for us.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, horror has once again struck tunisia, in Sousse, three months after the Bardo attack. I join in the condolences already expressed.  The target of tourist spots is emblematic in this small country of 10 million inhabitants for which tourism is a real lung: 14% of the national employment depends on it. It is also emblematic, because Tunisia, where the Arab Spring began, has continued its democratic transition at all costs. Terrorists want to defeat it at all costs. They don't hit randomly. Our solidarity should therefore be unwavering. This is far from the case! Tunisia needs our help in the fight against terrorism, but making sure not to question the fragile democratic benefits of the revolution and above all by massively supporting its economy to give opportunities to young people. So far, Tunisia has received too little, even so-called aid served mainly in the form of loans that have only increased its debt. The social crisis is deepening, fuelling despair. The borders remain closed. It is time to be up to the task, to put to rest, on new bases, the negotiation of agreements on both free trade and mobility.  We need to address the issue of debt restructuring, or why not? e its moratorium, develop regional cooperation for the benefit of the poorest regions, and establish a real partnership in the interest of the Tunisian people. The reforms demanded cannot be guided by ever more liberalisation for the benefit of European companies first. So yes, we have to help Tunisia, it must be a priority, there is an urgency.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to show my condolences, of course, to the victims of these brutal attacks in Tunisia. A few months ago I participated in the European Parliament's election observation mission in Tunisia with one of the Members who are speaking at this session today. I was able to observe in detail, without any interference, a clean and transparent electoral process and a social environment full of hope. The mission held many meetings with various civil society groups and political representatives and candidates, including the now President, Beyi Caid Essebsi. We were reminded that the "Arab Spring" is actually a conglomerate of very different situations, and that, if there was a genuine "spring", it was Tunisian, the only country where a totalitarian regime was defeated with peace and where a successful democratic rupture has occurred. But at the same time as they told us that, they also discreetly told us that Tunisians had felt alone, alone in the midst of a very conflicted region, with more than a million Libyan refugees and with pressure from terrorist groups, which unfortunately has either. And what has Europe done so far? The amount of money he has given Tunisia to contribute to its growth is ridiculous. Tunisia urgently needs our security support, it is clear; political, it is clear; but above all, economically, in order to achieve a stable situation that allows young people, one of the sectors most affected by terrorist realities, to have hope for the future. Tunisia is the only Maghreb country that can now become a full democracy and be our preferred ally on that southern border, the Mediterranean, to which Europe looks less than it should. We need, Commissioner, a formal, constant and clear commitment to Tunisia, because the peace of mind of your future is the tranquility of ours.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 21 people died in the Bard, 38 dead in Port el Kantaoui, near Sousse, a state of emergency in Tunisia. The aim of these terrorist attacks is, of course, to bring tourism, one of the key sectors of the economy, to its knees, as much as 10 % of GDP, given that the country has no appreciable hydrocarbon resources. Why this relentlessness? The very simple reason: Tunisia is a unicum in today's Arab world, the only real democratic transition that is being fully, if laboriously, taking place in a present of permanent instability in Syria as well as in Libya. A transition that frightens many, terrorists, of course, but also authoritarian Arab regimes, because it fully demonstrates the compatibility between Islam and democracy. It is an uncomfortable example: that is why Tunisia has so many enemies. But Tunisia is also many Tunis: it is its face on the coasts, more developed, more westernized, more linked precisely to tourism and the productive sectors – clearly afflicted there too by unemployment even for graduates and graduates – to a poor hinterland, full of poverty, which is the main basin of those 3 000 or 4 000 foreign fighters.  I strongly insisted in the AFET Committee on having a specific report on this country, because I believe that it has a value that goes far, far beyond its demographic size, and I agree with what President Pittella said in saying that we need a Marshall Plan: we cannot limit ourselves to areas, however important, such as cooperation on migration, security and security. , on circular migrations. They are fundamental, yes, but they must be given a political, economic and social plan, a broader plan. Our expertise is crucial, but if we do not also address the problem of debt relief, we will not live up to what Tunisia deserves today. If we fail, it will once again plunge into the darkness of an authoritarian regime or those of extremism, risking dragging the Maghreb with it as well.  The Tunisian people, on the other hand, have the clear will to carry out the jasmine revolution to the full: all the political forces we met in the observation mission want it, because they believe in democracy. If they finally break those chains, it is up to us too: let us not leave them alone!

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, our thoughts are of course with the victims of the recent attacks in Tunisia. I would like to welcome the decisions taken by Tunisian President Essebsi, who, even before declaring a state of emergency last Saturday, closed no less than 80 Salafist mosques. May our governments follow his example! Since the 2011 revolution, the radical preaching banned by Ben Ali has resumed, mainly targeting the Code of Personal Status which, imposed by Bourguiba and then reinforced by Ben Ali, allows Tunisian women to be full citizens. More generally, beyond the terrible attacks that hit it on 18 March and 26 June, it should be remembered that Tunisia is the country that today provides the largest contingent of jihadists to the Islamist factions currently raging in Syria, Iraq and Libya.  In Algeria, at the time of the hostage-taking of In Amenas, the terrorist commando numbered at least 11 Tunisians and it is still Tunisian citizens who form the core of the Islamic State in Libya. In Tunisia itself, since 2012, Islamists have been holding the scrub in the Mount Chaambi region. However, despite the recovery of the Tunisian state, the dismantling of its security apparatus does not bode well. Meanwhile, Ennahdha is positioning itself as a remedy. The Islamist party has certainly experienced a slight electoral ebb, but Rached Ghannouchi and his family remain in ambush. While observing the parliamentary elections last October, I was able to speak with The main political leaders of Tunisia. Ennahdha has skilfully anticipated its decline and, as part of a long-term strategy, this Islamist party continues its penetration of the entire social fabric, following the model of the Muslim Brotherhood. The maintenance of secularism in Tunisia is therefore more precarious than ever. European politicians have shown great carelessness in celebrating the impeachment of Ben Ali, even though secular Arab regimes are the only ones able to contain the rise of Islamism.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too will start by expressing my solidarity and my sympathy for the Tunisian people and passing on my condolences to the very many families affected by the series of tragic events and terrorist attacks. Tunisia is the best example of democratic transition after the Arab Spring, but it is for this same reason that it is the biggest target for those who have interests in destabilising it and with it, the proof that the values of democracy and Islam are fully compatible. Tunisia desperately needs the support of the EU to achieve its objectives in development and stability and it needs EU assistance even more today, after the terrorist attacks, which specifically targeted foreign tourists to undermine the tourism industry in a key period of the year. I mean massive, effective, economic, financial and technical assistance to Tunisia, in line with my colleague and friend Gianni Pittella, who mentioned the possibility of a special programme for Tunisia. Helping Tunisia also means that the EU benefits, because a stable, democratic and growing Tunisia will be the best example of what the countries of the region can achieve and aspire to. Reforms have already started. The country has a new constitution but it is still a young and small reality. Here I call on the Commissioner, and the High Representative as well, to help Tunisia technically in capacity building and counterterrorism intelligence and equally to consider the possibility of sending back Ben Ali’s assets, which are now disseminated among several EU Member States banks’ and financial systems.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, like any sensible person I was shocked and appalled by the cowardly terrorist attack on tourists in Tunisia. My sympathy goes to the victims and their families and loved ones. It reminds us that domestic and foreign policy cannot always be decoupled and that we live in a mutually-dependent world. But despite our grief at these horrible attacks, we must not forget – and work harder to ensure – that Tunisia is, and remains, a success story of how transition from dictatorship can lead to an open society. Tunisians who took to the street five years ago, asking for a more just and democratic society, voiced essential values as their aspirations. Transition is never easy; but those calls by young people sick of the injustices, the abuse of power and corruption, and the lack of opportunities and freedoms must not – and will not – be forgotten. The next generation deserves to find in Europe a reliable and committed partner in helping support further development, in building a free society, diverse and democratic, the complete opposite of the nihilistic and misguided dogma of political Islam advanced through violence. I personally do not like to think in terms of support for Tunisia. Let us work with Tunisians so they can build their own future with the EU as a partner. The announcements of negotiations on a trade agreement should fit into that picture and help create a freer society with opportunities for all Tunisians, especially the young generation.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over and above our outrage and condolences, we must say that the attack in Sousse, the second in a few months, had an important first effect: the entry into force of the state of emergency again.  We can consider this decision with a necessary decision, but it is good to know that this highlights two specific problems. The first concerns a still insecurity in the country, which can seriously destabilise Tunisia's future. The second is that the risk of a state of emergency will lead to a reduction in civil rights, and that is not good for democratic development and the consolidation of the transition process.  In this situation, therefore, we need a commitment to consolidate democracy, especially so that the country experiences a season of economic and social development and growth, the only way to defeat terrorism. Europe's role is crucial, as we have already indicated in several of Parliament's resolutions. Today, however, more needs to be done, much more. Tunisia needs more appropriate action.  You spoke, Mr Hahn, of an ambitious programme, but unfortunately we are not yet ambitious. We need the same financial support as we have given Ukraine. If we want to be close to Tunisia, we need to be aware of this new commitment and we must understand that the institutional and democratic consolidation of the Tunisian experiment also depends on the stability of the region and our security.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, firstly, my condolences to the victims and my absolute condemnation of the latest attacks in Tunisia. One would have to wonder what is going on in a country of Tunisia's cultural, political and religious tradition so that a young engineer is involved in the circle of jihadism, what is happening with the frustration of many young people in that country. It is clear that the security strategy is key, but it is also clear that it is not the only one. And it's not enough. If Tunisia does not grow, it will be impossible to consolidate the democratic process, and for Tunisia to grow it needs much more than statements in this House or than small funding programmes. If we really want to commit ourselves to a democracy at the gates of Europe, a democracy that can emerge triumphant from what we call, very badly called the 'Arab Springs', then we have to commit ourselves, Commissioner, really, thoroughly. And we're not doing it. The current President told us, when we visited Tunisia, that a swallow does not make spring. And, indeed, if we continue like this, we're going to wipe out the few swallows we have for now.

name: Gilles Pargneaux (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Tunisia is once again subject to horror with this act of terrorism that has struck it. We must reaffirm our message of solidarity with Tunisian women. At the same time, the debate must be an opportunity to ask what we can actually do to support our neighbour, Tunisia. I believe, Commissioner, that EUBAM Libya must first be allowed to return to Libya. This would, I believe, be a first step for Tunisia to no longer be the buffer state of the bankrupt state of Libya. Tunisia's destabilizing proximity is Tunisia's major problem. We must then finance Tunisia, even more strongly, as our colleague Panzeri has pointed out. In our new European Neighbourhood Policy, we must ensure that our funding is indeed much more important.  These are the two steps that we must follow, Commissioner, in order to make this act of solidarity, but also to act on tunisia's behalf.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the expansion of terrorist organisations in North Africa seeks, first of all, to sink democracy under construction in Tunisia. The cowardly massacres of the Bardo Museum and now on sousse beach, in which a Portuguese citizen died, show how the threats of terrorism, violent extremism and organized crime know no borders, interconnect and find recruits thanks to unemployment and social and economic exclusion that Europe itself, with recessive policies, unfortunately, makes tending in its neighbourhood. The European Union has a special responsibility to organise itself to fight the Islamic State and is not doing so effectively in Iraq and Syria. Closer, in Libya and Tunisia, Europe must act, first and by supporting Tunisia, its government out of democratic elections, economic development and job creation to give future to its young people, as well as in strengthening internal, maritime and border security.  Halting terrorist expansion also means that the European Union should open legal and safe channels for migrants and refugees, the only way not to strengthen the networks of traffickers who lend themselves to being used by terrorists, targeting European citizens today, sooner or later to strike European territory. Therefore, helping Tunisia to strengthen its economic and democratic security is also fundamental to the security of Europe itself.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I too rise to condemn the horrific terrorist attacks in Tunisia, which targeted mostly European citizens – many of them British, and some from my own constituency of the West Midlands. It brings back for us the pain of the 7/7 attacks, which we are commemorating in London. I would therefore like to offer my deepest condolences to the families of the victims, as well as to the Tunisian people, who have seen their country come under attack for the second time in just months. With a new constitution and successful parliamentary and presidential elections, Tunisia is an example for other countries in the region to follow. This is why we need to step up our engagement even further. Firstly, we need to gear up counter-terrorism and security dialogue with Tunisia and make sure that the state of emergency meets the high standards of international law. We also need to explore how we can offer support through the centres of excellence on terrorist prevention which are being set up by the Commission. Given that tourism is the second largest job creator, it is also crucial that we focus on specifying security measures for this sector for the future safety not just of Europeans, but of all others in Tunisia as well.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, my solidarity and sympathy, firstly, for all of Tunisia, but also for the families of the victims: European citizens, true, but also Tunisian citizens, both in the attack of the Bard Museum and in the attack of the Susa hotel, in which we have seen images of Tunisians protecting, at risk of their lives, European tourists. Because they are aware, more than ever, that tourism is a crucial source for their independence and autonomy, having no oil or other income like other neighbors. And that is known to the terrorists, who from the beginning have wanted and want to kill in Tunisia, the only example of a country, of the first modern democracy of the Arab world which, precisely, has been able to move towards reform in the most peaceful way within the region, and with a call to the European Union. They also challenge us to the fact that thousands of Tunisian young people, men and women, are now integrating jihad, when it was the young people who returned, in the winter of 2010 and spring 2011, to rebuild their country full of enthusiasm and life. What have we done in the European Union? Well, very little. We haven't done anything, really, compared to other regions we're helping massively. And in Tunisia, in that south, there is our security, our fundamental security, and there is also the need for so many young people to really do something definitive for democracy and for its future. That is why we require a shock programme, which this House has already called for, and which we are still waiting for, Commissioner.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the latest terrorist attack in Tunisia has shocked European societies, particularly Belgium and France. At the same time, however, we also had the decision to put Tunisia under a state of emergency, which creates particular problems for the democratic course of that country. The European Union must certainly have a strategy to tackle jihadist terrorism, and the first intervention the European Union must make concerns Tunisia's economic development. In other words, to hit the economic and social causes that have caused poverty and underdevelopment in the region. In order to do this, the issue of Tunisia's external debt must be addressed. Do you remember him, ladies and gentlemen, the famous Tunisian dictator, Ben Ali, who for twenty-three years ruled Tunisia, who was the IMF's favourite child, who when he fell from power found millions of euros in his house? The main issue, therefore, is to write off Tunisia's external debt to the IMF, France, Italy and other European countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, it's no coincidence Tunisia was chosen for another terrorist attack. And it was not by chance that tourism in Tunisia was chosen for one such criminal enterprise. Many victims died, their families died and of course we want to express great solidarity with them. But we must also express solidarity with the Tunisian people and we must, Mr. Commissioner, do everything we can to preserve the peace and stability of Tunisia in this situation. This requires various kinds of assistance, primarily institutional, in security terms, and all that we already do, but we must strengthen because Tunisia must remain as a model for all that bad that unfortunately happened after the "Arab Spring". Tunisia is a good example, let's preserve this example by joining forces and help the country as much as we can.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank you for all the contributions to the debate. Essentially, they also reflect our view. I can also assure you that Tunisia is paying the utmost attention. It did not take these terrible terrorist attacks. Incidentally, immediately after the last attack, I offered the Tunisian Government to come immediately, not only to express solidarity, but also to show European citizens that you can still come to Tunisia and spend your holidays. I have been asked not to come at the moment because, for understandable reasons, they are quite busy dealing with the current situation. But it should be said that we really stand by and support them. I also share your views, which are summarized under Marshall Plan. It is not just about Tunisia, other countries in the neighbourhood would also be potential candidates for such an updated 21st century Marshall Plan. I am in talks with our services, but also with the World Bank, which may have the most expertise here, that we are preparing a basic scheme here, so to speak, so that we can help as soon as possible. In Tunisia, I can say this, we have a massive presence, and we are also trying to scrape the money together. We will still have the opportunity to discuss the revision of the neighbourhood policy in the context of the Kukan report this evening. Our primary objective – and I believe we agree on this – is to ensure stability in the region. On the other hand, in order to ensure this stability, we must be institutionally and financially flexible, but also sufficiently flexible, in order to be able to react. I would like to make my request to you here – if we need this flexibility to ensure stability – that you support us in this regard. I take the security questions and suggestions with me. I know that High Representative and Vice-President Mogherini has taken action on the issue and, of course, here too, she sees and is looking for the possibilities that exist in connection with the situation in Libya. Finally, I would like to say to you– also at your request – that Tunisia will be on the agenda of the next Council of Foreign Ministers on 20 July and that there is an invitation to the Tunisian Foreign Minister, Mr Baccouche, to attend our lunch. This is the usual format, where there is actually intensive talk of tacheles, so to speak.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. Tunisia has suffered a horrific terrorist attack that claimed the lives of 38 tourists in the coastal city of Sousse. Much has been said about the Tunisian exception in the aftermath of the Arab Spring. However, despite political advances, the economy continues to deteriorate and most young people remain with no prospect of getting jobs and access to a better future. Tunisian democracy needs, more than ever, Europe's help. But Europe also needs Tunisia: it needs a Tunisia that can be a factor of stability in the Maghreb and that can infect, with its example of plural and secular democracy, respectful of the rights and dignity of women, countries that are now plunged into chaos and from which hundreds of thousands of migrants desperately trying to reach Europe come from. We have heard several European leaders say that, more than welcoming migrants from the Maghreb and the Levant, it is necessary to tackle the causes of migration in their countries of origin by fostering social and economic development. The diagnosis is correct – Europe can start applying the medicine in Tunisia.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – Instability in North Africa was boosted by the efforts of European powers to achieve regime change there. They did this without having a road map for the future. The resulting confusion has fuelled radical extremism, multiplying the security threat both inside and outside North Africa.  Still, Tunisia managed to achieve a fragile democratic balance that has become almost unique as a model for the area. This has made the country a priority target for terrorism, as witnessed by the recent act of atrocious violence on the beaches of Tunisia. Its fragility is caused by insufficient jobs, investment and economic growth. Precisely, terrorists aim to destabilise Tunisia by hitting at this fragility to create more unemployment, frighten investment off and undermine the economy.  The destabilisation of Tunisian democracy is contrary to Europe’s vital interests. There is a moral obligation and just as importantly a geostrategic urgency for Europe to counter this threat. This can only be done by a special programme, one that is suitably funded by the European Union, meant to help Tunisia counter the economic consequences of the terrorist threat it is facing and be in an effective position to sustain jobs, investment and growth.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on future EU-Cuba relations (2015/2616(RSP))

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, since the beginning of her mandate, improving relations with the Latin American continent has been a priority for the Vice-President/High Representative. The EU-CELAC Summit has underscored once again the strategic nature of our partnership based on shared values and aiming to promote joint solutions to global challenges. Enhancing ties with Cuba has been a fundamental chapter of this broader strategy. Some of the fault lines that have shaped global politics for decades are shifting with impressive speed. Sometimes we are so focused on the threats we face that we overlook the positive changes that are also taking place. We should not miss the many opportunities that are arising. Furthermore, Europe cannot take a back seat whilst someone else makes history. We should be driving the change forward, to make sure too that the outcomes reflect our values and our priorities, from trade to human rights. During these past months, the Vice-President/High Representative has engaged personally with the Cuban side. A first meeting was held with Cuban Foreign Minister Rodríguez during the CELAC Summit in January 2015 in Costa Rica. In March, she travelled to Havana and had a series of meetings, including with President Castro as well as with the Ministers for Foreign Affairs, the Economy, Foreign Trade and Investment. In April, Foreign Minister Rodríguez came to Brussels to relaunch the formal political dialogue. Finally a bilateral meeting was held with Vice-President Díaz-Canel on the margins of the EU-CELAC Summit. In February 2014 the EU approved the negotiating directives for a political dialogue and cooperation agreement – the so-called PDCA – with Cuba. This will provide an enabling platform for constructive dialogue and improve cooperation between Cuba and the European Union. The decision followed a lengthy reflection process in the Council. It took into account the incipient domestic reform process under President Castro. In parallel, Member States also increased their bilateral engagement with Cuba. Updating our approach in order to promote EU objectives in relation to Cuba more effectively was considered: encouraging political and economic reforms, promoting human rights and improving the lives of Cuban citizens. The agreement will include chapters on political dialogue and cooperation as well as on trade. Negotiations were launched in April 2014 and subsequent rounds took place in August and in March 2015. Ms Mogherini’s contacts with the Cuban side in recent months also served to provide additional impetus to the process. On 15 and 16 June last, negotiators met for a fourth round of talks in Brussels. The discussions took place in a good – and may I say constructive – atmosphere. Together we managed to achieve substantial progress, mainly on the cooperation and policy dialogue and the trade chapters. These chapters are now at very advanced stages and can hopefully be closed in the next round of talks. There was also progress on the political dialogue chapter, and the negotiators engaged in a productive exchange of views, during which positions were further developed and clarified. This discussion will enable a more in-depth preparation of negotiations on the proposed text in the next round, which means in early September. Members will be aware that it was agreed with Foreign Minister Bruno Rodríguez to seek to accelerate negotiations and conclude them soon, as both sides agreed that this would be to our mutual benefit. The progress accomplished in this round demonstrates the strong commitment of both sides to enhancing the relationship. Progress has also been achieved in an area which is, and will remain, at the core of EU relations with Cuba: human rights and fundamental freedoms. In March it was proposed to Foreign Minister Rodríguez that a dedicated and structured dialogue on human rights be set up. During the political dialogue meeting in Brussels, an understanding was reached to start consultations on the establishment of a human rights dialogue. A first session led by the EU’s Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, was held in Brussels on 25 June, in between a preparatory and a constituting meeting. The purpose was to discuss and agree on the format and objectives of such a dialogue before the PDCA negotiations are concluded, to give us a head start. Thus the human rights dialogue parameters will be designed in line with the overall terms of the agreement, from where they will derive continuity and formal blessing. The dialogue gives us an opportunity to improve mutual understanding on human rights and exchange experiences and best practices, as well as seek to identify potential areas of cooperation between the EU and Cuba. It also provides a platform to address recent developments and, where necessary and appropriate, to address concerns over individual cases. This dedicated dialogue will provide feedback and bolster the formal political dialogue at the political level. In the light of this positive engagement, it was all the more disappointing to learn of the incidents which took place in Havana last weekend, including undue violence and a large number of detentions. There is no reason to limit the peaceful expression of opinion, and the use of excessive violence against peaceful protestors is unacceptable. Those who overstepped the mark of the legitimate exercise of authority should be disciplined. We expect the Cuban authorities to take all necessary measures to remedy this situation, and we call on them to permit all peaceful forms of expression. During the meetings with the Cuban authorities, the Vice-President/High Representative also explored the prospects for cooperation and joint work on a number of foreign policy issues. These include Columbia, where Cuba plays a positive role in hosting negotiations between the government and FARC in the mediation process. Other such cases include global cooperation on health issues, in which Cuba has a strong role, as we witnessed during the Ebola crisis, or, potentially, cooperation on climate change in the run-up to the COP21 Conference in Paris. Obviously, the recent rapprochement between Cuba and the United States has also been addressed in these talks. Last week, Cuba and the US announced the reopening of their embassies in Washington and Havana. This decision, as agreed between Presidents Obama and Castro, ends a prolonged stalemate and will create new opportunities for Cuba, the region and beyond. The isolation of Cuba would make no sense at all in today’s world. It is a cold-war relic we should all be happy to dismiss. This is even more true for us Europeans, who suffered for decades from the artificial divisions imposed by a conflictual world order. A further normalisation is necessary and should include the end of the US embargo, which is outdated and inconsistent with the context. The EU has always spoken up against this unilateral measure, including its humanitarian impact on many Cubans and its territorial effects on EU-Cuban economic relations.

name: Luis de Grandes Pascual
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for your extensive and certainly hopeful information. It is clear that trade dialogues are moving forward and it is also clear, by their own diplomatic expressions, that, in political dialogues, each is expressed in the usual terms. I believe, Mr President and Commissioner, that the start of negotiations on a political dialogue and cooperation agreement with the European Union, on the one hand, and the thawing of relations with the United States, on the other hand, are two events which have marked a very important turning point in updating Cuba's relations with the world. It is clear, Mr President, that changes are taking place around Cuba. Changes that I would like to make faster, because, at the end of the day, they point to a new direction, which must be followed closely. Consequently, I would also like the European Union to be very present in this process, as the Commissioner said that it is doing so. Most Latin American countries are joined by a dense and close network of political, economic and cooperation agreements. Cuba, for well-known reasons, is one of the very few exceptions left on the continent. Let us hope that, in the coming months, the conditions will be met in order to achieve this agreement of political dialogue so that we can move forward in the intensification of our relations. A very important chapter, Mr President, of crucial importance in the context of this negotiation is that of human rights, and I am glad that you highlighted it in your speech, Commissioner. I welcome the first high-level dialogue between the Cuban and European authorities. Mr President, human rights and fundamental freedoms are not matters of internal order. On the other hand, they are the pillars of that community of values that is the European Union and of that wider community, which unites the two shores of the Atlantic, in which the friends of Cuba – and the Spaniards are – want to see it fully integrated. As I pointed out at the beginning of my speech, we must celebrate the timid steps Cuba is taking to open up to the world. Now, let's hope that Cuba will open up to Cubans as well. We want a Cuba fully integrated into the international concert, a Cuba that wins in prosperity, but also, of no, a Cuba that wins in freedom. A political cooperation agreement means that all parties undertake to do so.  But what is Cuba doing? He's doing it timidly while the others are acting. It is necessary to continue negotiating and, above all, it is necessary for the Cuban people what they have long asked for: democracy. That, Mr President, will be a revolutionary matter.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union and Cuba must develop a strong strategic partnership, a partnership based on development cooperation, economic and trade relations and political dialogue.  Some ask: what does the EU have, what does the European Union have to offer that can boost Cuba's openness to democratic values?  We have, I would say in the difficult times that are going on, we still have and we want to continue to have a model of humanistic and people-centered development, a model that adds to social and public service concerns, something that Cuba values, with the freedom of expression of civil society, individuals and institutions.  We have the possibility of including Cuba in the European system of trade preferences in order to encourage full respect for workers' rights and human rights dialogue, but, Commissioner, we need to act quickly.  It is urgent to derogate from the European common position on Cuba, an old, outdated position that limits us to open doors to constructive dialogue that has an impact not only on relations with Cuba, but also on dialogue with Latin America and Central America, such an important dialogue for the sustainable development of globalization and the planet. It is urgent to promote a deep dialogue with Cuban civil society and its institutions, without yielding to values but also without prejudice or action.  I express, on behalf of the Socialists and Democrats, our support and encouragement for the efforts of the High Representative in this regard.  We must be active partners in Cuba's journey to an inclusive, open and creative democracy of the natural environment for free debate and for the guarantee of fundamental freedoms. All this added to sustainable development and the provision of universal access services of which Cuba is one of the examples that best compared to the European social model.  We must build bridges to a better world. In the troubled times we live in, this is an extraordinary challenge and it is a challenge that we have an obligation to overcome.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – From my country, the Netherlands, there have been close contacts with Cuba for decades, especially in the ecclesiastical area. There is therefore great interest in the future relations between the EU and Cuba. From those circles, who are very well aware of the situation in Cuba, I hear the following reaction: official contacts from the EU with the authorities in Cuba are wonderful, but there is also a need for contacts with the opposition, the democratic movement and the defenders of human rights. Economic development is desperately needed in Cuba. There are openings for that. Let the EU wholeheartedly support private initiatives in Cuba. But at the same time, as Mr Hahn said, I am aware of the (even blatant) violation of human rights. Cuba currently has at least 71 political prisoners. It is nevertheless apprething that many are imprisoned for offences that have not yet been committed, because of the danger that they might commit those offences. There is even an official name and legislation for this. I hope that the EU will really denounce this, because this cannot be done for normal relations between the EU and Cuba.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, after months of insistence and to call for this debate on Cuba, and after the numerous delays in cuba due to the intervention of two major groups in this House, who considered it essential that the High Representative, Federica Mogherini, be present here, here we are without Mrs Mogherini, even if Mr Hahn is present. It is also really deplorable to see how the only announcement of the opening of diplomatic relations between the United States and Cuba has been a crazy race by the governments of the Member States to welcome this standardisation and also to arrive on time on the island to distribute what is left of the cake. All this without establishing conditions on human rights and democracy; without discussing and integrating Cuban civil society into the talks; forgetting the hundreds of Cuban opponents who have been fighting for decades for democratization and defending the fundamental rights of their fellow citizens, from inside and outside the island, who see them be left helpless by the voracity of better economic agreements of foreign democracies. I can only stress again that the bilateral treaty negotiations between the European Union and Cuba must be accompanied by a new unconditional agreement on the release of political prisoners and the development of freedoms on the island. Otherwise, we will continue to insist: European values must always be ahead.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in today's critical circumstances, where Cold War voices are intensifying, the effort to further develop relations with Cuba is a response to those who continue to propose deadlocked policies of intervention, blockades and embargoes, and it is particularly important that a small country which for over sixty years has been experiencing the pressure of a murderous embargo is coming to this debate on an equal footing. The morning's extensive debate on Greece clearly highlighted the essential problem experienced by the peoples of Europe: the withdrawal and continued withdrawal of the social state and the obsolescence of fundamental acquis under the bandit attack of the financial system.  In the face of this political choice, it is necessary to bend over carefully to what these proud people have achieved, defending human dignity, without negotiating their values despite the ruthless attack they have been under for sixty years. A country that spends 13% of its GDP providing universal public free education with impressive scientific results for the international community. A country with the best indicators at all levels of healthcare, with free universal access but also a pioneer both in the field of prevention and in the field of ongoing research in the pharmaceutical and medical field. I support with all my might the further development of relations with Cuba with the utmost respect for a people who, even under the most difficult circumstances, have not for a moment given up their dignity and right to decide for their lives and for their country. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a 'blue card' (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: n/a
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Sakorafa, do you really believe that the plight of Cuba is a consequence or an exclusive consequence of the US embargo? All other countries in the world are allowed to trade with Cuba. They should not distract from the harmful effects of socialism in this country by pointing to the US embargo. Don't you agree?

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. Mr Henkel, that is not my finding. I think the whole world recognises that for sixty consecutive years Cuba has been strangled, as – I remind you – it has been strangled economically, morally, socially and another country, and another small country, Gaza in Palestine. Exactly the same thing is happening right now. I think it is very positive that all this has been recognised, that all this is being overcome and that at the moment there is another way forward for Cuba, such a road that will lead it back to development. Allow me to say that what happened was the greatest crime that could ever have been committed to humanity against a country such as Cuba.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Thank you, Dimitrios. It's always a pleasure to talk when you preside. I have to say that we are, right now, correcting a historical anomaly. I would like to support, on behalf of my group, the progress that can be made in the negotiation of this agreement with Cuba. We are correcting a historical anomaly: the fact that Cuba is the only country with which we do not have an agreement. A country which we have obviously mistreated with the adoption, in 1996, of that common position, which I believe is also a real brake on the normalisation of relations in 1996, so I would like to ask, once again, that it be repealed. Both my group and I hope this goes ahead.  We would also like to see the role that the European Union has to play in relation to Cuba not only stick to supposed opportunities for multinationals and companies in the face of the new scenario that can be opened, but that we are able to build a balanced partnership, from equal to equal, in which we can normalise a situation with a people who are brother. On the other hand, I also hope that the European Union can play a very positive role so that, once and for all, this embargo by the Americans, which has drowned the Cuban economy in a very, very important way and which has prevented it from developing, will cease. So, on behalf of my group, simply saying that it is very important that these negotiations succeed, and we hope so.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an historic occasion. Finally, after decades, there is the possibility of lifting the embargo on Cuba, an embargo that has forced the Cuban people to industrial over the years: for example, in the medicinal sector, developing a very strong and flourishing phytotherapy sector. Cuba is a country where, despite famine, infant mortality is, after all, contained at continental levels.  However, we must not make a big mistake: to think that Cuba becomes the land of conquest of us or of the Americans. We absolutely must prevent the gradual transition to the capitalist economy from being a shock passage, a transition to savage capitalism which today, in the absence of an entrepreneurial class or people capable of managing it, will result in even greater inequalities and poverty than the crisis that is already taking place.  Our duty, therefore, is to assist the friends of the Cuban people and not to repeat the mistake that was made with regard to Russia: the agreement must be not only commercial but also political and human rights-oriented, especially for the benefit of the Cuban people and not aimed at exploiting their resources, let alone the famous hydrocarbons that are talked about so much in the Gulf.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I can only welcome the recent diplomatic rapprochement between the European Union and Cuba.  The policies of embargo and isolation of countries considered adversaries or enemies have always shown their inefficiency, even their harmfulness. However, I regret that it was not until the United States began a change of attitude towards Cuba, after decades of a severe embargo with dramatic consequences for the Cuban economy and people, that the European Union decided to do the same. How can we then claim that the Union has an independent foreign policy, when it is, once again, behaving only like the vassal of the United States? Finally, I hope that this diplomatic warming does not come at the expense of honesty and truth.  Since coming to power in 2008, Raul Castro has slightly relaxed the communist regime's rule over the population. But this must not make us forget the terrible political repression suffered by Cubans for more than 50 years, nor the tens of millions of deaths, nearly 100 million caused worldwide by communism.  This better world, which one of my EPP colleagues was talking about earlier, I believe we all hope so. However, this hope must not obstruct the duty of obligatory remembrance to entire generations who have been sacrificed on the altar of this mortal and dictatorial ideology that was communism.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to welcome the European Union's willingness to be open in its relations with Cuba and its attempt to implement a new approach with the aim of initiating political change. What we must not forget is that this is a totalitarian regime, and we must therefore exercise a great deal of caution when considering the normalization of relations with Cuba.  For Raul Castro's regime, the thaw does not seem to be synonymous with any political reform. (The President interrupts the speaker)  The Castro caste has no intention of easing pressure on political opponents or human rights defenders. The Cuban government continues to violently suppress dissent and discourage any form of criticism. Peaceful protests are causing panic among the regime, which has recently arrested the wives of political prisoners. Because, yes, there are still dozens of political prisoners in Cuba and thousands of innocent people are still arbitrarily detained and convicted, because they are considered a threat to the system. There is no improvement in freedom of expression. I remind you that Guillermo Farias had to wait three years before receiving his Sakharov Prize, right here, because the Cuban authorities had not allowed him to travel.  Cuba is in the same situation today: anyone who allows himself to criticize the government or uncover gross rights violations is severely punished. It is still strictly forbidden to stray from the official line of government, as this is the way a totalitarian project works with a single and obligatory ideology.  Focusing on the idea that economic change will lead to political developments seems to me to be a risky bet. We must be very attentive to the evolution of the Cuban situation, so that castrism does not continue in a new form of authoritarianism, like some communist countries.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to begin by transferring my congratulations to the Commissioner and Mrs Mogherini's team, because I think it is important that this House congratulates an important political decision by the High Representative, who was to go to Cuba. The European Union began several months before the United States had a framework of relations with Cuba, and this is already important. Why? Because Cuba is important. Because Cuba is a country with enormous geopolitical influence in the region. Just look at the peace process in Colombia to discover how important Cuba is. Just look at Cuba's ideological influence throughout Latin America to discover that Cuba is important. It is not by chance that the United States has decided to resume these relations, because it wants to resitute itself in Latin America. It's okay what's been done and I congratulate you. Second thing: it is very important that we do not hold old positions on Cuba. Ancient is the embargo, ancient is the Common Position. We must adapt the European position to these new times, which are very fast-paced, which are running at high speed. Nor is it good for the European Parliament to look at Cuba in a simplified way: some, pro Cuba; others, anti-Cuba. Thus we will not finish solving a major problem for Europe, which is to re-enter Latin America and recover a fundamental geopolitical space there. We must overcome simplism and Cuba must be helped to find a democratic, yes, democratic transition. But it will not be on the basis of demanding a series of principles that you will not accept. We have to be smart. The change is going to reach Cuba, it will come with trade, with personal exchanges, with electronic openness. What is needed is for Europe to help a transition which certainly has to go in that direction. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Michael Gahler (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you very much, sir. You said that we must also promote change through trade. I am not opposed to that in principle. But do you not have the impression that the current leaders are using trade liberalisation primarily to put themselves in pole position, so that, after democratisation, they will then be back at the top of the economic list? Do we not have to call for a political agenda in the first place?

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Your Honor, no one really knows, no one knows how the changes are going to happen. No one knows which political system is going to end up creating in Cuba, but trade is likely to influence human exchange. The number of Americans who have arrived on the island in the last six months has doubled. It's bent. Do you think that, with human exchange, electronic openness to the Internet and the media is not going to come to freedom? Will. That's why it's smart to work in this direction, Your Honor. Even if they take advantage of trade, that path is the good one.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the As a representative of German industry and a long-standing member of Amnesty International, I met Fidel Castro four times and spent hours talking to him about human rights, especially at the time about the abolition of the death penalty. As we know, it has been suspended since 2003 and, unfortunately, has not been abolished. But I also argued with him about the catastrophic economic situation, about the poor supply of the population and about the dilapidated houses in Havana. Each time he had as an excuse: this is because of the American embargo. Now I have already pointed out that other countries have been able to trade with Cuba and that it could not be because of it. But the American embargo was his standard excuse to hold on to power.  If the embargo had not been imposed at the time, the Castro brothers would have been out of the window long ago, and we would not have political prisoners in the prisons. That is why the European Union should put pressure on America to have this embargo lifted once and for all.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would probably be the last person to defend the policy towards Cuba of the last decades, and I would be the last person to say that it has been successful. But I would be the first person to say that racing with the Americans – who will go more in the direction of being forthcoming, and who will be more rapid, more intensive and more forthcoming at a time when there are very few changes in Cuba – is not an equally sizable mistake. I am looking at a paper which has been signed by thousands of Cubans, called the Agreement for Democracy in Cuba. If you read from point 1 to point 9, and further to point 10, not one of these points has been implemented. This is what the Cubans think is absolutely necessary to be done. I am in favour of a rapprochement, and I am sure that there is a certain benefit that we – and the Cubans too – can get from it, but there has to be conditionality. This means that if the Cuban regime will do A, we will adjust and we will do 1. If the Cuban regime does B, then we will react. It cannot go in the direction of the Cubans expecting concessions while basically refusing to discuss human rights. So firstly, there certainly needs to be conditionality. Secondly, we need to see the unconditional release of political prisoners; democratic reforms and, indeed, changes to the legal order. Do not expect any significant changes with Cuba if the legal order is not changed. We still have political prisoners. This has to change, and then I am sure that we will be on the right path. So I am sure that the Commission and the High Representative will take care of the conditionality. We will want to see results.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are celebrating the fourth round and above all progress in any area. Progress is made when talking equally, when respecting peoples' free determination, international law and the Charter of the United Nations. The bad news is that, for the fifth round to be held in September, we understand that, in order to continue to do so, the 1996 Common Position must be revoked immediately. It is unique in the European Union and is a total obstacle to standardisation, because it violates the principle of non-interference in the internal affairs of States and is also irrelevant when States already have bilateral relations. I would ask the High Representative to use her good offices so that the United States has just lifted the extraterritorial blockade and returned the illegal base of Guantanamo, and to propose a reflection to this House on the futility of so many years of interference and destabilization. Let's think about whether we need to stick like this with other Latin American countries.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that when we talk about relations with Cuba, I see a great deal of fervour in quickly seeking an agreement with cuba, that the only one with which we do not have an agreement, as if all the countries with which we have agreements are countries in which we live very well and have created fantastic conditions of growth and well-being.  I have many doubts about this and I am very concerned that openness on the part of the Americans may, in fact, mean a great attack from a capitalist point of view on what has been a place that has certainly stood out for an excellent health system, for an excellent education system and, if it is true that there have been violations of human rights , it is also true that the biggest human rights violations on the island of Cuba have been committed by the Americans at the Guantánamo base, even if this does not seem to worry us that much.  I therefore welcome the progress being made in relations with Cuba, but great care must be taken to establish priorities in these relations.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU is currently Cuba's most important trading partner, with a trade volume of around TWO billion euros last year. Now the United States is also taking its chance and re-establishing diplomatic relations with Cuba. When it comes to entering new markets, the United States is not using our European agility, but is proceeding very quickly and unbureaucratically. It is good if Cuba is to be opened further. However, it took the Union six years to give a mandate from the start of negotiations in 2008, only in 2014. However, we Europeans have a very important task to ensure that, in addition to respect for human rights in Cuba, Cuba's positive achievements, such as education and the health system, will also survive in the face of an imminent opening of the market towards the United States. Cuba therefore needs a strong European component, strong European support for building a free society with a social market economy. I hope for a free, democratic Cuba, combined with European values. Conf o en Cuba y en los cubanos, en un pa s libre y social, que comparte los valores democr ticos de Europa.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we have opened a new chapter in our relations with Cuba, and the Americans have done the same. However, human rights violations remain a constant. In 2015, short-term and arbitrary detentions are on the rise. The Ladies in White are still being detained in large numbers. Detainees are held in isolation for days and are beaten. Detentions are abundant. The state controls most of the media outlets and restricts access to the internet. The Cuban authorities still refuse to recognise human rights monitoring as a legitimate activity while assaulting human rights defenders locally. On the other hand, on 25 June 2015, the EU held its first high-level dialogue on human rights in Cuba. The topics discussed at this meeting offer hope that a constructive dialogue can be established. As we look to the future, we cannot afford for our stance on human rights to be violated. We must uphold a common position towards Cuba, stipulating full economic and political cooperation in the continuous process towards a pluralist and free democracy.

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as Cuba is opening up to the world, it is crucial that we take a strategic approach to relations that encompass all EU interests. So I welcome Mrs Mogherini’s visit to Cuba in March to spur on negotiations on the FTA. I hope that she and the Commission have the support of all Member States to push through a deal. Commissioner, I was pleased to hear from you about the human rights dialogue. It is quite clear that embargoes did not really work to improve the human rights situation. I believe that perhaps the dialogue and the FDA could be a tool for incremental change, given that it can be an incentive to encourage change and will require Cuba to gradually liberalise fields like communications. I believe we also need to look at geopolitics, and I am sure that our strategy takes into account Cuba’s relations with major players like Russia and China. Cuba signed an agreement with Moscow last year, allowing it to re—open intelligence facilities on its territory, while Beijing is one of its major trade and investment partners. Given that many EU interests in this context overlap with those of the USA, is the High Representative or the Commissioner exploring where there is scope for collaboration with the US?

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the negotiations between the European Union and Cuba for the conclusion of a dialogue agreement are indeed positive. However, we believe that this agreement can only be successful if there is indeed an end to the european policy of interference in Cuba's internal affairs. We do not see, for example, in this dialogue agreement the Cuban Government demanding that the European Union that all people have the right to quality employment, health and education and free for all, for example, happens in Cuba and not in the European Union. We therefore hope that the dialogue will take place on a basis of reciprocity and cooperation and to be non-discriminatory. This should in fact be the position of the European Union: respect for the self-determination of peoples and the Charter of the United Nations. With regard to the European Union's common position on Cuba, which has been hanging over the negotiations, I would like to ask the European Commission whether it does not consider that a policy based on equality does not really presuppose the immediate repeal of this common position on Cuba in the negotiating process.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, today's debate is taking place in the context of a process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the United States that has broader regional implications. And if the process of rapprochement between Havana and Washington is well directed, it may be able to narrow the space for populists across the Western Hemisphere, and especially the authoritarian left like the one Nicolás Maduro promotes in Venezuela.  Indeed, Maduro's anticapitalist and anti-American tirades have always been meaningless, but they sound even more absurd at a time when his ideological idols from Cuba are meeting with the US president and restoring relations with the US.  Now, it is important that we also understand in the European Union the nature of this process of normalizing relations between Cuba and the USA, but also the impetus for democratization and respect for human rights in Cuba and the entire region. And in this context, I object to claims from the European left that the EU must enter some sort of race with the US over cuba policy.  The European Union established diplomatic relations with Cuba a long time ago, we are long past the point that US-Cuban relations are only now coming to. So instead of racing with the U.S. for some fear of losing a position relative to Cuba, we need strategic cooperation with democratic partners in North and Latin America to promote common values. And in this regard, I think we must be ambitious in negotiating a possible agreement on political dialogue that must open the perspective of the democratisation of Cuba. It must open the perspective of a new Cuba in which there will be no more political prisoners, where freedom of speech, freedom of religion and, of course, freedom and the right of the people of Cuba to elect power in free and multiparty elections will be allowed.  This will not happen overnight, but Europe must never give up on these democratic goals. Otherwise, they would betray the Cuban people and those Cubans we rewarded in this Parliament with the Sakharov Prize, precisely because of their struggle for freedom.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the truth is that, listening to some speeches in this House, nothing seems to have happened in the last fifteen or twenty years. There are people who hold exactly the same positions, although evolution, in this case cuba, is more than obvious. Things have changed and, as things have changed, we also have an obligation to keep up. I wish we weren't as late as we are in our situation regarding relations with Cuba. We must end the Common Position now. We have claimed it in this House hundreds of times. And we have to end the embargo. And we must, of course, start with a human rights dialogue, which has already been done: Mr Lambrinidis has initiated a dialogue on human rights with Cuba. But, if you see the European Union's double standard on any matter, it is precisely in relations with Cuba. It is, indeed, as some Member has said, an anomaly, a historical anomaly, a political anomaly, and it is beginning to be a pathology of this House. You have to catch up, you have to be smart, you have to have height of sight, you have to sign an agreement with Cuba and you have to demand that Cubans, like all the peoples of the world, respect for human rights.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the United States and Cuba have decided that it is time for a change. I believe we Europeans should not only watch this process unfolding, but engage. Despite some criticism, this new diplomatic approach has the support of the American people and will be carried out by many people other than President Obama and his administration. The renewal of diplomatic relations is the result of collective leadership, as well as of widespread bipartisan efforts in the US Congress, the Cuban-American community, civil society, faith-based organisations and the private sector. In addition, there has been a determined willingness to change a policy described by those on both sides of the aisle – including Republican Senator Bob Corker from Tennessee – as being associated with five decades of failure. I am of the opinion that the European Union should welcome this decision and, through diplomatic channels, encourage this transition that is beneficial to the global and regional order and, most importantly, to the Cuban people. Our support should be directed to encourage democracy in Cuba and not in any way to legitimise the authoritarian regime currently in power. The transition in Cuba is about – to quote US Secretary of State John Kerry – ‘unleashing the potential of an Americas where countries combine their strengths to advance common interests and values’. I believe Europe should not and cannot be indifferent to this.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, thank you for the information provided on the negotiations on the agreement with Cuba. I see that progress is progressing and I hope that the European Union and its Member States will be able to achieve, through the agreement, a more important, more influential presence on the island, at the crucial stage it is going through. I don't know if it's going to be easy to negotiate pending. The most political part of the agreement is lacking and the Cuban authorities may now feel less in need of quickly concluding an agreement with the European Union after normalizing their diplomatic relations with the United States, after fifty years of rupture. On the other hand, let us not forget that, despite some modest reforms and openings, the under-the-bottom nature of the Cuban regime has not changed. I welcome the first human rights meeting on 25 June between Mr Lambrinidis, the Special Representative of the European Union, and cuban leaders. We must continue to insist on these issues, to transfer to Cuba our desire for change, for example in its criminal legislation, and to ask it to ratify the United Nations conventions on civil and political rights, as well as social rights, which it has only signed. As is well known, unfortunately, arbitrary arrests and acts of harassment and intimidation of representatives of the political opposition and human rights defenders continue. On this point, I refer to the report recently adopted by the Council — the annual report — and also to the words addressed to us today by Commissioner Hahn, informing us of what happened this weekend. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European Union and Latin America are united by many principles and values, including the dignity of the human being, the rule of law and democracy.
