Cuba should be no exception and I, therefore, hope that the meetings initiated on the 25th will continue and that human rights will take a relevant place in the negotiations of the agreement.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I agree that we Europeans must pursue a constructive policy towards Cuba.  We should focus on the interests of the people of Cuba. We have a great deal of experience in the transition from communist dictatorships to democratic societies. I think the Cubans want democratisation. It is not a question of continuing the communist dictatorship and the other alternative of a Reconquista from Miami.  In between lies the approach that people want. We can be very helpful in this: in the development of a democratic society that is genuinely Cuban, which takes into account its culture and traditions. Cuba does not have a one-party communist tradition to continue, nor does it have the Batista regime that should re-emerge – a democracy similar to that that has emerged in Europe in many transition societies. I agree with Mr Henkel that if the United States had lifted its sanctions decades ago – for example, with the fall of the wall – the regime would certainly no longer be where it is today, and the country would have democratised in the past.  I therefore hope that, with the offers we are making, including an agenda, an agenda, a timetable for a round table with an immediate objective, which means that the democratic opposition in Cuba will have a perspective on negotiating with the regime when the first democratic elections in Cuba – as in many other parts of the world – will take place.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say first of all that, of course, what Cuba has been through in recent decades is a heavy burden that would be very appropriate to release. However, the dialogue that the European Union wants to establish and which has open diplomatic relations with Cuba, I do not think that it can be opened without any conditions. I think that these limits should be clear and should be based on the defence of at least the fundamental principles of human rights. I want to subscribe here to the protection of human rights and to a certain doctrine, which was also formulated in the Czech Republic by our former President Václav Havel, when we consider human rights to be a truly fundamental value for which cuba's unfeasible or possibly worthless obligations cannot be exchanged. We should support these discussions in the interests of the citizens of Cuba, that is beyond doubt. But I think that these negotiations must also have limits that the European Union wants to share and which it can no longer go for.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is about time we ushered in a new period in EU-Cuba relations, based on the necessity of advancement of democracy in this country and the encouragement of economic exchange. We should accompany Cuba in the ongoing process of change and modernisation and strongly promote bilateral cooperation and political dialogue on important matters such as the promotion of human and citizens’ rights and freedom of expression in this important process of transition. Cuba has the potential to become a member of the ACP, and we should keep pushing and developing relations with this country by supporting this request, as it represents an important step towards a strengthened relationship between the European Union and Cuba by showing mutual respect through a proper committed relationship. Looking at advancements that Cuba could achieve in the future, I believe that the EU and Cuba have a great deal to gain in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, deepening the European Union's relations with Latin America must be a strategic choice for the Union in the modern multipolar world we live in. In this context, the restoration of European Union-Cuba relations is an important development, as the Union, through its foreign policy, could gain an independent position vis-à-vis that of the United States of America.  Of course, the restoration of US-Cuba relations will certainly help to strengthen Cuba's relations with the Western world. We consider the European Union-Cuba dialogue in the field of human rights to be important, but this should not be a pretext for indirect intervention by the European Union in the internal affairs of Cuba. We consider it important to improve the economic relations between the European Union and Cuba, but this should be done on the basis of the principle of mutual benefit and respect for the sovereignty of states. Finally, the European Union should stop covets the exploitation of Cuba's resources of wealth instead of a lentil plate.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, I had the opportunity years ago to talk to people who were in Cuban prisons, were falsely prosecuted, had false processes mounted. I had the opportunity to talk to people in Barcelona and what I felt was great hope, a great expectation precisely from the European Union and European countries. That's why we need to support these people and all the other people who have suffered in Cuba and who want democracy in Cuba. I, of course, support and strongly welcome the normalization of relations with the current regime as well. And it's very good that we're seeing steps forward, toward democratizing the situation in Cuba. Of course economic relations can help in this sense in one way. But I'm sure we must never forget the suffering of the Cuban people and the fact that we should respect all possible human and other rights on that beautiful island.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I also thank the Representatives of the Commission for the debate we are having here today, because I am very glad that most of you have quite rightly stated that the blockade has never eased anything. Silence, or meaningless agreements like the one we signed in 1996, also did not help anyone. This is simply a re-experience, and we should all realize that if we want to set our relationships as partnerships, all these things that we used to do in our foreign policy were wrong. Let's face it, let's start implementing these steps correctly. You often talk about human rights. The right to a decent life, to work, to housing, to free education, to free education, these are human rights that are quite normal in Cuba. Let us ask ourselves whether they are perfectly normal throughout the European Union. Before we start training someone, please let us be aware of the conditions in which people lived and lived in Cuba and in what conditions they lived and lived, unfortunately, citizens of the European Union, to whom we are unable to secure these rights. I am very grateful to the Commissioner for her actions and I beg the last sentence: the European Union is capable of an independent foreign policy, so let us do it and let us not be too happy about it.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – Cuba has been a taboo subject for many years in many respects, it has been a country for many years, isolated from economic cooperation with both Europe and the United States, and all of this has, of course, left consequences on one side and the other. I therefore, of course, welcome these progress or efforts on relations and the conclusion of an agreement with Cuba, and of course we must be very careful. It is a country that, of course, will not let it be forced, it will not leave a so-called forced democracy. And I think that the European Union must also respect diversity, diversity and, in fact, give the Cuban people the opportunity to decide for itself about its future.  And when we talk about human rights violations, of course we can read many of the decisions of the Court of Human Rights here in Strasbourg, and you will see that they are also violating human rights in other countries.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by thanking you again for this debate and for this very frank exchange of views that we have had on EU-Cuba relations. But may I also say in that context that I take note that, for instance, Mr Maura Barandiarán regretted the absence of Mrs Mogherini today. May I remind you all of the reason for her absence: it is simply that she is taking part in the Viennese Iran talks. I hope this is more than a justification and hopefully they can strike a deal as soon as possible. Coming back to our debate, I think that, as is usual in this case and for such a subject, the discussions have reflected a very broad range of positions which are not always easy to reconcile. Having listened to all the speeches very carefully, I feel that the European Union is on the right track with the course adopted in 2014: more and closer engagement with Cuba in order to develop our relationship and find peaceful ways of fostering basic EU interests. The conclusion of the political dialogue and cooperation agreement would be a significant step towards this. It would provide an enabling platform for constructive dialogue and for enhancing cooperation. Consolidation of our engagement and the relationship of mutual trust are essential to ensure that our relationship evolves in line with our values and interests. The EUʼs experience could be greatly relevant for the country in its quest for economic and social modernisation. The EU can demonstrate how to combine a regulated market-based economy with the demands, social protection and participation of citizens. Many of you have expressed concerns regarding human rights. We are particularly attentive to this matter and fully share those concerns, as I have already expressed in my introduction. This is why the matter has been raised consistently with our Cuban partners, and we have agreed to start discussions on human rights even before the conclusion of the political dialogue and cooperation agreement, to ensure that we have an operational platform for constructive and result-oriented discussions as soon as possible. If Europe wants to be part of the historic process that is taking place in Cuba, and if we aim at driving this process – if we want to encourage reforms, if we want to have a say on human rights – there is only one thing to do: engage with Cuba. That is what we are doing and what we will keep doing in the months and years to come.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU's initiatives on Cuba are in the right direction: progress has been made in all chapters towards the signing of a political dialogue and cooperation agreement and, recently, a specific dialogue on human rights has been opened. The direct involvement of the High Representative has increased the pace of negotiation and prevented the EU from being delegated after the resumption of diplomatic relations between the island and the US in December 2014. The S&D Group supports the development of these dialogues and is committed to overcoming the Common Position, which formally guides the EU's relations with Cuba since 1996. This is an anachronistic and misguided position that, in the new geostrategic framework, hinders the EU's relations with Cuba. We are committed to strengthening dialogue with the Cuban authorities and civil society, from the conviction that, if Cuba strengthens contacts of all kinds with the rest of the international community, the living conditions of Cubans will improve.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – The EU's initiatives on Cuba are in the right direction: progress has been made in all chapters towards the signing of a political dialogue and cooperation agreement, and a specific dialogue on human rights has recently been opened. The direct involvement of the High Representative has increased the pace of negotiation and prevented the EU from being delegated after the resumption of diplomatic relations between the island and the US in December 2014. The S&D Group supports the development of these dialogues and is committed to overcoming the Common Position, which formally guides the EU's relations with Cuba since 1996. This is an anachronistic and misguided position that, in the new geostrategic framework, hinders the EU's relations with Cuba. We are committed to strengthening dialogue with the Cuban authorities and civil society, from the conviction that strengthening contacts of all kinds with the rest of the international community will push the castrista regime into openness, and improve the living conditions of Cubans.

text: in writing. – The EU's initiatives on Cuba are in the right direction: progress has been made in all chapters towards the signing of a political dialogue and cooperation agreement, and a specific dialogue on human rights has recently been opened. The direct involvement of the High Representative has increased the pace of negotiation and prevented the EU from being delegated after the resumption of diplomatic relations between the island and the US in December 2014. The S&D Group supports the development of these dialogues and is committed to overcoming the Common Position, which formally guides the EU's relations with Cuba since 1996. This is an anachronistic and misguided position that, in the new geostrategic framework, hinders the EU's relations with Cuba. We are committed to strengthening dialogue with the Cuban authorities and civil society, from the conviction that strengthening contacts of all kinds with the rest of the international community will push the castrista regime into openness, and improve the living conditions of Cubans.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. – Cubans have long been isolated and have been more marginalized over the past few decades. Cuban society has suffered from this isolation, but the EU now has the opportunity to take proactive steps to improve relations and can show that we have not forgotten the Cubans who have suffered for many years under an authoritarian regime, but, on the contrary, that we are ready to lend them a helping hand in transforming the regime. Cuba's isolation, as High Representative Mogherini rightly pointed out, is a Cold War relic that has no place in the twenty-first century. Many EU Member States, such as the Czech Republic, have similar historical experience to Cuba, and it is these countries that can help to successfully democratise Cuban society. The Cuban people have shown us their hope for improving living conditions and therefore the European Union needs to successfully complete the negotiations and actively engage in the social, economic and political transition in Cuba and support the issue of improving the protection of human rights.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Yemen (2015/2760(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I am grateful for the opportunity to discuss, on behalf of Federica Mogherini, the situation in Yemen with you today. Amidst the turmoil affecting the Middle East, the crisis in Yemen calls for more attention from the international community. Yemen occupies a strategic position along the Gulf of Aden and the Red Sea, at the crossroads of the Horn of Africa and the Middle East, on the route connecting the Mediterranean to the Indian Ocean. There is a real and immediate risk of spillover of this crisis in an already troubled region. Furthermore, the latest developments in Hadhramaut show that terrorist organisations like al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, already rooted in Somalia, and more recently also Daesh, are benefiting from the vacuum of state authority in the country to regroup and regain strength. This is a threat for all countries in the region. The regional powers need to choose cooperation and common security issues. The only alternative to a more cooperative regional order is chaos. Saturday, 4 July marked the 100th day since the exile of President Hadi and the launch of the Saudi-led coalition airstrikes against the continuing advance of Houthi and pro-Saleh forces in Yemen. The country is facing a humanitarian catastrophe, with more than 3 000 Yemenis killed, over 14 000 injured, and 21 million people, or 80% of the total population, in need of humanitarian assistance, and a major food crisis about to unfold. Just to give you a comparison: there are now more people in need in Yemen than in the entire Sahel region. The EU’s position is clear, as portrayed in the Foreign Affairs Council conclusions of April 2015. We have also repeatedly – most recently in a joint statement by the High Representative/Vice-President and Commissioner Stylianides last Friday – made the case that there is no other way out of the current crisis than through an inclusive political process under UN stewardship favouring a genuine and constructive dialogue among the different parties. The continuing advance of the Houthis and forces loyal to ex-President Saleh, in contravention of UN Security Council resolutions, is  clearly unacceptable. But only a broad political consensus based on the parameters set by UN Security Council Resolution 2216 can provide a sustainable solution to the crisis, tackle the threat of terrorist groups and prevent further regional instability. Any long-term solution should address the underlying causes of instability, which are deeply rooted in local historical and socio-economic power structures. The EU fully supports the efforts of the UN Special Envoy, Ismail Ould Cheikh Ahmed, to recreate trust amongst the parties for a meaningful political deal. The consultations held in Geneva from 15 to 20 June could be a first step towards a return to an inclusive political process. We see a strong case for the gradual approach followed by the Special Envoy, first setting the conditions for a long pause in hostilities, leading to a sustainable ceasefire, coupled with a monitored withdrawal from key cities by the warring forces. The EU has been reaching out to all the parties in Yemen, including the Houthis. We believe it is critical for all the actors in the conflict to set a realistic path to peace in line with the parameters set by UN Security Council Resolution 2216. Our message to all parties is clear: engage in the UN-led dialogue process, with no preconditions, in good faith. All their legitimate concerns will be duly taken into consideration in a broad political settlement. The humanitarian impact of the ongoing fighting, bombardments and disruption of essential services on the civilian population, in particular on children, is reaching alarming proportions and exacerbating an already dire humanitarian situation. The targeting of civilian populations and infrastructures, including UN warehouses or hospitals, is also clearly unacceptable. In this volatile environment it is all the more crucial that humanitarian assistance reaches the people of Yemen. The European Union has been steadfast in its support of the UN efforts towards a lasting, predictable and sustainable humanitarian ceasefire. Such a pause should allow the urgent delivery of humanitarian assistance and essential supplies, including fuel, food and basic commodities, according to the principles of impartiality, neutrality and independence. It is essential, to this end, that access to Yemen for commercial shipping be further eased and that measures taken to implement UN Security Council Resolution 2216 be proportional and predictable. A UN-led inspection mechanism should be urgently rolled out to enable faster and more streamlined clearance procedures for ships bound for Yemen. In parallel we are calling on all parties to ensure respect for international humanitarian law and international human rights law, in particular by protecting civilians. Everyone should refrain from direct targeting of civilian infrastructure, notably medical facilities and water systems, and from using civilian buildings for military purposes. It is also of the utmost importance that all parties ensure the safety and security of medical personnel and relief workers and facilitate the passage of aid convoys and ambulances to the most affected populations without discrimination. The EU Humanitarian Aid Office – Echo – has already mobilised EUR 25 million in humanitarian assistance for Yemen to respond to the most urgent needs. We are also engaged in diplomatic efforts to ensure unrestricted access to humanitarian workers and aid relief so that vital assistance can be immediately delivered. More needs to be done, but international assistance will remain a drop in the ocean if commercial shipping cannot resume and bring the 80% of goods that Yemen imported before the conflicts and if Yemini warring factions continue to hamper the delivery of aid. Ultimately, the solution to this crisis has to be a political one, and every day that passes further entrenches polarisations and sees the risk of a protracted conflict with sectarian undertones grow. The EU will remain committed to playing its full role in supporting the UN and in reaching out to the parties and to regional players to set a swift path for peace. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to hearing your views on that.

name: Presidente. –
text: Let us begin the debate, which is a little intimate, but very important, and I would like to take this opportunity to greet visitors to the European Parliament.

name: Michèle Alliot-Marie
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, Yemen is indeed crystallizing most of the tensions and rivalries that exist in the Middle East today. The Persian Gulf could lose its geostrategic balance, as you pointed out. Imbalances in the Gulf could also affect the entire Middle East and the countries near the Gulf of Aden. Who can think that this destabilization would not affect our own situation, economically, safely or culturally? The European Union cannot therefore lose interest in what is happening in this country, which is certainly far away, very little known - as I have seen many times - because it can also have an impact on us. Today, Saudi Arabia, as well as eight Arab countries, Bahrain, Egypt, Jordan, Kuwait, Morocco, Qatar, Sudan and the UAE, supported by the Western community, are conducting, for the first time, a joint military operation to oppose the Houthi rebels and the Islamic State group. It should be noted that this is the first time that these countries, which often experience rivalries between themselves, are now in the same together.  However, we are well aware, as you are, that military action cannot be sufficient to restore a long-term national, political and security balance, so essential to regional stability. We must not forget that the Gulf countries are our first allies in the fight against the Islamic State group and against terrorism. So I ask you the following question, what is the European Union doing, by itself, to participate in the restoration of stability in Yemen? It is not just a matter of supporting this or that initiative. Because we are not suspected of having financial or other interests in the region, we have an opportunity to act with the parties.  What is the European Union also doing to effectively support the civilian populations who are the first victims of any armed conflict? Do you also intend to take initiatives to improve the situation of women in this country, which is not often mentioned and has probably the most retrograde status in the world.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is right that in this debate we put first and foremost our concern for the devastating humanitarian catastrophe occurring today in Yemen. The United Nations declared its highest level of humanitarian emergency, with over 80% of the country’s population in need of assistance. Prior to the conflict, more than one-third of the population – some 11.5 million people – suffered from food insecurity. Today, two million more have joined the starving. The UN envoy said the country is now just one step away from famine. It is a crisis for children, in which 1.8 million have lost access to education and one in three fighters are children. So our resolution makes the case for a humanitarian pause, backing the UN Secretary—General and marking the observance of Ramadan. My group stands with all who condemn violence on all sides – from the Houthis, al-Qaida and Daesh/ISIS. For us, however, this includes concerns about the humanitarian consequences of the bombing and of the blockade by the Saudi-led coalition. Regarding the request for military intervention from former President Hadi – someone whose term-of-office has expired and who had explicitly resigned – was that request more legitimate than the request of former President Yanukovych in a different sphere? In any case, that request to the Security Council was based on UN Charter Article 51, which concerns the defence of the country under external attack, and that cannot make it legal in this case. Our resolution calls on all regional actors to contribute to a return to stability. We call for an inclusive political process, which ends the polarisation of peoples based on religious sectarianism. Our resolution also understands that development must play an important role in what is the Arab world’s most impoverished country, if conflict resolution is to succeed in the long term. But this resolution is very much about the short term: to stop the targeting of civilians, to halt and then end the violence, to support all efforts towards a negotiated political solution, and to bring humanitarian relief in order to end the hunger and the suffering.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Yemen is an example of the Arab Spring gone badly wrong after the 2011 uprisings against the then President, Ali Abdullah Saleh, and of a poor country caught up in a proxy war between Iran militarily supporting fellow Shia Houthis and Sunni Saudi Arabia supporting the ousted government of President Hadi, now exiled to Riyadh. Saudi Arabia has intervened militarily with air power against the Houthi advances on Aden, and they in turn are supported by the previously ousted strong man, President Saleh. The country has become a humanitarian disaster zone, with more than 3 000 people killed, more than half of them civilians, including women and children, as a result of the Saudi bombing campaign aimed at driving back the insurgents and restoring the elected, legitimate Hadi government. There have been allegations of gross violations of international humanitarian laws by all sides. Matters are further complicated by piracy in the Gulf of Aden, and al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, active in many parts of the country. The EU has little role beyond supporting humanitarian aid; and of course I call, on behalf of my group, on all sides to return to the negotiating table and desist from further hostilities. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Tannock, thank you for accepting my blue card. Despite our obvious political differences, will you join me in supporting a cause that I know we are both very keen on? That is re-recognition for Somaliland – a stable country across the other side of the Gulf of Aden. Will you also join me in paying tribute to the great work that the Somalilanders are doing – specifically in the Port of Berbera – in helping refugees who have fled from southern Yemen?

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much, Mr Carver, because yes indeed, I think that Somaliland does deserve re-recognition. It has been democratic, it has upheld the rule of law and it is a stable polity which has fought piracy and combated Islamist terrorism. So for all those reasons, and the historical fact that it was once a British protectorate called British Somaliland and is entitled under the UN Charter and traditions to be an independent state, there is a very strong case to be made. But of course the debate today is not about Somaliland per se, although that is dear to my heart. The debate today is about what is happening in Yemen, and there has been, of course, a humanitarian crisis and disaster, as I have said in my speech, and many of the refugees have fled across the Gulf of Aden to Somaliland, to the port of Berbera, where I know the government in Hargeisa are doing their utmost possible to rehouse and accommodate this influx of refugees. But yes, thank you to the Government of Somaliland for doing that.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. The poor people of Yemen have suffered structurally from a lack of inclusive democratic governments, and the tensions and violence that that have resulted, for the past decades. Thousands have been killed and many more injured in the latest eruption of violence alone that started in the spring of this year. A report that the Saudi-led coalition is using cluster bombs should be investigated thoroughly by the United Nations and must have serious consequences, if confirmed. Independently-led investigations should also look at other crimes committed to assess whether these amount to crimes against humanity. The people of Yemen deserve justice, and a de-escalation of violence is needed to restabilise the country. There should be more respect for human life, and the human suffering must end. We therefore call on all parties engaged in this conflict to stop the use of violence, because while people suffer, al-Qaeda, so-called Islamic State, and other terrorist organisations benefit and grow amidst the chaos in Yemen. Ongoing insecurity is further stifling humanitarian efforts, leading to historic and tremendous chaos and crisis. As we can see, a toxic downward spiral is unfolding. The terrorists are going as far as recruiting children for their activities and using them as soldiers, and I think that that is disgraceful. We must work through and ensure that there is dialogue and de-escalation. But there is a political solution, including a more constructive role by regional actors, which – as many colleagues have pointed out – are very much involved in the situation in Yemen, leading to more and more violence. The EU should also reconsider its partnerships with some countries in the Middle East in this context. Foreign actors should stop the interventions, as I mentioned. They should stop adding fuel to the fire. We, as Europe, must support any UN efforts to lead in a dialogue that can lead to a peaceful and political solution to this terrible conflict. But the EU itself should do more and take a leadership position in ensuring that these UN efforts succeed.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, we are faced with a conflict which is causing terrible suffering but which also exemplifies us with the chaos of the area, that chaos which came with the delegation war and unilateral interventions. And it's a suffering we're seeing, with virtually nothing going on. We see how a Saudi-led coalition—curiously, Saudi Arabia, a theocratic dictatorship that is our friend because we're interested—is bombing with forbidden weapons and is developing a naval blockade affecting civilians. You can't get out of this situation by military means. That is why we demand an inclusive political solution, the lifting of the naval blockade, the ceasefire, the cessation of bombing, the cessation of arms supply and the investigation of the United Kingdom, France, Germany and Spain, in case they have breached the European Union Code of Conduct on arms exports.

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I very much appreciated the Commissioner’s comments about the long-term political solution being the only way that we can resolve the situation in Yemen. We cannot allow it to become a forgotten conflict because the turmoil, as colleagues have said, only helps Daesh and extremists and creates the perfect breeding ground for them. This motion focused on what must be done in the short-term to ensure that humanitarian efforts are able to proceed, and I very much endorse comments about a pause being  necessary in the fighting to allow humanitarian efforts to go forward. But we must also scrutinise the Saudi-led coalition, and we must scrutinise the actions of it, not least because many of our Member State governments – not least the United Kingdom – are assisting in every way possible, short of actual military intervention. The tactics are questionable; the legality of the action is also debatable; and we must ensure that this remains scrutinised by us, because we cannot allow this to simply play out while we watch from the sidelines and the people of Yemen continue to suffer.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, two weeks ago I hosted an event in Brussels with a delegation from the Southern Movement, an umbrella group bringing together the different political parties seeking an effective split, returning to the post Yemeni unification borders before 1990. The main speaker was Mr al-Jifri, a former South Yemeni Vice-President, who gave a detailed update of the tragic situation on the ground. He spoke passionately about the increasing humanitarian crisis, the fact that the international aid reaching Yemen is being distributed through Hodeidah port in the north, whilst Aden port in the south literally misses the boat. He also spoke of the increasing casualties and underlined how Yemen’s infrastructure has been completely obliterated. The pressing issue that must be addressed across the globe is the need for a correct diplomatic approach towards achieving a credible ceasefire so that the tragic humanitarian crisis that my colleagues across the House spoke about can be addressed as a matter of priority. I was astounded to learn of another issue that needs addressing urgently, and that is how someone who is taking part in the official dialogue might not actually be representing the very organisations that they claim to speak on behalf of. Certainly the Southern Movement delegates who attended my event left me with the distinct impression that they were currently unrepresented and that incorrect actors are currently at the table, incorrectly claiming to act for them. Now more than ever, the world has regrettably to accept the increasing divide across the Middle East between Sunni and Shia Islam. Yemen today is a tragic example of this. Accordingly, should not the international community honestly consider whether a unified Yemen is a viable long-term solution? I genuinely believe that the possibility of eventually – and I say eventually – dividing Yemen through its pre-unification borders is an option worth proper consideration. Have we learned nothing from the mistakes made a century ago by the Sykes-Picot Agreement?

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I listened very carefully to the debate, listening to the Commissioner's comments and speeches. I thank him for presenting the topic here in plenary today. We are debating the situation in Syria, the situation around the Islamic State, the situation in Iraq, and Yemen is being forgotten a little bit. At the same time, the situation there, from the point of view of the civil war, is very reminiscent of the situation in Syria, for example. What has been said here, I underline, is extremely strategic territory. The territory where the civil war continues may even grow into another international confrontation between Shiites and Sunnis, and I would consider that extremely dangerous. Every effort must therefore be made to calm the civil war. Personally, I am a little sceptical that the conflict will be calmed or resolved in some closer term. But at least to end the conflict would be very beneficial in my opinion. Also because the growing civil war is leading to terrorist organizations operating in Yemen. And that's extremely disturbing. It must be remembered that the weakening or liquidation of the central government in Yemen, the fighting that is taking place there, they are strengthening al-Qaeda, they are strengthening the Islamic State, and this is a scenario that is extremely dangerous for us. I therefore appeal to the European Union to strengthen political dialogue, but above all to address the humanitarian crisis, which I believe is extremely serious, is suffering from hundreds of thousands of people.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, a hundred days into the conflict, the security and humanitarian situation in Yemen is further deteriorating. I regret all loss of life in this conflict. I am concerned that violence has the potential to turn into a regional, sectarian conflict. Should this happen, it will further destabilise the Middle East and threaten Europe’s own security and economic interests. The EU, a champion of democracy and human rights, has the moral responsibility to help Yemen and its people. First, we need to end the violence, a humanitarian ceasefire to deliver aid to 80% of Yemen’s population; but the EU can only do so much. I therefore call on the regional powers, Saudi Arabia and Iran in particular, to show true leadership by assuming responsibility for the well-being of all Yemeni citizens. Weak governance, corruption, unemployment and unlimited social services have all been underlying causes of conflict in Yemen. The EU should use its international experience in institution-building and democratisation to train a new Yemeni government that would fairly represent and effectively govern all its citizens.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The chaos in Yemen is deepening and the country is becoming increasingly reminiscent of Libya and previous examples of countries that have been said to be failed states. The Saudi-led intervention of the Arab coalition has no effect. The negotiation process led by Sheikh Ahmed, the United Nations representative for Yemen, has recently slowed down, reportedly at the request of President Hadja. We receive media information about ongoing talks in Oman. Let us hope that all these efforts will have an effect, because Yemen is a country where very poor people suffer. There is a real humanitarian crisis and in the near future the role of the European Union, the High Representative, of all the institutions of the Union will be to organise a grand humanitarian aid plan for the people of Yemen.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Yemen is very close to the uncontrollable sectarian conflict and the international community, in particular the European Union, must step up diplomatic efforts to achieve a cessation of hostilities. The price to pay, if we do not act, is chaos, unbearable human suffering, the destruction of world heritage and the contagion of violence to neighbouring countries throughout the Middle East region. We cannot sit idly by and silent when we see the conflict in Yemen enabling terrorist groups such as Islamic State or Al-Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula to advance, an advance facilitated by the Saudi offensive that, in addition to indiscriminately penalizing yemen's civilian population, is blocking humanitarian access to the country, voting thousands to starvation and despair.  That is why the European Union must demand the lifting of the naval embargo imposed by Saudi Arabia and support diplomatic efforts by the UN and Oman in seeking a truce leading to a peace agreement.  At the same time, Mrs Mogherini must demand that Member States-Member States fulfil their obligations, in the light of international law and European rules themselves, with regard to the export of arms and military material to countries that use them in repression and violence against civilians, as is unfortunately the case with Saudi Arabia.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Firstly, I would like to commend the neighbouring states of Yemen, which have taken in refugees who have managed to cross the Strait of Aden. I think that their approach must be appreciated and that it contrasts with some of the views that have been expressed in the case of refugees on the ground of this Parliament or from some Member States of the European Union, including mine. Secondly, I would like to say that the humanitarian crisis that has occurred in Yemen should, of course, be dealt with best diplomatically, but above all by the initial demand for a humanitarian ceasefire, that is, to stop the fighting by both al-Qaeda insurgents and other groups, as well as from the Saudi-led coalition. I think that what would be most important is to make diplomatic efforts to establish a new Yemeni government, which will be established on the basis of the intrusion of all social groups within Yemen.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Yemen is in the grip of its most severe crisis in years, caused by conflicts and underlying problems of – please note – unequal access to power and resources mainly. It is not a conflict between the two wings of the Islamic faith. The recent developments carry grave risks for the stability of the Horn of Africa, the Red Sea and the wider Middle-East region. I am seriously concerned by the rapidly deteriorating political, security and humanitarian situation in Yemen. This could greatly exacerbate regional tensions and increase the possibility of a large-scale war in the area. According to the WHO’s latest figures, we are more than entitled to worry about the situation in Yemen. The unnecessary loss of lives cannot go on.  I back the EU’s position and its commitment to support Yemen and the Yemeni people, and I encourage and support, by all means possible, the negotiating process taking place. We need to engage constructively with the Yemeni parties in order to enable the de—escalation of the crisis. I am working on the efforts made by the United Nations, and I would highlight the need for a coordinated humanitarian action to contribute to the UN’s revised humanitarian appeal. I strongly believe that only a broad political consensus among the parties, attained through inclusive negotiations, can provide a sustainable solution, restore peace and preserve the unity, sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Yemen.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the situation in Yemen remains deranged and dangerous, with the country plunged into chaos. Commissioner, watching and reading the press over the last six months, the assessment in Yemen is as follows: armed conflict, bloodshed, military intervention by Saudi Arabia, naval blockade, removal of UN personnel and foreign diplomats for security reasons, persecution on grounds of religious belief, a huge humanitarian crisis, hunger, starvation, thousands of refugees fleeing and going to neighbouring areas. At the same time they are gathering because they want to reach Europe. Even in Greece we now have appeals from Yemen. At the same time, the jihadists are benefiting from this situation. So the question, Commissioner, is what the European Union is doing. As I said yesterday in another speech, closer cooperation with international organisations such as the OSCE and the UN could help bring about normality in Yemen. A political solution is needed for Yemen.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr President, if I may, I would like to say that I am not here to speak, but if the GROUP of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe has only one minute, I would ask you to give the floor to Mrs Izaskun Bilbao Barandica. I apologise, but I understand that there are four speakers... If there were five of them, otherwise I would ask you to give the floor to Mrs Izaskun Bilbao, because she asked to speak before me.

name: Presidente. –
text: We do not know that the honourable Member has asked for the floor. If you wish, I give you the floor. But I can give it to her, too.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: —Mr. President, what is quite certain— we stand before another incredible humanitarian crisis. And we need to be fully aware of that. Because this situation that's happening in Yemen today is not going to end overnight.  We see that there are various military interventions, various militias, paramilitarian groups operating in Yemen. The chaos is complete. Europe faces another major challenge of great humanitarian aid needs.  Millions of people will be hungry, a lot of kids will be able to not know how to survive tomorrow. That is why I call on the European Commission to make every effort to get us to invite all parties to the table. This is the only guarantee that the conflicts may be a little slightly and that we will avoid the humanitarian catastrophe in front of which, now, unfortunately we are definitely standing.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Yemen is once again aware of this long conflict that bleeds out one of the poorest nations in the world and because, last March, the bombing began and the suffering of the population grows to unbearable limits. On stage are all the unimaginable horrors: child soldiers, trafficking in human beings, attacking schools and hospitals and speculating on necessities. That is why we support an immediate humanitarian pause to resolve this emergency situation that will give way to a dialogue, without preconditions, under the umbrella of the United Nations and put an end to a conflict that lasts too long. We call for immediate humanitarian aid for the thousands of those affected and an international investigation into human rights violations. Active cooperation must be promoted to rebuild the country and the memory of all victims. And let me here be a special mention of the seven Basque and Catalan tourists who just now died eight years ago in an Al Qaeda attack in Marib and who testify to the longevity of this conflict.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as I said earlier, we all share the same goal: a durable cessation of hostilities and the resumption of UN-facilitated inclusive negotiations between the parties. In times of regional turmoil and ongoing sectarianism, this conflict can only increase instability and chaos. A negotiated ceasefire in Yemen, on the other hand, could help to build confidence that can contribute to the resolution of other issues in the Middle East. Only a broad Yemeni-led political consensus, responding to the legitimate grievances of all segments of Yemeni society, will provide a sustainable solution to the crisis. I remain convinced that confidence-building steps should be urgently agreed, including an immediate humanitarian pause with commensurate disengagement of armed forces in all areas including Aden, Taiz and Marib. This would allow international aid organisations to deliver urgently-needed food, medicine and fuel to citizens throughout Yemen. The lack of progress towards the resumption of an inclusive political track and the absence of steps towards de-escalating the conflict carry the risk of a greater regional conflagration, with serious consequences for the Gulf region, the Horn of Africa and, ultimately, Europe. Therefore, the time has come for all sides to restart the process of negotiations without preconditions, in order to restore legitimate state authority over the country for the benefit of its people. It is the joint responsibility of all Yemeni parties and regional players, with the help of the international community, to work towards this goal. Once again, the European Union remains committed to playing its full part in this process.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions to wind up this debate. The debate is closed.  Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The serious political crisis in Yemen has been going on for many months and has soon turned into a social and economic crisis, and the European Union cannot confine itself to the role of observer: political action must be taken, but also at the concrete level of humanitarian aid. Let us remember that Yemen is much closer to us than we are led to think: Yemeni refugees – but also all the people who have emigrated to Yemen from the Horn of Africa in recent years – will now turn to Europe for protection and asylum, exacerbating a phenomenon that we are already unable to manage satisfactorily.  Not only that: Yemen is a training ground for foreign fighters, as evidenced by the investigation into one of the two perpetrators of the Charlie Hebdo massacre in Paris. Two reasons why the moral imperative of helping a population to the exhausting should not be enough, we should move as soon as possible.  Finally, in practical terms, the European Union must call for a public commitment on the part of all those involved to ensure that corridors for the passage of humanitarian aid are guaranteed in all regions of the country. Even today, in fact, entire regions are impossible to reach.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the Annual Report on Human Rights in the World in 2014 (2015/2761(RSP)).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –  Mr President, it is a pleasure to present to this House today, on behalf of Vice-President/High Representative Mogherini, our Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World 2014. The annual report tells the story of the work the EU has done on human rights and democracy during the past year, both bilaterally with our partners worldwide and multilaterally. The year 2014 has been a year of unprecedented challenges to human rights. The world has not seen so many people fleeing conflict since the Second World War. Almost 60 million people are displaced worldwide. These millions of people fleeing their homes to find refuge from violence and economic hardship are an easy prey to violations of human rights. Finding an appropriate response to the manifold issues arising from these dire circumstances is often not easy. To ensure that the human rights of migrants are duly respected, we need to address all parts of the chain, providing immediate measures to save lives and fight traffickers while at the same time working on long-term strategies to tackle the root causes. The threat of terrorism poses an ever-growing challenge to our free and open societies, but we need to ensure that counter-terrorism activities are guided by the same principles that formed the foundation of our democratic societies. Respect for human rights is central in this regard. In the end, our ability to achieve sustainable improvements on human rights worldwide will also depend on our own ability to live by, and adhere to, these standards. Cooperation with this Parliament is one of the guardians of democratic principles and values and is therefore of utmost importance to us. In our concerted efforts to find solutions to the most pressing human rights concerns, the EU has taken action in multiple ways, and our report bears witness to that. It underscores the extensive work done by the network of EU delegations worldwide in following cases of human rights violations, meeting the lawyers of jailed human rights defenders, attending trials as observers and leading local, political and human rights dialogues with the authorities. In short, by being on the front line in defending people whose human rights are violated. In 2014 we held human rights dialogues and consultations with nearly 40 partner countries. In addition, many of the 79 African, Caribbean and Pacific countries that are part of the Cotonou Agreement conducted a dialogue with the EU, during which human rights issues in cases were raised. At the same time, the implementation of the 132 human rights country strategies has resulted in more intense collaboration between the EU delegations and Member States embassies on the ground and has led to more coherent human rights dialogues. Our main financial instrument in the area of human rights – the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights – has continued to support civil society organisations and human rights defenders worldwide. We have also strengthened our capacity to act in a coherent and effective manner by adopting guidelines on freedom of opinion and expression online and offline, and on freedom of religion and belief. The EU has reiterated its strong commitment to preventing and eradicating torture worldwide and has systematically raised individual cases during human rights dialogues, besides calling for the introduction of specific national prevention mechanisms. During the last year, we remained strongly committed to protecting children from violence, exploitation, abuse and neglect. The EU pledged more than EUR 100 million for the next seven years to gender equality and children’s wellbeing, including concrete projects on ending female genital mutilation and child, early and forced marriage. The crucial role of our Special Representative for Human Rights – and I am happy that Stavros Lamprinidis is with us today – in increasing the overall coherence, effectiveness and visibility of human rights in EU foreign policy cannot be highlighted enough. The year 2014 also marked the end of our first long-term policy on human rights, the Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy for 2012 to 2014, which has allowed the overall coherence and coordination of EU activities in the field of human rights to be improved. Progress could also be achieved in mainstreaming human rights across all EU policies and promoting greater coherence in our action towards third countries. Not least thanks to your valuable proposals, we managed to make remarkable progress in defining a new, ambitious, long-term policy document for promoting and protecting human rights worldwide in the next five years. I am happy to announce to the House today that, together with Member States, we are finalising the new action plan on human rights and democracy for the years 2015-2019. It will aim at substantive further progress in implementing the EU strategy adopted in 2012. It includes multiple dedicated actions focusing on those areas that require renewed political commitment and additional efforts. We intend in particular to concentrate on, firstly, empowering local actors and encouraging indigenous forces in a spirit of partnership, and secondly on addressing human rights challenges in key areas. These include freedom of expression, freedom of religion, anti-discrimination, gender equality, children’s rights, combating torture and promoting economic, social and cultural rights. Certainly we want to tackle and redress human rights violations in conflicts and crises. Further, we want to foster the coherence of the EU response in strategic policy areas such as migration, trade and counterterrorism. Finally, we want to deepen our effectiveness and improve the results of our tools. I am aware that this is a rather ambitious agenda. It will be the agenda for human rights in the coming years. Looking back on our activities, we have already come a long way. Despite the severe challenges that still remain, we should not underestimate the progress already achieved, hence our increased and concerted commitment for sustainable long-term solutions to the current complex and diverse challenges. We will continue to speak out on injustice and human rights violations all around the world. We will continue to challenge others as much as we challenge ourselves, and we will continue to critically assess our own approach and actions and, where necessary, adjust them. Your scrutiny is central and indispensable in this regard.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, I would like to begin by welcoming the adoption by the Council of the annual report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world in 2014, as well as the statement that Commissioner Hahn has just made. I am pleased to see that the European Commission is continuing the tradition of presenting this text to the European Parliament and I hope that the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, will be present in December, when Parliament debates and adopts its own report on this subject. I hope that the coherence and strength of our human rights and democracy policy will emerge as a winner from this inter-institutional dialogue.  In recent years, the annual report on the state of human rights and democracy in the world has really turned into a report on the implementation of the European Union's strategic framework and action plan on the same issue. Of course, this is a very positive development, because we need to take the time to reflect on what we are doing, day by day, to promote human rights and democracy. The annual report for 2014 leads me to wonder whether the interpretation given to the terms "implementation" is not too narrow. This year's report, which is almost 400 pages long, is actually a long catalogue that describes in detail the Union's actions. This includes the number of dialogues and consultations with third countries, the number of meetings with civil society, the details of human rights conferences, etc. I believe that the report should go further in understanding the terms 'implementation' and that it should also address the difficulties and, of course, the successes in the implementation of our human rights and democracy policy. It could thus fuel reflection on our policy with concrete examples. Similarly, again with regard to the content of the annual report, I think it would be important to put more emphasis on our policy of supporting democracy, because it appears to be in some way secondary to that in the field of human rights.  In reality, democracy and human rights are closely linked. The most basic rights of any individual are much more likely to be respected in a democratic system than in any other regime.

name: Elena Valenciano
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I am very grateful for the Commissioner's speech and I also know that there is a very powerful reason why Mrs Mogherini will not be here today. We all know why Mrs. Mogherini isn't here. And it's for a very good reason, for a very important reason. If Mr Lambrinidis is here, the Commissioner is here, and I thank you both for your presence. The analysis of the Annual Report cannot be a mere formality, nor a mere label. We are talking, from my point of view, of one of the elements that should inspire the heart of our external action. We are talking about a strategic approach to the role that the European Union has to play outside our borders. It is key, it is central, it is strategic and it is very important, not only because the number of humanitarian emergencies that are currently in the world is enormous: premature deaths, avoidable deaths, hunger, despair; not only because of the number of diseases, which we could also avoid, but also because of the immense number of displaced people, refugees, asylum seekers, desperately seeking a better life. Because there is something that occurs in all civilizations, on all continents and at all ages, and that is that human beings want to be free and live well. Everyone's entitled to the same thing. And I think the moment is especially critical, because we had thought, I think, a few years ago, that human rights were a struggle, a path that had only one direction forward, and we know that it is not, that it is a path of double direction, that we can move forward and we can go back, and my impression is that there are many human beings who are going back on the path to their dignity , towards true respect for their human rights. Why? For it is questioned, in many parts of the world, that human rights are universal, that they are indivisible, that human rights are the flag that all human beings need to raise. Because there are cultural, civil, political relativs that are calling into question that principle that was almost sacred to us. And they are regions of the world that have a lot of weight and have a lot of power, and that is why the European Union has to be much stronger than it has been, because we have the almost moral mandate to be the ones to continue to defend the indivisibility and universality of human rights; who we continue to say that all the women of the world want to be free, no matter where they live, because individually they want to be. This is the political task that the European Union has to face, knowing that we have many adversaries in this task.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Yes, this parliament has already had its hands full in recent years with countries that silence journalists, bloggers and human rights activists. In many countries, civil society has become considerably more difficult to play a role. Human rights are in a grey twilight zone in many countries. For the EU, human rights are at the centre, as an important pillar of our story. I would like to congratulate the Commission on european human rights policy. The human rights dialogue was extended to 37 countries. That is good. The instrument for democracy and human rights also gave EU embassies a greater role. But of course, the work is not finished. We must also reflect on the shortcomings of our policy. There needs to be more follow-up of human rights dialogues through verifiable and clear indicators. Countries that are making more efforts to reform should be better rewarded. European human rights programmes need to be more visible and discussed in depth. This is important in order to achieve even more success in the future.

name: Ivo Vajgl
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, unfortunately I have to deplore from the outset the fact that the European Union report on human rights does not follow a stated principle that we in our relations with the third countries attach priority to respect for human rights and international law. There are countries like Morocco, Armenia, Israel, Turkey and others which enjoy a permanent discount on their systemic violations of human rights and occupation of foreign territories. Let me give you two examples. Some days ago, The Guardian reported on how Morocco manipulated confidential reports of the United Nations concerning human rights violations and the situation in Western Sahara. Today – this is the second example – this House has ignored my call to commemorate the 1 500 civilian Palestinian victims, among them 500 children, who were killed in the attack on Gaza exactly one year ago on 8 July. It was too difficult for this Parliament to commemorate this event. Can we do better in the future? Certainly not with the new organisational chart of the EEAS presented recently by its Secretary-General. According to the proposed draft paper, the current directorate for human rights and democracy is being downgraded to an ordinary unit. This change of status is unacceptable and will certainly damage our overall effort to protect human rights.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I cannot burn Mr Vajgl's politeness. National selfishness is increasingly exacerbated. The hiatus between fine speech and bad practices are growing, not to mention double standards, depending on political allegiances and geostrategic interests.  How many, in fact, has the European Union taken in the 60 million refugees you mentioned earlier, Commissioner? What is the purpose of this report if the Member States, or even the Union itself, negotiate agreements, trade, sell arms in defiance of the "democracy" and "human rights" clauses, including with the world's worst dictatorships. I am thinking, in particular, of the countries of the Horn of Africa, of Eritrea and Sudan, but also of the Gulf countries or Egypt. It is the opposite of the need to act against the roots of the evil you were talking about. How can this report also ignore economic and social rights, at a time when inequalities are worsening around the world? This annual exercise is increasingly disconnected from real policies and serves as a justification for them. Rather than bringing the universalism of human rights, we are increasingly playing the game of the clash of civilizations. It is dramatic for "living together" here and elsewhere, and for human rights, everywhere.

name: Barbara Lochbihler
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the The annual report is a very comprehensive document and lists the EU's work in the field of human rights in foreign policy. I think I would like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks to all the staff in the EEAS, because a great deal of work has been done. Compared to other regions of the world, we can already say that the EU is a very active player and also an actor – compared to the other regions – who is working very consistently on the further development of human rights standards and who has also defended – and this has just become important – human rights achievements in recent years, such as the absolute validity of the universality of human rights. However, I would like the EU to take an even more decisive stand against all human rights relativism and, for example, to take more initiatives – for example, in the UN Human Rights Council with governments in the global south – to counter attacks on universality.  This report is a list of the work that has been done. I would ask you to consider whether such an annual report could not be partly different. It would therefore be interesting if evaluations were made as to the extent to which certain measures were also successful or not successful. It would be interesting to know, for example, how the human rights guidelines are applied by the EU delegations on the ground and what the results have been.  Such an assessment would certainly be important not only for the report, but also for the continuation and correction of one's own work. I said at the outset that the EU is a strong human rights player in foreign policy. The EU gains strength and influence, especially through credibility in its own actions. However, this credibility is seriously damaged if we lack consistency in complying with a policy in line with human rights in all areas, for example in our EU border and refugee policy, for example in our policy in the fight against terrorism. Last but not least, credibility is also reflected in the strengthening of human rights work in one's own institution, in the EEAS itself. There must be no downgrading or even weakening of working structures. Yes, mainstreaming is important, but mainstreaming human rights can only succeed if there is also a strong human rights directorate that can also keep up with the technical aspects.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by saying that I welcome this report. It reminds us that the basis of democracy and the basis of our EU cooperation is precisely the observance of human rights. Gender equality and women's participation in conflict resolution and the construction of democracy are central to security, both inside and outside the EU. Violence and abuse of women and girls are systematically used as weapons in war. It is a despicable phenomenon. Therefore, there must be a gender perspective in all the efforts made in this area. Among other things, women must be appointed as peacemakers in conflicts.  According to the report, important work is being done in this area, but it seems to be to a limited extent. I wonder what is being done to broaden the work and to create continuity. A key to the success of our work on human rights externally is also that we are credible and maintain a high standard at home. I therefore wonder how the Council and the Commission intend to strengthen the coherence between our internal and external human rights policies. Are there specific plans or specifically identified areas for this coming period?

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab During the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in the 1980s, the term "cargo 200" was known, meaning a coffin with the body of a soldier sent to the country. Wives, mothers, daughters could at least bury their loved ones. During the war in Ukraine, the Kremlin regime did not even give Russian women this luxury. Ukrainian Ambassador Konstantin Yalsieev, who was present at the SEDE meeting a few months ago, reported that a field crematorium had been transported to Ukraine. In this way, too, all traces of the presence of regular Russian troops on the territory of a neighboring state are also denied. Vladimir Putin inflicts incredible suffering and violates the human rights of his own people.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, the 2014 Annual Report clearly outlines the many human rights violations. This was largely a consequence of the conflicts we face.  Despite the enormous difficulties, the European Union continues its commitment to promoting respect for human rights and respect for international humanitarian law.  I call on us to continue to be an important actor in promoting freedom of expression and to strongly oppose the death penalty. We need to use the available diplomatic instruments and international partners to improve the human rights situation in many of the countries with which the European Union cooperates.  We must continue to support civil rights activists who have faced increasing pressure from authorities in many of their countries over the past year. These human rights defenders play an important role in promoting democracy.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The human rights report should be more than an annual compulsory exercise, and it is also because the European Union is one of the few global players for which human rights are at the centre – through the Special Representative Stavros Lambrinidis, through the framework of the human rights dialogues, which are very successful, which we have been able to expand – Myanmar, for example, I also hope that Iran will be present soon – , through the work of our delegations, where human rights are the focus of the work.  Sometimes I would like this emphasis on human rights to be not only hesitant, but more intense – as in the case of Azerbaijan, for example. I believe that it is very important that we also focus, above all, on strengthening the work of NGOs and on expanding the ever-increasing space that NGOs have globally today. NGOs are our natural allies.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the way in which We are talking about human rights today. The core of human rights is human dignity. Human dignity is universal, it is inviolable, it is indivisible, and it is related to the person. The EU wants to safeguard human rights, and that is a good thing. However, it is moving ever more away from these human rights. Human dignity, and therefore human rights, are not political, and they are not ideological. They don't come from politics, they were there before politics. And that is why politics cannot change human rights. But that is exactly what the EU believes it can do – here in Parliament, in the Council and also in the Commission. Mrs Post has just spoken about gender mainstreaming in relation to human rights. We serve special interests and make policy in the name of human rights. Let us return to the roots of human rights and preserve the dignity of the people! In many parts of the world, this would have won a lot.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome the Commission's efforts in the field of human rights protection. There is no doubt that the European Union is active, that it is promoting, I would even say, the universality of human rights at international level, which is not quite normal and obvious. For this, of course, I want to thank the Commission. However, I would also like to draw attention to a certain contradiction. We are constantly talking about fundamental human rights violations in specific cases in a number of cases of so-called urgency. Then we provide assistance to similar states or to the same states that we criticize here. I think that a certain conditionality should be included in our aspect of aid delivery precisely by good action in the field of human rights protection, by improving our own situation in that state, which we want to support. I think that this conditionality would suit the future progress of the European Union.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that we have an increase in human rights violations everywhere in the world and the fact that we have 60 million refugees and displaced persons is a terrible figure. We have many human rights violations, unfortunately also in member states, in our candidate countries that are close to us – but what I would like to focus on is the violation of children's human rights. It's a more recent phenomenon and in the worst possible way because children and young men are recruiting for new wars. Because girls are pushing themselves into unwanted marriages. Because little girls desec. There are major crimes against them, and I think this is something that we need to pay special attention to in this report and talk and act on the subject everywhere we can in the world.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, serious violations of human rights are now among the potential threats to international legitimacy, peace and security. In this context, some states export policy, exploiting human rights violations in third countries. They are interfering in the internal affairs of these countries. Other countries are being challenged by unsolicited human rights defenders to build their own image. Modern human rights challenges include actions to protect vulnerable groups of the population such as children, women, the disabled, refugees and minorities.  The European Union must have a serious presence in the field of human rights. Moreover, in its external relations it should not pursue a political ala kart, turning a blind eye to blatant cases of human rights violations, as is the case in Turkey. On the other hand, it should use human rights violations to explain that they must stop. The European Union itself must also respect human rights in its external action.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when we look back at 2014, we see a year of increasing instability across the world. We see human rights abuses by ISIS. We see actions by the North Korean government with a level of nastiness and a lack of respect for humanity which is frankly terrifying. We see cases like that of Raif Badawi, which is still going on today. Let us not impose a Western mindset upon other the countries, though, and go too far in looking at issues which go beyond human rights, but to our own personal views; and perhaps that is part of the failures that we have seen in terms of interventions in Iraq. I wonder whether, when we in the European Union seek to politicise trade as a matter of course, we are guilty of doing exactly that. I may be a UKIP MEP; I may not believe that these institutions and structures here are the right ones. But in a world which seems increasingly unstable, I can at least say that I agree that countries must work together in a spirit of cooperation, even though I do not believe these institutions are fit for purpose.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – When we talk about the state of human rights in the world, we often have advice, criticism and sharp criticism from different countries around the world. However, we can ask whether we are doing enough to substantially improve the human rights situation in the world. Even today, states that do not function properly under the rule of law receive significant development funds from European taxpayers and may even abuse EU citizens. Of course, with such states, we do not need the EU to stop cooperating, on the contrary, we need to monitor events more closely and put more pressure on our partners. If we do not stand up hard for our own citizens, how can we hold third countries accountable for ensuring a high level of human rights for their own citizens? I am convinced that the European Union must be more consistent in this area, because we have principles and values in which there is no debate between the Member States.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this very fruitful debate. I cannot agree more that maximising our internal-external coherence is of pivotal importance if we want our policies to be credible and to have real impact. In this process the role of this Parliament is vital. Mainstreaming human rights into all our external policies is an ongoing process, and despite much progress made so far we must continue our efforts. In that respect I fully agree that support and cooperation with NGOs is indispensable. If I take, for instance, only the neighbourhood area, there we have increased our budget for the support of NGOs by another 20% compared to the previous period. Finally, let me express my deep appreciation for the very constructive and enhanced cooperation with this House to ensure that we all speak with one voice in upholding the universality of human rights and supporting the democratic aspirations of our partners.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: n/a
text: in writing. – The Council adopted the Annual Report on Human Rights in the World in 2014, an extremely important report referring to numerous human rights violations around the world, defending and promoting human rights being the only way to guarantee security and stability in the world. It is to be appreciated that the EU has held formal human rights dialogues and consultations with many partner countries and regional groups. However, there has been a reduction in the area of action for civil society in many countries and an increase in the number of restrictions imposed on NGOs. The Union has condemned attacks against journalists and bloggers through public statements and bilateral relations and must continue to support human rights defenders. Efforts to prevent and eradicate torture and abusive treatment and to protect the rights of persons belonging to minorities should also be continued.
