At the same time, sustained efforts must be made and measures taken to support women who defend human rights and those in vulnerable and marginalised groups, to protect children from violence, exploitation, abuse and neglect. Funding for concrete projects relating to the cessation of female genital mutilation, as well as child marriages, premature marriages and forced marriages should be continued.

name: President. –
text: The next point on the agenda is the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the EU’s role in the Middle East peace process (2015/2685(RSP)). I have switched to English because we are going to have a vote. The S&D Group has informed me of its intention to request adjournment of this debate pursuant to Rule 190(1) of the Rules of Procedure. I give the floor to Mr Boştinaru, on behalf of the S&D Group, to move the request.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, you just said what I wanted to say. I just want to reiterate that, bearing in mind the importance of this debate and the fact that this debate is meaningful when the key player – the Vice-President of the European Commission – is there, the S&D Group, which practically initiated this process, repeated the call to adjourn the debate and to consider that debate possible with the High Representative in the Chamber. I would also like to inform them that we are coordinating with other political groups, and I hope that we shall agree that this debate will take place when all conditions are met.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Madam President, the EPP Group supports this request from the Group of Socialists and Democrats, but I must add that we regret that the announcement is so late.  I think we already knew a few days ago what Mrs Mogherini's programme would be and what arrangements could have been made before. But it is good to have the High Representative here with us, and we support that request.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the situation in the Middle East is untenable, and exactly one year ago today we witnessed, every minute of every hour of every day therein, for a few weeks, an onslaught on Gaza. 1 500 people were killed, including 500 little boys and little girls – exactly one year ago today. And okay, Mogherini is not here, and it would be better if she was, but we knew days ago that that was going to be the case. Surely as MEPs we have a job to do. Commissioner Hahn is quite capable and quite competent of doing what needs to be done, and as MEPs, we get paid well enough to do our job. Therefore we should be having this debate tonight, and I would ask MEPs to do the right thing – the decent thing – on this terrible anniversary that we are all reflecting on and to have the debate today, because unfortunately, in September I believe we will be back, because Israel, for instance, will violate international law and in September we will be back, having another debate.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, because our colleague made a statement which is completely untrue, I want to rectify that. Yesterday evening, just at the end of the day, we were formally and officially informed that the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy is still in Vienna for the negotiations on the Iran nuclear talks. It is completely unfair to blame the High Representative, knowing that she is working for peace in Europe.

name: President. –
text: Mr Boştinaru, I think it was clear why Ms Mogherini was not with us. The point was just whether the debate should be held with or without her, so that was the point. You made your point clearly. The debate is postponed to some time in the autumn.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Vincent Peillon's report on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa and the prospects for political stability (2014/2229(INI)) (A8-0193/2015).

name: Vincent Peillon
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, we have been talking all afternoon about issues such as Yemen or human rights, and we could also have talked about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, all of which are at the heart of the report on stability in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA). This report is certainly a bit dense, but it accompanies the Commission's desire to give a strategic line to Europe's action in this region.  In this report, we were obliged to review all the different subjects: Syria, Libya, Iraq, Yemen, Tunisia, the fight against the Islamic State group. At the same time, it is not in the accumulation of specific cases that we have sought to identify a precise and long-term strategic line. The principles we have adopted in this report are first and foremost principles of accountability. There would have been nothing worse for us, the European Parliament, than to divide ourselves by taking up this challenge, when our South is already in the state we see and our imperiousness proven. So we have always sought to listen to each other and to find consensus.  From this point of view, I would really like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs very warmly, Mrs M-nescu for the EPP, Mr Nart for the Liberals, Mr Belder, Mr Smith for the Greens, Mr Iglesias, Mr Permuy, Mr Castaldo, Mrs Vergiat.  Whatever the political orientations, apart from those who are frankly anti-European, we have sought to build a common, responsible and can be heard.  The principles that have guided us are as follows, and know that it has not been easy to define them. First, do not consider that the security challenge must be limited to security itself. Of course, we have to meet this challenge, and there is no excuse for terrorism, either economic or social. It has ideological underpinnings. From this point of view, we are fulfilling our responsibilities by calling for strengthening and better coordination of Europe's security action. But at the same time - this is the strategic line we want to adopt - we know that peace and stability can only come back if we deal with the long-term causes: the democratic question and the human rights issue, which we have just addressed, the economic question and the social question.  Of the three parts of the report, two are devoted to the economic and social issue, the democratic question and the question of human rights. This allowed us to find a consensus, in a balance where there would not be a single cause, but multifactorial actions. Yes, we must intervene on the security issue, we must strengthen Europe's action, we must provide assistance to States, we must better help to monitor borders, we must of course do everything we can to train those who must ensure security on our southern flank and at the same time we must deploy economic and social actions. The second fundamental line of this report is quite new and structures the whole process. It is to admit that Europe cannot - as it tends to do, as we have heard in previous debates - hope to solve all the problems alone, in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, through a number of invocations or interference.  This report is based on a balance between the desire to have concerted, long-term, coherent action and, at the same time, to rely, on the one hand, on the States, but also on all the multilateral instruments that exist, especially in the South. In conclusion, Madam President, I believe that on these two aspects we have found a strategy and we have managed to come together around the idea that Europe needs to be more present in order to take more decisive action.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I appreciate the opportunity to speak to you today upon the presentation of your excellent report on ‘The security challenges in the MENA region and the prospects for political stability’. You have very accurately described the main political developments in the region over the last four years and well highlighted the areas in which the EU could play an important role. As you know, the geopolitical landscape of the MENA region has been utterly transformed during this period. Today, the EU is facing an arc of conflicts and crises – from Iraq, Syria and an unresolved Middle East conflict, to Libya and the Sahel, with spillover effects throughout the region. At the same time, the talks with Iran give us hope that a more cooperative order in the region is indeed possible, and therefore once again I think it is justified that our High Representative is there and participating very actively in these discussions. Let me briefly mention the state of play and how the EU sees the situation in some of these countries. In Tunisia, following the attacks in Sousse, we are more united than ever to ensure success of the transition with the Tunisian people. I have instructed my services to use accelerated procedures to deliver our support, including measures directed at the tourism sector, which is demoralised as a result of this attack, and may I recall that we were able to discuss this issue in extenso earlier today. In Libya, the EU – together with the international community – has deeply engaged with the country, but I cannot emphasise enough my plea to Libyan participants to accept the UN proposals in good faith in the interests of the Libyan people. On the unresolved Middle East conflict, the EU stands ready to work with both Israel and Palestine, and all other major stakeholders, to return to negotiations with the aim of achieving a comprehensive peace agreement based on a viable two-state solution. The situation in Syria and its neighbourhood is a strong reminder of the urgency to reignite an inclusive Syrian-led political process on the basis of the Geneva Communiqué. We fully support the UN Special Envoy Staffan  de Mistura, and along with the UN we have launched an urgent humanitarian appeal for the region. As underlined in ‘The EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq as well as the Da’esh threat’, we are determined to support the efforts of those countries hosting a huge number of refugees. In this context I must mention the efforts of Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey: the burden they are carrying is enormous. We are also ready to cooperate with Iraq and other neighbouring countries on security and counter-terrorism issues and to move towards implementation of much-needed political and socio-economic reforms. Against this background, we welcome your excellent report on ‘The security challenges in the MENA region and the prospects for political stability’. We thank in particular Vincent Peillon for his work as rapporteur, the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) and all MEPs for their constructive approach to the challenges faced in the Mediterranean region. I would also include in my thanks, of course, the shadow rapporteurs. I fully agree with your conclusion that the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya and the increase in tensions in the MENA region are major sources of destabilisation, that the risks these developments entail for European security are serious, and that it is a huge challenge to effectively enunciate and implement a coherent conflict resolution strategy. I also agree with your conclusion: to effectively deal with this challenge, the European Union and its Member States must think strategically in the medium and long term. We must look at all issues from a broad, global perspective; we need to develop all-round policies, responding to the emergencies but also dealing with their deep causes; and we need to keep strengthening our cooperation with all relevant regional actors, for complex threats require coordinated responses. Crisis management is important, but it is not enough. Think of terrorism: in the long term, I believe that functioning and inclusive democracies, human rights, education and good jobs are the best antidote to radicalisation. As stated in your report, fighting terrorism must go together with supporting genuine democratic reform in the region. Some believe that countering terror requires repression. In fact it is the exact opposite: in the long run, a democratic environment is the only cure for radicalisation. Mostly this is about providing opportunities to the youngest members of society. Young people must be inspired by values that reject violence, create peace and build inclusive, open societies. This is why supporting education is so important. But education is of little use if we cannot also create jobs, and good jobs. This is vital to ensure that everyone finds a positive role to play in society. All communities must be given a chance to contribute to the social, economic and political life of their own countries. Entire religious and ethnic groups – Christians and others – are being forced to flee from lands they have inhabited for centuries. This has little to do with a ‘clash of civilisations’: the terrorists often know very little about the Qur’an. It is not a war of religion but a struggle for power and regional hegemony. The EU is doing all it can to halt and prevent this violence. We will not let sectarianism prevail. Moreover, I fully agree that the engagement and empowerment of women in the public, political, economic and cultural spheres is key to fostering stability, peace and economic prosperity in the long run. Women’s rights and gender equality must be basic components of the political and human rights dialogue between the EU and the MENA countries. The EU is committed to ensuring that human rights are mainstreamed in all its activities. Since 2012, the EU has engaged regularly with the League of Arab States, including the Arab Human Rights Charter Committee and the Arab National Human Rights Institutions. As you rightly point out, in the past the European Neighbourhood Policy sometimes failed to adequately take into account the specificities of each of our partners, including with regard to identifying civil society partners needing support and capacity-building assistance. The review of the Neighbourhood Policy that is on the way is an opportunity to introduce changes that will help the EU to be a stronger player. We intend to propose ways and means to further the European Neighbourhood Policy, to allow more tailor-made offers and solutions specially designed for each partner. I would also like to thank the European Parliament for the constructive input you have given and will, no doubt, continue to give. A comprehensive approach needs strong and reliable partners in order to be effective. Both Europe and the Arab world are targets for the terrorists. We need a truly global alliance to fight our common battles. As the report states, regional challenges call for regional solutions. In this sense, the report is very much in line with our commitment for closer co-operation with the League of Arab States and the Union for the Mediterranean. As agreed in the EU-League of Arab States Athens Declaration, we are working closely on counter-terrorism in the MENA region, on capacity-building measures and to address the ‘foreign fighters’ phenomenon. Before I leave you the floor, let me add something on the naval operation in the Mediterranean. After the mid-April tragedy, Member States asked the European Union to act against the human traffickers’ networks, to save more lives. In the space of two months, we set up and launched the operation. Countries from all sides of Europe are contributing. Things did not move on so smoothly on the domestic side of the debate. This tells us something. Our problem, most of the time, is a lack of political will. It is not our strength that is being tested, but our resolve. I look forward to hearing your views on this strategic debate.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I speak on behalf of the PPE Group. Our shadow reporting, Mrs. Manescu, is not available here.  I want to say first of all that it is no longer a secret that the Near East and North Africa are going through a very turbulent period. After the optimism generated by the Arab uprisings, today we are very concerned about developments in the region. We have states on the brink of collapse, redoubtable terrorist networks, millions of refugees and massive violence. Or Europe's security is inextricably linked to the stability and security of this region. That is why I would like to congratulate Mr Peillon on his report. This report proposes an in-depth analysis of recent developments and more leads to address security challenges.  I am also pleased that the High Representative, in her reflection paper on the revision of the European Security Strategy, recognised the need to redefine the Union's approach to the Near East and North Africa. I believe we need a comprehensive and ambitious approach that takes into account the causes of the rapid deterioration of the situation in the region. The threat of terrorism forces us to make consistent use of our internal and external security policies. Humanitarian assistance and development cooperation must also be harmoniously combined.  And, because we have spoken before about human rights, I would like to highlight a very important point for the PPE Group, namely the continued violation of religious freedom in this region and, above all, the freedom of Christians. Last week, our Group held a conference on this subject and we could hear shocking testimonies. That is why we believe that the Union must have a very clear strategy to protect Christians in this region.

name: Richard Howitt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, firstly, we regret the absence tonight of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy,  Ms Mogherini – though for the very best of reasons, because we can remain hopeful that a comprehensive nuclear deal may be struck with Iran this week, something which could help the country start to re-engage with us in Europe and others in the international community, and which can play an important role in advancing security for the region as a whole. Of course any deal must be fair, credible and fully verifiable. But this is a week where we also hope there may be genuine progress in another set of long-standing negotiations which at times had seemed intractable: the reconciliation talks in Libya. What marks both sets of negotiations is the real human suffering caused by lack of agreement, and the huge political obstacles existing which obstruct agreements from being achieved. If they are – and tonight’s debate must encourage that – it will be a victory for patient diplomacy, where I am proud that the European Union is playing the leading role in both cases. In a third conflict in the region between Israel and Palestine – seemingly the most intractable of all – this Parliament should welcome and encourage the more active role in political diplomacy which the High Representative is prepared to play there. I look forward to the debate with her in September. Vincent Peillon’s excellent report recognises that there are issues of mistrust and resentment about Europe in the region, based on history and on sometimes justified criticism of double standards against European countries ourselves. We have to impress on the countries of the Middle East and North Africa, and their populations, that Europe does not want to return to colonialism. We have to learn lessons by being consistent in our support of respect for democracy and for human rights amongst the countries, despite any considerations of alliance. When I sit in this Chamber and listen to statements about migration and terrorism, these are proper concerns. But we need to articulate them in a way which shows the countries of the region that we want to support peace, prosperity and development for them and their peoples, in their own interest first and not just through the prism of managing issues which are problems to us. Our response to the Mediterranean refugee crisis is a true test of our good intent in that respect. The new phenomenon of ISIS-Daesh is a huge and terrible concern. I add my own personal condolences for the deaths of tourists in Tunisia who came from my own country, Great Britain, but also from fellow European nations Belgium, Germany, and Ireland too. We need a better security response. Territorial advances against ISIS in Syria and Iraq are important if they are to be denied the claim of statehood which their name of so-called ‘Islamic State’ implies. We have to be careful in our own words and actions not to add to the narrative of extremism – which is ultimately self-defeating – by generating radicalisation rather than diminishing it.  For example, at Parliament’s Middle East and North African working group, which I am proud to chair, the European External Action Service recently told us that reports that terrorists were entering Europe under the cover of being refugees are not supported by one shred of evidence. Let us learn by what I started with – the value of patient diplomacy – rather than ramping up the rhetoric as we deal with the countries of this region. Finally, whether in Yemen, which we were discussing earlier, or in Libya, which I have already referred to, and in several other countries, we have to recognise that religious sectarianism is a huge cause of conflict and instability. One thing we must do, as Europe, is to engage with political Islam – not to agree with them, but to talk with those who represent political Islam – if we are truly to have a dialogue to pursue the common interests of our continent and theirs.

name: Bas Belder
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Exactly one week ago I was at the Golan Heights with some colleagues. What was happening there, a few kilometres away, before our eyes, was truly horrific. Syrian villagers are being bombarded incessantly by Jabhat al-Nusra, Hezbollah and then Islamic State. Horrible! I have to tell you honestly that you get a sense of shame when you see how the killing continues while the world community is passive. Although the UN is present in southern Lebanon and on the Golan Heights, it is powerless. There's only Israel there. I would like to pay tribute to the medical service of the Israeli army. At night, so as not to be in danger of being shot by snipers, those wounded evacuate from Syrian villages – now nearly 2,000 – and offer medical care under mortal danger. The Israeli military often perform heroic acts there. That's what I want to say. Early this morning I read in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung an impressively penetrating interview with the expelled bishop of Mossoel. He was talking about us, too. He was asked how he looked at us. I quote: "The people of the West are fighting for the conservation of species threatened with extinction. How, then, can they passively watch an entire people being driven out and massacred? How can they watch as a people slowly but surely disappears from the history of mankind? If a third of the Syrian Catholic Church is scattered around the world, it actually means the demise of this Church. I ask, I pray to the West and the world powers for help. Make an effort to drive IS out of our country. Today these warriors are with us. Tomorrow they will be with you." (End quote.) I would add: they are already here, the Syrians! When do we wake up?

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we have many things to point out about this report, because we understand that security in the area has a lot to do with the interventions that have taken place before. It also has a lot to do with the repressive treatment of all those who want to escape that chaos that precisely our unilateral interventions— or even, using these euphemisms, of "responsibility to protect" — have provoked. We therefore do not understand how this issue can be approached only through the repression, of Frontex, and not through investment, of a change in the asymmetry between unequal relations between the centre of the European Union and our neighbourhood countries. Only in this way can we have real security: not by injiating, not destabilizing and, above all, not having an unequal economy and trade.

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, there is much to admire in this report, and I would add my own congratulations to Mr Peillon and his team for some genuinely good cross-party work on this. Our group is broadly supportive and, as rapporteur for my group, I am very pleased to see that our wording on social injustice and inequality, and on how that is a breeding ground for radicalisation, is included, as are security, instability and corruption and how they interplay. The wording on the Israeli settlements and their malign influence within the wider region is also included. The all-out oppression of the Assad regime within Syria, the use of drones, the strategic importance of the Nile and the need to accelerate human rights in the EU – League of Arab States dialogue, is, we think, all very positive wording. That is not to say that we are entirely satisfied. This is a report about the security challenges in the wider region, yet it does focus very much on Daesh – mentioning Daesh 21 times. Daesh is, of course, a dreadful organisation, but it is one organisation amongst many in a very complex picture. Often it is as much a symptom as a cause. I would personally like to see much more vocal criticism of Israel’s actions in the region, given that it is a recruiting sergeant for radicalisation. There are forces of progress within Israel, and we must reach out to them and assist them in their efforts to have a constructive debate within Israel and with Palestine. The EU could play a leading role in that, but we are not. We also call, in the report, on some states to refrain from exporting terrorism. I am not sure that is helpful language; I am not sure it adds much value either. We also call for the EU to provide a safe haven for Christians, in particular from the Middle East, in the EU. If we are trying to criticise sectarianism, we should refrain from it ourselves. The plight of any refugee, regardless of their ethnicity or their religion, is equally dreadful. But all in all, we are satisfied with this report. I think it is a good contribution to a very complex situation, and I congratulate the rapporteur for his work.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to express my thanks to my colleague Vincent Peillon for his work, which has been very inclusive. I was pleased to see the attention paid to many of the demands we have made. I consider this report to be a fairly substantial step in the right direction. We are right to talk, as Mr Smith pointed out earlier, about some of the real and most fundamental causes of instability, which are poverty, marginalisation and discrimination. We are therefore looking for an approach which is political, economic, social and cultural and which is not limited solely to the security aspect. Clearly, I realise that theatre is in the throes of enormous instability and that providing a detailed analysis of every single context is impossible here. However, I wanted to stress the importance of putting the latent conflict between Saudi Arabia and Iran in black and white and the need for a confidence building that must be strengthened over time and, above all, the strong call for Turkey to assume a less ambiguous role than we have seen in recent years. I also express, of course, my concern about Israel's settlement policy in the Palestinian West Bank and express the hope that this report will also encourage the parties to seriously restart a credible peace process, given that it is one of the historically, but also at present, most difficult and dangerous hotbeds to deal with. I would like to stress two fundamental concepts that we must always bear in mind if we want a lasting solution. Firstly, political Islam must necessarily be an interlocutor and must be the interlocutor that allows us to isolate extremism decisively. The second is that we must, in my opinion, focus a great deal on working with the model countries – I am thinking precisely of Tunisia but also of Lebanon, as well as Jordan – by focusing our attention on them and pressing for healthy cooperation with international cooperation organisations, such as the Gulf Cooperation Organisation, we can achieve important results.

name: Aymeric Chauprade
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mr Peillon for his report and add some geopolitical elements that I have not read in this document. First of all, the tragedy of the Middle East is the assessment of the Euro-American policy that destroyed the plans to modernize the Arab world and which has in fact strengthened Islam in Societies of Muslim culture. This policy then re-established the Shiite-Sunni divide, which turned into a war exacerbated by strategic competition between Iran and Saudi Arabia.  And then there is the "Islamic State," which has allowed the United States to implement its oil strategy. In the summer of 2014, the price of a barrel, I remind you, ladies and gentlemen, collapsed sharply from $105 to $55, just as the "Islamic State" was putting cheap oil on the world market. This strategy of collapsing the price of a barrel directly hit states whose budgets depended heavily on high oil prices, such as Iran, Venezuela and Russia. Iran was pushed to negotiate on nuclear power and, as in the 1980s with Reagan and the USSR, Russia, which was already subject to Economic Sanctions by the European Union, suffered the brunt of the fall of the barrel.  These are some geopolitical realities that I invite you to reflect on and which I believe go beyond the wishful thinking that we all share for the future of the Middle East. The reality is that the destruction of the Middle East has largely served American policy to block the emergence of a multipolar world.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we face a negative and destructive synergy in the Middle East and North Africa. What have been, for a long time, internal conflicts have spilled over to the whole region now. The most dangerous thing is the melting down of borders between states in conflicts. These conflicts have become now international and vacuums are being filled by Islamic State and other extremist groups. Lawlessness, extreme violence and terrorism have become a new normality in large areas of Syria, Iraq, Libya and elsewhere. By the way, Middle East countries represent only 5% of the world population but provide one third of world refugees. Eighty per cent of civilians are unable to meet their basic needs now. Eleven million children lack possibilities for education. They form the ever widening basis of a new generation of terrorists. There are two points I would like to make. Among the different minorities, Christians have suffered most widely. Violence against them presents existential danger for the future. As a result, this ancient community will disappear from the region where Christianity was born, mainly as a result of the determined efforts of Muslim extremists to cleanse this area of all other religions. This is something the EU should address with the utmost seriousness, providing them with active protection and probably safe havens. Secondly, the situation in Iran, which has been for years a source of the exporting of terrorism and instability. To hope that cooperating with the Tehran regime and its Revolutionary Guards would help the fight against ISIS is, I would say, naive and would be like attempting to oust the devil with the help of Beelzebub. Why has Mosul stayed for more than one year under ISIS? Because local Sunni minorities are equally afraid of Shia militias, who do not make any difference between them and ISIS terrorists. So, Iran has first to demonstrate credible political will that it is really interested in restoring stability, especially in Yemen and Iraq. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I would like to thank you for your support. In fact, you have looked at the problem quite nicely – because this is a very serious problem – that is stretched between different religions, but I do see that this element has not been of such importance in European foreign policy so far. To what extent would you include religious issues in conflict resolution?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Could you ask the question once again, please?

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – I will just repeat this, but shift into English as well. My question was that your point of view, and then your panorama of the religious conflicts, was a mainly new element in the interpretation here in this room, and I was just wondering whether you feel a need for a further development of this argument.  That was all my question was about.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – As far as I can understand this question, of course, we need to generate a more intense and widespread approach to religious conflicts and, as I confirmed, our special care should be Christian minorities, which have suffered most as a result of fighting between Sunnis and Shias.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, first of all, what I would like is to thank the rapporteur, Vincent Peillon, for his work as rapporteur for a report which is very relevant to us. The result of the report is very positive because it maintains a good balance between what is general and what is specific, between what is regional and what is national, in the face of one of the most important challenges facing Europe today, which is to deal with the crises we face in the Middle East: from ISIS to the migration crisis , going through Libyan chaos, very different, interrelated things that directly challenge the European Union. The report covers all the great challenges that Europe has and it is very positive that it gives a multidimensional approach, that not only speaks of security, that it is not limited to that, but also talks about cultural issues, intercultural dialogue, poverty and inequality, something that is obvious: many times behind these great problems there are such solutions , so you have to go further or try to go beyond the surface. As for the Syrian crisis, first of all, it is right to support the actions taken by member states in the international coalition, but we must be well aware that military action will not be enough, not enough, to end ISIS. Of course it won't be. The European Union has allocated EUR 400 million in humanitarian aid to Syria and its neighbours, which is also not enough. It should be remembered that some countries such as Jordan or Lebanon continue to take in millions of refugees, while we are unfortunately unable to agree with States on a system of minimally solidarity quotas. On Egypt, the report calls on the Government to respect human rights and political freedoms. We appreciate the efforts that the Egyptian government is making in the fight against terrorism, but what cannot happen, as is happening, is that President Al Sisi hides in the fight against terrorism to systematically violate human rights and, in some cases, commit crimes, imprison peaceful protesters or sentence political opponents to death. As for the negotiations with Iran, on its nuclear programme, The High Representative, Federica Mogherini, now needs more than ever our support — we already know that it is not here today because it is working on this issue — a closed, clear and resounding support from the European Parliament, so that negotiations to end the current sanctions system come to fruition. It should be remembered that this new bridge we opened relocates all of Europe's geopolitical relations with the Middle East and within the Middle East itself. I want to talk, to finish, about the situation of the conflict in Israel and Palestine. We know that the status quo is absolutely unbearable, unsustainable, that we need to restart the peace process, that the composition of the current Government also does not leave much room for optimism, and that the European Union should consider additional measures. The system of labeling products from Israeli settlements is a minimum, as is also using some of the tools we have, such as the Union for the Mediterranean, something that we must take advantage of and which is in a fantastic city called Barcelona. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lopez, you have done a good job of summing up the problems that we face with ISIS, as many have already done in this Chamber this evening. It is a question where we hear a lot about the problems, but very little in terms of specific solutions. You said yourself that what we are doing now is not enough. So what do we do? Do we have more military intervention, given the problems that were caused in Iraq and in Afghanistan previously? We cannot apply sanctions to these countries. What is your proposal for action here?

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr Arnott, first of all, why does the Islamic State appear? Because of the situation in the area today, because of the power vacuum produced; if we resolve the situation in Syria and resolve the situation in Iraq today, we will have the best formula to help end the Islamic State. But it's not just that: the second thing we have to do is dialogue with the Arab world, with partners in the area, that they are involved in the struggle that, of course, must be carried out in front of ISIS. And thirdly, we must think about the cultural and economic reasons behind this issue. This is not easy, it does not have a simple answer, but that is why you have to get to work.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I have no doubt that Mr Peillon has put a lot of effort into this report, but it seems to be a ‘catch-all’ for every possible difficulty, tension and crisis across a vast region. Many of these countries are unrelated in the nature of the problems that they face. The main answer for him seems to be the European Union, as well as large helpings of motherhood, apple pie and blinding statements of the obvious. I seriously question the point of this sort of unfocused report and the associated hand-wringing. In any case, given the difficulties the EU is having in sorting out its own internal problems, I think a little more modesty would be useful. The EU’s main resource is  money – it has been endowed by our taxpayers with over-generous financial resources. However, at the moment we are clearly not getting a good return for our money. We should try and use our resources on a more targeted and wiser basis. There I specifically pick up what was said about the Middle East peace process. We have leverage on the Palestinians and we should use that leverage to bring them to the negotiating table.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would also like to start by saying that I think there is a great deal that is good in this report and that it is very broad and comprehensive. However, I would also like to raise a few issues that I think are missing. There are two issues in particular that I think are missing. The first is that no mention is made anywhere of Western Sahara, despite the fact that it is 40 years this year that the country has been occupied. The report that we are going to discuss after this, the report on the neighbourhood policy, which states that it is not acceptable for one country to occupy the territory of another country. But for some reason this is not true in the case of Western Sahara, because there we are constantly allowing a partner country to prevent the promised referendum. They are allowed to seize natural resources and they are allowed to change the population structure without any consequences whatsoever. The Sharians have chosen nonviolence. I believe in nonviolence, but we must also acknowledge them for the nonviolent work they do. We cannot forget them simply because they do not use force. The second issue that is also missing here is arms exports to the region. The report talks about the fact that there is a new situation throughout the Mena region and that we need to adapt our measures to the new situation, but we are not talking about what we ourselves are contributing to this region. Between 2010 and 2014, we accounted for 32% of all arms exports. In 2013, we sold arms for a total value of EUR 9.6 billion and in 2012 EUR 10.7 billion. We now need to seriously start thinking about whether we should really put the sale of weapons to a region where they may very soon be used against us.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I find myself agreeing with my colleague and esteemed opponent, Geoffrey van Orden. This report seems to be extremely windy and very worthy, but I am afraid that it does not have any practical or sensible solutions to the Middle East. Quite frankly, I think the European Union should not be involving itself in this matter. It should be left very much to the great powers and to NATO, who can better deal with it. One of the things I find interesting about North Africa is that the countries we have not interfered with, such as Morocco, have a stable government and an emerging democracy. The more we keep out of interfering in those affairs, the better. But what we should be concentrating on is the threat from ISIS coming across the Mediterranean from North Africa. We should not be encouraging people to come across. We should try to stop that. There are far too many woolly words about people and refugees. This must be stopped for the good and safety of Europe, or we will have even more problems being imported into Europe itself. We should also stop arguing with Russia. With Russia we have a common enemy in a medieval, religious conflict which, quite frankly, we do not want to be part of. Russia has a similar problem in its southern republics to the one that we have. I think we were better off cooperating with Russia rather than fighting with Russia. At the moment, all the European Union seems to do is squabble with Russia over Crimea, which is not at all sensible. Let us leave that out. Let us be friendly with Russia. Let us try to make sure we do something sensible in the Middle East and not carry on the sort of nonsense we have been doing up until now.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I do not clearly share the last speech before me on Russia policy, and I do not believe that the majority of the House should. However, since this is not the subject of this report, I do not want to go into it further. I do not think we can, of course, touch on all aspects in a short period of time. That is why I want to focus once again on the word Tunisia, which we discussed earlier. I had suggested that we consider whether we might convert our suspended EU Border Assistance Mission Tunisia-Libya into a border protection support mission directly for the Tunisian side, in order to stop the infiltration of terrorists, especially from Libya. Libya is my other catchphrase. I think we all know what the situation was at the time of the overthrow of Gaddafi. It was right, in my view, that we did not intervene there as an EU, but as some Member States. I still believe that we prevented a real massacre in Benghazi. But – and this is the big thing – after that, it was not desirable for us to take action on the ground with our tried-and-tested programmes, such as security sector reform. I believe that we could have done well, partly because the Libyans at least had money, and in return we could have carried out, among other things, a security sector reform. That did not happen. We know what the situation is there now, and that is why I think it is right that we support the efforts of the United Nations, but also the efforts of Algeria and Morocco to strengthen the internal Libyan dialogue. That is explicitly in this report.  And then, if it really leads to success, if hopefully we soon have a unity government in Libya, then we should come back with the offers and offer the Libyans, among other things, a reform of the security sector, but also other things to make state-building possible. That is the key to achieving an end to the flow of refugees via Libya.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by welcoming the author of the report for the quality of the report and above all for the lucid view on the issue of the Middle East and North Africa that can be produced from Europe.  First, there is a clear refusal of the theory of the clash of civilizations, of the confrontation between a supposed Western essence as opposed to an essence of the Islamic world, which would be homogeneous and would be doomed to face each other. On the contrary, there is a very clear understanding of the complexity of the situation in North Africa and the Middle East. It is a historical reality of extreme complexity and marked by deep divisions – political divisions, religious divisions, cultural divides, social and economic divisions and which, in fact, today lead to a somewhat chaotic situation throughout that region.  And what should Europe's reaction to this neighbouring region be? The reaction must always be placed on the political and diplomatic level. And I believe that this is where the secret of our intervention has to be, and it is well placed in the report. Turn all this into an issue essentially at the political level.  The report deals with some of the most important issues: the conflict between Israel and Palestine, the issue of ongoing negotiations to resolve the Iranian nuclear issue, the call for the European Union itself to make a political contribution to improving relations between Iran and Saudi Arabia, to overcoming a conflict that is now a structural conflict in the whole region. It takes a very serious and realistic approach to what is now one of the biggest challenges we are facing in that area, which is the challenge of terrorism, and makes an assessment without any kind of contemplation. There are several answers to be given and none of them can be excluded, because they must, moreover, be articulated with each other. Finally, I would like to focus on an issue on which the previous speaker focused on me, which is the issue of Tunisia. Tunisia today is a special country in that region. It was in Tunisia, as we know, that the Arab Spring began. It is now very easy to challenge the Arab Spring and even launch the idea that, truly, those countries are not prepared for the construction of a rule of law and a true democratic regime and that the Arab Spring has increased conflict and increased chaos in the region. But the truth is that we cannot, as Europeans faithful to a certain set of values, remain insensitive to those who in these countries fight precisely for the construction of a rule of law, for the separation between the public sphere and the private sphere in religious matters, for the consecration of freedoms, for the building of a true democracy. It was in Tunisia that the Arab Spring began, and Tunisia is the example, so far the only successful example, of that same Arab Spring. And unfortunately, it's been attacked for that very. The recent attack there is an attack not only on the Tunisian people, but is an attack on a demand to build a democratic rule of law throughout that region. And the European Union has a duty of additional solidarity with Tunisia. Tunisia has expressed this will, it has made calls for enhanced cooperation, and we must be up to our responsibilities. It is a neighbour, and it is a neighbour which now means much more than its own historical-geographical dimension and therefore deserves special attention from the European Union.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: "We describe the threats and challenges in the Middle East and North Africa that we face, but actually what answers we have. Just before that, the pre-speaker recalled the Arab Spring. It was the Arab Spring that was supposed to be the answer, but what did it bring? War, increased threat to Christians, threat to security in the region. And this is a new wave of immigration that we cannot deal with. The financial decisions that we made yesterday are also the aftermath of the Arab Spring.  Let's think about what we can do concretely. We see that it all goes on, we see what is happening in Sinai: attacks on government forces, attacks on Israel. Let us think of concrete things, such as the implementation of the announcement of the fight against the infrastructure of smugglers, who organised a huge industry of smuggling people into Europe and which we were to oppose. So far, we have not requested united nations permission to act against their infrastructure where it is built: in ports. And let's really help those who need help. Syrian Christians are waiting for help with equipment: who is to help them? It is we, the Countries of the West, that should help them. And these are specific things that we can do for the security of this region.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Peillon on his report. It covers, of course, a very broad, very complex theme, also of particular topicality and, of course, there has been much effort that has had to be made to be able to compress this very broad reality in its text. I say of particular breadth and topicality because from Tunisia to Iraq and Yemen a long arc of instability, crisis, conflict has been opening up for years, including clashes in Libya and the war in Syria. Unfortunately, its end is not near - I am referring, for example, to the conflict in Syria or to the long Israeli-Palestinian conflict - because, despite the efforts made by the international community in these years, it does not seem to be going to be resolved any time soon. I also say that it is a complex reality because it encompasses very different situations, many of them linked, as has been said here, to the uprisings known as the 'Arab Spring', but serious differences of a religious nature are also present in some of these countries; I mean, for example, the opposition between Sunnis and Shia. And this is therefore a very important report for the European Union, because it refers in large part to the neighbourhood, to that neighbourhood, to those countries so close to those with which we are joined by numerous human, economic links, including, among these links, energy links. What happens there has an impact on Europe and we are seeing it; we are seeing it in the flows of immigration and also in the tragic threat of terrorism, which strikes not only in Arab countries, but also continues to do so in Europe, and notably in France.  That is why I believe that greater European involvement, greater attention to this area, is desirable. Consider the very serious threat posed by the so-called Islamic State or Daesh, which also has oil resources and which has an impressive territorial implementation above it, taking advantage of the weak state structures of the areas where it is located. European involvement is therefore necessary, with the difficulties that this has for Europe and without forgetting respect for human rights and our principles. I understand it's a difficult problem. We need intense dialogue, not only with Arab countries, but also with their organizations. I'm thinking about the Arab League and the Gulf Cooperation Council. And one last word to highlight, President, concern about the situation of Christians in the area, in several of these countries, who are still persecuted

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Madam Vice-President, first of all I thank Commissioner Hahn for his opening thu words on this important topic of the Middle East and North Africa, and I would especially like to thank my colleague Vincent Peillon for his document which also received great support in the Foreign Affairs Committee, which really tosses a number of topics, in terms of functional topics, but also an essential geographical entity on the fringes of the European Union that today represents one of the main global crises and has virtually no country that you mentioned in your report. , without being in a certain way or in a state of war or in a state of terrorism, as we have unfortunately seen recently in Tunisia, or poses a threat of migratory risks to the shores of the European Union and requires our strong response. I would like to point out here that as Members, part of the Delegation of the Foreign Affairs Committee, we have recently been to Tehran and sought to contribute to the efforts that High Representative Mogherini, together with others in the six, seeks to make as a political agreement, as the implementation of the agreement in Lausanna, these days in Vienna. I believe that this is also extremely important for the stability of the region itself, because in a way it is to recognize the role of Iran, which practically through conflicts with Saudi Arabia, the so-called proxy wars bring wider instability to the region. In this regard, we must make the maximum effort to fight Daesh, against the Islamic State, which is indeed a kind of creation that no one has anticipated, and which in a terrorist way shows what atrocities can be done at the beginning of the 21st century.  In this sense, I also want to say that the persecution of Christians we have witnessed for the past few months, and perhaps the last two years, is inadmissible and that we must do everything as a European Union, either through political action, or by the presence of our missions to prevent this.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Unlike my friend Andrej Plenković, I will not declare my support for Commissioner Mogherini. I declare my support for our Christian brothers and sisters in these regions – it is much more important. I would like to say that I have a lot of respect for the work that the Commissioner is doing, but I think it would be better if the Commissioner was sometimes silent and not talking. Her statements have been very controversial recently. More important, however, is what we should be doing for the region. Politicians need to judge the situation on the facts, not on ideas. If the Arab Spring ended in disaster, it must be said openly – yes, it was a disaster, and unfortunately we cannot be blind to reality in this matter.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: Thank you, Mr Czarnecki. May I tell you and defend Mrs Mogherini briefly? It is certainly their job to comment on various points. Because you thought she should keep her mouth shut. It is their job to do their job and also to make a public position on it.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the migration wave to Europe is a more serious challenge for us even than the current instability in Greece. In our close neighbourhood, there are millions of people who see salvation from violence and misery by storming the European Union border.  The most important question we need to answer is how we can respond to this challenge and contribute to political stability in the countries of the Middle East and North Africa. Such an answer is not easy, but it is of great interest to us. Unfortunately, I believe that air and possible ground operations against the extremist group Islamic State should be carried out. But change has to come from within. Of course, I agree with colleagues who said: A solution must be found on the Palestinian issue. European countries should also improve cooperation with the collection and exchange of information with each other and with some of the governments of that region. Religious communities should be encouraged to cooperate with each other. A good example is those 800 Christian volunteers who joined the Shiite militia two days ago to take part in the action to liberate the Iraqi city of Mosul from Islamic State. The primary responsibility in the fight against fundamentalism should be on Muslim communities, and especially their distinction from the abuse of religion by terrorists. Improved coordination between member states' security services and those in the region, such as Turkey, Iraq, Lebanon, should stem the flow of funds to Islamic State from selling illegal energy sources; as well as internet service providers and social platforms must disclose those who want to join Islamic State and extremist propaganda.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, Honourable Commissioner, the situation in the Middle East and North Africa is undoubtedly the most serious security challenge for European nations. The disintegration of a number of countries in this region under the pressure of the organized Arab spring sparked at least two fateful threats before us.  On the one hand, this is the huge migrant wave that is flooding the European continent, threatening to destroy the economies of European countries and permanently change our continent demographically and culturally, religiously and every continent, and in a direction with which I disagree. On the other hand, statelessness in the region has become a boon for the development and rise of extreme extremist Salafist Islamist organizations such as al-Shabab, Boko Haram, al-Qaeda, Islamic State, etc.  They are all at war against us, against our traditions, customs, culture and values. They want to replace them with a caliphate. Today, they cut heads not just in Iraq and Syria, but in Lyon, France. It is high time we looked at this threat responsibly. There is a single adequate response to this threat. It is not a statement or statement. He's a military man.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: Madam President, the instability in the area covered by Mr Peillon's excellent report is unfortunately not new. But never, no doubt, has its magnitude been so great, never, no doubt, it has carried such direct threats to our own security and, no doubt, never before has a parameter in one corner of this region had had so much influence over the whole region, so it is extremely complex, today, diplomatically, to isolate one of the crises in the region from another. This is a completely new challenge.  On the basis of this very general observation, I would like to stress three points. The first is to remind all our colleagues that we are not facing a one-off crisis. We are facing a structural crisis, I would say tectonic, which is affecting all these societies in the Near and Middle East. The security dimension is only the most spectacular part of these sociological, economic and institutional changes. This phenomenon will last for years, perhaps even decades, and we must act and be prepared to act accordingly.  Second point, in this type of movement, it is illusory, unfortunately, to hope for developments that are spontaneously virtuous. This is a bit of a flaw in the reading of the Arab Spring, which was just one episode of these profound changes. Egypt will not become Sweden overnight. Therefore, we must also, again, not abdicate our values, absolutely not, or our norms, but we must prioritize our priorities, as well as the way we value the local interlocutors with whom we have to deal.  Thirdly, we must also recognize that our means of action are relatively limited, especially if we act in scattered order. None of our states alone are in a position to have a decisive impact on the changes in this region. So we have to act collectively, because it will encourage the countries of the region to act collectively, too. Those are the main points, in my view, that we must include in our action, which, I repeat, must be long-term.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last week the Kurdish National Congress held a conference in Brussels on Kobani, a city that has been 70% destroyed in fighting between its Kurdish population and ISIS extremists. The conference made an appeal to mobilise the international community to rebuild Kobani. Kobani needs humanitarian aid. Deputy Mayor Kobani Enver Muslim pointed out that winter is harsh in Kobani and time is short. The bravery of Kurds fighting Islamist terror is admirable, whether they are Syrian or Iraqi Kurds. I bow to the bravery of the Kurds. By redoing Kobani and pushing OUT ISIS, they have given the world a challenge – we need help, not just humanitarian aid.  Many countries have heard the Kurds. For example, my country, the Czech Republic, donated 500 tons of ammunition to the Iraqi Kurds last fall. The Allies helped the Syrian Kurds open the offensive by bombing ISIS positions. Of course, participants in the Brussels Kurdish National Congress welcomed such assistance, but I also heard urgent calls for a united military intervention against ISIS. That is why I would like to appeal to our strong ally in NATO, Turkey. Turkey is now a hegemon in the region, and I would expect it to be able to put its relationship with the Kurds above any nationalist stance and reject the voices calling for the Turkish army to intervene against the Syrian Kurds.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the latest challenges in the Middle East and North Africa have raised great concerns in the Western world. Rising tensions in the region are delaying the economic and social development of the peoples of the region and creating massive waves of refugees, which are now flooding Greece and Italy. Following the terrorist attacks in January 2015 in Paris, the fight against jihadists must be effective and based in the long term on supporting the democracy and economic development of countries. At the same time, however, the European Union must isolate those countries that support the jihadists in Syria, Egypt and Libya. During the recent election campaign in Turkey, the opposition revealed Turkey's co-operation with the jihadists in Syria. Hurriyet also recently revealed that Turkish authorities are harboring the various slave traders who are transferring thousands of refugees from Syria to Greece for a fee. So what measures does the Commission intend to take here, Mr Hahn?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I was very much looking forward to the launch of the Union initiative for the Mediterranean and the Union for the Mediterranean was established. I even had the opportunity to work in one part of that Union. Unfortunately, today we can say that the Union for the Mediterranean, after everything that has happened in recent years, practically no longer exists. That's why I think we need to find an answer, a comprehensive answer for the Mediterranean, the Middle East, the countries of North Africa, and I think the European Union can use its credibility today and maybe launch a new comprehensive initiative because, I'm afraid, whatever our priorities (relations with Turkey, relations with Israel and Palestine, relations with countries that are good examples: Tunisia, Lebanon or Jordan, relations with Egypt) , that individual things will still matter to us, but we may not be able to solve the whole problem. So, I suggest we seriously consider a new comprehensive initiative.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, because of their great geopolitical and geostrategic importance, what is happening in the Middle East and North Africa directly affects world peace and political stability and of course also affects the European Union.  What is happening in these regions now is: civil conflicts, lack of democracy, political instability, economic and humanitarian crisis, increased terrorist action and a large movement of illegal immigrants to Greece and Italy. All this has happened because until now the European Union has pursued a policy that did not serve its interests but was identified with the policy of the United States. So we need to change policy. We must demand that the governments of the countries govern in a democratic manner; We must also prevent the freedom of movement of terrorists and European citizens fighting on their side, and finally we must stem the flow of illegal immigrants.  Here it must show European Union determination and not raise its voice and shake hands with Greece and the Greeks, because once again they have demonstrated their traditional dignity and pride.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, ISIS is acting to rule by abolishing borders, creating the so-called Islamic State killing anyone who got in their way. The Islamic State is an extreme form of threat to Christian communities living in areas we consider the cradle of our faith, and today they are about to disappear completely.  Unfortunately, the international community is passive and only observes from the sidelines how people are killed and how the entire Christian people are wiped out. The European Union needs to have a clear strategy on how to protect Christians, but also how to help Israel, which is in the environment of nine terrorist organisations and whose security is also at risk. It is a public secret that part of the money sent by the European Union as humanitarian aid to the Palestinian Authority finances the salaries of terrorists and that the money acquires weapons that attack the Israeli people.  I ask for an inquiry into the spending of European Union money in the Middle East, as I ask for an amendment to be rejected by my rapporteur calling for abortions to be payed for by raped women from the EU budget. This is inhumane because we need to give women security by containing terrorism and preventing rape, not responding to violence against women with new violence, which abortion certainly is.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, I would like to thank commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Close cooperation with the Arab states – with whom? Egypt, perhaps, Jordan could be. But otherwise? Religion certainly plays a role. Islam is divided into Sunna, Shia and many sects. A terrorist threat, but not a real interlocutor. Israel, the only democratic constitutional state in the Middle East, is the only credible partner. However, Europe has a serious image problem in Israel, because we are only confronting this reliable country with sanctions. Iran, on the other hand, exports terrorist structures to Latin America, Africa, the Middle East, of course, Asia. And Iran will now become very rich if sanctions are lifted. There are scientists here. Is Iran a reliable partner in the context of nuclear energy? No support from any partner who is not absolutely reliable and credible! That should be our stipulation. Iran wants the nuclear bomb. Who wants to deny that? We should take the Iranians seriously. They are capable of anything. They want to destroy the state of Israel and with it the Jewish people. This is non-negotiable. This is in no way negotiable, no matter which state in the Middle East makes this a fundamental demand against Israel.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – The foreword, Mr Danjean, has analysed very lucidly the tectonic crisis that we are experiencing in the Middle East and Africa, but I think that today's analysis and the report would not be complete either if we did not recognise that this tectonic crisis is the result of a chain of our mistakes and misestading the situation in this area. Our illusions that we will export the European model of democracy to the Middle East, our misconception that we have supported all who have told us that the fighters of democracy, our passivity, when dictator Bashir brutally violated human rights and carried out the genocide in Darfur, our recklessness in the creation of the State of South Sudan, our inefficiency in the dialogue on peace between the Palestinians and Israel, is our misjudgment of the Arab Spring. We have enough knowledge in Europe, we need to be able to use it as an effective policy.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all thank you for your generosity in giving me ten minutes to recover later on. Secondly, I would also like to ask you to pass on my gratitude to the previous Chair, Mrs Lunacek, as she has rightly clarified that the duties and responsibilities of our High Representative include raising her voice if it is necessary. One can disagree about the content, but the fact that she has to raise her voice is, I think, clear and should not be challenged in any way. Coming back to the debate, I would like warmly to thank you for an extremely constructive debate on the Middle East and North African region (MENA), a region that is most urgently crying out for the attention of the European Union and the whole international community. Despite accelerated transformations after the Arab upheavals in 2011, political, economic and social dynamics in the region prove that democratic transformation can only come after the consolidation of stability, a genuine conditio sine qua non for democratisation. As has been stated, instability has, sadly, become a common feature of the MENA region. Therefore the EU needs to work side by side with our partners to help in this process of change. We must therefore jointly address such a security challenge. By the way, I see Mr Gahler is no longer here but, as he has raised this issue twice today, I would like to clarify – concerning the idea of having a kind of border assistance management on the Tunisian side of the Libyan border – that this is something we will take into account and reflect on. But it also depends, of course, on the agreement of the host country. But quite honestly, I do not believe we have any choice, as friends, partners and neighbours. With a series of common threats ahead of us, we need to seek overlapping areas of consensus, forging an ever stronger link between the EU and the Arab and Muslim worlds, as well as others in the region. We can say without contradiction that we face regional challenges and that such challenges call for regional solutions and these solutions need to be carried out by, and with, regional actors. Bilaterally we have, of course, to express respect for diversity. Diversity is the core feature of our European history and it is our strength, but we should also show respect for diversity when we look outside our borders. We need to understand diversity and complexity. All this should be done in a comprehensive manner and not just with a focus on the hard security issue. Together with our partners in the region, we must jointly address the links between security and development, involving civil society in our cultural dialogue and fully respecting human rights standards with a view to widely tackling all horizontal issues, from migration to economic integration. We need to work in both bilateral and regional frameworks across the region. Everyone has a responsibility to contribute and everyone should be given a chance – Muslim, Christian, Jew or non—believer, Sunni or Shia, Arab or Kurd. Only inclusive democracies can navigate such tough times. Finally, let me reiterate that it is the common understanding of the High Representative, myself and all the other members of the Commission that, when it comes to our neighbourhood – in particular in the Mediterranean – we should be in the driving seat to resolve the problems; we should be there and take care of the situation. Of course we need some allies there, but it should be clear that it is our immediate interest and we should, once again, be the ones who are pushing hopefully sustainable resolutions.

name: Vincent Peillon
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, anyone who might think that we can lose interest in our South is wrong. The problem of stability in the South is also the problem of stability at home, and as we have addressed it, the problem of economic, social, human and democratic development in the South will obviously have repercussions in Europe. Those who dream of making the European Union a fortress will be denied by history. It has not been like this in the past, it is not like that in the present, it will not be like that in the future. So we have, in our own interest to care about the South.  In these times of crisis in Europe with the Greek question, with the Council on Migrants, there is still an element of optimism in the work we have done, because we have avoided a number of banalities or repetitions. We have tried to build together, and I thank the various shadow rapporteurs again, for a common strategic vision. Of course, Europe can blame itself for things, but the instability of the Middle East and North Africa region is not Europe's sole responsibility. And Europe is expected.  I have heard some say that the European Union must have its own policy, but they are the same people who oppose a common foreign and security policy. The solution is that there is more Europe and that we accept a common foreign policy. This is not yet quite the case and it is clear that in this area too, a number of European states are playing their own partition. There is no common foreign policy without a common security policy.  We have developed this report in accordance with our principles and taking into account the multiplicity of factors we have mentioned. That is why we must support the initiatives of the High Representative and the Commission. First, more generosity towards migrants. What has been done is insufficient. President Juncker reiterated this this morning. He is right: we will not get away with it. Secondly, of course, we need more political initiatives and therefore more coherence between us. This report is a modest contribution, but we have taken up the challenge of finding a common thought. If we want to act together, we must first think together, be intelligent collectively and define a strategy together. I think the result is pretty positive. I am very grateful to all those who have collaborated in this work, regardless of their place on the political spectrum.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 9 July 2015. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments and resumed at 9.35 p.m.) Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – As I have stated before and will state again, there is no security in Europe without security in the Mediterranean. This is why the EU must contribute all its efforts to help decrease the tension in the Middle East and North Africa by ensuring that its internal and external policies reflect today’s realities. We must review our policy action relating to the region to ensure that they reflect the post-Arab Spring environment and concerns of growing terrorism in the area. Terrorism in the MENA area is not simply a regional problem – we have seen that if we continue to ignore the situation in the area this could have dire consequence on the entire world. We have already seen the dangerous consequences of the destabilisation of certain regions due to serious security and humanitarian crisis. That of the horn of Africa region resulted in millions of internally and externally displaced persons and led to a situation where refugees have found themselves living in protracted situations for over three decades. We must not make the mistakes of the past, and we cannot allow the same thing to happen in the MENA region.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. – We must continue to stand united in the face of the increasing violence and killings carried out by Daesh against religious minorities, including Christians, in the Middle East. The European Union is a leader in aiding refugees. We also have a moral obligation in Europe to further increase efforts to protect the persecuted. The effectiveness of assistance is significantly enhanced by the critical efforts of local churches for the sake of Christian and other indigenous minorities displaced by Daesh. Without them, the advance of extremist Islam in the Middle East would have been an even more serious catastrophe. I refer to specific examples: the Chaldean Catholic Church in northern Iraq, or the Jesuit Refugee Service in Syria, are currently responsible for the day-to-day care of hundreds of thousands of refugees. This is mostly done from own resources and international church donations.  Churches run proven projects and directly reach those most in need. However, the current EU aid procedure does not consider local churches to be partners and hinders their direct participation in European aid projects. It is essential that the EU's aid and development institutions see professional ecclesiastical aid organisations as partners in humanitarian action. We cannot leave out those most affected by the resolution of the situation. There is an urgent need for EU decision-makers to work together with local partners to overcome the humanitarian crisis.

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D)
text: in writing. – For decades, the Middle East has been dominated by the Arab-Israeli conflict. The Muslim communities in the major EU countries have naturally been affected by these ups and downs, in turn, influencing the diplomatic position of those countries – consequently, of the EU – on the conflict itself and the attempts to find a durable solution to it. Coupled with the radicalization generated by the current world economic and financial crisis, the number of anti-Semitic manifestations in Western Europe has increased and the official EU positions on the Arab-Israeli conflict got tougher in consequence. The reality is much more complex: the Middle East and North Africa have become the object of a border-breaking process: Libya, Syria, Iraq and Yemen have now, for all practical reasons, fluctuating borders, nobody knowing how they will look in the future.  The attempts of ISIL – a product of an intra-Muslim bitter conflict – of filling the vacuum thus created is already contributing to the radicalisation of the EU Muslim communities, displacing the old Arab-Israeli conflict as the number one cause of it. Consequently, the EU should revise its traditional perception centred around the latter, refocusing instead on the redrawing of borders in the Arab world.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I have carefully read the report on security challenges in the Middle East and North Africa, as well as the prospects for political stability in the region. This 27-page document is, in my opinion, full of generalities and wording, of which, unfortunately, little is apparent.  This report rightly states that tensions are rising in the Middle East and North Africa region, and that the continuing conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen and Libya are highly worrying. The situation has also not improved after the Arab Spring, and the effects of the fight against the Islamic State are weak. But we know all of this.  The problem is that the European response to these threats is still insufficient. We are mainly concerned with reducing the effects of this global crisis, helping migrants, rather than eliminating the sources of this widespread crisis.
