As the report does not provide precise solutions to improve security in the Middle East and North Africa region, I think this is disappointing.

name: Presidente. –
text: The sitting is resumed. Once again, I would like to thank Commissioner Hahn for the great work he has done on this day. He has been here for over five hours, so thank you very much. The next item is the report by Eduard Kukan, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy (2015/2002(INI)) (A8-0194/2015).

name: Eduard Kukan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the European Union needs a more strategic, ambitious and forward-looking neighbourhood policy. Setting this policy right is currently one of the greatest challenges in the EU’s external relations. It is in our interest to have a stable, secure, prosperous and democratic neighbourhood. I call therefore in my report for us to go back to basics, to reinforce the creation of an area of prosperity, stability and good neighbourliness. We are facing new challenges in our neighbourhood: the crisis in Ukraine, developments in the southern and eastern neighbourhood, migration, terrorism, energy security. In a situation like that, the EU needs to be able to react promptly to changing realities. More than ever, we need a politically- driven neighbourhood policy. The EU needs to show leadership and vision. We need to be aware of the diversity of our neighbourhood but, at the same time, keep the single policy framework. It is understandable that countries in our neighbourhood have different ambitions and expectations. We need to be ready to differentiate between the partners but expect results in the shape of reforms from those who show a clear interest in closer relations with the EU. Faced with numerous crises, we need to use our foreign policy instruments in a more flexible way. We should be able to mobilise sufficient resources through our financing instruments. I call, therefore, for this policy review to be reflected in the mid-term review of the external financing instruments. More importantly, our know-how may often be more important than money. We need to look at the possibility of using it more efficiently in processes of state-building, transformation, democratisation or conflict resolution. Support for democracy, human rights and the rule of law needs to stay at the heart of the reviewed policy. We need to strengthen partnership with the societies in neighbourhood countries and promote the values which are at the core of the Union. The reviewed policy needs to include numerous aspects of security. Therefore, I propose including support for capacity-building and state structures able to deal with the security threats in countries affected. We also need to strengthen our partners economically. The EU is the model for economic development but also provides the opportunities for neighbouring countries to broaden their markets. Therefore, we have to be open to closer economic integration with our neighbourhood partners. The EU is a successful project of regional integration and as such should be at the forefront of supporting regional cooperation. We have a great deal of experience which can help our neighbours to work and come closer together. I support strengthening the platforms for such cooperation like the Eastern Partnership and the Union for the Mediterranean, but also cooperation at the lower level of local and regional authorities. As the saying goes, we do not choose our neighbours but we can choose the relations we build with them, so let us do just that.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you once again for giving me a break; this is old collegiality between Commissioners. I would also like to thank all of you for the opportunity to come and discuss with you the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) and I am particularly grateful to Eduard Kukan and also to the shadow rapporteurs for their hard work in bringing together the views of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on such an important issue. We have just come to the end of our public consultation on the ENP review based on the joint communication we published in March. The Vice-President/High Representative, myself and our teams have held consultations with Member States, national parliaments, partner countries, civil society, social partners, local and regional government, businesses, think tanks and academia. It is not often that Europe’s foreign policy is opened up to such a widespread debate. Of course, consultation, views and advice from Parliament have been a key part of this process, and I have greatly appreciated the opportunity for me and also my officials to meet you on several occasions to share information and ideas. In the consultation there has been a great consensus that events in the eastern neighbourhood and in the southern Mediterranean demand a new approach to the ENP. We need to rethink our approach and put our partnership on a new footing. Your own reflections have underlined the need for greater differentiation in the way we work with partners. This is a principle that has found a positive echo among our partners and with Member States. We need to find the right formula for each of our partners in a way that serves our own interests and theirs. It is clearer now even than it was at the start of the review that we need to work closely with our neighbours on common challenges such as migration, terrorism, extremism and energy security. This year, 2015, has given us ample proof that this partnership cannot be a one-way street but must be one based on mutual interests and need. Some of these partners are seeking a close integration with us and some do not currently have this aspiration. This is the reality to which we must adapt our policy. We need to identify how we can show our relevance to this diverse range of partners while at the same time remaining true to our fundamentals. Our aim is a prosperous stable neighbourhood. We will continue to support democracy, the rule of law, human rights, and efficient and accountable public institutions as essential ingredients for the neighbourhood we want to see. When I visit our partner countries I make a point of ensuring that I visit civil society organisations. I believe that they play an essential role both in ensuring accountability and the fair development of their societies and in providing vital advice to the European Union. Where we have successful cooperation in place we should pursue it, but we will aim to be more responsive and more flexible in how we can support those wrestling with painful reforms. We will work harder to make sure that our support is coordinated so that each country can draw maximum benefit from the help on offer from the EU and its Member States. Where partner countries want a more focused agenda of cooperation, we should be ready to offer this. I believe there are some key areas that are emerging as the natural focus for some of our partners: economic growth and decent job opportunities, particularly for the young; promoting business links in targeted sectors; circular migration that offers opportunity without draining talent permanently away from home, alongside the continuing efforts to tackle the challenges of irregular migration. We must do all we can to make sure that all our foreign policy and security tools are brought together to help resolve conflict and develop the resilience of our partners. Where we can, we must reach out for partners beyond the neighbourhood who share the EU’s interest in stability and development. So I am looking forward to hearing your views on these and other key elements of the review.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague, Eduard Kukan, on an excellent report! It is a report that examines the limits of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the one we have at our disposal today, and also proposes a vision of what the European Neighbourhood Policy should be. And I think here is our main problem - we need a strategic vision of the Union's relationship with both the southern and eastern neighbourhoods. Both face exceptional challenges in economic, political, security terms and, in order to be able to respond to these challenges, the Neighbourhood Policy must be strategic, focused, flexible, coherent and have a clear political direction.  In particular, I believe that we need to have very good coordination between our foreign and security policy and the neighbourhood policy, respectively. We need, in other words, a fine calibration of the principles of differentiation and more for more, respectively. Our partners who want an advanced level of engagement with the Union and who are working on reforms – like Moldova – must be rewarded. The prospect of becoming a member of the Union is the most important catalyst for reforms. We must not forget this.  On the other hand, supportfordemocracy, the rule of law and good governance must be the core of the revised European policy. Having a vision of the European Neighbourhood Policy is not enough. It takes resources that match our ambitions to really engage more in neighbourhood policy. Only in this way will we have an effective policy – after all, which is indispensable for the credible foreign policy that we want.

name: Andi Cristea
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, our neighbourhood is less stable than ever before, and the divergence of aspirations of our partners has never been greater. It is clear that we need to rethink our policy. Looking at the security dimension today, conflicts are a reality to both the east and the south. So far we have decoupled the security issue from everything else, but security – even if outside the remit of the ENP – has an impact on the building of a well-functioning state and associated reforms. We need closer coordination between the ENP, the CFCP, the CSDP and development policy. The EU needs an approach which mobilises all available instruments and resources in a coherent way. On the issue of ambitions and membership perspectives, countries to the east have made radically different choices on their relations with the EU. We have to acknowledge this important change, and this can only mean one thing: we need to do more for those which have real and tangible European ambitions and have decided on the European path. This report also establishes a strong position on the false dilemma between values and interests. Democracy, the rule of law and human rights are in the interest of neighbouring societies as much as our own in terms of stability, security and prosperity. The social, labour and gender dimensions of the ENP have a crucial role to play in this regard. Let me conclude by thanking the rapporteur and colleagues. We were able to build convergence on the way ahead, and I am confident that, with tomorrow’s vote, we will be sending to the Commission a strong and ambitious text.

name: Marek Jurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A Polish political writer and prime minister of our government Stanisław Mackiewicz said that politics is the art of distinguishing important things from invalid ones. The essential priority of our neighbourhood policy must be to strengthen the independence and national character of the states that originated in eastern Europe after the break-up of the Soviet Union. Of course, someone will say that this is one of the two main and not the only direction of the neighbourhood policy, but a policy that cannot select and prioritise is not a policy at all. We have a lot of work to do not only in the political sphere; strengthening Ukraine's independence is also a problem of the revival of its culture, strengthening Georgia's independence is a problem of the rule of law, not to mention Belarus, where there is a struggle for the national language at all. If we are unable to undertake these tasks, we will not really meet the objectives that we set ourselves when we talk about neighbourhood policy.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate our colleague, Eduard Kukan, on his report and thank him for his work. I really enjoyed working as co-shadow from the ALDE Group. As a result, we  now have serious input from Parliament into the review process to be finalised by the Commission and the External Action Service. The European Union’s neighbourhood today is more complex, challenging and fragmented than ever. It would not be fair to blame the Neighbourhood Policy for all this. The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) was the right and timely response after the EU enlargement and accomplished a lot, in Eastern Europe in particular. Equally, we need a right and solid response at this stage. With all the positive things that I have to say regarding our joint work on the report, I must say, however, that I had wished for a more clear conceptual split into two dimensions of the European Neighbourhood Policy – the Eastern Partnership and the Southern Neighbourhood. I remain convinced that these two dimensions should be separated and allowed to develop in their own distinct direction and with no rivalry whatsoever. This split is dictated by reality on the ground and the processes that take place. Nevertheless, when it comes to the main principles of our new neighbourhood policy and our report, I believe that the ENP has to be ambitious, proactive and policy-driven in the first place. Anything else would be seen as the EU’s withdrawal, and this area would be used as a playing field for third countries, the neighbours of our neighbours right on our doorstep – the doorstep where our security, as well as insecurity, is placed. As we all agree, the differentiation principle is becoming key in the ENP. For countries in conflict, the EU should focus on conflict resolution, humanitarian work, migration and refugee challenges. The second group of our neighbours is those which currently have less interest in closer relations or in making long-term reforms. Here I believe the EU should place greater emphasis on better governance and building sustainable, democratic and stable countries. The third group of our partners are those seeking an advanced level of engagement with the EU. These are Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, our associated members. It is clear that they are far from ready for membership today and that they need to focus very seriously on implementation of the Association Agreements. We cannot deny their membership perspective in the long term. The Association Agreements are clearly not the final step in relations between the EU and these advanced neighbours. This is certainly in the EU’s interest.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In its discussion paper on the reorientation of the Neighbourhood Policy, the Commission has raised the right questions, such as those about taking into account the social conditions and interests of the partner countries or the involvement of the neighbours of their neighbours. In her paper, it also indirectly states the failure of the previous concept of EU policy in the immediate vicinity – in both directions, south and east. Undoubtedly a piece of realpolitik in the question, but before its conclusive answer, the AFET Committee, contrary to the rapporteur's starting point, has ducked away in Mr Kukan's working document, as if the majority of the committee did not see the failure of the Neighbourhood Policy so far or was insufficient and wanted to remain in the beloved routine of standard reports and debates. I am in favour of linking the concrete social conditions of the partners to the developments there, which are accompanied by enormous social and cultural challenges. Accompanied by national, ethnic, religious and ideological contradictions, serious social problems, unemployment and poverty, and the significant exodus of qualified people from neighbouring countries. The continuing widespread corruption that is eating up the economic and social coexistence of states and only further erodes people's last confidence in state structures, as well as other human rights violations, require the fundamental change in the strategy of the European Neighbourhood Policy. One example is the situation in and around Ukraine in the east, the frozen conflicts in Transnistria, Abkhazia and Nagorno-Karabakh, for example. This, however, eliminates the very need for policy standards and their conditionality, as the report mantraically continues. I am also in favour of the approach of balancing interests with the countries of the neighbourhood as the basis of the ENP and of the involvement of their neighbours. This, in turn, would take us back to the international standards of cooperation agreed in the Helsinki Final Act, in their complexity of the political, economic, cultural and human rights dimension. In response to your questions in the consultation, Commissioner, I believe that we should also resolutely move towards a CSCE or OSCE 2.0 within the framework of the ENP, and make constructive and mutually acceptable proposals for this. Why not finally consistently venture a new beginning? Neighbourhood policy must be part of the EU's external action, which is based on the need for cooperation for mutual benefit and is not governed by the logic of an internal market alone.

name: Tamás Meszerics
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Kukan for the exemplary collegial and cooperative attitude with which he steered through a difficult and wide-ranging report. I personally enjoyed our work immensely and I thank you for that, Mr Kukan, together with the shadow rapporteurs. I rarely enjoy the luxury of two-and-a-half minutes’ leisurely time, but nevertheless I want to concentrate on one aspect which unfortunately was left out of the report. I would like to try to convince those who are still with me on the merits of it. We are all supportive of differentiation, flexibility, efficacy and coherence in our policies towards our neighbours. This is natural for us as well. We offer our full support for all measures that could strengthen our common policies. However, the valued principle of ‘more for more’ squares badly with conditionality and coherence once we observe that some of our neighbours happen to backtrack on development towards democracy. What are the options that we are left with if one of the neighbouring countries happens to imprison some political opponents or threaten them with the death penalty? As much as we like soft power – and its best expression is ‘more for more’, and we agree on that – unless we are able to say that we are going to offer less for less if backtracking takes place, then our policies are not going to be highly coherent. This is very important because our neighbourhood policies, as the report itself shows, have produced mixed results at best in the last couple of years. The failed state of Libya and the less-than-half success of the Eastern Partnership show that the new challenges in our immediate environment need new responses. These new responses are enumerated in the report and we offer support for all those measures. I would like to end by asking colleagues to support this report with their votes.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), on the surface, claims to have aims of fostering peace, democracy and human rights in the European Union’s neighbouring countries. Whilst this is a noble aim, western intervention, as we already know, has hardly worked wonders in either the Middle East, Ukraine or North Africa. The ENP essentially amounts to the European Union using hard-pressed taxpayers’ money to foster – or, as some might even say, buy – influence to move countries closer to European Union membership. With a cost of EUR 15.4 billion, might I respectfully suggest that, rather than looking outwards – and bearing in mind the current situation in Greece, which we have all heard about with vested interest today in Parliament – instead, the European Union would do better to put its own house in order first before seeking to expand its tentacles further.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Johannes, first of all thank you for your introductory presentation and for presenting the neighbourhood policy, the reform you are making, I would say, all this year. But for your entire mandate and for the legacy of your tenure as Commissioner for Enlargement and Neighbourhood, I will reiterate once again: the credibility of the European Union's foreign policy as a global actor is literally fraying at our effectiveness in our nearest neighbourhood, be it the Eastern Neighbourhood or the Mediterranean, so here's the Middle East, as we said a little while ago at the point before.  I would like to thank my friend and colleague Eduardo Kukan for his dedicated work in drafting this report, which is the main document by which we, Parliament, contribute to your consultation process and the neighbourhood policy review you are doing and which I hope will be completed this autumn.  What seems crucial to me, and what we can say we have learned a kind of lessons in the past 10-15 years, is an individual approach to each of the countries involved in the European Union's neighbourhood policy. There are very specific crises that are affecting both east and mediterranean today. With regard to the Eastern Partnership, it seems to me that the differentiation is very clear. We must support the ambition of those countries that want towards the European Union and understand that other countries have not made this choice at the moment. But that doesn't mean we don't need to make available our instruments, contractual or financial, to improve those relationships and trust.  When it comes to the southern neighbourhood, I am very inclined to try, despite difficult circumstances, to reactivate in a certain way the Union for the Mediterranean, which was one quality and good idea, but in terms of the stalemate of the Middle East peace process or the new crisis, it is not allowed to develop. In this regard, Commissioner Hahn, with this report by your colleague Kukan, you will have our support to make this policy a powerful tool of european union foreign policy.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, announcing the review of neighbourhood policy, High Representative/Vice-President Mogherini said ‘our region is in flames’. In this debate, we are saying that we must not only continue trying to extinguish the flames, but we must also be better at stopping the fire from starting in the first place. It is true to say that, in the past, Europe has too often made the assumption that there would be steady, if sometimes slow, trends towards modernisation, reform and democratic development in our neighbourhood. But what we have seen, whether in Ukraine or in the stalled Arab uprisings, are sudden shocks and reverses which require Europe’s neighbourhood policy to have a much greater emphasis on and capacity for fast—moving political intervention and diplomacy. We also recognise that five of the six eastern partners are now confronted with unresolved or frozen conflicts, which require such intervention too. I support some of the principles emerging from the review. For countries which themselves choose to come closer to the EU – Georgia, Moldova, Ukraine, Tunisia and Morocco – yes, let us intensify our relations in a more differentiated approach, recognising the challenges that they still face. We say we want more people-to-people contact, more public diplomacy and more civil society dialogue. Frankly, we also need a sea change to massively increase this element of the policy compared to the past. ‘More for more’ is a good policy which should be maintained, but let us recognise that the incentives which we offered were insufficient. And, as we have just heard, the revised policy must also address the challenge of ‘less for less’. We need to be self-aware when we say at the same time that we want more partnership and local ownership but also that we want a better, more focused, defence of European interests and values. But I do have some fears that the journey from Vilnius to Riga means that this review is actually cover for reducing the ambition behind our European Neighbourhood Policy, and that so-called enlargement fatigue means there is a retrenchment of membership prospects for the countries in our neighbourhood. Both of these dangers must be resisted. So often I hear colleagues in this Chamber advocate a strong European common foreign and security policy, with Europe as a global player. The truth is that there can never be true respect for Europe’s global role if we cannot play a more dynamic and effective role in dealing with the problems of our very own neighbourhood. That is an argument for a more ambitious neighbourhood policy. Commissioner, you will have our support if this is the choice you make. Finally, we have let down those brave protesters on the Maidan. There are people in that country, and across the neighbourhood, who look to us in Europe. We should have the same high expectations of ourselves as those people have of us.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. When the European Neighbourhood Policy was created, the situation in the east or south of Europe was completely different from today. In the East, we are dealing with a hybrid war led by Russia against Ukraine and we have witnessed the annexation of Crimea. The Russians are also actively playing into conflicts in the case of Georgia and Moldova, where they are either an active party or pursue policies that they use for their own political purposes. And in the South, we're dealing with the conflict in Syria and the ISIS offensive -- a barbaric organization that's growing in territory.  That is why, today, when we are debating the reform of the Neighbourhood Policy, we should do everything we can to maintain, firstly, a strong coherent and assertive position of the European Union towards Moscow and to defend our interests, both in the East and in the South, but for this to happen we need much more active and effective EU diplomacy, the activities of EU diplomacy, which I am calling for from here and what I am asking for from here.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, a revision of the neighbourhood policy was necessary. His failure is obvious. There were times when we thought it was going in a great direction, but we think that, in the end, it hasn't. We continue with a Eurocentric and asymmetrical vision. Our model of democracy is the best and the one to be imposed, and we continue to maintain no self-criticism about the role of the European Union. Not to mention the incentive approach, reward our effective partners or those who make the reforms we want. He's got a neocolonial tufillo. The European Union continues to seek stability based on relations with political elites, to which we forgive anything in order to maintain that stability. Often that stability is the Roman pax, the peace of the cemeteries. We have a common European security policy subordinate to the policies of the United States and NATO, and yes, there is talk of destabilization in our vicinity, but we do not come to our responsibility. And we have it, unfortunately: interventions or the sale of weapons to certain regimes. We can talk about Libya: unilateral, improvised action that has helped create total chaos in the region. What do we have right now? We have a failed state, two governments. And we want to pull by shortcuts, war shortcuts, repressive shortcuts. And we believe that regional efforts must be continued. Neighbours, Algeria and Tunisia, must be counted on to support a national dialogue and also to continue to support the United Nations Special Envoy. Syria: we play gods again. We destabilize the country and contribute to the emergence of the largest terrorist group that threatens not only the entire region, but also us: the Daesh, which occupies parts of Syria and parts of Iraq. It is time to work with the Syrian government and in regional key. We must listen to Mr de Mistura and put pressure on our allies, those we were talking about earlier, Saudi Arabia or Turkey, unfortunately, too lax with these terrorists. You can't take down any terrorist groups just with bombings. And finally, in order to finish, we are very sorry that Western Sahara has disappeared and, on the other hand, Morocco is spoken of in these terms. Because Morocco is the main recipient of funds from the European Neighbourhood Policy of the European Union, but instead there is no talk of the occupation of Western Sahara. No state in the world recognizes Morocco's sovereignty over Western Sahara and the European Union, unfortunately, remains de facto complicit and a collaborator of the Moroccan occupation.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I think it is very clear that the neighbourhood instruments to which the European Union had been endowed were not sufficient and did not work well, and we were not able to react when the Arab revolutions occurred in the south. I think that's very obvious. We must also reflect on how our relations have gone throughout all these years, and I believe that there is a pillar that we must address in an absolutely crucial way, which is the fact that we have trade agreements with these countries that have damaged the economic development of the entire southern Mediterranean. I believe that this is one thing on which as Europeans we must do absolutely self-criticism. I believe that the revision of The European Neighbourhood Policy is crucial. We must see all these things. We are obviously concerned, for example, that we do not leave abandoned all those young people who for so many months and even years have been on the street. I am particularly concerned that in Egypt there will be a regression of what had been a democratic aspiration, a certain return of a totalitarian regime, and that we are not able to react to that, that we settle down and that we do not face it. And I also want to say that I am concerned about the situation in Tunisia. I believe that we must be able to make a policy right now that allows democratic transition and democratic consolidation in Tunisia to work.  And finally, I conclude by saying that we must also see a little bit of how our instruments work, be able to improve these instruments, and, from this point of view, I would like to highlight the role that the UPM Secretariat should play in Barcelona and that we examine all the projects it is developing, whether in terms of energy or in support of civil society , and how they can fit with the regional dimension of neighbourhood policy. Because we currently have too much duplication of instruments and this is a very central one, for which I think we should bet and work. With this last thought I would like to finish my speech.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to stress the importance of neighbourhood policy and the timing of this report by Mr Kukan, whom I would like to congratulate. Because in it you can find, Commissioner, as Mrs Mogherini too, answers to the questions they raised in the communication or questionnaire they launched a few months ago with a view to updating the neighbourhood policy. I believe that an ambitious neighbourhood policy, understood as a long- and medium-term strategic commitment, is needed, not mere crisis management; a realistic neighbourhood policy, differentiated by country, in dialogue with them, not imposed. In this regard, for example, I hold the recent meeting in Barcelona , although I remember in April , of the Foreign Ministers of the countries of the southern neighbourhood with the countries of the European Union. The unfortunate thing is that it took seven years. We also need a neighbourhood policy that takes into account the interests of the parties involved, their needs, without forgetting, of course, neither our values nor, logically, our interests. We are at a pivotal moment in our neighborhood. It has already been said: in both the east and the south we have very complex scenarios. We need to be active, have sufficient tools and means, dialogue, I insist, with neighbouring countries, and help them often at the institutional level, because their structures, usually their institutional or political structures, are weak or insufficient. I think we have to have a non-purely defensive view of the neighborhood. We are interdependent, their safety and prosperity is also ours. Many of these countries have a young population and abound in resources, also energy. We need them. And, therefore, I am in favour of a positive view of the neighborhood as well. We cannot get carried away by pessimism or the serious problems that now affect these neighbouring regions. Finally, we must strengthen the institutions we have endowed ourselves with. I am referring to the Union for the Mediterranean, the Eastern Partnership and other regional and subregional structures. Fortunately, many of these ideas are in the report, in the good report of my good friend and colleague, Mr Kukan, and that is why I would like to congratulate him again.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: I would first like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Kukan, for a resolution that contains many legitimate points, including the much-needed differentiation, the need for a more political and less technocratic vision of the European Neighbourhood Policy and the centrality of European values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights, without double standards. The most important thing is that this resolution confirms that EU policy should benefit the peoples of our neighbouring countries and not the political elite there. Nor should it be motivated by self-interest, such as stopping refugees. We are demanding reforms of the rule of law and guarantees for human rights for the simple reason that the people are better off in a just and well-governed country. This is even a duty for the countries of Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, with which we have signed association agreements. These agreements go beyond just trading. They also have an important political component. Some politicians argue that the neighbourhood policy should only be a geopolitical tool. They want to keep a hand in the face of bad regimes and look away when fundamental rights are violated. They are not so strict with demanding agreed reforms. The geopolitical goal of stability in a troubled region, combating terrorism or reducing Russian influence justifies the means in this view, namely turning a blind eye to abuses such as selective justice, nepotism or human rights violations. A credible neighbourhood policy requires a political vision that is not motivated solely by geopolitics and is not merely based on spheres of influence. Take Ukraine, a country that deserves our full support and where the people have also expressed their desire to reform by EU standards. In these difficult times for the country, it is important that the European Union stands ready to help. I am convinced that this is not necessarily the best thing to do with huge sums of money, with muscle language towards Russia or with unrealistic promises of eu or NATO membership. The best thing Europe can do is to lecture the government in Kiev, ensure that agreements are made, and finally get through the reforms that the country so desperately needs and which the Ukrainian people also crave. The new policy must therefore be ambitious. What I would like to say to Commissioner Hahn this evening is this: the common values on which the European Neighbourhood Policy is built, namely respect for human rights and the rule of law, must not be undermined under the pressure of geopolitical interests.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Honourable Commissioner, honourable Members, as it is known, the European Neighbourhood Policy established in 2004 aims to prevent the emergence of new dividing lines between the enlarged European Union and its neighbouring countries. This is the turn and place to congratulate rapporteur Kukan on the undertaking and on the work done on this report. Unfortunately, however, we can say that this is not happening at the moment. To the east and south of Europe there is a complete disintegration of countries, as typical examples of this are Libya, Egypt, Syria, Iraq. There, new dividing lines are created when it comes to values. The Christian values of European nations, or, say, European values, are opposed by the increasingly aggressive and force-gaining radical Salafist Islamism. The huge migrant wave that floods Greece, Spain, Italy and Bulgaria cannot be missed. This wave of illegal immigrants will hamper economic prosperity and threaten the stability and security of Member States.  In the northeast, we are seeing the same process: the state of Ukraine is in a severe political, economic and humanitarian crisis. A new dividing line is being built on its territory, which takes us back to the cold war years. Thus, there is also the issue with the states of Georgia, Armenia, Moldova, the Black Sea Basin in general.  In this situation, I believe that the European Union needs to rethink its neighbourhood policy. It is important that the Union takes an active and active role in the disintegrating Arab Spring countries and thus will ensure both the peace and prosperity of the Member States in the European Union and neighbouring countries.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, there is a Portuguese in my country that says this: to those who want evil to their neighbour, they come along the way. That is, when we harm our neighbors, we suffer consequences from it. And, in fact, the European Union cannot be considered a desirable neighbour to anyone. Because a neighbor who looks at the other only from the perspective of his own interest cannot be a good neighbor.  As you would expect, this report advocates strengthening the association between the European Union's neighbourhood policy and the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy. The perspective of this policy is increasingly militaristic intervention. Interestingly, and I quote: "in the name of a more active role in the peaceful resolution of ongoing conflicts". What it cannot fail to joke about, were it not for the European Union's own military intervention, and the unmanageable interventions of the European Union, the very cause of so many ongoing conflicts. Or were it not the countries of the European Union that provided war material and support and funding to the so-called Free Syrian Army, when in this Parliament we remember saying in hysteria that everything should be done, everything, to end Assad? Exactly, it was with this support that a monster was created today known as Islamic State, a terrorist threat to these countries, but also to the countries of the European Union. Or was it not also the precious help of the European Union to the Libyan people to end the regime, through armed external intervention, which ended not only the lives of many Libyans, but also the stability of the country, which created a non-state dominated by lawless mercenaries, chaos and more atrocious violence? Or was it not the european union's latest aid to the Ukrainian people by instigating the conflict that has caused a country to divide? A neighborhood policy that had a real interest in the other created conditions for this other to develop. In these countries it will certainly be thought that, with their neighbours, we might as well be alone.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – The European Neighbourhood Policy was set up as a security and stability area around the European Union in 2002. The report notes that we are spending very little money on neighbourhood policy compared to the money spent in third countries. Have we already established an area of security, stability and good governance around the European Union? The revised Neighbourhood Policy must offer wide opportunities for cooperation for all neighbours. This must include both financial support and access to the European Union's research, industrial achievements and openness to human relations. Well, most importantly, of course, visa regimes have been facilitated, especially for young people, artists, scientists. I propose a faster solution to visa-free travel for the people of Ukraine and Georgia. Of course, the openness of the European Union must depend on political conditionality: the more a neighbouring country is democratic, free, the more market economy operates there, the greater the opportunities we have to open up to it. Above all, however, let us not forget that the neighbourhood policy is designed for our neighbours. There is a saying that a good neighbor is more important than relatives. Therefore, the neighbourhood policy must be adequately financed, otherwise we risk continuing to turn our heads on how to resolve conflicts in neighbouring countries or where the ever-increasing influx of refugees is being made.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Tajani, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Tajani, for the work he has done on this report. First of all, I would also like to thank my group colleague and friend Eduard Kukan very warmly for this outstanding report. Like many of the previous speakers, I believe that the European Union's neighbourhood policy does not yet meet the ambitious ambition of Article 8 of the Treaty. At the same time, the problems at the borders of the European Union show how right and at the same time important it remains here to continue to work towards a good and, above all, peaceful neighbourhood. In order to achieve the ambitious objectives of Article 8, I believe that three points are of particular importance, and that is what the report explicitly mentions.  Firstly, the European Union's immediate neighbourhood must remain a strategic focus of the European Union's external policy in our own interests.  Secondly, cooperation with civil society in the partner countries of the Neighbourhood Policy is very important, because its representatives and organisations are crucial to the development of democratic and constitutional structures. Thirdly, each country requires a tailor-made approach. Not all the enabial countries of the ENP want or can move closer to the European Union at the same speed and in the same policy areas. This report by Mr Kukan makes a valuable contribution to the continued support of the European Neighbourhood Policy for democracy and the rule of law in our partner countries.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, dear Commissioner, colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Sánchez-Neym, for his excellent work. Firstly, I would also like to thank my colleague, Mr Kukan, for his report, but I would also like to draw your attention to the fact that it has recently become apparent that the current European Neighbourhood Policy is not able to respond adequately and quickly to rapidly changing circumstances. That is why a differentiated approach and policies tailored to each country's needs are needed. I believe that attitudes must also be changed. We work with equal partners, and sometimes tone and attitude offend our partners. Sometimes it seems that this programme is only necessary for our partners, but the European Union is doing charity. That is not the case. For example, who is most interested in working together on borders – so that illegal migrants do not enter EU territory and smuggling – do we or they? Ecology cooperation : can we really believe that our strong borders will protect us from the ecological catastrophe that could happen in a neighbouring country? I therefore believe, colleagues, that we should cooperate with all our neighbours within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, differentiating these relations in the form of both resources and other envisaged incentives. Thank you!

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one of my memories of my youth and political nature is the Helsinki Conference of 1975, which launched the process of european détente and became the trigger for almost revolutionary changes in the field of human and minority rights. The Helsinki process, which began 40 years ago, led straight to the fall of Soviet communism and, consequently, to the dismantling of the Iron Curtain and the emergence of today's unity in democratic Europe. It is a strange irony that, on this anniversary of the epoheaval Helsinki Final, Russia, which is one of the founders of the OSCE, cannot celebrate with the other founders. We are experiencing a serious decline in peace, security, dialogue and cooperation, just as the initial, encouraging results of the European Neighbourhood Policy have turned back in the meantime. As a result of the retracting Soviet imperial heritage, eu policy of the Eastern Partnership has been the main cause of a lasting crisis. The situation makes it entirely justified to review our European Neighbourhood Policy with strategic needs. The interests of the European Union and the countries of the European Partnership require the renewal of our neighbourhood policy based on european values of fundamental human rights, the rule of law, democracy, freedom and human dignity. Finally, allow me to congratulate rapporteur Kukan on his great work.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, looking back in time, I think of 2012, when the European Union was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. And then three years have passed, and we see flames in the neighbourhood of a peaceful Europe, a Nobel Peace Prize-winning Europe. Perhaps the most mentioned Ukrainian crisis today deserves the most words, although it should be added that these crises are not just on their own at any point in our neighbourhood, not because something would have been overturned in some countries, but, I think, they have more context, so it is very time to put the neighbourhood policy under comprehensive and conceptual review. I believe, Mr President, that this neighbourhood policy cannot be successful if Europe is not united.  I am a little distreated that we have two very, very prepared Commissioners, Mr Hahn and Mrs Mogherini, who deal with these issues and are being negotiated by other European leaders instead in most cases, although obviously what they are doing is not useless either. But we need unity here, and that includes not making friends with our opponents in certain EU countries – I might even think of the Orban-Putin friendship here. So I believe that the real stake of the neighbourhood policy is how Europe can deal with it, and I am afraid that we will have to work for that Nobel Peace Prize for a second time, this time in the neighbourhood.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – I greatly appreciate the efforts of the Commissioner, his team and the commission as a whole to promote our values, our principles and our interests in the wider neighbourhood in changed circumstances, aware that the former strategic approach based on a unified view of our neighbourhood must be overcome.  In changed circumstances, we need to pay much more attention to the pragmatic aspect, we must do everything we can to make progress wherever possible, and in taking into account the real frameworks, we do not forget our principles. I am pleased to see the Commissioner at work that understands our neighbourhood and uses that understanding practically. I think that we will continue to witness very challenging challenges that will require many more adaptations to the new situation, but I know that together we will work together to strengthen peace, strengthen an area that shares common values, common principles, as well as in the perspective of common rules.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this report is very important for the consultation on the new European neighbourhood policy as a strategic tool. It is not possible to develop Europe without active policies oriented towards our neighbours – eastern and southern partners. They have different capacities. We must distinguish between European neighbours and the neighbours of Europe: countries which may one day join the EU and those which cannot for geographical reasons. We should divide the processes of enlargement and of building neighbourhood relations. They require different activities. Neighbourhood policy tools should develop connections in some key areas, such as energy security, trade development, the common digital revolution, transportation solutions and fighting terrorism. All of those fields are crucial for growth. European neighbourhood instruments will have an impact on economic changes and also on improvements in the states’ functioning based on democratic rules, the rule of law, capacities for transparent administration and the development of civic society. All those measures and cooperation should change the quality of life of many people. These activities should be understood as an investment, not only in the future of the neighbouring countries but also as an investment in our European future, with a clear rate of return when peaceful development will change the life of societies and, in addition, reduce the waves of immigration.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to first congratulate Colleague Kukaan on the good outcome of his work on the report. The huge challenges in both the east and south oblige us to rethink neighbourhood policy. A new policy must take into account changes-threats in the region. Unfortunately, not only is there no solution to frozen conflicts, such as Karabakh and Abkhazia, but new ones are being created, such as Crimea and eastern Ukraine.  In addition to conventional military conflicts and terrorism, we also observe hybrid, information and propaganda wars, external financing of anti-European extreme political parties. Such factors exploit our internal weaknesses. The European Union consists of democratic states that do not invest in propaganda but which have the right to respond with the truth.  Countries like Russia use the economy and energy as a tool for pressure and dependency creation, not for mutually beneficial cooperation, as it should be. For example, the proposal to expand Nord Stream and the Turkish and Greek flows under discussion create political disunity within the European Union. The aim is to create a contradiction between Brussels and member states, as well as between member states themselves and between companies and governments.  Unification makes power, not disunity, and "Divide and Conquer" should be our primary goal. We must firmly protect the rights of neighbouring countries for an independent choice of regional and international partnerships, strengthen cooperation with state organisations, with the non-governmental sector in this region.  We must use all possible tools to support civil society, such as the new European End of Democracy Fund. I support the idea of informal meetings of foreign ministers from the region and the European Union, but I also think it is good to have meetings of both interior ministers and security services. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue. – Thank you very much, Mr Kovatchev, for the fact that you accepted my blue card! You said about frozen conflicts, but please be honest, do you have that finished recipe, how can we at one point resolve these frozen conflicts, including in Georgia, the Republic of Pieds and other places, at one point? Thank you!

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – If I had the recipe, dear Mr. Colleague, I would have said it. You know, these are conflicts, some of them have decades on stage, as in The Gorno-Karabakh, for example. The Ming group is working unsatisfactory, there is no result and we are trying in some way to give our proposals to solve these problems. But not only are they not solved, they are increasing. That said, in addition to these conflicts, we have new ones, such as in Crimea and eastern Ukraine. There's no prescription. What we're trying to do is help, but obviously we can't find the right path yet.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, europe's neighbourhood is very unstable today, so shutting down these crisis hot spots quickly and effectively is in our greatest interest. I therefore believe that any assistance on our part to the countries in the neighbourhood is much needed and welcome. However, it must not be unconditional and this is well recognised by the rapporteur and proposes a model of rewarding the progress of these countries, which we call "more for more".  I agree that helping those who implement reforms more boldly and quickly should be more generous and concrete, but I also think that we should be much more critical of the wrong policies and failures of our partners and for less to give less. It has happened in the past that european taxpayers' money bought the favor of irresponsible, even autocratic, authorities in third countries because of someone's geopolitical interests. I hope those times are behind us because no politician has a mandate to spend taxpayers' money so irresponsibly on policies that ultimately backfire on them the most.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, congratulating Mr. Kukan on his report, I want to say a few sentences about the Eastern Partnership.  We need to provide eastern European countries with a European perspective. This is the best way to make sure that in these countries and even those who do not want to be part of the European Union today, such as Belarus, after all, we are creating a force that will be for the European Union. My personal example is my country Croatia – in the 1990s I was one of the few who spoke at all about the European Union and the need for Croatia to join the EU. I am here in the European Parliament today and it is a great honour to be together with you. So let's create a European perspective for those governments that want to join the European Union. Let us create and open these opportunities, but let us also create for those who may not want to do so today, because there are people in every country who want to see their country in the European Union. Regimes pass, states stay. The European Union, I am confident, will not fail. In fact, it will remain and will spread.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the European Neighbourhood Policy is part of the European Union's foreign policy, so it must be coherent. This concerns both the Eastern European Neighbourhood Policy and the south. At the same time it should be based on specific principles such as respect for democracy, the rule of law and human rights.  I want to focus a little on the Union for the Mediterranean, because at the moment, as we said in a previous debate, there is enormous instability. Huge waves of refugees, thousands of refugees, are now coming to Greece and Italy. There should be a very specific policy to deal with this phenomenon. Above all, there must be stability and peace in the region. Secondly, an area of economic development must be created, investment made, jobs created, especially for the new generation of these regions; Under these conditions we can also have a serious neighbourhood policy in the South.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the Conversely, I would like to thank all those who have so far persevered, expressing that this is indeed an important policy. I can also tell you that, by the end of the public evaluation, we have received some 250 written opinions from all over Europe and from the neighbourhood. This shows, therefore, the great interest that this policy has shown. I fully share the view of all those who say that the neighbourhood policy is part of foreign policy. Foreign policy also always means defending the interests of the country for which foreign policy is made. And we are making foreign policy for the European Union here. We must make our interests very clear. If you look at the current situation – and this has been sufficiently mentioned – then we do indeed have a situation in our neighbourhood that requires us to take care of our interests, that we focus above all on the solution or – and I would like to attach importance to this – on stabilising the situation. Because we have a situation in our neighbourhood where there is a territorial conflict in 11 of our 16 neighbouring countries, that there are a total of around 20 million refugees living in our neighbourhood, and that there is a very weak structure here, which is also very weak in economic terms, that is to say, all things that are suitable for Europe to be and indeed to be an addressee – as we know – , that people are trying to come to Europe from this neighbourhood, or that there are at least very intensive aspirations here for increased cooperation with Europe. That is also okay, and we accept it, and it is even welcomed. Therefore, it is important that we develop the ability and skill to respond individually to our neighbours, that we identify the common denominator of interests and, on the basis of this, finally come up with tailor-made solutions. However, I also think that, in the course of our revision of the Neighbourhood Policy, for example, we may have to work out something much more strongly, which is already in the draft and which has also been reflected in Mr Kukan's report. It is about the regional dimension, about the subregional dimension. This, too, is something that we need to address, that we are pushing for greater cooperation between individual countries in our neighbourhood. The founding idea of the European Union was to ensure, through increased economic cooperation, that there would be no further armed and military conflicts. This european Union's concept of peace has proved its worth, and it is worth transferring it to our neighbours as well. Overall, I believe that we must adopt a pragmatic approach. This does not mean, however, that we are abandoning or disregarding our fundamental values. Here I think that in many countries civil society is our natural partner. That is also why we have increased the corresponding budgets, because we believe that this is actually the way in which our fundamental foundations can be found, especially in those countries where the authorities may not have the attention we would like to see. Finally, I would like to reiterate the idea of stabilisation. In view of what I have described, stabilising the situation must be our primary task. In order to achieve this, we need maximum flexibility in our institutional, regulatory and, ultimately, financial possibilities in order to be able to react accordingly. I mention this because I do not rule out the possibility that I, together with the High Representative and Vice-President, will occasionally come to you in this regard. Because, as I said, flexibility means responding to new challenges and perhaps revising what has already been decided here in order to be able to respond better to new needs and also to act accordingly. Thank you again for your support so far, also for the kind words you have found today for our work. I am sure that this is, so to speak, only an intermediate step for further intensive work on the subject. Even if we finally have a communication, this is nothing more than a celebration of status. But this does not end the work, but on the contrary, it has to continue.

name: Eduard Kukan
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all of the nine colleagues who stayed this long and contributed to the discussion. I did not mention it in the beginning, but I would also like to say that it was a very nice project to be rapporteur for this report, and to work with the shadow rapporteurs who came from different political groups but were a team guided by the principle that everybody wanted to contribute positively in order to achieve results in the future, because everybody agrees that the European Neighbourhood Policy is a very important part of EU external policy. It was really a very interesting cooperation. I would like to offer my thanks and appreciation to Commissioner Hahn for the many discussions which we had with the representatives of the Commission and for his consultation paper, which really focused on the most important issues of the European Neighbourhood Policy. I think this was a very interesting and good debate; there were many views expressed in it. Thank you for your appreciation of my work. Some of the criticism was levelled especially at the fact that there are not many results which the ENP has achieved since its inception in 2004. I can agree with that, but we learned our lessons, and that is why this report is very timely. It contains many issues and principles which could be used in order not to repeat the mistakes which we committed and to be more prepared for the fast-developing situation in the neighbourhood countries. There was only one statement from which I have to distance myself fully. It was the one which portrayed the EU as the military threat to its neighbours and the institution which causes all bad things in the neighbourhood. Nothing is more divorced from life, and I think this I have to reject very adamantly. I think this debate also showed that we are all interested in having an efficient, pragmatic European neighbourhood policy which would serve all the EU countries’ interests and also the interests of our neighbours. So let us hope that this will be the final achievement of this report and of the directive which is being prepared by Commissioner Hahn for this autumn.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 9 July 2015. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: in writing. – Recent events call for immediate solutions, and intensive communications are needed between EU and neighbourhood countries. The EU has to implement appropriate treatment of the neighbourhood countries’ claims, take common responsibility, inspire the judicial, economic, social reforms, the fight against corruption, and pay attention to the rights of the national minorities in the partner countries. For example, as a first step of the administration reform in Ukraine, the law ‘on voluntary association of local authorities/communities’ was adopted in which point 4, article 4 states that during the administrative reforms the historical, linguistic and ethnic characteristics have to be taken into account. The related article of the regulation provides an opportunity for the national minorities to organise at the municipal level. However the 11th article of the Government’s resolution containing the implementation of the law does not include directives considering the ethnic aspects as it is in the law, which can affect detrimentally the national minorities. It is very important to modify the Government’s resolution as soon as possible according to the law and considering the rights of the national minorities living in Ukraine. I therefore call on the EU to pay necessary attention to the necessary reforms in Ukraine and other neighbourhood countries.

name: Fernando Maura Barandiarán (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I believe that security, stability and prosperity should not constitute exclusively the approach to this new European Union neighbourhood policy; it will necessarily have to go hand in hand with the values of democracy and respect for human rights, consubstantiating to the European project. In this context, culture can play a fundamental and dynamic role as a soft power from which the EU and its Member States can benefit from their relations with border countries. In this house it is often said that culture promotes democratization, peacebuilding and respect for human rights. The time has come to put these right words into practice. Neighbourhood policy would have to open a cultural and political dialogue to provide incentives and provide adequate tools to facilitate internal reforms in these countries, supporting civil society and democratic groups and parties to promote dialogue and pluralism.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. The time has come for the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) to realign itself with current geopolitical scenarios. The ongoing review by the Commission lays the appropriate foundations for reviewing the principles, scope and instruments of the ENP, while noting the new challenges posed by recent developments in the political situation in the Eastern Partnership countries and on the southern shore of the Mediterranean. We must build on the lessons learned from the experience of the last ten years in order to strengthen policies of partnership and cooperation with neighbouring countries and thus promote stability, economic development and security on Europe's borders.  I believe, however, that the review of the ENP should be accompanied by a broader discussion on the EU's general foreign policy. Economic pressures, the risks of geopolitical resilience in large areas close to us, migratory flows and the threats posed by international terrorism need a strong response and a shared strategy at European level. I therefore hope that an in-depth discussion can be initiated to ensure that the EU's relations with neighbouring countries are more fruitful in the future and a vehicle for development and stability at global level.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – As the political situations along our borders continue to become more volatile, the coherence and strength of the European Neighbourhood remains one of the most important priorities for the security of this Union. Relations between the EU and ENP partners continue to help promote prosperity, stability, security, and good neighbourliness, based on the values of democracy, rule of law and respect for human rights.  The ENP has achieved success; with the one-year anniversary this past June of the signing of the EU Association Agreements with ENP partners Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine, citizens from these states are noticing already the opportunities presented by further integration into the European Neighbourhood. Nonetheless, the reforms proposed in the Report on the Review of the ENP, especially with regard to increasing security cooperation between the EU and ENP partners, should be regarded with utmost importance.  As the neighbours of our neighbours continue to exert unwonted pressure on the partnership, the EU must ensure the rights of our neighbours to make independent and sovereign choices on foreign and security policy and economy, free from external pressure and coercion. I look forward to a strengthened ENP that will be mutually beneficial to all parties involved.
